Oh gosh, that's hard to read. Could you put it inside <--pre>--<--code>-- tags, please?

x=2. find_dot=str(x).find('.') s1=str(x)[find_dot+1:] s2='' va1=s1[0].find('4') s2=s2+str(va1) va1=s1[0].find('3') s2=s2+str(va1) va1=s1[0].find('2') s2=s2+str(va1) va1=s1[0].find('1') s2=s2+str(va1) va1=s1[0].find('0') s2=s2+str(va1) va2=s2.find('0') s3='a'+s2[va2] b=s3.find('0') s3=s3[b] b=s3.find('0') new_x=x+(-1*b) s4=str(new_x)[:str(new_x).find('.')] print s4

This is how I solved it: 

print str(x+0.5)[:str(x+0.5).find('.')]

Hi,

what about this:

x = x + 0.5

x_str = str(x)

result = x_str[:x_str.find('.')]

print result

Cheers, JS
the point of my program is to avoid this method :)
what u think about it??

print int(x+0.5)

i didn't used str() but int() is the complement function to str() so i thought it would be okay... and it was :D

This works:

s = str(x + 0.5)

print s[:s.find('.')]

xt = str(x)[str(x).find('.')+1] y = x + '5'.find(xt) + '6'.find(xt) + '7'.find(xt) + '8'.find(xt) + '9'.find(xt) + 5 result = str(y)[:str(y).find('.')] print result

was how I did it before it dinged 2 days later and I saw the simple 1liner:

print (str(x+0.5)[:str(x+0.5).find('.')])
me too...!

I think it's a clever idea. I like the way you've collected together all the results of the search of the first digit after the point to see if there is a 0 in the string. Then used the result of that string, being 0 or -1 to decide whether to add the 1 to round up or not.

It took me a while to work out what you were doing, hence the slow reply.

It's a totally different way of thinking, and I'm sure that idea can be used somewhere else, sometime. Thank you for taking the time to look for this solution and for sharing it.
sure it was ok, even round(x) was graded ok, but it makes the assignment way easier.
aha... thanx it took me a while to figure it out, but finaly i solve it
At this point, I think all solutions are interesting since we can learn about new functions such as int() and round().

"

@thecakepie i did

"
WOW! All that just to do round(x).
it 's my pleasure to do that
I like the use of the -1 from the find in this method. I wouldn't have thought of doing that.
@MLDev i didn't figure another way for this purpose
Very simple and elegent! I applaud you, Black Rose.

Here's mine:

print str(x + 5 + (str(x)[str(x).find('.'):str(x).find('.')+2].find('.5')) + (str(x)[str(x).find('.'):str(x).find('.')+2].find('.6')) + (str(x)[str(x).find('.'):str(x).find('.')+2].find('.7')) + (str(x)[str(x).find('.'):str(x).find('.')+2].find('.8')) + (str(x)[str(x).find('.'):str(x).find('.')+2].find('.9')))[:str(x).find('.')]

Sort of the brute force version of the much more elegant:
print str(x+0.5)[:str(x+0.5).find('.')]

Kudos to those who saw this!
nice... in just one line

data-item.data-item-item:
"

From the Announcements page.

Before the grades for the first homework come out, weâ€™d like to say a few things about grading and Udacity in general.

It has been great seeing a positive atmosphere of help and collaboration on the forums. Our mission is to create an excellent environment for free online education and we appreciate everyoneâ€™s contributions towards making that a reality.

Weâ€™ve done our best to make sure all the grading is correct and fair, but it is inevitable that there will be some mistakes. When looking at your homework grades, we understand that it will be very frustrating if an answer you think was correct is marked as incorrect. Please check the answer for that homework, and if you still feel that your answer was graded unfairly, please report it in the forums. We will not be able to address all of these issues right away, but we will do our best to address as many as we can. Also, please donâ€™t get too stressed about your homework grade and do keep in mind that the lowest homework grade will be dropped in computing your final grade.

Once grades and solutions are out, you are encouraged to post your code to the forums and ask for feedback. This will allow other students to see alternative approaches, and perhaps you have a better approach than our answer to share with other students. In the event that our grading was faulty, posting your code will also help the TAs figure out exactly where our mistakes were.

Keep learning! Stay udacious!

"

data-item.data-item-item: I just converted a comment to an answer in the forum and I noticed that the answer count in the question list did not update the number of answers for the question.

Hi, everyone.
Is it possible to implement Python in a Libre Office or Open Office macro?
I have already done it using Libre Office VBA, kinda Visual Basic but specifically for Libre Office. But I think Python could be better for improving a Calc spreadsheet.

Thanks :)
Does our code have to be able to round negative numbers?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: No. Only positive integers less than 100,000 or so.
Is it possible to do it with negative numbers from what we've been taught so far? Just curious.

You could do just negative numbers, or just positive numbers from what has been taught in unit 1 but you'd have to write the code to do one or the other, not both.

With what we've been taught in unit 2, you can write something to deal with all numbers, positive and negative so long as they aren't too big.

If you want to use it via the web browser you can try a free online interpreter:

  • repl
  • IDEone

Or you can download it on your PC. You should check out the main Python downloads:

  • Python

I hope these links are useful!

edit:

On a Mac you can also use the terminal and Python-- I suggest using IDLE's editor.

  • For OSX
"
IDEone uses v2.6.4, which is the closest match to what udacity is using (v2.6.6)

"

You can use any editor you like including TextMate or anything else.

You then need a Python interpreter to run the code.
Python is built in on the Mac, you'll have to download it on Windows.

Just save your Python code (usually with a .py extension) and then go to the Terminal and run:
python myProgram.py
Replace myProgram.py with whatever your file is called including the path to it if needed.

You can also just start the interpreter by typing:
python
It will then go into interactive mode where it will evaluate your expressions as soon as you type them and press Enter so you can play around with it.

If you're looking for a full blown IDE (that will do code completion, project management, etc) try PyDev.

"

data-item.data-item-item: I also teach online classes and love the pen being used in the lecture recordings. What is it and the software used to create the recordings?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

looks like the wacom cintriq - a graphicstablet where you write and paint on a ""touch-screen""

"

It looks to me like he's using a mechanical pencil plus some computer vision to superimpose a copy of the writing on the foreground.

Edit: I might be wrong, I just saw a mouse cursor under his pen ... it's probably some tablet.

I don't know which technology he is using, but as a student I can tell you that this method is really helpful. If you also teach in class think about using it with a projector and upload the handwrite lecture files somewhere to let your student re-read it :)
i have to say that this time the lectures are awesome.
digital pen with touch screen sensor on touch pad ...
i m searching for this technology .

"

In my university, teachers work with HP EliteBook, which is really nice. It's directly writing with a pen on the screen.
But it's an expansive computer !

There is two main other systems :
-Wacom tablets : There is no ""screen"" but just a Touch surface. I think it is what they are using when I see the pen (Google it)

-In some cases, you write with real ink on a real paper, but there is a device to record the motion of the pen (like a WiiMote)

"

as i said earlier... look for wacom cintriq, because the pen is a wacom and the
cintriq is a graphics-tablet normaly used for artists and designers (like me..).

"

From the pen you can tell he is using Wacom Cintiq, as Nemesis has mentioned before, with a fairly good overhead camera and a screen recording software such as Camtasia Studio. The recorded video appears to then be matched up with the software using chroma keying. Or the team, being as smart as they are, wrote a program to do the screen recording and keying at the same time for easy video layering later.

"

"

It's the Wacom Cintiq 21UX

"
graphic tablet and stylus is used( I think), it's better than AI's marker and board.

"

@NeilR

Wacom Cintiq is a professional and expensive tablet. The cheapest way to do that is buying the Wacom Bamboo Tablet and using Camtasia for recording and Photoshop to canvas (or other similar programs).

"

"

@NeilR

A cheap recreation of this would be: (does not include overhead recording)

Wacom Bamboo Connect -- $79

Fraps -- $37 (there may be a cheaper one available)

Gimp -- FREE (Open source competition to Adobe Photoshop)

Windows Movie Maker -- FREE (for Windows only)

iMovie -- FREE (for Mac OSX only)

Total Cost -- $116

"
I'm also very curious about the hardware and software used to produce these pencasts. The hand makes it much more alive than those pencasts where you see only the pen strokes.
I think what we are seeing is a projected view, since when the hand obstructs the video, it is being visible on the hand of the instructor

Here I was thinking that once we all mastered Python, we would all be able to make ourselves transparent at will.

I bet some house made vision software was made to detect when the hand overlaps a drawn graphic coordinate and then simply changes the alpha state of the hand in the image.

I have played with OpenCV(a computer vision library) via Processing, and can imagine this could be done fairly easily for the people of god-like prowess who are Udacity.

That being said...pure magic! Brilliant! Beautiful! Crisp!

The speculations on the hardware sound spot on, but I wouldn't know, never held a stylus.

I am much more curious about the hand magic, because I am betting that is being done with code, and code is why we are here, and it is cheap, and I will soon be producing my own.

Hope Udacity is considering a 'How to Turn Yourself Invisible ' class!!!
Wow, Zebriah, thanks for the information!
@dileep98490 No, if it was a projected view you would see color and image distortion due to the skin pigment vs. white pigment and camera perspective.
Np hope it was helpful :D

I am trying to do something similar using an iPad, a stylus and ScreenChomp. But I'd like to be able to film my hand, as well, so that I could gesture to what I've previously written. Any idea how you'd do the Chroma Keying? I understand how to green screen, but this seems like a different ball game.
A possibility to open the code for the open source community?

"

Is the overhead camera mounted on the ceiling? Perhaps a simple, inexpensive camera like the ""IPEVO Point 2 View USB Camera""? It is only $69 (US Dollars) on Amazon.com. I have seed this document camera used in other conferences, but capturing the audio and video live needs more research. If anyone is interested here is a link to the IPEVO camera I was talking about - a LOT cheaper than a cluncky ELMO:
http://www.amazon.com/IPEVO-Point-View-USB-Camera/dp/B002UBPBTC/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&--qid=1330559623&--sr=8-1

"

The Wacom Cintiq 21UX is only part of the answer, although a significant answer. Now what overhead camera is used?? Occasionally we see the top of his head/forehead if he leans in too much. Therefore, I think he has a webcam mounted above his desk perhaps.

"

Pretty sure that the pen is a Wacom pen ( I have one in my hand) and the software is Autodesk Sketchbook Pro ( I recognise the tools you occasionally see like the one used to change pen colour, and the ""loupe"".)

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I am protesting hw1-1.

Now that the deadline has passed and we can discuss the homework, I'm interested in the variety of methods people used to solve question hw1.9. I'm also interested in how people found their way to these solutions.

I knew the str() function would be used to strip off the post decimal garbage, and that mathematical manipulation could not be used on a string. Of course stripping the right of the decimal is not enough when you need to round up. I realized that if I added the right number (0.5) it would bump the number to the left of the decimal up only if it is 0.5 or more.

Here was my code:
x = x + 0.5
s = str(x)
decimal_position = s.find('.')
rounded = s[:decimal_position]
print rounded

I used 5 lines because I'm trying to make my code easy to read.

So... What was your approach? How did people do this in one line? How about the conditional approaches?

str followed by square brackets threw me off. It's probably not good to use str as a variable, when you are also using it to convert numbers to strings.

Nicky is probably right that it was tested by a different compiler.

This will fail to round up if the tenths-place digit is greater than or equal to 5.

One of the tests suggested in the problem presentation was that given x = 27.63 the output should be 28. Your code would output 27.

"

The code provided should work without problems and here is an explanation of why it does:

The name str is originally just bound (""associated"") with the function that converts something to a string formatting of what you pass to it (it actually calls the method __str__ of objects that are passed to it, but this is just an implementation detail).

In python, you can, though make another binding (read: ""reassociate"") a name to a new object (even if it is not of the same kind as before, although this is discouraged).

So, in the code presented, we are assigning a string to the name str, which means that, from that point on, it is not a function anymore (and you can't call it as one).

data-item.data-item-item: For testing2 quiz where s can be any string, I do not understand how s.find('')always evaluates to 0. Could someone try and help me understand this better?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Think of every string starting with 'nothing' (''). If you search for nothing you will always find the very start of the string which is 0.

I will try to explain in a very simplified way.

For example:

s = ''      # an 'empty string'  s = s + 'a' # the string 'a' (nothing + 'a')

All strings have at least 'nothing' within them. If you search for nothing it's going to give you the only valid index it can which is 0.

"

Well you also have to keep in mind: s.find("""",-1)==len(s)

"

Also, if you do the following:

s = 'abc' s.find('', 1) #this results in 1 s.find('', 2) #this results in 2

Pretty much the empty string is found in the beginning of any other string or substring that you're searching in.

"

->-- Well you also have to keep in mind: s.find("""",-1)==len(s)

we get to the explanation of this - ==len(s) - in one of the next lessons i guess!?

"
I've mentioned talking about this in office hours with Dave. In all likelihood it functions this way because it made implementing the find function elegant. A lot of things in Python are like that.

"

do we ""learn"" this too? ->-- ==len(s)

"

"

I think of it as if .find() search whatever you ask it, so if you tell it to find """", you're basically telling it to search for everything because every string will match a string that hasn't any particular restriction (it's not an 'a' or a 'b' etc.).

Hope it helps! :)

"

You have 4 prints. Original question was to find POSITION, which is a number, not a string.

search = 'zip'  s_seq = text.find(search) print text.find(search,s_seq+1)

Same silly error as I did with the first question (I just marked all URLs from the list, which were valid and did not even notice HTML at the bottom of the page) - you need to read assignment carefully:

#Assume text is a variable that #holds a string. Write Python code #that prints out the position #of the second occurrence of 'zip' #in text, or -1 if it does not occur #at least twice.

Which means that your code is supposed to print number 18 and number 18 only (you are printing other things):

 print text.find('zip',text.find('zip')+1)

You have to set the task and stick to that task. What you did is calling debugging and can't be in production or submitted homework.

x_string = str(x)  decimal_start = x_string.find('.') decimal = x_string[decimal_start+1]  find_5 = decimal.find('5') find_6 = decimal.find('6') find_7 = decimal.find('7') find_8 = decimal.find('8') find_9 = decimal.find('9')  decimal_carry = (find_5 + find_6 + find_7 + find_8 + find_9)+5  x_round_string = str(x + decimal_carry)  x_rounded_whole = x_round_string[:x_round_string.find('.')] print x_rounded_whole

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Did you put the x = 3.14159 assignment below the commented text? I think that messes up the autograder (because I assume they run tests on a variety of numbers by changing the x assignment that was already given to us, and if you have a later x = 3.14159 the result will always be 3 no matter what number the autograder is testing).

"

Your code may work but, by using the ""round"" function, you have not done your code with only what we have been taught to that point.

Hint: we were given the conversion from an integer to a string via str(integer). Using that, the job can be done without the ""round"" function.

Is this enough?

"

You were allowed to use round() function. It was stated that it was allowed to use other things not introduced in the course several times on the forums. I think the problem is the extra print you have, which was not in the specification.

Actually they said that if you use round, as long as you still come up with the correct answer it will be counted as correct.

However, if they are explicitly setting x and overriding the x given in the program, the autograder probably was unable to substitute other numbers to verify their algorithm is correct.

I would think that all of the print statements would be an issue. The question was to print out the nearest whole number to x. You have also printed intermediate values, that I guess violate the expected response.

Yes, I did, but I tested it on 5 different numbers. I think the code is ok, and it should be graded as correct. Do you know what I should do to make that happen? The same goes for the Find 2 task -
i got the correct result , and code is ok

zip_first_occurence = text.find('zip')
print zip_first_occurence
zip_second_occurenece = text.find('zip', zip_first_occurence + 1)
print zip_second_occurenece

Yes, I did, but I tested it on 5 different numbers. I think the code is ok, and it should be graded as correct. Do you know what I should do to make that happen? The same goes for the Find 2 task -
i got the correct result , and code is ok

zip_first_occurence = text.find('zip') print zip_first_occurence zip_second_occurenece = text.find('zip', zip_first_occurence + 1) print zip_second_occurenece
Again, I think it's the extra print statement as you were supposed to print out just the second occurrence.

Unfortunately, code is not ok in both scenarios. You used round() as well as a lot of unneeded prints.

You can use it for debugging but not for submitting.

IMHO!
Yes, they said we could use round. So its not that that makes it incorrect. Printing intermediate values could be, but yet, the code is correct. Do you now what I should do to change the grading?
It's because of your first print statement. You were supposed to print and only print the rounded number without the decimal point and without anything which followed the decimal point.

"

It's also possible that @fnenu has correctly identified the problem (the extra print statements that weren't asked for in the question).

Either way, I think it's probably just one of the downsides of taking a class with tens of thousands of students: there's no way for an actual human being to look at all our code and evaluate whether it's okay or not. Maybe if it caused enough problems they'll consider redoing the autograder, but that might be a huge hassle...

"
but does that make it incorrect or just confuses the autograder?
OK, it`s clear now! Thanks! :)

data-item.data-item-item:
"

homework 1.9 give the answer is a string. but the question is ask for whole number, I think the answer is not right.

And the instruction said ""Your submission does not need to work with numbers above 100,000."" this avoid using loop command.

The answer can only use ""find"" ""str"" and string index, no loop no if no while. The output should in whole number, not string, not decimal.

My answer is use ""find"" to detect ""dot"" and number, use -1 to do switch.

===============================this code output number===================================

#Given a variable, x, that stores #the value of any decimal number, #write Python code that prints out #the nearest whole number to x.  #You can assume x is not negative.  # x = 3.14159 ->-- 3 (not 3.0) # x = 27.63 ->-- 28 (not 28.0)  x = 3.14159  #DO NOT USE IMPORT  #ENTER CODE BELOW HERE #ANY CODE ABOVE WILL CAUSE #HOMEWORK TO BE GRADED #INCORRECT  #x=6753.1149  x_string=str(x) dot=x_string.find('.') decimal=x_string[dot+1:]  plus=decimal[0].find('9')+1 plus=plus+decimal[0].find('8')+1 plus=plus+decimal[0].find('7')+1 plus=plus+decimal[0].find('6')+1 plus=plus+decimal[0].find('5')+1  x=x+plus x_string=str(x)  stop=1  intx=0 stop=x_string[0].find('.')*x_string[0].find('.')*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('9')+1)*9*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('8')+1)*8*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('7')+1)*7*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('6')+1)*6*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('5')+1)*5*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('4')+1)*4*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('3')+1)*3*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('2')+1)*2*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('1')+1)*1*stop intx=intx+(x_string[0].find('0')+1)*0*stop intx=intx*stop  stop=x_string[1].find('.')*x_string[1].find('.')*stop stop_str=str(stop) mult=(stop_str.find('1')+1)*9+1 intx1=intx*mult  intx=0 intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('9')+1)*9*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('8')+1)*8*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('7')+1)*7*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('6')+1)*6*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('5')+1)*5*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('4')+1)*4*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('3')+1)*3*stop intx=intx+(x_string[1].find('2')+1)*2*stop #Given a variable, x, that stores #the value of any decimal number, #write Python code that prints out #the nearest whole number to x.  #You can assume x is not negative.  # x = 3.14159 ->-- 3 (not 3.0) # x = 27.63 ->-- 28 (not 28.0)  x = 3.14159  #DO NOT USE IMPORT  #ENTER CODE BELOW HERE #ANY CODE ABOVE WILL CAUSE #HOMEWORK TO BE GRADED #INCORRECT  def RoundNumber( nbr ):     decimalAt = str(nbr).find(""."")     if decimalAt == -1:         return nbr     else:         wholePart = int(str(nbr)[ :decimalAt ])         decimalPart = float( str(nbr)[ decimalAt: ])          if( decimalPart <-- .5 ):             return wholePart         else:             return wholePart + 1  print( RoundNumber( x ) ) {result 3} print( RoundNumber( 27.63 ) ) {result 28} print( RoundNumber( -2.9 ) ) {result -1} print( RoundNumber( 10000000.5 ) ) {result 10000001}
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: What are all the print statements at the bottom? Did you leave them in? If you did, I think it's because you didn't follow the specification which was just to print out the rounded version of x.

"

The assignment was to use what we had been taught to that point. You have gone well beyond what we were taught by using ""def"".

Just straight line your code without using ""def""

Last, the code was to process only ""x = 27.63"". Your last print does not do this.

By the way, I recommend making your code much simpler. It can be done in two statements.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi :) I submitted the following code for Homework 1.9 and it was marked incorrect, though when I ran it it gave the correct result. Would like to understand where the mistake is, grateful for an explanation:

x_plus = x +0.5
string_x = str(x_plus)
before_dot = (string_x.find ('.'))-1
nearest_whole_x = string_x [before_dot : before_dot+1]
print nearest_whole_x

thanks!:)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

The problem is:

string_x[before_dot : before_dot+1]

If x=3.1415, it correctly extracts the ""3"". However if:

x=34.1415

It doesn't extract the answer ""34"" but instead just the ""4""

If you did instead:

nearest_whole_x = string_x[ : before_dot+1]

You'd have been ok.

"

Is Backus Naur Forum considered a Context Free Grammar and if so, isn't it true that this kind of grammar is considered ambiguous?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Backus Naur Form has the power to describe Context Free Grammars. But since any Regular Grammar can be described using a Context Free Grammar, you could say it describes both.

data-item.data-item-item:
I found variables confusing to many students. I used to a number of buckets or containers to help students understand. You could then physically move numbers or objects about.

Also the = sign should be defined as process the expression on the right hand side - store the answer and then empty the container (variable) and put in the answer into the container

eg you have the number 5 in box1

so the expression box1 = box1 + 2 is done in four stages

step 1 Process the right expression box1 + 2

    This involves getting the existing contents of box1  ie 5 and adding 2 getting 7

Step 2 Store the answer in step 1 which is 7

Step 3 Empty the left hand side that is remove the number 5 from the box making its contents zero

Step 4 Move the stored number into the container - ie it is now 7

It sounds a bit lame like this - but with real containers it works well - I'll have to do an animation.

Also useful for lists (open locker numbers 3, 5 and 37, and put paint in them please)

And, I just can't pass up the opportunity to say, Linux rules -- BOTH MicroSoft and Apple lock you in to their way of doing things. And, things are getting worse in that regard, as both fight to rule the world. There is Proprietary and there is Open Source. One enslaves, the other sets you free.

data-item.data-item-item:
Define a variable, name, and assign to it a string that is your name.After not figuring this one out I went ahead and looked at the answer. I went back and plugged it in and was told it was also wrong.

What's up?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Could you show me the exact code you entered? I believe the grading on this assignment is correct. Here is what my IDE had:

#Define a variable, name, and assign to it a string that is your name.  name = ""Peter""
"

name = 'brian'

print 'hello ' + name
You don't need to print anything. In retrospect the grading there is probably too strict.
Got ya thanks

"

@Brian, your code is correct and there's nothing wrong with it, but the IDE marked it as wrong because it just asked for the variable name to be assigned a string value. When the online IDE sees the print 'hello' + name it says, ""hey, hold on a minute, there's a lot of extra things here that I didn't expect"" and it marks the quiz as wrong.

Just know your code is 100% valid, it's just the quiz was expecting you to only do name = 'brian' and that's all.

"

<--p>--Here is a sentence that <--a href=""http://udacity.com"">--contains a link<--/a>--<--/p>--

Probably not a good fix for those who don't want to write posts with HTML tags, but it's something fairly quick to try if you post disappears because of some other format issue.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Forgive me if this question has been asked before, but what exactly does Prof. Evans
mean when he said that FORTRAN wasn't ""precise"" enough?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Unfortunately I haven't seen Professor Evans around the forum. Perhaps our TA, @PeterUdacity, would be able to get a quote from him?

"
I'm not sure the context of the statement as I can't locate in the videos, but I am assuming he is talking about mathematical precision and rounding errors. What video is it?

"

Every programming language has a grammar, something like a set of ""rules"" of how expressions can be used on a valid program. Nothing really much different from a grammar of a natural language, like English or Portuguese.

But programming languages, as languages designed to work on machines, need to be defined with a higher degree of precision than natural languages, with zero ambiguous expressions, for example.

Now, answering your question: what wasn't precise enough at time is the grammar of the language, not the language itself. Like Prof. Evans already said, the grammar of FORTRAN was presented the first time using basically examples, instead of general rules applicable to any case given. One good method for establishing this general rules is known as BNF -- Backus-Naur Form -- explained on the same video (if my memory doesn't betray me =D).

If you already have some experience with programming, maybe it's helpful to see with your own eyes the first attempt to define the grammar of FORTRAN in this scanned photocopy: Specifications for the IBM Mathematical FORmula TRANslating System

"
The Grammar video, I believe, in Unit 1.

it wasn't that much advance (limited functions) as today's computer languages like java, c, c++ , python etc in which we can do almost nay thing , we can create objects ,stacks , queues etc..hope it answered ur question
grammer and other rules ..and similar stuff in fortan was limited

The first thing that comes to mind is that you can use variables in FORTRAN without declaring them. This is, these days, considered bad practice, and of course, down the line, could make code more difficult to read. If you declare a variable type in FORTRAN you have to use (I think) the word IMPLICIT.

That being said, I must say, I loved FORTRAN when I took it more than 30 years ago!

data-item.data-item-item:
There is two branches of Python: Python 2.x and Python 3.x
I know, they have minor differences in syntax. Which one I should use?

By the way. Which Python interpreter is used?
There also a lot: CPython, Jython, PyPy, Stackless Python...

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: As for the version: Python 2.6 is used in this course.

Python 2.6 is the version used in the course, so you should go with that. Although I doubt that they will use the features that aren't already in 2.5, since this is an introductory course. Note that 2.6 doesn't get bugfixes anymore, and every valid 2.6 program works also in 2.7, so you can also use that. There are few things you can do with 2.7 that wouldn't work in the interpreter used for quizzes and homework, but those things won't be taught in the course.

Python 3.2 is the most recent version of the newer Python, and while it's possible to write code that works on both Python3 and Python2, it's somewhat complicated so for this course, you should just leave it out.

What comes to the other interpreters: use CPython. It is the default version that you get when you download from python.org, or install the python package in Ubuntu or other Linux distributions. It has the widest support of language features (as it is the driving implementation), standard library and 3rd party packages. For example, while I doubt we will be using it, numpy is a package for heavy computation that is not supported in many other interpreters (I'm not sure if anything else than CPython has full support).

Jython and IronPython are meant to be used within the Java and .NET virtual machines, and their benefit is the ability to hook into other code on the same platform, no matter what language they were written in. But since we don't need that ability, it just adds to the complexity. Also they don't follow the language as quickly, and for now Jython is still Python2.5 only.

PyPy is an interesting project that has the main benefit (for end users) of being faster. But for the tasks we are doing in this course, speed isn't very crucial. You might want to check it out, but it won't help you with the course. There are some even more esoteric versions of Python, like Stackless, but they are for increasingly specific demands, and best left for advanced work.

data-item.data-item-item: I have been into many programming languages. The question that keeps popping up in my mind is why have they chosen Python for the design of a search engine? Has been any specific reason for choosing Python, for instance, Python being more robust or efficient or any such reason? I have a good knowlegde of object-oriented languages and procedural languages, so I just wonder why Python was chosen.. Is it just a matter of choice or is there some intelligent opinion behind this?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
The main reason for choosing Python must have been because this course is meant for students with no prior programming knowledge and Python is one of the easiest languages to pick up. Factor in that it's a very high-level, popular language with lots of available modules and you have yourself a recipe for one hell of a language!

Courtesy of @Sol3r -- One of the main focuses of Python is readability. This helps new programmers more than just about anything else. The ability to read code is paramount to becoming a successful programmer. Also, Python is an interpreted language, as opposed to a compiled language. This means that students don't have to put up with the messy business of using compilers which would result in numerous issues that could be rooted in the choice of compiler, the compiler version, the student's OS, and a number of other things.
And how about Visual Basic?

If you say you have a good knowlegde of programming, let me be straightforward:

Python is a language designed to be the most human-readable possible. So its syntax is the simpliest possible to obtain easier codes to read and maintain. Not only syntax, but all other features of this language seek this ultimate goal. It makes Python an excellent programming language for introduction classes of computer programming or anything related.

I think you pretty much hit the nail on the head. One of Python's main focus is code readability, so people can naturally pick up the syntax much quicker. Also, the fact that it is a scripting language and uses an interpreter rather than needing to be compiled means the course can do nifty things like provide the embedded interpreter to allow students to experiment immediately within the lesson.

@smartmuki -- Not to insult anyone, but I don't think anyone has a desire to learn VB. Python is a widely used programming language in industry. I don't know whether VB is, though I doubt it.

@Sol3r -- Those are excellent points. I'll add them to the post.

This would be a great question to add to the FAQ as well!

Edit: It is actually already there, but this post does add some more points to it.

"

That's such a good suggestion that I'm going to give it it's very own section on the ""suggestions"" post. :P

"

Python is relatively easy to use. It's structure means that with some experience you can reasonably quick pick up other languages, such as the very commercial C.

It also has the big plus that you can get results quickly - which is a great boost to newcomers.

It is also free and without too much difficulty can be installed on any computer.

Even someone thinking of using Visual Basic, VB, would benefit from doing a Python course, such as this first, as they would then have a grounding in programming techniques.

VB lets a beginner get quite good results quickly - but in my experience the majority of beginners just play with the package and do not really develop or understand the more advanced techniques.

I agree that being able to pick things up quickly is good for beginners, but your claim that learning Python leads to being able to pick up C reasonably quickly is concerning. C and Python live on opposite sides of the universe. C is statically typed, Python is dynamically typed. C forces the use of pointers onto programmers, Python handles pointers for you. C is a procedural language, Python is object-oriented. I could go on and on.
I think one of the other considerations is that you can run Python on any computer - Windows, Linux, Unix, Macs so anyone can play with it

I agree. At most, learning Python first would allow you to get a decent foundation on algorithm design and things such as conditional logic. It would be a good stepping stone into the world of programming, but I think for all of the reason James stated it wouldn't be a quick transition for most.
And how about the little function in the Python library called urlopen?? That alone is probably worth its weight in gold--at least for CS101!

"

@James: Thank you very much :)

"
coz its the easiest and simplest language. . .watch the video in which sir shows his favorite comic book. in that comic every thing is explained.
It would have been better had u read the above replies before posting an answer.. There are some beautiful answers above..

"

@James You could also add the point by @Chris about the portability of Python..

"
lolzzz ... i know my reply is a nerdy reply ... but whatever, i was trying to help ya ..
I appreciate everyone's help :)
It wasnt RedMars who asked the question - Why did we chose Python! It was smartmuki x-( :(

Another (probably) important reason: Guido van Rossum, the creator of Python, also known as BDFL (Benevolent Dictator For Life) in the Python community, works for google since about 2006... :-)

IMHO the chief reason for using python is that it is perhaps the best entry language for someone learning programming. I think it is too dry, and with not so much glamour. When compared to other popular languages (perl, ruby), python is a Japanese garden, while perl or ruby are the Amazon forest (with all its beauties and dangers implied...)

But in the end, for cs101 indeed I think python is the choice.

I like Perl... and I think it's as easy as Python to understand at first. All languages are easy when you start and get more and more complicated as everything moves to higher levels and more and more functions.

I think choosing one over another is rather trivial, as this is about introducing people to CS, which is more about thinking how to solve problems, there question here being, how do we collect all data on all webpages on the WWW....

If you want to understand just computers though, something as easy as logo or GW basic or even Pascal is enough, though those languages are probably more limited than python. Some might even say that there's no need to start programming in order to understand the introduction to CS....

Do not think that Python is a lesser language, because of its simplicity. In my company python is THE LANGUAGE OF CHOICE, we love it. We do everything from webapps, homepages, server scripts and so on. Mostly speed is not an issue for us anymore, like it used to be at least.
The simplicity is its strength, and with more and more things moving to become web-apps - Python is becoming a stronger contender for tasks you would not have imagined to do before. Hey, Clean code, Object Oriented and perfect for the web. Whats to complain about? --)

Add Pyjamas to the mix and you suddenly have no problems at all creating apps with GUI, web or desktop. Most things you probably want to do, can probably be programmed in Python. If you need the speed I would rather look at GoLang, which mixes the structure and speed of C++ and Python into one :)
hi.. i am new to python. Can I know what is the industry that usually use python? I am dealing more to c programming for low level applications, not quite familiar with high lvl programming... thanks

"

I have been programming Python for at least 4 to 5 years.
Although I don't think I have seen it's whole potential, what I have done many, many things with it, and I can say I'm satisfied.
It is very easy to learn and to use. In a day or too, you can get very proficient at it.
It is 100% object oriented.
It is FAST [faster than PHP, Ruby, and sometimes Perl].
It is installed on almost every major Linux distribution, so you can count on it right out of the box.
It is free and open source.
You don't have to pay to work with it, nor for any development environment.
It is highly portable. You code once, and you can run your code on Windows, Mac, Linux, and some cell phones.
It is very light weight [Your computer won't suffer as it suffers whenever it runs Java applets or programs]
Comes with batteries included. There is a HUGE library that comes along with python, with which you can do GUI stuff [tkinter], connect through the internet, access ftp / telnet stuff, do complex math, encrypt stuff, haves a built in database system [sqlite2], XML parsing, multiprocess stuff , command line options parsing, you name it.
You can easily extend your programs with C or Fortran if you want number crunching speed.

Your development time decreases 10 fold. I used to code with C, but doing even simple stuff took ALOT of time. With Python, you spend less times trying to get the simple stuff running, and you focus more time on your main goals.

It is interpreted, so you technically can be running your code as you type your statements. You don't have to wait for your python program to compile in order to run it.

Lets say you have a script that have been running for a year non stop [lets say is a server for a very high traffic website or MMRPG]. Lets say you want to update a library that your sever is using, but you CAN'T have a down time nor restart the server. With Python, you can update your library on real time [you just need to program this functionality, but is very easy].

I have been working 3 years at my current job. And although my work is 90% with PHP, I've coded easily 400 python scripts for fixing stuff, merge databases, parse data, export data, and many other things.

Python, since it is community driven, open source, will always be there for you.

You can always have the latest release without having to pay a dime. On the other hand, Micro$oft languages are mostly for a fee, so if you want the latest thing, you'll probably have to pay. There are some ""developer licenses"" that allows you to use their programs and languages, but in real life, your customer or your company ends up paying the bill for that language [and most of the time is a LARGE bill ].

Where I work, almost 90% or our servers are Linux based. Some run PHP, other Python, on Apache servers. If this company decided to use Micro$oft technologies and languages, their operational costs would be much, much more higher than what they pay right now. We have hundreds of servers, so multiply the cost of a single Windows Server license times that, and you can get the idea of how costly this can be.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I don't understand your question. Can you be more specific please?
Yes - we can theoretically make the processors smaller as they get faster, but we are approaching other limits - the sizes of atoms that produce other problems in making things much smaller
Well, if you make the processor smaller, then that is less distance that must be traveled within the processor, taking up less time and making the cycle faster. I think that is what you are asking.

If I understood your question right - yes, we can make processors really small, but some time we will approach to quantum level, quantum processors, which is a completely different world and the laws of this world are not yet fully discovered.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Python is case-sensitive. Try to use 'print' instead of 'PRINT'.

[edit] I've just tried your code and it works for me if using lowercase print command. You may also notice that 'PRINT' is not highlighted, so it is just not recognized.
Python is case sensitive so PRINT should be print. Also, be sure to use decimals so that you don't run into rounding errors.
Your divison is integer divison. The divison needs to be floating point. Then only the answer will be correct.
Computer languages tend to have fixed terms.
Your answer is correct. Thanks.

data-item.data-item-item: what does mean Karma points??

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

FAQ:

How does the karma system work?
When a question or answer is upvoted, the user who posted them will gain some points, which are called ""karma points"". These points serve as a rough measure of the community trust in him/her. Various moderation tasks are gradually assigned to the users based on those points. For example, if you ask an interesting question or give a helpful answer, your input will be upvoted. On the other hand if the answer is misleading, it will be downvoted. Each vote in favor will generate 15 points, each vote against will subtract 1 points. There is a limit of 200 points that can be accumulated per question or answer. The table below explains karma requirements for each type of moderation task.
â€¢ add comments ->-- 0
â€¢ delete comments ->-- 400
â€¢ close own questions ->-- 60
â€¢ reopen own questions ->-- 120
â€¢ retag questions ->-- 150
â€¢ edit any answer ->-- 400
â€¢ open any closed question ->-- 600
â€¢ delete any comment ->-- 400

So practically, it reflects the activity and experience of user.

"
Excellent!!!

What if you gave away 'a lot' of your points to others by mistake? Without giving names... it's me. Meaning I wanted to give points to someone who gave a really nice reply, but I had no clue it was subtracting from my karma, and I ended up giving a lot more than I intended?

Maybe it's called Darwinian selection?!? :/
Happens :)
Those numbers are incorrect (the FAQ is outdated). There's a discussion in the cs373 forums about what to set the reputation ratings at.

Those karma points will immediately be credited back to your account after you have given me all your points.

LOL

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I was surprised in the last videos, when we search ""<--a href="".
There can be other attributes in a link and the order is free.
So we could have ""<--a id=""myid"" href=""theurl"">--Link text<--/a>--

It's not so difficult, and it would have been a good exercice :
1) Search ""<--a ""
2) Search "" href="" after the beginning of ""<--a ""

What are the other ""bad cases"" which where omitted (but are not really interesting to implement as a quiz in this first unit) ?
1) Some \"" in the middle of the href="""" string, (in a GET parameter for example)
2) ""href="" inside the string of an other attribute
3) A link with no href attribute at all (i'm sure there are so cases in Javascript for example when we create a false link). So we should first search the closing >-- and then search if there is a ""href="" betwen.
4) Putting the string to lowercase, to avoid ""hReF="" or ""<--A""

Are there other things we should be aware of in the real HTML world ?

"

data-item.data-item-item: How has the team embedded the python interpreter on to the web browser?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

They're using ember.js along with the ACE editor on the client side (your browser) for syntax highlighting. When you click ""submit"", your code is sent to the server and interpreted, probably with some custom server code.

"

"

The content page needs both java and flash, I think it is safe to assume the embedding was made with java but I didn't check. There are a couple web-driven python shells like this you can use without installing Python. IDEone is the one you should use to be sure the syntax is the same as this class.

IDEone

@jzegan hopefully we're not going to be nitpicking about what is embedding and what's not. On the broader sense of it, having an external script available in your webpage as an interface (the shell window) can be called embedding, although not enclosed within [embed][/embed] brackets.

@zebriah codepad's version is 2.5.1.
To figure out the version, type those commands:

import sys print sys.version
"

"

It's not embedded, it's what Chewie said. Python version is 2.6.6.

Edit
To further roughly clarify, when you click 'Run' the code you type in the editor on the page (along with a couple other parameters) gets POSTed to the server inside of a JSON object, executed by a Python interpreter on the server, then a GET request gets a JSON object with the status of the execution and you get ""Your submission was saved"" or the request gets repeated until you do. Similarly when you click 'Submit'.

@Angel,
Indeed, it's pretty pointless, however ""embedded on a web browser"" makes me think of the code being actually executed ""on the browser"", in which case with an implementation such as Pyjamas, Skulpt or LLVM.

"

Python (Command Line) got the result, but the online didn't.
I'll try again.
Yep this is the thing to do. If it's actually an incorrect submission we can help the student, if it's something wrong with the grading code than I can figure it out.

Question of Hello!!! got a bug again.
I defined and printed out, but it failed.
Even the result of online Python got the result.

I kept getting mine wrong until I used 1.0 instead of 1 for the first part of nanobyte. I couldn't figure it out, kept changing my equation around and trying different symbols (even though they just said to multiply everything) and it turns out I was just missing the decimal, which will give you a more exact answer than if you use just 1/1000000000.
Is that what happened to you?
i had the same problem as ifoundxaway. i was going crazy!

Ditto! I kept having problems until I actually used the exact expression 1.0/1000000000. Despite what the video shows, if I kept using 1/1000000000 I would not get the correct answer, for some reason.

This has to do with the rounding down of integer quotients in python itself. When you use the decimal, if casts your integer into a float, and you get a float as a quotient (result). The program would otherwise round down to a wrong answer. This may or may not be the case that you are seeing, as until I see the code and what was rejected versus what was accepted, its all just conjecture.

Coincidentally, you could also have done division with the './' operator, IIRC. This should have worked as well.

Yes, I kept getting a result of 0 when I enclosed parenthesis around the quotient 1/1000000000. If you do not use parenthesis, you will get 29 as the video solution indicates:

299792458 * 100 * (1/1000000000) =>-- 0

299792458 * 100 * 1/1000000000 =>-- 29

I think borromeotlhs has it right. When using parenthesis, it does that calculation first, and since it is an integer calculation and won't use decimals, it rounds the answer down to 0 (ie 1/1000000000 gets rounded down to 0). Then when you multiply by 0, the result is going to be 0.

Without parenthesis, the calculation is done from left to right, which keeps you from having a 'round down to zero' in your calculation.

data-item.data-item-item:
"
# Write Python code that assigns to the  # variable url a string that is the value  # of the first URL that appears in a link  # tag in the string page.  # page = contents of a web page page ='<--div id=""top_bin"">--<--div id=""top_content"" class=""width960"">--<--div class=""udacity float-left"">--<--a href=""http://www.xkcd.com"">--' start_link = page.find('<--a href=')

First I tried:

url = page[start_link:] print url

Which outputs: <--a href=""http://www.xkcd.com"">--

Then I tried: 

url = page[97:118] print url

Which outputs: ""http://www.xkcd.com""

Then I tried:

url = page[98:119] print url

Which outputs: http://www.xkcd.com (no quotes)

But it is still telling me to try again! Anyone see where I am going wrong?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You don't have to output anything. Just save the URL into the variable
Did you remove the print instruction? It gets marked as wrong if you keep it there.
HINT: Try figuring a way to create variable that find the place value instead of typing it.

"

Maybe it's because you hard-coded it (i.e. you explicitly wrote the starting and end point index), which is not generic enough. Consider e.g. a longer URI/URL, then your approach is not flexible enough.

The algorithm in pseudo code is sth like:
Find the first quote ("")
Find the last quote of the href attribute
Extract the URI from the indexes you got

This approach also works for links with larger/smaller length.

"

How are you getting 118/119 in the first place? What I mean is, think of a way to get that number without guessing/counting. Your code should work for a link of any size. Think of what the link ends with and how to use string manipulation to extract up to that point.

Hope this was some help!

do not use numbers. you need to come up with the method that will find position of first quote and method for second quote. put that values in variables start and end for example. then url = [start + 1 : end].

using hardcoded values is bed idea. try to make program that will extract link from any page.

You can get a nice explanation by looking at a post I just made in the forum :

Answer to Unit 1 Final Explained

I posted it a few moments ago
Ah yea, didn't realize it had to be generic!

You need to open the Terminal application (through Spotlight or whatever). Then, type python, hit Enter and you should be presented with the Python prompt, ready to follow your orders. Something resembling this:

francesca-computer:~ francesca$ python Python 2.7.2+ (default, Jan 21 2012, 23:31:34)  [GCC 4.6.2] on darwin Type ""help"", ""copyright"", ""credits"" or ""license"" for more information. >-->-->--

Alternatively, you could install iTerm for a friendlier terminal app and/or IPython for a friendlier Python interpreter (however, the latter may be difficult to install in MacOS X if you don't have a C compiler).

"

Hi Francesca,

The Python Interpreter is accessed using the Terminal on a MAC. Launch Terminal using Spotlight. One you have Terminal open, Type Python on the Command Line and it should launch Python 2.7 for you. You should use Python 2.7 and not 3.2 for this course.

Once you have Python launched, you can type help() at anytime and it will give you a help function.

It will take a little while to get used to using the Terminal, but keep at it and you will soon get the knack of it!

Good Luck and I hope it all goes well.

This is absolutely the only ""group"" that I can truly endorse. Good job to all the kids taking this course. Well done already, and good luck going forward! :)

I'm an eleven-year-old three and a half times over, but because my father played some clever tricks on me when I was young, I was programming by the time I was eleven. Taking this course at eleven is a fantastic idea.

Yes, you'll learn useful computer skills that can help cement your future and all that. You'll also learn useful ways of thinking: how to break big problems down into smaller, approachable steps, and trust that putting them all back together at the end will give you a working solution-- how to try to plan for all possible cases, including the unforeseeable ones-- how to be very, very, unmistakably specific in your language-- how to think about a problem not in terms of the starting point (what the problem looks like) but the eventual goal (what an ideal or acceptable solution will look like)-- and, when things inevitably go wrong, how to tell from what DID happen what you should do differently next time.

Those abstract skills are way more valuable than knowing any one programming language, or knowing how a search engine works. You can parlay those into an advantage in anything you do, from programming to politics. And, honestly, learning that stuff now will make the rest of your school life much easier, because those are some of the skills that make up thinking itself and school never seems to have time to teach you that part, but requires you to do it anyway. You're doing yourself a huge favor by being here. Good luck!

Young man, DO NOT ever let anyone tell you that you are either too young or too old to learn ANYTHING!

You can learn anything at any age provided two things:

1) You must truly WANT to. Not if someone else wants you to, but YOU want to.
2) You must be willing to put in the time and effort. This is what is known as discipline.

Remember, some things will come easy to you, some things not so much. Push on! Work on it from different angles. Ask questions. BE PERSISTANT! Everyone was a beginner before they were an expert. No fear.

I will GUARANTEE you that if you apply these two things to anything in life, you will be successful.
Good luck!

and NEVER give up!

data-item.data-item-item: Am i wrong to think that one of answer option is wrong. Computers don't write programs do they?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Please check next answers: Answer

"

Some of them do, think of a compiler that generates a computer program after reading some input. Anyway, most programming languages aren't designed with that use case in mind. A computer can write in any language its programmed to, but nobody would say that english is designed to be written by a computer. So I think the question is wrong.

Computers do write programs. This can be explained easily in case of complied languages(such as C or C++) where an object code(which is also a program) is created. The object code basically tells the computer as to what is to be done as program written by us is more user friendly, the object code is more computer friendly. The object code is basically like a map which replaces the command written by us to a Turing primitive. Example: If we store a value in a variable, the process within the computer may not be as simple as that. There is memory allocation, where the address of the memory location is fed so that something points to that location. Then there is movement of the value to the memory location. When we do x=10, the computer generates a code which may go something like this
LEA [si],2312h
MOV si,0Ah
where the first command points at the address in the memory in which 10 is to be stored. The second statement moves the hexadecimal value of the number 10 i.e A, to the memory location previously described. This code is generated by the programming language. This is further broken down to binary numbers as well.They are programs as well. They are generated by the computer. Sometimes in case of compiled languages, the compiler may actually find an alternative and better method to arrange the program written by us to increase efficiency.
Hence, to sum up, computers do write programs.

"

I think that generally this question is not straight forward. It should be more precise because it depends on what you think about the whole process of writing-- e.g. when I'm writing this reply I am writing it but I do not follow exact creative process as, let say, Fyodor Dostoyevsky when he wrote ""Crime and Punishment"". We both write but in other senses. Do computers can write^H^H^H^H^H translate programs? Yes, they can. Do computers can create algorithms that solve new problems? Simply put - No, but hey one can argue that this is the essence of writing programs.

All in all - it just should be more precise IMHO. --)

PS.
Better analogy - you can't turn on your computer and expect that it will write anything for you.

PS2.
Aditya: What you said can be explained better if you use word ""translate"". Computer translate High Level Language syntax to low-level language syntax (Assembler) but it will not write your program-- It will translate program written by you in the form that it can compute.

"

I agree with Aditya,

In short, we program in a high level language, such as Python or C, and the interpreter or compiler takes what we have written and translates it to a low level language, machine code and then binary.

You can code your program in binary if you want, but wouldn't it be much better if we allow the computer to do that for us? :)

Well so you basically said that you agree with Aditya and then you said that computer translates (not write) programs written in HLL. So it writes or translates?
If I will translate one of the Lem's book to english I'm writer or translator?

In addition to just translation, the compiler will do optimization and all sorts of other things.
I guess that would be the equivalent of taking some existing scientific work and using it as the basis for your own modified experiments.
It isn't a totally original work, but it could qualify as writing, depending on the definition that you choose to use.

I don't disagree that computers do write programs, but I find the wording of the answer confusing. Contextually it implies that computers write programs designed to be read by humans. Is this correct? In the examples discussed here a computer will write a program to translate human friendly language into computer friendly language, designed to be executed by a computer. I'm unaware of a situation where the computer written language is designed to be read by a human.

data-item.data-item-item:
What is wrong with the expressin +33?
In my interpreter it give the response 33

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

try to remember the Python grammer : Expression operator Expression .. check the video link
video link ...

"

The grammar given in the question is not the same as python's grammar - so your interpreter accepts +33 as a valid python expression. In the question you cannot derive +33 from the grammar rules given and so +33 isn't a valid expression in the very simple language given by the question.

Are you trying to increase 33 by one like in C++ (I think it's called pre-increment/decrement operator)? If you are, here is one way of doing it:

>-->-->-- count = 33 >-->-->-- print count 33 >-->-->-- count += 1 >-->-->-- print count 34

data-item.data-item-item:
"

So here is the question: 

# Final Quiz # Write Python code that assigns to the # variable url a string that is the value # of the first URL that appears in a link # tag in the string page. # page = contents of a web page

Here is how we get the result:

Finding the start of the link tag

The first thing we want to do is find the index of where <--a href= is. We do that by using the find function to get the position of the first occurrence of <--a href=

start_link = page.find('<--a href=') # This returns position 89

Finding the actual link

The second thing we want to do is return the position of "" (double quotes) starting from start_link (position 89) so here we use <--search string>--.find<--target string>--<--start number>--

first_quote = page.find('""', start_link) # This returns position 97

Now we know where the first quote begins, and with that, where our link begins (first_quote + 1).

Finding the ending quote

Now that we know where the first quote starts we can find the ending quote. To do this, we return position of ending (second) "" beginning from where the first quote was found (position 97 + 1)

end_quote = page.find('""', first_quote + 1)

Had we not included + 1 we would have gotten the first "" in our result which corresponds to first_quote.

Saving the URL

Now that we have the positions for our first_quote and end_quote (start and end positions of the first URL) we can use these indexes to sift our our URL.

url = page[first_quote + 1: end_quote] # don't forget the plus one

Happy Coding :)

"

Why is it important to not have the first "" of the URL ? (sorry if it is a silly question...)

"
Quiz explanations are encouraged.
I would recommend not posting homework explanations until after the due date however --).

@raccoon: Not a silly question!

We want to store just the text of the URL itself - because later, our web crawler is going to be trying to follow those links, collecting more links, etc.

If we try and go to a link that begins with a quote, we're not going to get anywhere - we'll just get an error! So we remove the quotes so that we can visit the pages later.

Hope that makes sense!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
IndentationError
You are commiting one of the cardinal violations in Python when you mix tabs and spaces in your indentations. Many editors do not match the correct amount of spaces with your tabs, now you have a mess on your hand. Please use the customary 4 spaces only, avoid tabs!

The answer is in the error message that you recieved.

line 7 print 7 * 7 * 24 * 60 ^ IndentationError:

you probably have a tab space before your print command, try deleting any spaces in front of the line.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

The quiz named ""What is a programming language?""

One of the correct answers were choice # D, which says: ""A language designed to be read by humans, and written by computers.""

Are programming languages written by computers?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: A computer can dynamically generate code based on previously written code. So, a computer can write a programming language, but it cannot design one. If one ever did, then we would be witness to the birth of sentient machines.

Humans can write a program in a language to tell the computer to write code probably based on what it receives. Humans need to let computer make decisions for itself.

Think of skynet for example from the movie: Terminator. They have to create their own code to tell the machines to kill humans. But thats a little too big.

:P

sure, there's plenty of programs that write other programs (and in other languages).

Most web pages tend to generate a lot of javascript on runtime.

I thought this was explained in the answer video. He explained that programs can be written by other programs - for e.g., what you feed in to Python interpreter would be translated to something else. I suppose you could read that as well, which makes choice D correct. I too wasn't sure why until I saw the answer.

"

See the response in this similar thread.

"

"

A good example is CoffeScript which compiles into JavaScript. Another example would be the Cfront compiler which converted C++ to C.

"

"

No computers do not write programming languages. Computer languages are designed by humans. Once a language has been designed, a piece of software called a ""compiler"" is written. The compiler is responsible for turning the human-written code into the 1's and 0's that the computer can understand.

You can think of the compiler as a translator. When someone sets out to design a new programming language, it basically means they are designing a new translator.

For example, you could write a compiler that follows this rule:
When I come across ""2 + 2"" I should invoke the processors adding ability on the two operands

Or, you could write a compiler that follows this rule:
When I come across ""+ 2 2"" I should invoke the processors adding ability on the following two operands

It's all just a matter of translation. Python, being a very high level language, is very easy to read. This is because it's designers created a ""translator/interpreter"" that could read something very similar to natural language, and translate it into machine language.

So while it is true that computers can ""write programs"", they cannot (yet) write/create a programming language.

"
More importantly he asked you to pick the best possible answer but you have to pick all 5 to register a correct response.

I think there is a semantic confusion here. He's not asking if a computer can write a programming language, he's asking if a computer can write in a programming language. This simply means that a computer can generate code that complies with the grammar of the language and correctly replicates some functionality.
Thanks for the discussion. I was really confused, but now I know that code is written by computers too!

"

Well. This is an interesting question, I think. There are programming languages that are geared towards building compilers/interpreters. My favorite is the ""lex/yacc"" combination, but these days, the new kid in town seems to be Antlr. There are also java-y ones, that I also enjoy, jflex and cup. But, of course, then the programmer is still building the language. But, I think this doesn't exactly address your question.

It seems like you are asking, does a computer every write ""code"" in the sense of something other than (say) machine code or assembler. The answer to that too, is yes. Take the examples I mentioned: lex/yacc, they take as input a lex and a yacc source, and output C code, which when itself compiled, produces a compiler. But, a more intuitive answer would be when you hit print on your word processor or whatever, often your printer driver is writing postscript or pcl. Of course, in both of these cases, the output isn't meant to be read by a human, but by another machine.

Antlr's claim to fame tho, is that it takes an antlr file as input, and outputs a human readable compiler... Or at least that's what I remember, tho I can't seem to find a reference to that now. So. The answer to your question is a definite yes. Computers do write programs in programming languages for consumption by both humans and other computers.

"

I wouldn't say code is written by computers. Code could be generated by computers because the computer was programmed to do so. I didn't find the quiz that useful. Yes it sparked all of this conversation but I don't see how this kind of questioning will be useful to beginners.

"

If you're somewhat new to programming but well-acquainted with math, Project Euler provides a number of computational problems that can you can use to practice your coding skills. Project Euler is geared more towards math than computer science (I think), but the lower-level problems--at the very least--will definitely help familiarize you with basic programming structures.

Many of the problems are designed in such a way that they require you to consider processing time, as well-- with an efficient program, each of the problems should take less than one minute to solve. However, if you insist on taking a brute-force route rather than consider more nuanced approaches, solving the problems can become increasingly difficult very quickly.

Project Euler really is a lesson in creating efficient and succinct programs!

Also, note that Project Euler provides what are essentially coding prompts-- you're not required to use a certain language, so you can stick with Python or attempt to create a solution using another language of your choice. That being said, Python is the third most popular language on the site.

You may be up sh*t creek without a paddle. Iran has just stepped up it's censorship of the internet massively over the past few months. Proxies will not work, OpenVPN handshakes are detected, even SSH tunnelling is now detected and blocked. They're blocking all HTTPS connections even.

One viable option is to try using the Tor projects new tool called obfsproxy - blog.torproject DOT org/category/tags/iran
But this is very likely to be paaainfully slow.

I heard the PPTP protocol is actually unblocked, because it's trivial to decrypt - but it's tampered with and slowed to being unusable as well.

If you have a python interpreter installed on a linux box, there is a patch/wrapper that should allow you to use SSH tunnelling by obfusticating the initial handshake, which will get you past the initial handshake blocking being used. More details here - paste.debian DOT net/155833/

If you don't have an SSH tunnelling provider, I use and recommend VPNSecure DOT me

Hope this helps. If all else fails you'll need to get someone to download all the youtube videos, and send them to you another way, or host them somewhere for you. Perhaps the course organisers should consider having a straight http download location available on request ?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Hi there!

There is no reason why you shouldn't be using the newest version. If you feel comfortable with that, go ahead. :) I sure am going to use it.

However one of the reasons for using python 2 instead of python 3 is that a lot of code out there on the web was written using python 2 and some of the functions used have become deprecated and replaced by their newer counterparts since the coming of python 3, but that code is still in use and a lot of development over that happens. Python 3 is new and it will take time for people to switch over to that.

If you choose to use python 3 just take care of some little things and all shall be fine. For starters, the print function is python 3 should be used in the following syntax:

print (""Whatever u wanna display""), i.e. use of parans becomes necessary. Refer documentation for further details. Hope this helps :)

data-item.data-item-item: Google search engine is build using which programming language ?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

""Depends on which part of Google you mean. The back-end of Google's MapReduce implementation, which processes webpages and builds web indices, is written in C++, with front-ends for Python and Java (see here).

So, the real work (data processing within the compute cloud) is done by C++ libraries, but the development can be done in higher-level languages that call these routines. When you submit a web query, results are fetched from the huge indices produced by the back-end jobs.""

Source: stackoverflow

data-item.data-item-item:
Hello

I'm a newbie regarding backend languages

Is there a special reason why the search engine project will be build in Python???

is it possible to use Ruby instead??? or php?? what's the difference?

just wondering

thanks!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I believe the commonly agreed upon reason, discussed in prior posts, is that Python is a high end yet simple to learn scripting language.

I've built a similar search tool using PHP. You can use any language.

They've probably chosen Python because it's the easiest for newbies to learn, easiest to use as a teaching tool for general programming concepts, and the error handling is more elegant than some other languages.

"

Here is an answer WHY.

"

Whereas PHP is more of an, and evolved from web-programming, it us often used procedural (i.e. PHP has concepts of Object-orientation, but simple built-in types are not objects) and often has confusing functions for the same computation. PHP really has some flaws where Ruby and Python do not. (they have others --))

In Ruby and Python everything is an object. The both have an elegant syntax (I would consider Ruby to have a more beautiful syntax) and allow the programmer to express complex concepts very easy.
Even though I would consider Ruby to be superior in terms of syntax and tooling. Python is widespread used for numerical computation/modeling, natural language processing, biological computation and prototyping through it's use of NumPy and related libraries, e.g. NTLK for Natural Language Processing.

Though I think Ruby has a more elegant syntax and better tooling, especially , python has good tooling, better libraries for some cases and is widespread used for many tasks.

Well Ruby and Python do not differ that much. So knowing one helps knowing the other.

At the end of the day you must make a decision. I think Python is the best one.
ok, thanks a lot for your explanations

I have done allot of PHP scripting, but the projects allways make me mad. 1. The code becomes bloated and 2. the community is full of code where they mix html and php all in one file.
I LOVE how clean python apps usually become in terms of readabillity and that it is OO from start (I started with PHP ca 2000). PHP usually makes me mad - Python is elegant in my eyes.

I teach a couple of web programming courses, including HTML/CSS/JavaScript &-- PHP/MySQL. They have always worked for my purposes, but most of my own programming is pretty light-weight, so I haven't experienced the same frustration that others may have. However, as I try to emphasize to my students, every language you learn is another tool in your toolkit. I was very pleased to find that this course was using Python, as it is a language I haven't had an opportunity to use yet.

One thing I would note is that Michigan State University (my alma mater) is now using Python for their introductory Computer Science course. I was kind of shocked to discover that, since when I went there, our intro CS course was in C++. The reason I mention this is that it seems that Python may be getting more common than most of us are aware of.

data-item.data-item-item:
Looking for a few (up to 10) high school and /or middle school students that would like help getting through this course. I am willing to help you through the course. I am a high school math teacher and an electrical engineer.

The purpose in me providing this help would be to get an understanding of how easy or difficult this course is for High / Middle school students. We (my school) is thinking of enrolling a number of students in the April course. Thus, any experience I get working with students now would help me prepare for the future.

Help would be via Skype sessions or via Google Hangout sessions. Help would be available 3 to 4 times per week, about an hour at a time. Interested?? reply back and let me know.

Cheers!

Kevin E.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: i admire ur work .. . if u r an engineer then y u r a high school teacher ??? just asking

Bachelors and Masters in Electrical Engineering, worked in the field about 15 years.
Masters in Mathematics Education. Been teaching for 8 years.

I'm in high-school, but by the moment I don't need extra help with cs101 (I haven't finished Unit 1, so I don't know the real difficult of the course) -- but maybe it would be good for 373, if anyone is going to do like you with that class.

Kevin,

I am a middle school teacher. I would be happy to help/work with you as well.

I am, like SrMico, a high school student, but I don't need any help for now. I will be happy to give you feed back on how difficult it is for me. If it helps your understanding I'll also tell you that I'm an honors student with straight A's, so the courses difficulty for me may not accurately reflect its difficulty students in non-honors classes.
Zach - I would love to have your feedback on this as a high school student. I will touch base with you at the end of unit 2. Thanks.
Excellent. Thank you. So far, no students have asked for help yet.
Also a high school student (Year 10), all good so far but will be in touch it things get difficult :)

Por cierto alguien me puede explicar lo de la velocidad de la luz divido por la velocidad de cpuÂ¿?
Entiendo que 2.7 Ghz sean 2700 millones de ciclos por segundo pero lo que no entiendo es lo de la distancia de ciclo, no se si me explico, el capitulo 18 que un procesador de 2.8Ghz tiene una distancia de ciclo menor que el procesador de 2.7Ghz

Te esta preguntando cual serÃ­a la distancia recorrida en el tiempo que tarda en ejecutarse un ciclo de reloj.

Al poder ejecutar mÃ¡s instrucciones el procesador de 2.8GHz en 1 segundo el tiempo que consume cada ciclo se reduce y por consiguiente la luz recorre una menor distancia.

Salu2!!

Un Hercio significa que ocurre un evento en 1 segundo, por lo tanto, en 1Ghz ocurren mil millones de eventos en ese mismo segundo. Dicho esto, la luz viaja a 299.792.458 m/s-- es decir, que necesita 1 segundo para recorrer esos metros. Por lo tanto, en una millonÃ©sima parte de ese segundo, recorrerÃ¡ una millonÃ©sima parte de los metros. La cantidad de metros por segundo de la luz se divide por la cantidad de hercios porque los dos comparten la misma unidad de tiempo: el segundo. AsÃ­, cuantos mÃ¡s gigahercios, menor distancia recorre la luz, porque menos tiempo pasa ---)
