Edit - This is a better way to do this, I think. Use the requests library. 

from requests import get  req= get(url) html= req.text

Explanation - We are importing one function from the requests library - get, which is the http method, or verb, used to get data from the server. When you open a webpage in your browser, you're using GET. There are various other http methods, another one we use frequently is POST - used to send data to the server, like when filling out a form.

get returns a request object, i.e, req is a request object. It contains various other information like the status_code, and the headers.

code= req.status_code headers= req.headers

I'll add how to do this with other libraries later.

Depreciated

You can download a webpage by using the urllib library.

import urllib # Get a file-like object for the Python Web site's home page. f = urllib.urlopen(""http://www.python.org"") # Read from the object, storing the page's contents in 's'. s = f.read() f.close()

Example taken from here

So after f.read(), you can use the find method on s to extract links.

"

open the desired page then right click , then click view page source , here press ctrl+F , and write
<--a herf= , u will c all the external links

"

A web page is a text file made up of code. Just as an experiment, try the following:

1) download a webpage with the 'save as...' option.
2) find the HTML file you just saved.
3) change its suffix to "".txt"" and open it with a text editor (like Notepad).

You'll see the exact same thing you would've seen by the 'view page source' option. That's because an HTML file is nothing more than a text file of the proper code. A browser interprets that code so that you see the ""web page"", but it is the code that is in the HTML file, not the images or layout per se. No ""extraction"" of the code is needed.

Does that help to answer your question?

Alexey, I can't give you the python syntax for what you want done, because i'm only learning it now, however i've programmed for many years so i can explain the high level concept to you.

You have already been told that a web page consists of nothing but text, well text with formatting instructions to be exact. If you want to extract or (read) the contents of a web page you will execute an http - get command this basically tells the server to send the page to you.

That's exactly what you get a whole page of ""text"". Depending on how you are wanting to process the page you can either recieve the whole page at once or line by line.

TO do anything with this page you then use string manipulation ((which i believe is the topic of the first lesson I havent looked at it yet)) and then perform whatever steps you want to.

If you are looking for a url for example you will examine every line looking for ""http"" the assumption being that would be the start of the url THEN process everything until u reach a space . That will indicate the end of the line as you KNOW that url can not have a space in it :)

That is very high level but i hope it helped

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi,

In the class I saw that if you includes in a sum, for example, a point, Python will use decimals. How can I do the opposite thing, to truncate the result.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You can truncate the decimal result of any floating-pointer number x by calling int(x).
Ok, thanks. And it only truncate or aproximates to the nearest number? For example 4.6 ->-- 5-- 4.2 ->-- 4.
No, it only truncates the decimal portion of the number. i.e. 3.9 ->-- 3, 4.2 ->-- 4
Ok, thanks a lot

You can use the round() function

Usage - 

a = 3.7 b = round(a) # b = 4.0 a = 3.2 b = round(a) # b = 3.0

It will round off the number to the nearest integer, but it will remain a floating point number, hence the .0

You can pass the precision you want to the round() function too.

a = 4.17 b = round(a,1) # b = 4.2
Oh! Thanks to you too!

Using both round() and int() in conjunction you can create truncated numbers and still round.

a = 4.4

b = round(a) #b = 4.0

c = int(b) #c = 4

print c

Giving the answer of 4 without a decimal format.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: If you're going to tell us that you had problems, don't you think you should describe the problems?

"

Go to Python official website and download the 2.7.2 version for Windows

"
My problem is, that I got only a black little window - not what we have in the course...

I've installed python on windows 7, and had no problems.
Once you download the installer, run the .exe, a wizard should show up, like any other software.
Once finished you should have python installed.
Your environment SHOULDN'T look like the one for the course. It should function the same though.

"

Does the little black window you see have information about python at the top and then a prompt like "">-->-->-->--""? If so this is a python interpreter. You can type commands in here and have them evaluated just like the online interpreter we have in the course.

If you want to actually write programs and then run them as a completely separate step, you should have IDLE installed (it comes with Python). This will allow you to write your programs in one window (like the top section of the online interpreter), and execute it in another window (the bottom section of the online interpreter). There are getting started guides for IDLE which can easily be googled for. They'll explain the process with better detail than I can at the moment.

"
Thanks for your input - so I got it right - the black window is normal - I am happy - so long

We are making an effort to make the quizzes and especially the homeworks more straightforward in the future. Until we learn functions most tasks will end with printing the answer out.

data-item.data-item-item:
Anyone out there interested in making hangouts to discuss our progress in g+.

If anyone is interested maybe we could create a shared circle for each course. Let me know what you guys think.

I thought it would be a great tool to help each other. Up to 10 people can do a videoconference in G+.

Besides this maybe the course teachers could consider doing a Hangout on air!

I would be interested in seeing the potencial of this tool in making remote teaching even more engaging.

Duarte

PS: I have been loving the course so far... congratulations on a job well done.

anevazoune to user status sou sto forum analoga tous pontous exeis extra dikeomata.
ap'to faq

When a question or answer is upvoted, the user who posted them will gain some points, which are called ""karma points"". These points serve as a rough measure of the community trust in him/her. Various moderation tasks are gradually assigned to the users based on those points. For example, if you ask an interesting question or give a helpful answer, your input will be upvoted. On the other hand if the answer is misleading, it will be downvoted. Each vote in favor will generate 15 points, each vote against will subtract 1 points. There is a limit of 200 points that can be accumulated per question or answer. The table below explains karma requirements for each type of moderation task.
â€¢ close own questions ->-- 0
â€¢ reopen own questions ->-- 0
â€¢ add comments ->-- 50
â€¢ retag questions ->-- 500
â€¢ edit any answer ->-- 2000
â€¢ delete any comment ->-- 10000

"

data-item.data-item-item: Videos can be sped up as used in last semester's Database class for instance. How is it activated generically on youtube?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I lower down the video quality to 240 px :D :D

"

If you are referencing speed to the video load times then as smartmuki stated lower your player resolution. But if you are referencing playing the video at about 125% playback speed I do not believe there is a way to do this on youtube. You'd be able to accomplish this by downloading all the videos and playing through them with VLC Player or similar media player. Hope this helps.

"
how to do that?

See when you play the video, look at the bottom of the video for a black stripe where you have the symbols for play/pause and volume.. On the right, you would see a * sort of symbol just to the right of CC. Click on this button(which says change quality) and select 240.

data-item.data-item-item: Hi I was just checking if we need to check in each day for class?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: loll No :D There's no virtual attendance being taken :D
Nope, the units are uploaded weekly! You can watch them whenever you got the time

"

Waves his hand over his head franticly ""Present!""

"

"

I don't think it's necessary (certainly it's not required). But based on my experience with the AI Class this past fall, I would recommend checking in on the ""Announcements"" page of the class site fairly often. Sometimes there would be corrections or clarifications posted during the week, or interesting links or other relevant information.

After all, if you already have a browser open, it just takes a minute to look.

"

This post is done to thanks UDACITY specially Dave and Sebastian... you are great my friends!!!

God bless you all!!!!
thanks for the info on check in
I am neither on Google+ nor on Reddit, but on facebook. So would like you all to ask if you want to create a closed group on facebook and join in?? Please let me know your views..

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
What's the point of making studying groups outside of udacity? Why not study with ALL of us here, together. That would be more fulfilling than segregating the class in little isolated groups. Studing together is the point of having the forums.

Just a thought.

"

@JoelM I agree. This is a fantastic place to interact and learn. Facebook would just be a burden to follow, while also stealing extra data from us! :/

"

I definitely agree it would be like segregating the class into groups. Thats why I asked for all your responses.. The points behind mine posting the question were:
1. People have made groups on G+ and Reddit.
2. Currently, the forum is a little messy. It would be great if the forum is updated as per the suggestions list. :)

Yea the forum is veryyyy messy. Try going to the IRC channel where we are all at. A lot of interesting conversation about class takes place there. If you are not sure as to how to get there, do a quick search for IRC channel and the original question should show up.

data-item.data-item-item:
I am wondering if the progress we are making along this first week is being saved. I mean: I am watching the videos one by one and taking the quizzes, but as the progress option is not available, is my work being saved? Or when the progress option is available, will I have to start from the beginning again?

Lots of thanks in advance

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Yep! Every single action on the site is logged. It's just not displayed right now. Some of the team is working on that now. It's a high priority.
Ok, thanks, this are good news!

Don't get me wrong, though: I assume you don't mean to be hurtful towards others but just made this topic a little funny thing that happened because there were so many groups forming and you wanted to be in one too --)

"

Hmmmm... this is a hard one... First: I haven't seen a ""comp scisters"" group (or any group relating to gender for that matter) and couldn't find it in the Udacity forum, neither by search nor by manually clicking through 10 pages of posts. So I couldn't take a closer look at that. So everything I say after this point is a generalization about community life.
I kind of understand the need for women to have a safe place, because in an engineering field like computer science, sexism is really at its worst. It just drains you when you have to defend yourselves against comments like ""they won't invent the warp drive anyway - they're all blondes!"". This is a male stereotype, makes for a laugh with the ""bros"" but being the target of it will annoy the F* out of you after a while. What if there was a pop culture meme about men not being good drivers? Or men being too emotionally unstable to be reliable in crisis?
These are called ""microaggressions"" - please look up the term on Wikipedia.
Worst part is, these pop culture memes really find their way into everyday life - women in the military? Heaven forbid! Look up Katrina Hodge while you're on Wikipedia --)
So it's easier to just shut out the rest of the world and stay with people who understand you, share your interest, and all that in an environment that makes micro- (or macro-) aggressions less likely to happen.
I don't mean to be nagging - I simply hope to spread some tolerance and understanding.
Thanks for taking the time to read this! =D

"

"

The ""Comp Scisters"" group started out of the ai-class last semester. Now, I actually am in the engineering field. I disagree that sexism is ""at it's worst"" in this field. Microaggression. What crap. I'll tell you what I think. There are actually women who accomplish in all these fields. I don't have to go to Marie Curie or Ada Lovelace. I can talk about Claudia Perlich three time winner of the KDD award. I can talk about Daphne Koller, I can talk about plenty of women today who accomplish just fine, in the face of all these horrible microaggressions that allegedly make it impossible for women succeed. BULLS**! People find it so horrible to admit their own failings that they want to say ""Oh, no. It's not me. It's because society is slanted entirely against my whole group."" No, sorry, buddy. Sometimes, it's not your whole group, it's just you that's inadequate. TOLERANCE AND UNDERSTANDING. Typical condescending crap. If you think that instead of balkanizing us all into ever tinier and tinier groups perhaps we should instead try to all get along as a single group, it must be because you're ""intolerant"".

What I actually think, is that we should forget about our divisions, and we should all just have our single group, and we can and should all learn from each other. Who knows what wisdom is tucked away in the Russian group? In Comp Scisters? Why can't that be shared with all of us?

Especially in an online community such as this, we can behave in a manner that ignores all the divisions. Is it going to be a completely benign atmosphere in here, of course not, no human endeavor ever is. But, I defy you to back up your claim that ""in an engineering field like computer science, sexism is really at it's worst.""

Before you respond, I do not accept the notion that just because a particular group is not exactly divided 50/50, that there must inherently be discrimination going on. Go look at imdb's voting records. You'll find men vote more often than women. By the same naive and stupid measurements that people claim makes ""IT inherently sexist"", one would have to conclude, I think that IMDB is sexist. This notion, I think is inherently preposterous. I don't think there's anything about IMDB that is slanted to make men more likely to vote than women. Also, I suppose coal miners and janitors are discriminating against women. And, perhaps when I was taking my psych degree, the psychology department was discriminating against men, since there were so few men in the psych program. I think it's entirely plausible that different groups might just inherently enjoy different things. So, if you're going to go off, telling me about how few women there are in IT, I find that a laughable ""proof"" of discrimination.

"

"

Two of the following quotes come from the same poster, one does not. Guess which is which.

""I kind of understand the need for women to have a safe place, because in an engineering field like computer science, sexism is really at its worst. It just drains you when you have to defend yourselves against comments like ""they won't invent the warp drive anyway - they're all blondes!"". This is a male stereotype""

""I'm 32, didn't make it through university and I've been going from job to job for a couple of years now. I see Udacity as my big chance to learn enough about creating webapps to become an entrepreneur in the field.""

""People find it so horrible to admit their own failings that they want to say ""Oh, no. It's not me. It's because society is slanted entirely against my whole group."" No, sorry, buddy. Sometimes, it's not your whole group, it's just you that's inadequate.""

Please notice nothing in the quotes or in the nicknames gives away the gender of the poster, only what kind of people they are.

Mir i Druzhbi! (Peace and Friendship)

Interesting. I wonder tho about the quote that the first one refers to as a horrible male stereotype that's oppressing women. And I stand by what I said. Rather than balkanizing ourselves into tinier and tinier groups, humanity should join together and forget about their petty differences. There's no need for a ""six fingered CS101 study group"" or a ""short men CS101 study group"" or an ""obese CS101 study group"". I can understand why there would be a need for language specific study groups tho. And, I do think people who scream endlessly about discrimination sometimes do so, because they don't want to admit that perhaps the problem isn't discrimination against their entire group, but that they themselves are somehow wanting. It is blue.... it is beautiful.... it has no borders....
TBBT = The Big Bang Theory
Greeting for everyone with brown hair!!!

What if there was a pop culture meme about men not being good drivers?

There isn't? Is that more of an assumption than a meme, since people take it for granted rather than actively crack jokes about it?
Greetings fellow Browny!
I get the feeling there's a non Brownie infiltrating our group.

@bnsh said:

What I actually think, is that we should forget about our divisions, and we should all just have our single group, and we can and should all learn from each other. Who knows what wisdom is tucked away in the Russian group?

I agree with most of this and think that it would be great if we could all just get along. However, I do understand the need of people to have a discussion group in their own language if English is hard for them.

Furthermore, one advantage of smaller groups can be that it is easier to (kind of) get to know each other. This decreased anonymity can motivate people to stick with it. Even if you don't know each other's real names, a group of ten people would miss ComputerDude123 if he stopped contributing regularly, but a group of thousands wouldn't.

Having said that, I'm against gender segregation because I think that it would be a complete non-issue in an online setting like this if people wouldn't bring it up themselves.

"

The language-based groups are obviously useful-- people can explain things to each other in their shared primary language. I see the national groups as the same thing with a different label.

I could see the use for a group for women in IT to discuss the experience of being a woman in IT, so that younger or career-changing women can make a more informed decision about whether that's what they want to do, and so that, when appropriate, the guys can stick their heads in and say ""actually, that happens to us too."" The danger, of course, would be defining men as ""The Other"" which gets demonized (and if this never happened in settings where women are the power group, there would be a lot more men in women's studies classes, maybe even sometimes as the professor).

"
Is this the frat house? I have brown hair!
Hey- what about the females with Red hair? Do we get to join the League of Red-Headed Gentlemen? Or do we have to form our own group?

When I was younger I would have agreed that a group just for women was stupid and would have agreed with everyone's arguments against. After spending years being the only female where I've worked I feel very differently now. I found I couldn't really make friends with a lot of my male colleagues (it seems like their wives/girlfriends wouldn't approve.) When I finally started working with women engineers I found it very refreshing and they had a perspective that I had that the men didn't. There's support and understanding between women engineers who work in a male-dominated field.
I didn't participate much in the online forum for the intro to ai class and I joined CompScisters right after the class ended. My participation there convinced me that I needed to increase my participation here.
So- I understand the annoyance at a separate group, but I think you may find more female participation here because of it.
If any of you really want to discuss the issues of being a female engineer I'm sure we can get the women to do that, but I don't really know why men would be particularly interested in that.

"

Kimberly, I hear what you're saying, but I really don't get it. I work closely with a married female engineer who I go to see a movie with every Tuesday. (She gets free tickets from her cable company or something.) There's no problem, I don't think with the girlfriend or her husband. And, she's not retarded, she and I (and a bunch of other men (sorry)) are taking the ml-class together. (I took it last semester, so I'm leading the group, but of the rest, she's in the lead, and last Thursday, they all got together (without me, which I was glad about) and begged her for help with the homework, which she's already done.) And I'm not that young either, I'm 43. I really just don't see the discrimination angle. I also don't see that men discount the opinions of women.

It seems to me that in groups that I'm in if a man were to do that, people would think that was not just offensive, but really ludicrous. It's unfortunate that women continue to think of themselves in this victimish sense. Like I said, these days, there are huge numbers of women who are succeeding, not in some token ""Oh, let's be easy on the girl sense"", but in a very real sense. My favorite example is Claudia Perlich, like I said. I've seen talks by Claudia Perlich, where after she's given the talk, the only thing that's gone through my head is ""Yeah, I can follow what you were doing now that you've done it, but how did you come up with that???""

I am interested in what you call the ""perspective that you had that the men didn't."" Are you sure it wasn't the ""perspective that Kimberly had that non-Kimberly's didn't""? Or are you saying that women have a perspective that relates to IT (say for instance, ""Well, women think a hashtable is better, but men think more in terms of vectors.""?) that is different from men? I'm not trying to be confrontational, but I really just don't get it. It's too bad that there isn't private messaging on this forum because I for one, really wouldn't mind hearing your opinions, but, perhaps a private conversation would be better for it.

I think I'm going to create a dreadlocks only group :D

stunned this was at the top of the list in terms of popularity

"

bnsh, I don't feel like you are being confrontational and I'm happy to explain as best I can. I'm not surprised that you don't get it. At one time I wouldn't either. There was a women's group in grad school that my friend would bring me along to. I just thought it was weird to have a women's-only group, especially since there were so many more women in grad school than undergrad. Now I wish I had really participated more in it.
As kind of a side note at work I've formed both a company-wide social group and a women engineers group. The two groups tend to talk about different things. I've told men before that they can come to the women's group but they have to talk about nail polish. --) They normally say they don't want to come after that. I do have other ""women's"" events in life that we invite some men to- the men that kinda hang out and chat the way women do.
So- some things women would talk about on their own may be: discrimination they've personally faced, getting more girls to get into engineering, social issues they've dealt with with ""personality differences"" between women and men, the balances between being a mother and an engineer, how to lead people from different cultures. I've found that women want to talk about these soft skills and human interaction more than men and share trials and tribulations more. One issue I'd personally discuss is being too demure and shy and because of that get listened to less (specifically by men.) So- I'd bring up what I'd need to do to overcome that, others give advice, etc. When I've brought such things up with men they really don't have a lot to say on the matter/understand what I'm talking about at all. Men talk about other things and that's good too.
Yes- I've worked with men where there's absolutely no problem and I've worked with men with TONS of issues. There are men who discount the opinions of women, there are men who will intimidate women, harass, etc (and I've found that those men are less-intelligent than the men that do listen...)
Maybe some women see themselves as victims. I don't feel like I do. I think I try to figure out what the issues are and how to fix them. In some ways I see a women's group the same as something like a group for the blind, or those with dyslexia... One thing that I specifically like about women is that I find that quite a few men will bullshit and pretend to know things they don't, and that hasn't been my experience with women. When working with women engineers I've found them to be more honest and I end up wasting my time less (even though there are men like this as well.)
One other great thing about a women's engineer forum- I didn't like females much growing up. I just hung around men and was happy that way then I found women engineers and found they were so much like me and that I could form a much better bond and friendship with them than any other females.
So- one reason to form a women's lunch- there were something like 5 women software engineers in the company, all spread-out. If men in my group wanted a men's only lunch all they'd have to do is not invite the two women in the group. One day I did push myself into a kind-of men's only lunch. They were having lunch with a Muslim friend that I didn't know and I think they tried to tell me that it might be uncomfortable for me, but I thought nothing of it and went anyways. The Muslim guy refused to shake my hand and said it was part of his religion. He also made some comments about his female boss and other women he worked with and I did feel really awkward and out of place there. All the other guys that I actually worked with I felt great with all the time and loved working with them.

One last comment on a women's only group: some women feel more comfortable talking to other women than men. I'm perfectly happy bringing up any women's issues and talking about them with men (but I think that would just be totally boring for them and wouldn't make any sense), but not every woman is that way. Just think of some cultures that are very discriminatory. Remember- this is a world-wide group and some of the women have been treated very badly by men/society, told they aren't good enough, smart enough, should just be raising children, etc. For them the supportive atmosphere really makes a huge difference.

"

One last thought: if there was a group specifically for male nurses I wouldn't think it would be ludicrous, but a group specifically for female nurses would be. I could see that men could have issues related to their gender and that field (that they'd face prejudice that they were lacking in empathy, that other men would put them down, etc...)
Blonde, brown or black dreadlocks? I think you should be more specific.

""In some ways I see a women's group the same as something like a group for the blind, or those with dyslexia...""

So you think being female is a handicap? I thought it was politically incorrect to bring up penis' envy in our days.

"

Hi, I am the founder of CompScisters, so I thought it appropriate to weigh in.

For those of you who could not find CompScisters, we are located here : CompScisters - and it is correct that we were originally named AI-Systers last semester.

I find it kind of humorous that people think this is some kind of clandestined group that possess knowledge that is hoarded and not shared in some way. CompScisters is a place to hang. Pure and simple.. It is a setting where women who work in the STEM field, many of whom have never worked with another woman, can talk to other human beings who have experienced the same situation. It is truly an amazing experience to be in a group with 200 other women when, personally, out of 12 years of working in the field, I only had the pleasure of working with one - and many have never had the pleasure at all.

But as for the fear that we are hoarding information - let me just remind you that we are the same women who populate and share in every other forum as well. When there have been times that ideas or resources have been originated in CompScisters (and there have been, because although many are gorgeous blonds they also pack an intellectual punch) - I have personally made certain to either cross post or ask the member to cross post the knowledge so that it is shared. No knowledge is gender specific. Our members all follow this rule. All information is shared with other forums (last semester in the Intro to AI group).

If you are a man or woman and are interested in gender issues then there is a correlate of CompScisters, called CompSciblings- which Peter Norvig joined this past week (heard of him ?)

I will not be spending any time defending our group. Sebastian Thrun supports it fully, here is the email he wrote about it last semester :

""I can't believe anyone votes against this. I think the gener issue is a really big thing in our field. I feel we are leaving out 50% of the world population, for no real reason. Please feel free to post my email. I would love to have a more balanced gender participation. Perhaps our class can help a little.

-- Sebastian Thrun""

If there is a need for a group of women called DLD Women DLD Women who include such illustrious members as Arriana Huffington -( in case you are wondering who else is a part of this group :DLD Women's Video of Members - then perhaps there is a need.

According to DLDWomen, this is the ""Female Decade"" - the decade that brings women to the tech table in the same numbers as men - as opposed to the 10% who come currently.

There are many women who have said that this is not a group for them, in one way or another. I completely support them. This is a group, for (all online STEM students : Udacity, Coursea, and MITx) female students. Women come and go, they are against us intellectually for a period of time, join for curiosity then stay.. and some come and exit with gusto !

But we are 277 strong, and exist because there is a need - just like the language based group exists because there is a need. And agreeing with it, or not agreeing with it, is irrelevant. It is nice to be ""Liked"" but it is more important to persist and exist regardless.

Best -
Jacqueline Spiegel

"

Yuri,

That's what you got from everything I said?

"

""I will not be spending any time defending our group.""

One page of chatter before that, another page of chatter after that.

Jacqueline Spiegel do you think ""there is no real reason"" that superior education should leave out a vast majority of people, those who have insufficient IQ? Do you think ""there is no real reason"" that professional athletic competitions, or space exploration, should leave out a vast majority of people, those who have inadequate physical shape?

I don't care if you are male or female, and the automated graded system does not either. If you or your peers feel so horribly discriminated, use the alias ""Jacques Spiegel"" and stop seeking attention.

"

Yuri Gagarin, I am really glad you asked the question.

There is an assumption, by mostly men but some women, that the reason we need this group at all is because we feel discriminated against.

Nothing could be further from the truth.

We need it because out of 160,000 who signed up to take the class last semester there were only 16,000 - our voices were not very loud, and we wanted to hear each other.

I have only worked with men (with the exception of one woman), I have only ever been hired by men - and in truth I have had a wonderful time in my profession. I really have enjoyed it. The people whom I have worked with were all good blokes.

But that does not take away from the sadness that there are few people like me out there. Or that sometimes it is easier to hear things recast in a way by someone who has a similar experience, or the fact that it is super nice to be in a place where you are not different any more.

What Sebastian and Peter did when they created first their Stanford class and then Sebastian's Udacity - is level education for all. As long as you can have access to a computer (and that unfortunately is still a big if for many in our world) - you can take their classes. And the grading system does not care what your sex is, and more than that neither does Sebastian.

But while we are here, it is my contention that there is a social element to this aspect of our lives. And we might as well live it up a bit. That is what CompScisters is for.

It is a fun, warm, light, serious place where any issue can be discussed, most of which are technical, but some not.
Puuh, some say mine are brown and others say they are blonde. The length should be at least >--50cm :D

Over my career, I have belonged to several professional math and science organizations whose goals were to share information and build collegial relationships. Unfortunately, this meant a lot of newsletters, flyers and expensive conferences.

My life is busy and my time precious. Fortunately, there are listservs, and I can now have online interactions with other people in IT easily and effectively through fb. I belong to several fb groups related to AI, and I am so grateful for the information, insights and humor shared by my colleagues. I see absolutely no issue with connecting with other women in IT.
Superbly said.

Thanks for taking the time to share all this info with us Jacqueline!

Your post is the epitome of grace and patience (in contrast to the strange and rude post from Yuri!)

Well done Compscisters and Compsciblings for all the important work you are doing :)

Either could use Boadicea, queen of the Iceni, as a part of their logo. After all, Starbucks uses a Siren. ---)

No red-haired ladies allowed in CompScisters. Everyone knows red-heads are independently-minded.

While I generally agree that using a non-gender specific username and avatar would be a good way to make sure you aren't profiled in a certain way. However it has some problems.
If you are a woman or man looking to go into a field that is dominated by the other gender it is nice to know that you aren't the only one. I was talking to a young girl a few weeks ago about how school was going for her and she was almost embarrassed that math was her favorite subject. If she was aware of a strong group of women and girls that like math she might feel more comfortable.
I don't think that segregating out answers and knowledge and putting them in a category only for one gender is a good idea. Groups for language support make sense.

Eric, feel free to have her join CompScisters. We are happy to support and mentor. If there is a need for it, and wouldn't it be wonderful if there is, we will spin off Compscisters as a mentoring group for younger women. Thank you so much for bringing this to our attention. The only thing that I would request if she does decide to join is for her to contact me personally first, so that we welcome her and keep her in the fold actively.

I just installed Python 3.2.2 to get the interpreter/console on a Mac with Lion
to have the last Python and because I prefer to see the colors in the shell/interpreter.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It depends on the code. Please post the code you want to try.

In py3 some changes are made, for example print must be called as a function
e.g. print(""foo"")

"
There are enough differences to cause problems. I'd stick to 2.6, or at least something close, if I were you.

"

This course is using Python 2.6-- Python 3.x versions introduce some backwards incompatibilities with respect to Python 2.x.

For example, the syntax of print statements has changed. In Python 2.x (i.e. the examples on this course) you would write:

>-->-->-- print ""Hello""

But this throws an error in Python 3, whose new syntax for print is:

>-->-->-- print(""Hello"")

You're better off installing Python 2.7.2.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Select the most appropriate release that meet your needs. The current production versions are 2.7.2 and 3.2.2. If you don't know which version you should use, you may visit this page.

I just downloaded Python 2.7.2 which seems to be popular. Direct Download Link

You may also wish to download Win32all, Mark Hammond's add-on that includes the Win32 API, COM support, and Pythonwin extensions. It's available from the pywin32 project on SourceForge.

Python for Windows ships with IDLE as part of the distribution. (Which I didn't like very much!!!)
You can follow this thread for other python IDEs.

For more information about Windows-specific behavior you should know about when using Python on Microsoft Windows, you can visit this documentation.

I'm still searching for a good, free, lightweight IDE. Any help will be greatly appreciated...

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Good post. Also as a note, this class is using Python 2.7. If you download 3.x then you will run into trouble when trying out the code presented here because there's a few differences between 2.7 and 3.x.

As far as IDE goes, go to this page where a large list of IDEs are listed and try a few and see which you like. The list contain IDEs for Windows, Mac, and Linux so there's something there for everyone.

Hope that helps.

"

"

You can use Notepad++ which feels very lightweight, but actually has reach functionality.

You can e.g. make a shortcut like Ctrl+Alt+P to execute your python script immediately from Notepad++. You can e.g. specify your script to execute in interactive mode, where the interpreter loads all you script variables executes it and you can then use it in interactive mode session for further inspection:

<--Command name=""Python"" Ctrl=""yes"" Alt=""yes"" Shift=""no"" Key=""80"">--&--quot--C:\Python27\python&--quot-- &--quot---i&--quot-- &--quot--$(FULL_CURRENT_PATH)&--quot--<--/Command>--

Just put the above in your shortcuts.xml (in your Notepad++ folder).

"

"

You can use Python portable . Python Portable have a nice and easy IDE. With Python portable v3.2.1.1 i have trouble with the python syntax when i start the python source, but v2.7.2 (197MB on my USB-Stick) works fine :)

"

"

pyscripter is a great IDE for Windows!

"

"

ActiveState as usual has a very nice python download called ActivePython Community Edition, that provides an interactive shell

I am running the 64 bit version on Window 7 and have been enjoying following along the course material

"
Thanks for mentioning Python Portable, it really is essential if you don't have admin privileges. The non-portable installers all require an admin password.

"

Aptana_3

All you need to know :)

"

"

In my opinion you can use PyScripter , it is light weighted and great to work with. You should give it a try. Or you could just try pytools for visual studio.

"

Tnx for your help.

Notepad++ is my favorite editor and I'm glad I can use it for Python too.

Here's another way to interpret python files in Notepad++

Hit F5 or Run->--Run... to open the run dialog, and add this command in the input box:

cmd /K $(FULL_CURRENT_PATH) $(CURRENT_WORD)

Then you can either save or run this command. Here I call a command line (with the /K switch, so it doesn't close after execution or errors), I also added the CURRENT_WORD ,if I want to add arguments (I keep some for debugging as comments in the code).

Note that I have python.exe in my PATH so i can call the .py file.

Also you can open %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\Notepad++\shortcuts.xml (keep NP++ closed while editing) and play around with the command.

"

For easy tasks an online interpreter is my favourite choice

see codepad

"
Yeah, Codepad is very cool and handy...

Wow, I've found choosing an IDE/editor to be the most overwhelming part of Python so far. Thank you for posting these options! The browser interpreter in the course material is great for learning/studying, but I want an environment on my machine for the homework. I've never installed this much software trying to find an editor before. Evar. :D

"

Notepad++ is great, but you don't need to do that by hand. You can use the ""run >-- run... (F5)"" menu option-- then you can save the command. You do need to enter ""$(FULL_CURRENT_PATH)"" though. And you must save the file before launching this command, since Python needs to read it from disk.

Notepad++ commands

"

Thanks for the site, I was searching for it but couldn't find it anymore. You're right, but actually I have another level of indirection, i.e. I'm using a separate batch script for each execution command to make some more difficult tasks in one hand.

Hi Peter,

It appears that you responded to my question about ""Quiz Hello!!!, as I see ""1"" in the answer column on the right side. But where I should I go to see your ""answer?"" I clicked the number ""1"", which didn't take me anywhere. I went to twitter but didn't see any answer.

Sorry that I'm so backward but I'm very appreciative if you can direct me where to go see your response.

Thank you very much!

Hi

Thanks for your response.
I realized that you kindly responded my ""question.""
So I clicked to your email address just in case.
Then I saw the title of my question and clicked it, and here I am.
I will try your response shortly.

Thanks mucho.

"
Awesome! Glad to see you were successful. It took me a while to find how to open the questions too. My first reaction was to click the numbers as well.
Click the NEXT button?

data-item.data-item-item:
"

It would be nice if this could be a place where people come and dump their code. Because maybe they cannot figure out why it doesn't work on their own for example, and need help or discussion. I'm not talking specifically about coursework, but mainly about stuff some of us may be fiddling with just to learn a few new things on the way. At least for this first week when we are still not overwhelmed.

[Edit] I subscribed to Python Tutor. You can get a daily digest of beginners' posts about their attempts at Python coding, and discussions on common problems.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

You can use a service like pastebin to do just that.

"

I guess you may be just right! Thanks, I didn't know about that. Gosh, so many things I have no clue about! :)

Nevertheless, we could discuss the code we dump there here if other people agree.

You might want to consider stopping by the ##udacity-cs101 IRC channel on irc.freenode(dot)net. We're having pretty lively discussions there.
You can get feedback to pastie/pastebin posted code there, as well.
You dump your code there and then put a link to the dump here. Then anyone who wants to see the code can just click the link.

"

In addition to free code hosting sites I recommend Gists at Github. You can save your own code samples and grab them later. You can make them public or private. Plus, it's a good idea to begin getting involved with SCM and a host like Github!

"

"

Here is an example of something that is puzzling me.

I use Python 2.5.1 on Mac OS X 10.5.8.

These are two very simple functions I got from a textbook. Working from the terminal interpreter I imported them ('from X import *') one at a time. I called them, and one works, but the other doesn't! Why?

This one works:


 def area(radius):
     temp = 3.14159 * radius**2
     return temp


This one doesn't:


 def absolute_value(x):
     if x <-- 0:
         return -x
     else:
         return x

And I get the message:

   File ""<--stdin>--"", line 1, in <--module>--
 NameError: name 'absolute_value' is not defined

Why one is defined and the other isn't, when both seem to be pretty straightforward!?

It's in the class FAQs, you should take a look at them.

"

I recommend reading through the unit 1 notes and reading the Python hand out. I also suggest grabbing a free ebook such as Dive Into Python and give it a read!

"

Prepare more, look for more info, and wait until the assingment is publish.

Best Regards!!!

"

Use the time to practice Python (and do the homework assignment once that's available!).

Over in the ##udacity-cs101 IRC channel on irc.freenode(dot)net we're passing around links of Python practice games - those links will make it to the forums as soon as links no longer break posts.
We also do challenges, such as ""brew your own IRC bot in Python"" (easier than you'd think!).

"

Download a manual for introduction to programming for dummies, and enjoy the world of computation and algorithms

Never ever again see a traffic light ..... NEVER!
NeXT Step?

"

You could try some of the problems in Project Euler.

Alternatively, you could google around for some open-source material. MIT, Harvard, Stanford, and others all have introductory programming courses available online (lecture videos, homework assignments, quizzes, etc.). I'd like to point out, though, that those open-source materials are very unlike this, as they are simply online and there is no ""sign-up"" or interaction between you and the professors. You can simply look at their stuff. I believe MIT's introductory courses use Python. Standord's introductory courses use Java, and the Harvard introductory course uses C.

Additionally, there are hundreds upon hundreds of various books you can find on the internet just by googling them. A lot of these are open-source. I'd recommend you make sure they are open-source before downloading them, however. Unless you don't care. That's cool, too.

You could also attempt making your own programs based on what interests you. There are some libraries you could download which would help you with this.

I would also recommend sources such as StackOverflow (a programming Q&--A site) where you might pick up some hints and tips. Reddit has a large amount of programming subReddit's (essentially discussion boards) based around various areas in programming, the different programming languages,and they even have a subreddit titled /r/learnprogramming for those looking to learn more.

That's all I can think of off the top of my head.

"

"

I'm surprised nobody has mentioned Khan Academy's Computer Science lectures on python. Using the videos as supplemental material will help increase your understanding of programming and python in general, IMHO.

Khan Academy Computer Science vids

I'd also recommend installing a Python interpreter on your choice of operating systems and then learning the basics of how it works. Even though it isn't required for this course, it will be helpful to have the ability to save your work for future referencing.

Do take advantage of IRC. Many programmers spend a lot of time hanging out in various channels and it would be beneficial to start building your network of contacts so that you have someplace to turn if you ever get stuck or if you want to help other people by practicing your newly developed programming skills. The latter of these two methods will give you a deeper knowledge of your subject because teaching is one of the strongest forms of learning.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Would a search engine written in Python stand on its own online?
Not necessarily looking to build google in a 7 week course. Not looking to build google at all. But can you get away with a search engine that works well, written entirely in Python? Or would it provide a good base for getting to understand the basics and then you'd need to write it over in another language?
Just Curious.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Regarding to the all information provided - it will be standalone working project written in Python.

Funny you should ask that.

The first version of Google Search was written in Python[1]. They proceeded to replace search algos and indexing with C++ to improve efficiency. They do still use Python from what I hear, supposedly for many of their in-house development and administrative tools.

The point is, Python is very readable and let's you get things done quickly - you can always break things out into C/C++ modules (or whatever other language you fancy) down the road for efficiency and scalability.

Don't be afraid of the concept of rewriting something, either. As you learn your coding ability will improve, and you will want to rewrite portions that you've written early on in a more elegant fashion.

  1. Steven Levy, In the Plex How Google Thinks, Works, and Shapes Our Lives, Simon &-- Schuster 04/2011

The first version of Google Search was written in Python.

[citation needed]

As one posted stated, the original Google was wrote in Python. Plus, I believe Youtube is done mostly in Python even today (unless they re-did most in C or C++).

Python is a great language to build prototypes. Once you have the system built you can pinpoint slow areas of the code and re-do it in a language like C or C++. This is a pretty typical strategy for many systems. Python has great C support built in with the ctypes module. You can actually call and use native code or build your own wrappers.

I highly recommend starting with Python.

Thanks.
What are wrappers?
Sorry. Begginer.

A wrapper is code you write around other code. For instance, you can write Python code that uses C code and hides the fact that it uses C code. This enables you to work entirely in a high level language like Python but use low level APIs such as C APIs.

"

The juicy parts of the embrionary Google were actually written in C++, but the crawler and the URLserver (the thing that keeps the record of what URLs to fetch and handles them to the crawlers) were in fact written in Python.â€ 

â€  Brin, S.-- Page, L. (1998). ""The anatomy of a large-scale hypertextual Web search engine"". Computer Networks and ISDN Systems.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: The audio sounds great to me. (better than the coursera videos).

sound is perfect and easy to understand - iÂ´m german, so no problems here tworivers --)

Best regards!!!
I have no problems hearing anything in the videos. In fact the quality is good enough that I can tell that a laptop keyboard is being used. :)

"

I perceived the quality as ""just fine"" when I did Unit 1.

But since you're asking, I'm going to give you the nit picky feedback...
I've been listening to the material in a fairly quiet environment myself. There is a little bit of clipping here and there but nothing that would justify re-recording anything of Unit 1 as far as I'm concerned.

Dynamics fluctuate a little here and there which may make listening to the audio more strenuous in somewhat noisy environments. Gentle compression would improve on that, though it's really only a smidgeon of compression that'd do the job of leveling out the fluctuations a little when they do occur.

I really think the audio is good enough, but if you wanted to go all the way, making sure the recordings don't clip and then compressing it very carefully would take you the rest of the way to ""awesome"".

"

about the audio I have no complaints, but I really like to have the option of subtitles in the videos, this option could also be very useful for people who can not hear very well

edit: so, no complaint at all
they have subs, just press on cc
thanks i didn't notice the cc option on the youtube videos

I think the audio levels just need to be set a little more generously so there is less chance of peaking. If you really wanted to improve it further, maybe a mike screen/fuzzy cover thing to reduce the sizzle and pop just a tad and normalize the audio. Finally, a noise reduction pass on the audio would be icing on the cake. Noise reduction has really come a long way. Audacity, the open source audio editor, was pretty good at this the last time I played with it. It was literally like a one click thing.

I should add that this is a minor issue, IMO. The course has been great so far. I'm not sure how much time you want to spend on perfect audio quality if it's going to take time away from developing the courses. If it doesn't make a difference, we can talk about lighting next :)

"

data-item.data-item-item: just wondering how many people are taking this class.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I believe The registration continues until the 28th, so the total tally will not be until after that date
The Introduction to AI class was said to have over 160,000 students. I'd like to think that Udacity will top that.

To echo Carl Sagan, billions and billions.
Okay, not really.

"

What's our measurement for ""taking"" the course? Signing up, completing any amount of work, or completing some particular amount of work? You're going to get different numbers for each of these because for a free online course, the commitment level inherent in just signing up is very low, so there'll likely be a higher percentage of no-shows or people who do a little and then quit, compared to what you would see in a paid class. (Of course, some of the people who do a little and then quit will still have learned something, so it's a judgment call as to whether they should be counted.) Also, because Udacity isn't awarding formally recognized certification or credits of any kind, there is no external reason to ""tough it out"" if the material or time commitment becomes difficult.

I like the free-choice learning model, for both philosophical and practical reasons, but non-enforced participation comes with tradeoffs when you start trying to describe a group of learners numerically. There are probably several theses and dissertations waiting to be written on the effectiveness of the model, and it's going to come out behind more formal models if we don't take into account the effect of expanding access (e.g. many people here wouldn't have learned to program at all without this class).

And I have rambled way too long to explain why I wanted to ask the very simple question of who we count as part of our class.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I need 2k :)
How about disliking posts?

Aslo, i would suggest to decrease comments to 0, but increase opening new question to 50.
But i think it will be against the rule that everyone can ask questions :(

Yes, we should be able to down-vote posts. Yes, the karma requirement to post comments should be reduced to 0. No, asking a new question shouldn't require 50 karma.

Posting comments is great. It allows for a discussion without getting in the way of the question/answer nature of this forum. We should allow -- and encourage -- all students to post comments when what they have to say wouldn't suffice as an answer.

If we increased the karma requirement for opening new questions to 50, then new students wouldn't be able to ask questions. This is discouraging.
I'd like to recommend that we be able to close other student's questions. This would allow us to quickly put an end to a question that has been asked 50 times by linking to the original question.
True... but there should be some sort of other forum for those with karma <--50 :)
It will take few minutes to gain 50 karma and will save a lot of time for others to go and read the same question over and over.
You have to understand that, while it may not take long for you to get 50 karma, for most of the students in this course (beginners), it could very well take a few hours.
It's worth noting that down-voting works now.

How do you suggest the new student gets the 50 karma when they're not an expert at anything and really need help? It doesn't seem like this is the right sort of situation to be gagging people like that. It sounds quite elitist, when we should be remembering that this is a beginners' course so you can not expect everyone to be able to even be able to work out the karma system enough to know how to get 50 points to be able to post a question.

We haven't all grown up in the internet age with all the advantages of using forums before. Please please please remember we're here to learn and to help those who don't know so much to learn as well rather than put barriers in their way.

In my original post i mentioned it , that it against the rules, meaning that it's beginners class.
The only thing i don't like, that people don't search.
Maybe we should ask for bigger search field?
no abuse tho...
A new student can quickly gain a lot of karma by asking good questions. Not that hard really.

It is expected that there will be one person per account and that no person will use more than one account. To received a certificate of completion you'll be expected to submit all of the homework and pass the final exam on your own account.

That said, there is no harm in watching together, just make sure everyone turns in their work.

This is my example:

url=page[start_url+1:end_link-1]

I originally did the code below but it wasn't accepted because it was kind of hacky and just me counting the number of characters vs. using .find to get the positions of the quotations.

start_link = page.find('<--a href=')--

start_link = start_link + 9

9 = number of characters that is <--a href=""

It isn't just about getting the correct result, since you could get that by just looking and printing with a print command. It's about finding any link that is in the format stated in the course. If it were changed to bbc.co.uk your code wouldn't find it. You want to write the code so that if you didn't know exactly what the link itself looks like, more than it starts with <--a href=""some link here"">-- where it says some link here is the link, you'd still be able to find what's there.

"

This string parsing stuff is a bit problematic in real life, given the presence of other attributes on the anchor tag, given non-well-formed web pages, etc. If the pages are well-formed you can parse the anchor tag with XML, which makes more sense than bit-by-bit string parsing. If the pages are not well-formed, you can usually force them into well-formedness with Tidy or similar libraries and then use XML on them. I'm curious to see where they go with all this, whether they address these real-life issues eventually, because the string parsing can get a little tedious.

"

I never actually bothered finishing the final quiz. I did this instead (Doesn't work for answering the quiz, you have to use page.find)

import re  import urllib2  __author__ = 'UberMouse'  class LinkExtractor:      links = list()      def __init__(self, page):         #Regular expression that should match most links         regex = r'<--a.*href=?""(.[^ ""]*).*>--(.*)<--/a>--'         match = None         #While there are more links to match, continue         while re.search(regex, page) is not None:             #Get match from page             match = re.search(regex, page)             #If match succeeded             if match is not None:                 #Add link to the list as a (href, link_text) tuple                 self.links.append((match.group(1), match.group(2)))             #Remove matched link from page             page = page.replace(match.group(), """")  print LinkExtractor(urllib2.urlopen('http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/astronomy.html?n=78').read()).links
"

that's a good one too
To be more extensible and take into account the possible presence of other attributes, your reg_ex could include an actual regular expression. :-)

"

Here's a solution that finds all href's taking into account other attributes, uppercase/lowercase, and quotes/no quotes:

def getElements(tag, page):     elements = []     source = page.lower()     start = source.find('<--' + tag)     if start >-- 0:         end = source.find('>--', start) + 1         element = page[start:end]         elements.append(element)         elements = elements + getElements(tag, page[end:])     return elements  def getAttribute(attr, element):     attribute = ''     start = element.find(attr) + len(attr) + 1     end = len(element) - 1     if(element[start] == '""'):         start = start + 1         end = element.find('""', start)     elif(element[start] == ""'""):         start = start + 1         end = element.find(""'"", start)     elif(element.find(' ', start) >-- -1):         end = element.find(' ', start)      attribute = element[start:end]     return attribute  urls = [] for element in getElements('a', page):     urls.append(getAttribute('href', element))  url = urls[0]
"

"

To be honest.... this would be a dead easy task using XSLT

You just match on hyperlinks and only output e.g. these links and skip the rest of the xhtml. The nicest thing is that you don't have to take care of dealing with spaces / quotes etc.

<--xsl:template match=""a"">--
<--xsl:value-of select=""@href""/>--
<--/xsl:template>--

url_start = page.find('""', start_link) url_end = page.find('""', url_start + 1) url_length = url_end - url_start - 1 url = page[url_end - url_length:url_end]  print url

I was trying to limit the use of hard coded values, but because it was assumed that the URL was wrapped in double quotes, I thought this solution was OK in the end. I am thinking though that maybe the 'url_length' variable was somewhat unnecessary.
