data-item.data-item-item: I noticed so many very experienced programmers taking this online course. Does it mean that once i become a programmer, I will have to learn every language. I thought the idea was once the concepts were understood most problems can be solved in any language of choice?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
You will never knew everything. Different people using different way of using the same language, not thinking of others.
Personally, i've never worked with python, but have some knowledge of bash, php, ruby, etc.
Every language is different, if you learned Mandarine, you won't speak Russian.
What is important in programming the algorithm, the rest are only instructions that can be found in manuals

I know a thing or two about Python. There are a few reasons why I'm taking CS101:

  1. CS373 is more advanced and is also being offered. Why not kill two birds with one stone?
  2. This course also teaches computer science, in addition to programming. I want to know how to make a search engine.
  3. I wanted to have the opportunity to help others. I've posted many questions on Stack Overflow and other people have taken time out of their day to tell me what I'm doing wrong, and how I can fix it. It's time to pay it forward.
  4. I'm a HUGE proponent of these education startups. I wanted to get in on the ground floor this time.

Every language has it's strengths and weaknesses. Some languages are great for specific mathematical tasks (say linear algebra and Octave, or statistics and R). Some languages are great at string manipulation (perl). Some are great at OS like tasks (C) etc. I think a good programmer isn't a zealot about their language of choice, and instead considers them different tools in their belt... And, uses the right tool for the job. So, yeah, if you become a programmer, it will be in your best interests to learn at least two languages. If nothing else, knowing (at least) two languages, allows you to more cleanly separate what you are trying to do, from how you will express what you are doing in whatever language you are using. (IMO, of course)

There is a principle called Turing equivalence that says that in a deep sense, all programming languages are equivalent. Because, all languages can at base at the very least, emulate all other languages. But, still, some languages make certain things easier to express than others.
I have experience in other languages. I am taking this for fun outside of my education. (still in college). I think it's more for self-enrichment than anything else.

I been programming with Python for a year building websites with the Django (python) framework, and I just thought it would be fun to look at the basics again.
I finished unit one quite quickly, but I already learned some few new concept :) To become good at anything, your foundation has to be rock solid. And that is especially valid when you do programing. For example the robotics car course was way too difficult for me, partly because of the math (I am trying to finish the whole 303 tests at KhanAcademy) partly because of my weak python programming skills. Hopefully I can take that course later :)

It's practically impossible (not to mention unnecessary) to learn every language. There are hundreds of them.

I thought the idea was once the concepts were understood most problems can be solved in any language of choice?

From my experience, you don't normally get to choose your language when you are hired as a programmer. Unless you are working for a start-up company, they probably have their tools and languages chosen already. It is up to you to learn them.

As for why experienced programmers are here... They are probably interested in learning something new. I've got a programming job, but I don't know much about Python or making a search engine.

I'd say for a lot of people, taking this class is less about learning the language (I'm pretty comfortable with C++, C# and JS already, so picking up the ideas in Python is pretty easy) and more about learning the principles behind building a search engine. That's what I'm most excited about anyway.

As bnsh said every language has it's strengths and weaknesses. I come from the main frame world and most of the languages were compiler based. Knowing the strengths of different languages helped me to write programs that were more efficient. Taking FORTRAN for number crunching and cobol for I/O, for example speeded things up alot. Picking the right language for the task, helps alot. I have to admit though that in the real commercial world, this is not always possible. Some companies allow you only to work with one language.

So to answer your question, no you don't have to learn every language but it helps to know more than one.
Python is my first program ever, so far i feel pretty much comfortable with it, simple and clean code (:

"

My reasons are similar to JamesBrewer's:

  • I want to learn Python better, and
    I'd like to know how to build a
    search engine.
  • I'm also taking CS373
    and already took ""Intro to AI"".
  • I'd like to see how they were going to
    teach the subject. Perhaps I can pick
    up some tips.
  • Plus I figure I should be able to
    breeze through this course, for the
    most part, so it shouldn't take too
    much time.

Though I agree with the sentiment that the underlying algorithms, etc, are what's important and to focus on general principles, don't fool yourself. It takes quite a while to become an expert on any one language. It requires an enormous investment of time to learn all the idioms of a language, the pitfalls, best practices, and so on. It's almost always underestimated, even if you're a fast learner.

"
It's all practise at the end of the day! :)

"

I think, to state the obvious maybe, that you will have noticed by reading the answers that computer science or programming is a life long journey. You can never be ""up to date"" so be prepared to learn something new everyday :)

"

As far as I'm concerned, I signed up for CS-101 because:

  • I have signed up for a few advanced courses @ Coursera and I want to get used to the whole online learning concept before they start
  • Building your own search engine? HOW COOL IS THAT? :D :D

On a side, and completely unrelated note, my first programming language was GWBASIC (in 6th grade) :D
I find with Python I seem to always be learning new ways of doing things. There's always seems more one can learn. And of course it will be fun to learn the basics of creating search engines!
mikaofsweden, I know this is offtopic but you mention KhanAcademy. Did you go through their Python programming video. Any comments? suggestions? differences?. Thanks

"

You won't have to learn every language, but there's a good chance you will want to. Sure, once you learn one language you may be able to solve most of the problems out there. But you'll realize that there's probably a better, easier way to solve some of the problems (don't confuse ""better way"" with ""easier way"" - they're NOT the same thing as you will learn in the future). That's why we start picking up other languages. They offer different strengths and weaknesses as a few others have said, but way more importantly, they teach you how to think about problems differently!

A career in software is about the journey, not the destination.

"
Sometimes you learn more about something when you think you already know it.

Hi. No I did not try the python class at Khan. I am just trying to refresh all my math from the ground up. It seems impossible to become really good at programing without great math skills. And - KhanAcademy is really really fun when you get in to it the way he explains it at the TED.com conferance (view it!). I have finished over 100 tests now and feel like math is fun for the first time in 25 years (I hated math most of my life).

I am a programmer with more than 10 years experience. I am taking this class because:

  • It is very refreshing to see how basics are thought nowadays with top teachers
  • I don't have much experience with Python and I want to fly :)
  • I want to learn about search engines

There isn't any end to learn new things in programming world :)

My answer is similar to James Brewer and other experienced programmers with one added reason. My 15 year old son is also taking the course and it is much easier to help him if I have a better sense of where the course is when he asks a question. A lot of questions (especially coding questions) can be answered in many different ways from the very simple to the very complex. I wanted to make sure I didn't overly complicate an answer for him.

I know how to program in quite a few languages and yes, many of the basic concepts are the same. However, each language has its own characteristics so learning how to work with one won't mean you know how to work with all of them.
Personally, I wanted to learn Python. Since I work and am currently finishing a Master's Degree I don't have a lot of free time, so I thought this class might be a good way to learn Python in a simple and organized way that wouldn't take up too much of my time. I also want to take the CS373 class in April and think it will be easier and less time consuming if I already know how Python works.

"

As George Orwell would put it: ""All programming languages are equally powerful, but some are more powerful than others"".
Once you get experience developing non-trivial programs in several languages, you will come to appreciate this.

"

I am an old dog and I want to learn a new trick. I am not a programmer by profession, but I have experience with several languages, going back to the 1970's. Python is relatively new, and I would like to learn from a CS professor, rather than try to figure it out from a book. I am also taking CS 373, and I love this format for learning. And it is free. How much better can it get?

1. Support the change in education that is happening
  2. Learn Python
  3. Promote Computer Science to newbies (I'm participating in a Meetup as well for this class)
  4. Learn about search engines
  5. Yes, continual learning in computer science
  6. I had a background in AI but still learned a lot in the intro to AI class
  7. It is beneficial to review basics sometimes. Even after the first class I've learned about things I didn't know (well- specifically about women in the history of computer science.) But- by reviewing the basics I can better explain ideas to others.
  8. Meet people interested in the same stuff
Programming is not about know a lots of languagues, is about found the correct algorithm, the most fundamental is the algorithm, and then, comes the code

For me it is a gentle way of learning Python, which I've never used and I like the way it is being taught. I come from a lecturing background and the concept of doing something very big in programming - like a search engine - is the right approach.

I have experience in programming with C++ and this experience helped me to solve the first problems in this course, but the type of challenges that we'll face are totally new for me, so I'm attending to CS101 to discover new techniques and new way of thinking to improve my programming knowledge....

I self learned PHP, and can do websites that work for me, but I am a bad programmer.

Taking CS101 course let's me learn a new language, but also learn good programming practices.

So, later you can choose the language you prefer, but it's good to learn how to structure your programming, and this will help you to do good programming in other languages you choose to learn later

I am really a newbie in this field and I am following the course to:

  1. learn more about how a search engine funtions

  2. re-energize and revitalize some of my good old brain cells

  3. better understand the kind of humor that programmers tend to find funny

@aowonubi you're right in your initial belief that an experienced programmer doesn't need this course and can learn Python on his own elsewhere. The people who are taking CS373 as well, like myself, had better learn Python faster that in CS101, or we couldn't deal with CS373 to begin with.

My personal reasons for taking CS101 are: that I'm enthusiastic about Udacity and online education-- that CS101 will mean a very light workload after all-- and I want the CS degree that Udacity will be eventually offering to the people who complete all their courses.

There are many good reasons, mentioned by earlier posters, but I like to accentuate importance of information acquiring proficiency. Amount of information on Internet increases with every second and so increases the time for separating needed info from ground noise. Google, Yahoo and other search engines are great, but if you want something, tailored specially for your own needs and want to decrease time spent for finding interesting information, then knowledge how to search information automatically is almost must.

In reality, Google and Yahoo are databases with amazing amount of information, but currently is their output focused for human readers â€“ 10 links per page, everyone with 2-3 lines of abstract. But they could put up also a page, with output for automated search engines â€“ 100 links per page (one line per every link), date, when link is visited etc. Then those, who want to use their own specially adjusted searching engines, get links without unneeded overhead. And it's fine, when Google includes also paid links from sponsors to the list â€“ when such ad's aren't too welcome for human analysts, then computers are much faster and can easily check some additional pages, when searching needed information.

data-item.data-item-item: For the experienced programmers in this course, What are your criteria for selecting a programming language to use for your projects?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: This is a silly question. The choice of language should almost always be directly related to the project. You wouldn't try to write a website in C would you? One thing a lot of new programmers struggle with is picking the right tool for the right job.
Your answer makes it sound like it was a good question if it's something people struggle with in getting right.
It's not a good question. If you take 30 seconds to consider how silly it is, you'll see. :)

It all depends, different programs for different projects. It's good to learn atleast 3+ languages so you have a tool box of programming languages. Python is always good to know (: makes the job more efficient.

My criteria for projects I do at home is simply efficiency. How much I can do during the small amount of free time. Sometimes I also pick a language for a project just for learning so in that case it's more or less the lack of knowledge of it.

Well its like choosing the best tool for the task. You will not even try creating advanced 3D shooters with Python, but you will probably love creating smaller apps, scripts on your computer and web-pages with it. For writing Android Apps, you could for example write apps with Python with the Kivy framework (www.kivy.org). But you would probably choose to learn Java since the Android platform optimized for that.
On the iPhone you would use Objective-C and so on since it is optimized for that platform (and of-curse because Apple chooses to censor their platform and keep it closed)

"

For me, it always been on a ""need to know"" basis.
And then ""fun to know"" :)

I've learned quite a few over the years, some because of curiosity, others because it was needed on the job (vbs and powershell specially..)

The key is to be able to understand the pieces of code you'll be looking at, then catch logical errors, then be able to patch it, then be able to write your own stuff. To me, in that very order. The first two comes faster as you hop languages. Logic is logic, basically.

If you start a project, you might not know what kind of sources you'll be looking at to hack it all together and create your final script/code. Knowing more languages allows you to be able to ""translate"" code to the one you chose.

EDIT
More precisely, and in line with how James understood your question, there is no such thing as ""one language for all tasks"". In all different projects, a different language/environment will arise and given your knowledge of different languages, you will be able to pick the one you will want to use or decide to learn a new one if what you know can't be applied.

"
I've taken a lot more than 30 seconds to consider the question. Maybe you should too? --)

I think what @aowonubi meant was 'what language for what project', not 'what language for ALL your projects'. Depending on what it really meant, it is silly or not. Being from Nigeria, english might not be his primary language so maybe give him some space for explanation?
Did you mean how people select one specific language for all their projects or how someone select a language for a specific project? This is not the same...
There are no silly questions, only silly answers...
@GianlucaG and then you're right, the answer should have been different. Explaining why and how to do better.

Look at the question from the positive side.

when you go the gas station, what kind of fuel you use for your vehicle???

It all depends on whether we have enough money to buy the best, or second, with which the car work better.

For the choice of a programming language is at user choice, it's up to you!!!

Best Regards!!!

Coming at the question from another angle, and probably not the one you're looking for, the commercial side, I asked someone who makes these sorts of decisions for large scale projects in his job.

As for commercial projects, there are too many factors to answer with a simple statement. It depends on
- Resources/knowledge within your own organisation
- Customer preferences
- Environments, legacy, current, new
- Required Interfaces (a bit less of a concern in more current systems, as webservices and xml-exchange is fairly common and they are well supported in all languages)
- Requirements (platform, scalability, transactional, etc)
- more items I can't think of at the moment

I believe the main criteria are:

  • Your existing familiarity with the language. If it's an important project, and not just for fun, it may be best to stick with what you know to get the job done
  • The suitability for the project, i.e. for
    web scripting the natural choice would be
    JavaScript because it's built into
    every browser
  • The opportunity for
    learning. I've never done Python
    programming before, so I'm regarding
    this Udacity course as a project to
    get a new language under my belt
  • Cost. A particular language may require investment in new tools, although the majority of languages have free options now
  • Your coding platform. If you code on a Mac or Linux box, you may find certain restrictions on the tools you can use for a particular language (Visual Studio only runs on Windows) and vice versa (XCode, which is used for iPhone development, is only for Macs)

As others have mentioned, there isn't a single programming language suitable for every single task, so it's good to learn a few so you can make an informed judgement for each project. I suggest also learning a modern C-style language such as C# or Java - both of these have free Integrated Development Environments for coding, compiling and debugging your programs. The great thing is that often languages have very similar syntaxes, so after you've learnt one, you already have a head-start on being proficient in the next!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Hi Napolean,

This course is a great place to get started learning how to program and understand what computer science is all about. I would say that if you complete this course with a good understanding of the content then you will probably be around an intermediate on your scale. I'm not sure though that your scale is a good representation of programming competency though. When you discuss programming competency / experience it might be better to think of things as mile markers. For instance, they say it takes 100 hours of programming (actual programming) to start thinking like a programmer. After 500 hours of programming you should start to recognize familiar themes in your code and learn more efficient ways of doing things. I'm sure there are many more mile markers along the way, but they say it take 10000 hours to become an expert at anything. My best advice to you is to program, program, and program some more. The best way to learn is by doing.
You will be experienced enough to tackle learning another language :)

data-item.data-item-item: Obviously this course drew my attention because of my desire to learn to code, but let me take a step back. For any fellow educators enrolled in this course (K-12, postgraduate, etc), I thought a post dedicated to how learning is taking place within this learning community would provide a worthy background discussion to the content of this course. What do we see going on here that can be implemented (or avoided) in settings where students share physical spaces?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: This is not the place for this discussion. These forums are meant to be a question/answer-type place for course-related material.

"

@James... Thank you for your input. Your passion towards this forum confirms my suspicions-- there is something powerful at play here. There are perhaps 100,000+ students in this learning community and you do not share a physical space with any them... Yet look how invested you are. Instructors are providing content that inspires and the learners are shaping the learning environment and expectations and expanding the learning taking place. That's powerful stuff.

The email we just received from Udacity stated discussions about Udacity's approach are welcome.

"
Welcome to Udacity Holliday! We are eager to learn ourselves how we can improve the learning experience. Happy to hear your feedback.

The powerful stuff that's going on here is that the teachers preparing the classes are among the best and brightest on planet earth. And just thinking of that gives you a thrill. Moreover it's free!
Also, this informal environment and the quick interactivity going on in the forum just makes you feel so not alone. I don't remember ever this spirit of collaboration neither in high school nor university.
And collaboration for what? Nothing! Just free, sheer enjoyment in being able to help. I'm in awe...
Educators working in the distance learning worlds know that this approach is powerful and it works!

As @GianlucaG points out, the instructors at Udacity are at the top of their fields. Having world-renowned scientists sharing their knowledge with you directly is not something that most people, including myself, have had a chance to experience before. It's hard to ignore someone who has been instrumental in the development of the first autonomous car, especially when that is the subject of the course they're instructing.

I agree that what we are doing here has amazing potential, but for this potential to be fully realized, some order must be maintained. This is why I go around policing other people's threads. The same thing happens on Stack Overflow and that site is widely considered to be the best Internet question and answer forum for programmers.

You might have noticed that in the previous paragraph I said 'what we are doing'. I feel this is an important distinction to make. Of course we all owe Sebastian Thrun and his colleagues the utmost gratitude, but, with that said, Udacity couldn't happen without the community that we are building here.

In the spirit of full disclosure I'd like to make another statement: what I am doing here is not solely for the good of the community.

Their is a part of me that wants Udacity to succeed because I'm a huge proponent of education startups. The current educational model is broken-- we all know this. There are a few people (Sebastian Thrun, David Stavens, Salmon Khan, etc), however, who are willing to go the extra mile and put in the long hours that are required to completely revolutionize an industry. I have the utmost respect for these people and I hope that one day I'm up to the challenge of joining their ranks.

But there is also a part of me that wants the best for this company for much more selfish reasons. I want to learn from the smartest people in the world. I want to help others open doors to worlds of knowledge they never thought they'd have access to. I want to network with genuinely smart people whose interests run parallel to my own.

These are all things I plan on finding here at Udacity. If I have to upset a few people by telling them that they're not using this forum in the way it was meant to be used, then that's a price I am willing to pay.

"

Please see my response here.

"
+1 for 'me too'. Learn, help, network and new education model.

"

Here's an excerpt from an article on Reuters that has a great way of describing this teaching stategy (in bold): ""[Udacity/Thrun is] at the forefront of a new, more personal way of teaching â€” think of them as having screen-actor skills in a world which has historically rewarded stage-actor skills. When you teach online, youâ€™re teaching in a conversational manner, in a one-on-one space. And it turns out that many students â€” quite possibly most students â€” prefer being taught that way, as opposed to the old-fashioned model where a lecturer stands up in front of a crowded classroom and declaims to many people at once?""

""screen-actor skills in a world which has historically rewarded stage-actor skills""... love it!

"

"

Here are some other discussions taking place in this forum that have value to this post on pedagogy:

  • ""Ethics"": Honor Code
  • ""Intimacy""... comparing the format of CS101 to traditional lectures: link text
  • ""Homework"": link text
"

ya that will work however stylistically speaking you want to put computation and assignments on different lines as to not confuse yourself or anyone trying to read your code

years = 23
days = 365
age = years*days

that makes it a little more clear and just to be a tiny bit more nit picky i would also change the variable names to better describe what they are (i.e.: days could be made into days_of_a_year)

data-item.data-item-item:
I understand this course is one of the first of its' kind. Meaning that it is designed to teach a mass of people for a low amount of money.

But my question is other then learning for personal gain, which to me is highly important, does this course give you legitimate and transferable university credits? Would it also provide a form showing that I was enrolled and participated within the class for so many weeks?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I am not sure that completion of the course will give you transferable university credits (although I highly doubt it will), but you do get a certificate upon successful completion of the course.
The only things you'll take away from this course are knowledge and certificate of completion. You will not receive any sort of official credit for having taken this class.
You can always add it to your resume/job application as an extra knowledge when applying for a computer related job.

The original Artificial Intelligence course allowed you to sit in a proctored exam environment at a couple universities in Germany. If you passed the exams in that environment, you would receive a certificate that would be the equivalent of an AI course at that university, which would potentially be transferable.

So it is my belief that in the future, something like this may happen through Udacity's curriculum. But as it stands, this is just for the thrill of learning!

Wit beyond measure is man's greatest treasure.
In this context, learning is its own reward.

I also wish I could get some university credits - since it really is a university level course. Guess I could always contact some Swedish Universities and ask the professor to give me a test if the CS 101 course matched this one and then get some credits.
If anyone knows any Swedish professors willing to do this - please let us/me know :)
I work with managing and hiring programmers - and if someone showed me a certificate from here I would accept it as proof. Hey - it would take 2 minutes to figure out if they were lying anyways.

data-item.data-item-item:
Normal metric measurements are chunked in thousands, so measurements less than a meter are usually expressed in millimetres(mm), not centimetres (cm)

The main units used as per the ISO standard are e.g. nano, micro, milli, Kilo, Mega, Giga etc.

Yes in some countries people use units like deci (for fluid), and centi (for distance), as these are simple large units to express a whole number in

The speed of light example is not a whole number, and was expressed with 9 digits of precision. This is not a case that the convenience units like centi should be used. 0.299792458 m should be written as 299.792458 mm

If decimal simplification was the aim, it would have been 2.99792458 dm

Another reason to use centimeters is to help us Americans out...about a generation and a half of us, now, have grown up with centimeters and millimeters on our rulers, so we can visualize them more easily than the metric lengths we aren't as used to, like meters. @micromu Yes they often are (probably because of European influence on Chinese manufactures, and perceived marketing to Women), so are other non-precise measurements like dress making. The speed of light with multiple decimal places should be in a fine grained representation like mm. There is a big difference in 29 cm and 299 mm

"

In Europe we definitely use CM to describe things in our daily life. MM are usually used when need of higher precision, and DM when its ""quite rough"".

I work with Chinese factories every day, and the most common measurement is the CM when talking about larger objects and MM when working on smaller object or just being precise.

The thing is, since we Europeans/Asians use the metric system, we really do not care if someone says dm, cm or mm since we do not need to do semi-complex math in our heads (inches being 12 to a foot, being 5280 to a mile etc). 1.99 M is not something we need to sit and calculate to figure out how many CM/DM or MM it is. Cheers

"

"

It all comes down to the precision you need to have. I am from Europe, and I can definitely say that usage of cm beats mm. Not everyone is an engineer, you know. People say ""I am 190 cm tall"", not 1900 mm. Ordinary people are used to visualize things in cm, not mm. Oh, and water consumption is measured in hectoliters. Wine glass is usually 2 deciliters. Buying ham or bacon? Decagrams. People expect various units in various settings.

The fact is, that in the example you are not looking for some ultra precise measurement of how far the light travels in one nanosecond, you are meant to visualize it. And at these lengths, people are used to cm. Should it be the larger distance (large as distance between two cities), people would expect kilometers.

So I think centimeters are perfectly OK.

"

In Canada, where I live, cm are used frequently. We only use mm for very small things. Snowfall is measured in cm, for example, not mm, but rainfall is measured in mm. We use cm about as frequently as Americans use inches.

What's a Programming Language?
Are Programming Languages Written by Computers?

There are at least three threads in which there's significant discussion about the Quiz in Unit 1.5 (nugget 4004/3003):
What is a programming Language?
in which all of the following answers are correct.

  • a language designed to be executed by computers
  • a language designed for describing programs
  • a language designed to be written by humans, and executed by computers
  • a language designed to be read by humans, and written by computers
  • a language deisgned to be read and written by humans, and executed by computers

Given this, the Glossary entry for ""Programming language"" is significantly lacking and should be revised:


Programming language
A language designed to be read and written by humans, and executed by computers.

I would revise it, but alas the Glossary is provided as a pdf and as such is not editable.

Therefore, I humbly request: a class wiki.
--Dan

Following Unit 1 about links extraction, I would like to know a bit about Relative and Absolute links and how they are differently (and correctly) handled in the extraction process in a WebCrawler.

An Absolute link has a fully url like this:

<--a href=""http://www.udacity.com"">--The best education platform in 21st Century<--/a>--

A Relative link takes in account where the webpage is, like this (supposing your browser is displaying Udacity home page):

<--a href=""/overview/Course/cs101"">--Build a Search Engine <--/a>--

"

That's a good question! I believe this has something to do with how Google's PageRank algorithm works. Part of a site's page rank is based on how many times the page is linked to on other websites and the PageRanks of those sites.

For example, say there were two sites linking to the Udacity home page, namely Watching Grass Grow and The New York Times. The link from The New York Times is considered to be more important than the link from Watching Grass Grow and will have more impact on Udacity's PageRank.

So yes, Google works, in part, by seeing what sites link to a particular page!

"

"

I answered this one in the video office hours (which should be posted soon), but will add a bit more here. People often get into ""religious"" arguments about the best programming language, but there's no real need for this. The most important thing for an introductory CS course is to use a simple language so students can focus on learning the important concepts instead of complex language syntax. One can make very good arguments for using either Python (simple and elegant language), Scheme (simplest grammar and semantics of any candidate), or Smalltalk (purest programming model). In other intro CS courses I have taught, I have often used Scheme, and its definitely a great choice for learning to think about computing in the right way and being able to do everything from a very simple grammar. But, most students find the Python grammar more natural and easier to understand, and it is also the case that a Python program to do something can usually be significantly shorter than a Scheme program for the same thing. I like Ruby a lot, but don't think its a great first choice for a language since there are so many quirky and unexpected things in Ruby, and so many different ways to do everything which makes it harder to understand other programmer's Ruby code. Java and C++ are horrendously complicated languages that have their place in industrial software development, but make doing simple things so difficult that they are appalling choices for intro CS courses and their prevalence has done our community a great deal of damage. As an example, the first program students typically learn in an intro CS course using Java is to print out ""Hello Word"" (which is one line in Python, Scheme, etc.). In Java, just printing out ""Hello Word"" requires at least 10 different syntactic elements, and involves many things students won't fully understand even after taking several years of Java programming courses.

"

Some of the things in Python are the way they are because of good reasons and long traditions (like starting counting from 0, which is done in essentially all programming languages, and you will see as the course goes on, makes most code easier to write and understand than if indexes started from 1)-- other decisions are fairly arbitrary, like find returning -1 when the target string is not found. It is probably the best choice, but another reasonable possibility would be to produce an error (for our use in cs101, its good that it just returns -1 since we don't have to cover how to handle errors to use it, but for more robust programs one could argue it would be better if it produced an error).

There are lots of documents that discuss design decisions in Python. An amusing overview is Tim Peters' The Zen of Python.

We won't be able to offer direct feedback on the homework answers, other than if your code works correctly. Peter will be providing discussions about the answers, though, so you'll be able to see what we think are good answers. Of course, these are not the only good ways to answer the questions, and it is likely that some of you will come up with better answers that ours! After we have posted the homework answers, I would encourage you to post your answers that are interestingly different or better than the solutions in the forums for feedback (just please don't post any answers until after the homework deadline, so everyone has their own chance to solve the problems).

These are subjective decisions, and there is often a tradeoff between having shorter code and having longer, but easier to understand code. Shorter is better than longer, but making code easy to read and understand (and hence, most likely to be correct!) is the most important thing. There are often clever ways to make the code shorter, but it is also easy to make mistakes and harder to find them, if too much is combined into one complicated line, rather than being broken into a few simpler steps.

We answer this one in the recorded office hours, but I'll expand here. Figuring out is a given webpage contains malicious content is a very challenging and interesting problem which many people are working on doing better. For the cs101 course, we are focused on keeping things as simple as possible so everyone can understand the core behavior of a search engine, and more importantly, learn the main computing concepts we will cover along the way. We do encourage ambitious students to go beyond this, and figure out creative ways to improve the search engine such as adding safety indicators, but there are tons of other interesting possible extensions that I hope some of our students will explore.

"

Don't have much time for ""framing"" these days, but you are welcome to reproduce and adapt this as you see fit.

"

The basic reason that most languages use 0-based indexing is that the variable name represents a memory address where the values will be stored. In an array, the indices are offsets from that address. So the first index gives you x+0: the exact address. (There is also multiplication involved, to accommodate different element sizes, and different CPUs.)

"

"

""Corpus"" means a collection of texts. In this case, it means a collection of pages that are posted on the Web. ""Good"" means useful, and ""better"" means more useful -- for whatever types of information or services you want your search engine to provide. If you want to attempt a general purpose search engine like Google, it would probably be a good idea to start with Wikipedia, or some subset of Wikipedia pages.

"
Additionally having a 0-based index makes it easier to use module (%) math to loop back around to the beginning of a loop without having to add additional math.

Why is -1 the index of the last character of a string, as in s[:-1]?
Doesn't -1 come before zero when counting positions from left to right? It seems to me that -1 would be the index of character before the first one, which is zero. Since this has no meaning in relation to a string, I would expect an error. However, this isn't what happens.

When we're asked to find the second occurrence of a string within a string, we have to already know where the first occurrence is. How do you do this find operation for subsequent occurrences without knowing the position of preceding occurrences? Do you use nested finds? That seems messy. Or, do you just assign variables that reflect first, second, and so on occurrences? The variables get assigned as they fall in a sequence of steps (or as you run the sequence)?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I am not sure, which option you are speaking about, thus here is explanation for all of them:

  • s[i:].find(t)

Let's have s='udacity', t='city', i=3. Then:

  • s.find(t, i) ->-- 'udacity'.find('city', 3) ->-- 3

Note that find returns position of the searched for string from the beginning of the searched string, not from the position you were searching from, i.e. result is 3, not 0.

  • s[i:].find(t) ->-- 'city'.find('city') ->-- 0

String 'city' was found, but since the searched string was modified (first three characters were cut off), the searched for string was found on position 0, which is not equal to 3 returned by s.find(t, i). (Is this the place you are referring to? If it is the case, why 2?)

  • s.find(t)[:i]

This is an error, since s.find(t) is number, which can not be indexed.

  • s[i:].find(t) + i

Works for s='udacity', t='city', i=3, but does not work e.g. for s='udacity', t='dog', i=3:

  • s.find(t, i) ->-- 'udacity'.find('dog', 3) ->-- -1

Returns -1, because string 'dog' was not found.

  • s[i:].find(t) + i ->-- 'udacity'.find('dog') + 1 ->-- -1 + 3 ->-- 2

Find itself returns -1 as well, because string 'dog' was not found, but then i (number 3) is added, which makes final result 2 instead of -1.

  • s[i:].find(t[i:])

This is obviously wrong. E.g. let's have s='udacity', t='Xity', i=3. Then:

  • s.find(t, i) ->-- 'udacity'.find('Xity', 3) ->-- -1

  • s[i:].find(t[i:]) ->-- 'city'.find('y') ->-- 3
Well done.

Ok ok.! Actually I was thinking find(t) as an alone letter t.But in the question it represents to the whole string t='city' which is city in first option.! Its correct. But if one consider it as an alone letter t in the string 'city' then the position will be 2. Well thanks for the explanation.! :)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I haven't seen the last part of the assignment yet, but generally anything <-- 3.50 rounds to 3 and anything >--= 3.5 rounds to 4. At least this is what I've always been taught.
It is better to look at the second digit after the decimal (the one following 5). Leads to a more sound answer.
Good question. 3.5 should go to 4.

The only concepts demonstrated in class have been variable assignment, string indexing, string find()'ing, and new in this question str().

AFAIK decisional control structures, loops, methods for converting strings back into numbers, etc. have not been discussed, and I believe at least one of these is required to complete the question (I wont mention specifics for fear of giving the question away).
It is possible to solve, i.e. using mathematics. You have to do basic arithmetic since we've had the basic operations it is solvable without using for loops and if conditions.

The solution was mind bogglingly simple, once I stopped thinking too hard.

I have previous programming experience, (although I'm rusty, and python is new to me) and my first attempt was quick and easy, and gave me the right answer, using a function available in every programming language.

I was finished with my homework, and started reading the forums, and I saw the post by @PeterUdacity stating ""you actually can solve this question using what has been shown in lecture"" and I thought.. hmmm really?

Thanks for making me think (too hard) for the solution. I think it would have been easier, had I not already had the answer in my head the moment I read the question. Coming up with the solution with ONLY the info we've been provided (not using round(), if statements, while statements, etc. ) took more thought than it should have.

Don't over-think it.

""You must unlearn what you have learned."" - Yoda

"

I spoke quickly earlier, this problem was trickier than I originally felt. I realized that I was in error earlier as I too had used something not yet shown.
Happy to say that I found a solution using only what we have been shown after knocking it around the hamster cage a bit. My solution took 20 lines though...but uses nothing outside of the unit and str()

Whoo-hoo!!! Great question!! I really hope speculation about being able to resubmit until satisfied is true. Either way I feel good, but I will feel better if my last submission is the one to be graded.

I'm trying to state this vaguely enough to be a nudge rather than a spoiler but I'll understand if someone thinks it's too much.

The trick is to NOT try to program the rounding process we learned in grade school. Instead, look at the next integer up as a finish line, and do something to the number you start with, so that numbers which round up will cross the finish line, but numbers which round down will not.
Try scanning through the unit notes in supplemental materials. That's how I found everything we 'know' from the course already.
I am absolutely and completely stuck. I've been thinking about it for about 4 hours and I am no closer to the answer.

I posted a tip before but it either got eaten, or deleted for being over the line into spoilersville. To try to put it more vaguely just in case...the trick is to do something to the number you start with, so that if it would round down, the left side of the decimal point doesn't change, but if it would round up, it does.

That's pretty much giving the answer away.

Some say this can be done in 1 line of code, and they are right. However converting a number to a string is pretty inefficient and should be avoided performing twice if possible.

"

@Eric Matt

The one line solution involves doing the string conversion twice, which is pretty inefficient in my book.

Yeah. This is one of those that, once you think of the solution, you'll kick yourself. I spent a good hour before it clicked. I'm pretty sure you're overthinking it.

OK try this. Make a list of everything you can do to a number (pick a digit, multiply, etc.) and try doing those things to numbers that are on either side of the round up/round down barrier. Trying to write a program for the human way to round a number is a blind alley, for purposes of this assignment.

If I can chime in ... it's not a competition ... and no Bell curves ... sharing is cooperative problem solving and even if someone gives ""too much"" one time there are opportunities to ""get it"" later. And congrats to all of you who ""get it!""

"

Are you responsible on how people learn? Obviously, many community members are having problems with this question. The problems vary from knowing a little math (adding the right number) to python programming. The community consists of many types of users... noobies being one. They come here for help. Tips, spoilers, or whatever... its the users choice, and Udacity's choice to remove Tips, spoliers, or whatever. People learn differently. There is no monopoloy on how people should 'REALLY' learn.

@dedos, the only problem is that posting answers is against the TOS. Point 3 states that:

(students) will not share content or solutions to homework assignments or exams

"

"

@Fuzzmz, ... and Udacity will take care of delineating where the line is drawn. It appears that 'content' and 'solutions' vary in definintion as this thread shows.

"
Ahhhhh......the slightly convoluted way (programming the rounding process) by which I attained the answer now seems pretty dumb. Although, I did manage without conditionals.

"

At the risk of repeating myself, ""it can be done"" is not a helpful answer when someone is stuck. If we weren't supposed to discuss useful approaches to problems, these forums wouldn't be all that useful.

"

"

The TOS would probably have something to say about posting a complete solution, but I still think discussing approaches would be OK. As stated in the course FAQ, ""For the homeworks, you may discuss the questions with other students in the on-line forums and in-person study groups, but everything you submit should be your own work.""

"

"

But to quote from a reply @PeterUdacity made when I commented that I wasn't sure how much help was appropriate:

""Try to do your best to clarify the problem, but avoid talking about how you would answer it. I know this is vague. I'll talk it over with Professor Evans later.""

Also, keep in mind that they have said in multiple places with respect to the last homework question that they do not expect us all to be able to do it. They will post an answer and explanation, and we can all discuss and re-explain all we want, once the deadline has passed.

I know it's a really hard line to draw, and very frustrating not to be able to help. But I think a lot of the discussion of this problem has gone well beyond the ""clarify the problem"" and into the ""how you would answer it"" territory.

(as an aside, and a defense of @cbandarrinha, when this answer was first posted there were a couple links, including one in this thread, to an actual solution hosted at pastebin. They've since been removed. But that seemed clearly over the line.)

edit to add: from my perspective, when I was stuck because I was convinced that I needed either conditionals or int(), posts that said ""it's possible to do it without either of those things"" were an absolutely perfect hint. They reassured me that continuing to think about it wasn't a total waste of effort, but still forced me to come up with the solution on my own. And with several days before the homework is due!

"

I think there are even slightly different ways of thinking of this problem and achieving the rounding without using things not taught in class yet. It's more challenging to restrict oneself to not to use the round function or if statements. After the submission deadline the different answers should be discussed in one place in the forum - I'm not sure if it was appropriate as answers to this question or to start a new question Â»Solutions to HW 1 #9Â« then and discuss different solutions there?

"

@Lisa... A user makes an active choice to 'click' on a link which they know they can get the answer. If you are a student that has already solved the problem then it's good to compare your answers with others. If you are a student that is stuck, doesn't care or is fed up of waiting, the choice to click on the link is still yours and you'll learn something (hopefully).

This is a very vague/grey area as @PeterUdacity has pointed out. If they define the rules to strictly they would have to police the site constantly looking 'rule violators'. If they define the rules to vaguely... well that's why we're here.

Some of us think that some users are sharing too much information and others are grateful for the posts. We all approach and solve problems very differently. @Lisa has great self-motivation to continue moving on and pushing forward after being reassured... others don't have that or haven't developed it yet. Either way I think what @Avrila Klaus has done is more beneficial than delimiting.

If many feel that these types of posts are sharing 'too' much information then perhaps a special tag that is announced with the question that states: 'Some users feel that TOO much information is being shared about solving the problem in this thread... Enter at your own Learn-isk'. The announcement would deter those self-motivated users who do not want too much information in solving the problem (active choice). The announcement would also bring in those users having the most difficulty.

The choice is and always will be yours.

a one line answer isnt necessarily the best answer.
I submitted a five line answer with comments explaining what each line does. This makes it easier for other programmers to understand - something that should not be forgotten about in the real world where other programmers will be updating your code.

Anyway Ive continued working on the problem and Ive got it down to one line.
did your second line include the print command - if so maybe you can incorporate that into your first line ???
or did you do the arithmetic on a seperate line - this also can be incorporated .

For those who are congratulating themselves on the brevity of their answers, keep in mind that while fewer lines of code may be more efficient, it might also be more prone to error. Variables are a great way to store information in a way that clearly describes what the code is doing. Use them! They will also have the effect of greatly reducing head-scratching later on when you revisit/edit your code and are left attempting to figure out what in the world your highly efficient print statement is doing.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

To solve this problem as quickly as possible, we need more information about the problem. If you're experiencing this issue then please take a few seconds to fill out this form.

  1. Browser Version
  2. Flash Version
  3. Plugins Installed
  4. Operating Systems
  5. Javascript Console Dump

I'll take a little bit of time to edit this with more information on how to do each of these things.

Browser Version



Google Chrome: Click the Wrench icon beside the URL bar and select 'About Google Chrome'. The browser version will be under the words 'Google Chrome'.

Flash Version



Google Chrome: Type 'about:plugins' into the URL bar and search for 'Flash - Version:'.

Plugins Installed



Google Chrome: Type 'about:plugins' into the URL bar and provide the name and version number of each plugin.

Operating System



Ubuntu: Open a terminal and type cat /etc/lsb-release. What's the value of DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION?

Javascript Console Dump



Google Chrome: Attempt the load the 'Course Contents' page. The error should be generated. After closing the alert box, press CTRL+Shift+J, bringing up the Google Chrome Debugger. Open the console by clicking button on the bottom tool bar (second from the left, looks like an arrow and three horizontal lines). There should be some red text in the console. Copy this text.

Open a new tab and head over to Pastebin. Past the text you copied here and link to it in your response. Make sure you format this link correctly or your entire post will be blank.

"

I had the described problem with Firefox 10.0.2 on a fully patched Windows XP, even after logging out, deleting all Flash cookies, disabling all add-ons and clearing the cache. (The next thing I tried was a complete uninstallation and reinstallation of the Flash plugin, but when I returned from that, the site had already been fixed.)

Even without that bug the following problem seems relatively serious:

With Firefox + FlashBlock, the course content page hangs in the ""loading"" stage unless youtube[DOT]com is whitelisted in the FlashBlock options. This should be explained somewhere.

(Also, this comment came up totally white at first due to a feature described in a question ""Why do comments come up totally blank?"" and also several earlier ones. Apparently these questions are being closed aggressively, with the result that I had to go throuh 7 pages of questions until I finally found a relevant question that also had a relevant answer rather than just completely unhelpful pointing at the search function. How does one search for such a bug without knowing what words the original reporter(s) used to describe it?)

Problem only occurs when trying to submit my result of Unit2-HW#6
When I go back, my content is there, even from another browser (so not in local cache). The marker stays as a yellow dot, no green check mark. It's been like this since I first tried, around 23h15 EST on tuesday. When I have a problem like this, it usually resolves itself after a couple of retries.

In clear, I think my data is safe, but as others could experience such, I decided to post about it.

  • Browser : Chromium - v17.0.963.46
  • Flash Version: 11.1 r102
  • Plugins Installed
  • Remoting Viewer, Native Client
  • Flash - Version: 11.1 r102
  • Java - Version: 1.6.0_27
  • Google Talk Plugin Version: 2.2.2.0
  • Operating System : ArchLinux vN/A
  • Javascript Console Dump

-IMPORTANT EDIT

If ""Something bad happened"" pops up, although your work is saved on the server, it has NOT been submitted to the grading system! If this happen, chances are your code do not work with the in-house queries the servers makes before accepting the submission (e.g.: infinite loop). If you try again and it works, maybe it's the communication with the server, but if it never works, broaden your tests with your code (query with empty string, None, int, ...) until you find a bug and fix it.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
The way we give out assignments is such that not every student is expected to correctly solve every problem. We want to challenge everyone! We label the more difficult questions using gold stars so that you shouldn't be discouraged if you don't solve it. The more gold stars the harder the problem is. When I took Dave's theory class, I think he made a 100-year open problem a dozen or so gold stars.

I'll update the question below the video to have this information as soon as I get my admin account fixed.

We hope you enjoy the assignment!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Thanks a lot Peter!!!
thanks for the info peter. :)

Hi, Peter.
I found the first homework very well balanced.

How comes that one feel so at home in here? I am looking forward to watch Unit 2!

Many thanks from Tenerife (Canary Islands)

Javier Ruiz
Hi Peter, it's a great idea....thank you!!
Two stars question is really interesting! I have some programming skills, and it takes about 40 minutes to find correct solution. Thank you!

The assignment is very well balanced and covers Unit 1 completely and adds some twists too....
which is really interesting.....:D
I really enjoyed the last question in the homework, it gave me the high of a lightbulb moment!
Have you considered setting up a fast track of sorts? That way, people who are already familiar with the basics of computer science/programming/python will be able to utilize their time better
Was it a 100-year-old unsolved problem? --)

"

@Dave Ray, from wiki, ""In science and mathematics, an open problem or an open question is a known problem that can be accurately stated, and has not yet been solved""

"

Can you enroll in both classes?
Yes! Keep in mind CS101 is intended for students with no previous programming background, while CS373 assumes students have prior programming experience.

Are we still talking about the gold star problems? It has been talked about, but just because you can't solve a problem doesn't mean it's not worth looking at or attempting.

If we are talking about the course in general, this is an introductory course. For those with more experience CS 373 is recommended.

data-item.data-item-item:
I think the statement of the problem in the quiz is a little bit ambiguous. Here is why.

The question asked to show the equivalent statement, not the one that would produce the exact same result in all cases. So in my opinion answer 3 can be considered correct because it is equivalent. And it is equivalent in the sense that you would have to check that the result is greater than or equal to i to find out whether the search was successful or not.

Answer 1 may be considered equivalent or not, depending on whether the position in the original string is what you're primarily looking for. If that's what you want, then it's not equivalent because you have to do additional biasing to the result (adding i). If you just wanted to know whether the original string s contained substring t, then it's also equivalent.

Anybody agrees with me?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

The definition of ""equivalent statement"" is exactly ""would produce the exact same result in all cases"". At least in this class, as clearly explained in the quiz Understanding Selection.

In that quiz, the question was:

For any string ""s"", which of these is always equivalent to ""s""

And he explains the question saying:

So, your goal is to check all of the expressions here that have the same exact value as ""s"", no matter what string ""s"" is initially

Therefore, in the next quizzes and homeworks, consider that ""equivalent"" is equal to ""always has (or produce, or result) the same values, no matter what else has or happens"".

"

"

The ""Finding With Numbers"" quiz presents the question:

For any variables s and t that are strings, and i that is a number:   s = '<--any string>--'   t = '<--any string>--'   i = <--any number>-- which of these are equivalent to s.find(t,i):

And offers these possible answers:

1)  s[i:].find(t) 2)  s.find(t)[:i] 3)  s[i:].find(t)+i 4)  s[i:].find(t[i:])

This quiz might be seen as confusing because, in the question, variables s and t are given with single quotes (in other words, as equivalent to the literal string '<--any string>--') while variable i is clearly not presented as a specific value.

It would have been less confusing to have the presented values of variables s and t not be within quotes at all.

(Note that the question for this quiz is not ""...which of these is always equivalent to..."")

"

The only possible answer is 1), given normal parameters, but under ALL condition none are

When you click done, it marks 1) as wrong, as highlights 2), 3), and 4) in green as correct? A bug!

"

I am sorry, not convincing enough. One cannot state that ""equivalent"" means ""returns same exact value"" just because in the other quiz they had a definition, sort of. I may have missed or skimmed through that other quiz after all.

I do not want them to mark answers that are currently marked wrong as correct. All I want is for them to specify the statements somewhat more unambiguously. For this particular quiz they could state that they expected the return value to be exactly the same in all cases, not just that the functionality is equivalent (as I thought). I mean, is it that hard?

"
I think we aren't supposed to give or suggest specific answers, but I might be wrong.

"

Hmmm. To the dude who now proclaims not to be a noob at programming but just Py. Please note.

The professor was correct when he defined s = '<--any string>--' in this manner because in all programming languages that i know of the ONLY way to indicate to the compiler that anything is a string is to enclose it in quotes, either 'single' or ""double""

which is why he said ""which of these are equivalent to s.find(t,i)""
AND NOT
""which of these are equivalent to s.find(""t"",i)"" as that would be the
letter ""t"" or actually the string consisting of the letter ""t"" only

AND this is also why he had to write
""s = '<--any string>--'"" which means ---anything between these two quotes
IF he had written
s = any string -- this would have meant -- the variable ""any string"" which is not a correct variable according to the syntax of Py anyway

So the only possible way to describe it is as he has

"

"

Saying ""the functionality is equivalent"" is ambiguous, because we don't know what you mean by ""functionality"": does it mean finding the index from where the match occurs in the string? does it mean determining whether or not there is a match?

Two expressions are said to be equivalent if, for each possible value of the variables involved in them, they both produce the same result

By that definition:

''[0:].find('a')+1 which evaluates 0 cannot be equivalent to ''.find('a', 1) which evaluates to -1. So case 3 cannot be a correct answer.

But the supposedly right answer (case 1), is also wrong because:

'wrong'[2:].find('o') evaluates to 0 while 'wrong'.find('o', 2) evaluates to 2

"

"

@Iurii As soon as you have to do extra processing beyond what is offered in the answer then it is no longer equivalent. So in your example where you say, ""And it is equivalent in the sense that you would have to check that the result is greater than or equal to i to find out whether the search was successful or not."" is extra processing needed beyond the given answer of ""s[i:].find(t) + i"" in order to make it equivalent. The same goes for your second example.

"

@nnutter I am sorry, but why '>-- -1' or '!= -1' is not extra processing, but '>--= i' suddenly is? And what if all you wanted was to find out whether the string contains some sub-sequence starting from some position (i.e. you did not care about the index in the string at all)?

All I would like to see is better definitions of problems' statements. I did not intend to start flames about 'what if we'd do this or that'. So better written definitions -- less reasons to start pointless discussions.

"

@Iurii What usually, in computer science, we mean by ""equivalent"" is that: ""same result"", no matter how it's processed/calculated/read/written/executed/done.

If you are new to compute science (the target audience of this course), then you are excused for not knowing it (though you're not excused for jumping quizzes: it's not valid as an excuse for not learning something from past quizzes).

If you are not novice to the subject, i'm sorry, i won't try to convince you anymore that you are wrong: every computer scientist student knows what ""equivalent"" means in questions like that. Just use Ockham's razor.

There's no ambiguosity on the question.

"

"

@Kleiner First things first. I did not jump quizzes. But still saying something like ""that was stated in the definition of another quiz so you're expected to know it now"" is wrong. Such attitude is what making programming (and other subjects) so hard to learn, don't you see? Humans are not machines and they tend to forget, some have hard time concentrating all the time and easily get tired so they could easily overlook the definition in the previous question.

Also I am not 'new'. In fact, I've had my own experience teaching programming to children (teenagers). And I know very well that all people are different. Some (like you) think that 'equivalent' means 'same', others do not. I've heard of no such convention you're talking about though. Well, of course now they will all know what 'equivalent' means in questions like that, but what about the questions of some other type then? If you think there is already no ambiguosity in the questions, how hard is it to write question statements (of any type) even less ambiguous?

"

You're not wrong in preferring that method-- no one is. However, I still feel it would be less-confusing to say --- and this is just my preference --- s = <-- any string >-- ... with spaces not mattering ...then the programmer would know that the variable assignment needed action, on their part, before moving on.

data-item.data-item-item:
Just to be sure:

The input of the program (var x) is always a positive decimal number.

Eg:

  • 3.14 -->-- 3
  • 6.5 -->-- 7
  • 123.98 -->-- 124
  • 2.0 -->-- 2

but not integers such as:

  • 2
  • 7678

(meaning that I will always find the decimal point)

You're right, just remember that spaces are not allowed (I'm sure you do remember that and what you've typed is just for more readability:) and also there could be a case like "" 27. "", which is also decimal, in fact.

print x

data-item.data-item-item:
I'm curious if the course will have information about preventing some of the basic gaming by web site owners/designers to increase their rankings?

Thanks,
MBF2234

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Though I think that is generally dependent on the search engine in question and comes up more naturally in a natural language processing course. However, this course should teach us sufficient amounts to work with other toolkits available for python.
Its all going to come down to how you decide to rank your results. It looks like they start to cover that in week 6, but you could spend years trying to perfect your algorithm.

This is an interesting topic and one which major search engines spend a lot of time on. After all, the quality of their results is of paramount importance. Google has a section for website owners called Google Webmaster Tools where you can get guidance on this sort of thing and by association see what Google regard as 'gaming' or manipulating search results. Give the 'Webmaster Guidelines' page a go for a start (unfortunately, the forum isn't letting me post a direct link for some reason).

I hope we cover some of the more obvious techniques, such as a site which is nothing but links to other affiliated sites, but it's fascinating just to research this and try to out-think the bad guys yourself :)

"

Link for ya :) Google Webmaster Tools

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: From the video: the str() function converts an integer into a string. ie say the x variable holds 3.14159 as an integer value, the str(x) would convert it into a string, after that you can fiddle around with that string using the string indexing/selection techniques learned previously.

"

@Soumyadeep i think you just solved it for everyone me included :( i was stuck in the last question gave up for a few mins to relax and couldnt log back (something bad happened msg ) on now i'll feel i cheated...

"
I am not sure if Soumyadeep really gave the answer away. In my opinion this doesn't work for a value >--= .5 ... but maybe i am wrong. I'm kinda stuck on this one too right now.
Actually Soumya has only given a start to the question but end u only have to think... I have already done that but I am stuck after that part.. :P
True, this is only a part of the answer...

"

There are different types of variables.
For example:

  • string - ""asdfhui124678"" - can
    contain anything
  • integer - 127 - can only be a number
    without decimal places
  • float - 1345.1337 - Can be a number
    with or without decimal places aka
    floating point number

Basically all the operation we learned so far, substring, find etc all operate on strings! But the given number is a float, so I think you can neither use find or substring as we learned so far. But when you can convert the float to a string, you can use all the functions.

So by

number = 123.23 number_as_string = str(number)

you have a variable number_as_string which you can use as basis for find etc.

"

"

@Alex - you'll need more than the str() and find() functions to solve the homework! If you just use them to chop off the fractional part of the number, your answer won't be correct if the number needs to be rounded up instead of down.

"

"

I found a way to do it with no ""if"" or ""%"" it was surprisingly easy. :)

"

Here's a tutorial that explains all of the built in data types.

You can find more by just Googling it.

str() is a function. You can find more about this by googling for python str() function

Are we supposed to finish all of Unit 1 completely before doing the Homework assignments? Cause the assignment you're talking about, I did it and I have never learned anything about recognizing a link in a sourcecode or webpage.. I'm not finished the Unit yet and I'm finding most of the Homework assignments impossible. Will I get a failing grade if I get too many questions wrong?

The way the questions are designed, personally, I know I will fail this class, so I'm thinking of dropping out even though I really really really want to finish it to learn the stuff.. The Homework assignments are way too difficult for me.. The questions in general are too difficult, they are multiple choice questions, but they are all trick questions, there are choices that are types of examples that weren't covered in the videos, so you have to use induction to solve them (you can't use old knowledge, you have to use old knowledge to induce new knowledge).

I have a learning style that makes it impossible for me to induce like that and solve problems.. It's actually a learning disability.. So am I destined to fail this effing class? It's pissing me off, I don't like being set up to fail.. I want to succeed, my sense of personal worth is involved, if I fail, I will be depressed. And the way the questions and assignments are structured, it's designed so I fail, me at least, I'm not talking about anyone else.

It's really upsetting me. @PeterUdacity can you help me?

"

"

I'd love to help out. So what I recommend doing is whenever you have a question, ask it on this forum. There's a lot of great students here that are willing to help you out, including myself. Make sure to ask specific questions so that you can get good answers. Try not to worry too much about your grade-- you are here to learn and have fun doing it!

A web page is just text with some annotations. The browser reads this text to display the web you are used to seeing on the Internet. For a quick look, right click to the side of this page and choose view source. That's what our servers send to your computer. From there your browser figures out where to put the text and what colors to make everything. It's kind of cool!

Links are specified with the predefined syntax in HTML (the language that web pages are specified in).

Here's a link to udacity.com that would say click here to learn:

<--a href=""http://www.udacity.com"">--Click here to learn!<--/a>--

That renders on your page like this:

Click here to learn!

To describe what all that means, the <-->-- are used to specify a ""tag"" (an annotation). The <--a>-- tells the browser that you want to put a link there. The ""href"" stands for ""hyperlink reference"", which just means the destination of the link. So href=""http://www.udacity.com"" just says that this link goes to Udacity's page. And what is in between the <--a>-- and <--/a>-- is what's displayed.

The goal of the problem is to look at the HTML that's below the question and pick out the links on the page. So if the link I showed above was on the page, you would look for the <--a href="" and see that there will be a link that points to Udacity's webpage.

"

"

What I couldn't figure out was whether the URI in the XML Namespace counts as a web page.. or a hyperlink or whatnot.. That's what I call a trick question, cause a beginner like me, I can't tell the difference yet between a url and a uri..

Example:

<--head>--
<--title>--Title of the document<--/title>--
<--/head>--

<--body>--
The content of the document......
<--/body>--

<--/html>--

"

Where are the gold stars? I figured that was the case. I don't like not being able to answer things, I'm getting the feeling I'm not the only one. :)

(Edit: Is the gold star the little gold circle in the Unit 1 and Homework 1 list? Where some sections have green checkmarks and some have yellow dots? So the Strings Homework assignment is meant to be difficult?)

@antiface, your comment disappeared because most likely you used links or html code in it. To use links/html in a comment surround them with a ` character on each side.

If you want to include clickable links, then you need to type them as [text](http://url.com)

The last problem in Homework 1 has a gold star. Not being able to answer things is frustrating, but challenging problems are valuable because you can get a lot out of them without even solving them correctly! Some of my favorite problems I've ever had the opportunity to do were ones I didn't get right.

You're absolutely right, Peter, now that I think of it. I did a good thing by asking questions in the forum. Now that I have a much better perspective - a better perspective on programming in Python in general, as well as a better perspective on how statements work and the grammar too - I kind of find it funny how frustrated I got, and over a simple problem!! Geeze, it's as though I thought it would be easy, I would just fly through the course and never encounter any problems.. It's been 15 years since I've taken any courses.. It's only normal that I couldn't get back into it at full speed after a 15 year hiatus.. I feel great now, though, looking forward to the next Unit! Thanks everyone! :)

data-item.data-item-item: I'm making a group for old Commodore 64 users. Commodore PET users need not apply, Commodore VIC-20 users need not apply, Commodore Amiga users need not apply, and of course it goes without saying that Apple/Atari users need not apply. I won't even mention TI 99/4A people, TRS-80 people or Colecovision people.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Well, I thought it was funny (though perhaps you didn't mean it as a joke --).

"

@tworivers, thanks! I think the problem is that people think the group I'm proposing is insufficiently exclusive. They probably would have been happier with say a group like ""Commodore 64 users who then switched to Amiga and then switched to Linux""

"

My wife gives me a hard time because I still have my C-64, and the datasette that came with it... and the wonderfully noisy 1541 (which is currently connected to my Windows computer so I can play all my old stuff with a C-64 emulator), and she doesn't understand how awesome it is!

What?! She doesn't understand how awesome it is?! How could anyone not?! It's like not recognizing the awesomeness of a rollercoaster! Or of lunar colonies!

Unfortunately, I don't have my C64 anymore, I'm a flawed member of my own community. But, I do carry it's soul with me, in the form of an android C-64 emulator, and Frodo on all my desktops!

"

Not having the original equipment isn't as important as still feeling that little twinge of joy whenever someone mentions the old beige box.

To my wife's credit she has certainly put up with a lot of my geek tendancies, even to the point of buying my favorite t-shirt from think geek that simply says ""I adore my C-64""

"

data-item.data-item-item:
I don't get the checkboxes and text fields in the homework videos. The video just ends without giving me any input fields to answer the question. I tried Chrome and Firefox. Does anyone have an idea what the problem could be?

EDIT: by the way: I have the same problem with the homework of the self driving car course

David explains that in order to get an accurate result( ie not truncated to an integer) you must express one of the numbers in the formula as a decimal.

I've also noticed IF i do not convert the values to their decimal equivalent but do the calculation by referring to the values by their variable name ie

print speed_of_light * meter * nanosecond

..it returns 29.9792458.

Q: What exactly is going on here?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
When you write it like this

print speed_of_light * meter *
nanosecond

then, AFAIR, nanosecond variable is defined as 1.0/100000000 in the code to this example so the whole arithmetic operation is also converted to decimal numbers as stated by David.

It happens because Python promotes types of numbers from simpliest to more advanced and by that I mean integers are subset of decimals numbers that's why they are promoted.

Editing is bad. :P

Anyway you got the 0 because correct answer is a fraction less than one. Think about what you get if you do 12/5. You can't get integer number, closest integer number will be 2 but correct answer is 2.4

And while we are here - read about MODULO operator-- it's quite handy and it embraces this whole concept.
Thanks astronaut! That explains it perfectly :)

"

Astronaut is absolutely correct here.

Here is something interesting that happend while playing with their python interpreter.
I changed nanosecond = 1.0 /1000000000 to nanosecond = 1/1000000000 and used
print speed_of_light * meter * nanosecond and got ""0""

Can someone please try this too?

"
Quibit: Read my edited post, now it explains that too.
I guess it is because it converted to an integer so nanosecond turned out to be 0.
