data-item.data-item-item:
In the last CS101 course homework, what about if the variable 'x' holds the value 3.50000 ? It should be turned into 3 or 4 ? Since these two number have the same 0.5 numerical distance to the previous 'x' value ?

(English is not my native language, therefore I will make some mistakes, sorry! )

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

4
You may also want to check on WolframAlpha

"

0,1,2,3,4 round down
5,6,7,8,9 round up

so the answer would be 4

"

That's a fair question. It depends on the tie-breaking rule chosen for the particular problem. Since the homework question is not specifying which rule should apply, it's fair to say there's ambiguity and no solution is completely correct.

I'd say a professor should clarify this problem.

"
Standard practice (in the US at least) would say that .5 rounds up. Without further comment from someone official, that would be the safe assumption.

"

The answer given by @drashy is a correct answer.

When a number, fraction, etc is positive you rounded to the next integer (Number), in this case 3.5 is rounded to 4 (Round half up), and when the number, fraction, etc is negative you rounded to previos integer (number)..

For example -3.5 is rounded to 3 (Round half down)

Best regards!!!

"

It may be standard practice in US elementary education, but it is certainly not standard practice in the computation or electronics industry. As this is a Computer Science course, I'm not sure that would or should be the safe assumption.

You could define what you are going to do using the # in front of the notes.

I would personally do what most people are suggesting below, eg drashy, and make .5 up to the next number which is 4.

Good luck
Python's round() function rounds away from 0. So that would round up in positive cases, and down in negative cases.
I agree with you all. It seems the best choice. Thanks you all.
My understanding is that x.5 rounds up because of the possibility that it could, due to measurement errors or digit truncation, be x.5000000...01 or greater.

"

It actually depends, 3.5 can be rounded to 3. Although I wouldn't worry about it for the HW.
see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rounding#Tie-breaking

"

"

citation please? or are you just declaring that? or are you making the argument that ""equally many numbers are rounded in both directions, so this must be right.""? that's not clearly the correct reasoning.

consider rounding 0.0 0.1 0.2 ... 0.9 with that rule.
the amount of rounding down will be different than the amount of rounding up. i'm defining ""the amount of rounding"" as the absolute value of the difference between the actual number and what it is rounded to. so the amount of rounding for 0.8 would be 0.2 because the absolute value of 1.0 - 0.8 is 0.2.

the amount of rounding down will be:
0.0 + 0.1 + 0.2 + 0.3 + 0.4 = 1.0

the amount of rounding up will be:
0.5 + 0.4 + 0.3 + 0.2 + 0.1 = 1.5

and 1.0 is not equal to 1.5.

i'd like to see a clarification or be told that we don't have to worry about it.

"
hear hear! hopefully they don't care what we do for .5 or they clarify soon.

Been years since I did this so this may be a hazy memory but here goes

3.50 should round up to 4 while 3.49 should round down to 3

I seem to recall that what we had to do to achieve this in COBOL was to add 0.001 to the number before we did the rounding. It worked I think but that is from a very long time ago so I may have got it wrong.

Any other ageing ex-COBOL programmers around to say I am right or want to correct me?
In the grading we'll let you do either way. But, I've never seen a round function that didn't round 3.5 to 4.

"

@PeterUdacity - How about the staff adding a comment in the homework's template code to make this explicit? Judging by the number of questions about this issue, it's obviously something that quite a few people are concerned about. Experienced coders will know that one should round up, but CS101 is targeted at absolute beginners.

"

The problem with half up rounding is the positive bias it introduces, which is unacceptable in many disciplines. For example, your FPU is most probably rounding half to even by default (3.5 would indeed round to 4, but 2.5 would round to 2).

if the digit before the rounding off digit is odd, then it is rounded up . i.e 3.57 will be rounded to 3.6 which then can be rounded to 4. so in this case, 3.5 should be rounded up to 4 as the digit before the rounding off digit is odd number, so it should be rounded up which is 4.!

As stated in the question's header:

# write Python code that prints out
# the nearest whole number to x.

nearest whole number is the main key sentence, this has no ambiguity if we read well.
If you need to verify it, google it! I know, I had to do it to be sure :D

Nearest whole number splits the decimals in half, 0..4 (round down) 5..9 (round up) as stated in other answers.

"

@Chewie this is the ""nearest even number"" rule, ""nearest whole number"" was specified, hence the lack of ambiguity

"

"

Here's a good article that will explain all things rounding.

"

"

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rounding#Tie-breaking

"

"

Beside the ""5 is in the middle ... so we could go up or down."" bit, which they did not deny, yes it's a good reading.

"

"

read python documentation, built-in function round

"
Right, it's just a standard that everyone agreed upon. Same as why we * and / before + and -.
Really, in this case, standard = general misunderstanding.

"

Round() would be the right function to use. But for floating point functions you should usually research FP issues for what you are doing. For example Python round function demonstrates an unexpected difference where a round(2.675, 2) gets rounded down to 2.67, this is due to how python rounds. The number gets converted to a binary value first, and that representation is not completely exact in all cases. See Python floating point issues

If you wanted to eliminate the rounding bias you would need to use a method like rounding half to even or a stochastic method.

See Rounding tie breaking for a list of common methods.

"

"

In the instructions it says:

""We will not test submitted code on a number such as 3.5, but as a general rule most round functions would round 3.5 up to 4.""

3.5000000 is the same as 3.5

"
it is in the teacher comments at the bottom of the page
there is a banker's method that flips between 3 and 4 50% of the time, but they specifically are asking for 5 to round up
Looks like this clarification has been added recently. Great to see the staff updating the site to solve all these teething troubles.

From A level maths, 25 years ago - if I remember correctly

.00000000... to .4999999... round down
.50000000... to .9999999... round up

This gives a fair 50/50 split - no bias in increasing or decreasing values.

Rounding .5 always up and never down introduces a bias, and if we choose to program it this way, we should first determine that this bias is negligible for our purposes. I understand that it is negligible for purposes of this exercise. I'm inclined to guess that there are a number of practical applications in which the bias would not be negligible.

In the comments near at the bottom of the video, they say that they will not be using any .5 test cases, so they are aware of this problem, and are dodging it by not testing for it, letting both be correct

"

For example in Java, how the rounding should behave is configurable with a RoundingMode constant, from what I understand the suggested rounding is the ""school rounding"", here called HALF_UP.

"

You can use anything that doesn't involve importing new libraries. We like to encourage students to only use material that we have covered in class. Often limiting yourself like this can lead to some of the coolest solutions!

Yup, but the homework can be solved using only concepts covered in the first unit-- I encourage you to try that! However, if you already know what an if statement is, you can use it.

jphme,

The homework can be solved using only concepts learned in the first unit-- I encourage you to try that! However, if you already know more than we've taught you, feel free to use other concepts as well (except for importing libraries).
thanks this clears my doubt perfectly.. :D

"

I think it's actually more tricky if you already know how to program because you tend to ""overthink"" the problem. For example, I just wanted to create my own round function!

But that is too complex. There is a very simple, elegant way to solve this problem using JUST what Prof. Dave has taught us so far.

ProTip: Walk away from the problem for an hour or so, then return to it. Repeat, if needed. You will be amazed if you just let your brain work on a problem on its own while you do something else!

"

data-item.data-item-item:
What motivated you to enroll in this course? tell us how this course will serve you.

What you think about the first unit?

What would you say to udacity for having implemented this study all free and accessible to everyone.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
What made me join the course

Having taught basic programming and computing to UK further education, (equivalent to American community college) I am interested in the course to learn Python and to see how the course was delivered.

I am thinking of developing some training modules of my own and will take some ideas from the course.

Impressions of the course

I am very impressed. The short video sections and a lot of practical questions/ work to reinforce points are extremely good.

The fact that we are developing something both practical and on an impressive scale is fantastic as anyone finishing the course will have a great confidence boost.

The framework for delivering is good - obviously a few bugs as it's new and quite complicated.

I am really enjoying it.

What did I think of the first unit

The first unit is well structured and quite entertaining. There are a couple of things I would have done differently - eg I would have spent more time on variables - but bearing in mind I am used to dealing with weaker students preparing for university it is probably not comparable. (I will write up suggestions some time later).

Udacity

Thank you - the fact it is free opens up the programme to a lot of people who would not get an opportunity to use it. I feel it will boost unemployed people or people in dead end jobs and some will go on to become programmers or work in the industry.

Personally I think that governments should spend on projects like this - but without getting too involved.

I personally am grateful to the UK's Open University, which allowed me to study part time and got me out a rut in my late twenties - where I working in factories and on building sites. I moved from their courses to a university then trained in computing and ended up teaching.

This project seems like the start of something similar - which will boost people throughout the world.

Final thoughts

I quit formal teaching about ten years ago as the government made us teach in a very uncreative way. Effectively we were made to teach to the textbook and very specific narrow topics.

Earlier we were allowed to do things are own way - so we would let students experiment with programming - making many mistakes - yellow writing on purple backgrounds etc or giving the students the framework of a game - let them do things with the game and then tell them afterwards they now understood arrays, indexing, searches etc. But not any more.

Just tick box teaching - arghhhh

What motivated me to enroll

I love computer games and learning, i spend most of my free time either playing or browsing the internet for documentaries, lectures and learning math in Khan Academy , having droped out of school at 13 there was no way to enroll to a computer school in greece, am hoping to learn enough to give me a start at programing and i intent to take every other follow up class Udacity is working on.
Maybe thanks to Udacity i'll get a way out of the horrible low paying jobs am stuck with due to my foolisness or maybe i'll just learn a lot more about my favorite tool/hobby, either way i win :)

I think what Udacity (and the Khan Academy and other sites i havent heard of) is doing is the future of learning, instead of having to wade through a ton of unrelated things you can study what you realy like to learn especially if you cant afford it in the offline world.

The first unit was to my surprise easy enough to follow for someone with zero experience like me, sure i got stuck a few times but nowere near as much as i expected

Thank you Udacity and everyone involved for this opportunity

data-item.data-item-item: This would be a good time to mention a Python pitfall having to do with indentation. Otherwise some students may not understand their code generates and error message if there is unexpected whitespace from the left margin.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

This might be a good reading: Python: Myths about Indentation

In short:

Code usually starts at column one:

x = 'a string'
print x

But is delimited with spaces when in a code block: 

if x = 1:      print ""x is 1"" else:    print 'x is not 1'

Something like this will give an error: 

x = 'a string'       print x

It could be more elaborated, but you can get the idea. Read along the link for more, in-depth, information. (I'm at work, after all.. lol)

"

I agree with you my friend about whitespaces..

Best Regards!!!
Excellent info!!!

"

People must also be careful about writing the code with an external editor and then copying this code to the web interpreter. It might not work due to the fact that different editors will handle tabs and indentation differently.

data-item.data-item-item:
why do we have to use the print command to get the answer insteadof directly using the expression.
As :

  • speed_of_light * meter * nanosecond
    instead of
    print speed_of_light * meter * nanosecond-

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Because you have to get a screen output to show the results, this can be done with print command, if you just put speed_of_light * meter * nanosecond the results doesn't show in screen and doesn't get saved in any variable.
but it does show the result when i don't use print in the interpreter in my desktop...thats tha confusion.

"

Depending on what you are running, it will often display the output of an expression in the console of that interpreter so that you can view it without having to ""print"" it. Say you saved that file as a .py file and then ran it in a linux terminal, windows command prompt, or the IDLE python shell, if you didn't tell the program to print anything the program would do the calculation, but nothing would be printed.

I hope that makes sense, I am sure there is a much better explanation that someone could provide.

"

"

and do not forget that python in some cases PRINT the expression without need to write PRINT before your expression. You can try this:

PRINT 2 + 2

or

2 + 2

In both cases the result will be ""4"".

I'm not sure about when python use PRINT command itself and when not.

"

"

It looks like the auto-printing of expressions without the print command is a feature of the interactive interpreter.

This is the answer I found:

When we are interacting with Python at
the >-->-->-- prompt and we give Python an
expression, the result is printed
automatically. This is the way Python
responds when interacting with a
person. When we run script, however,
we wonâ€™t be typing each individual
statement, and Python wonâ€™t
automatically print the result of each
expression. Instead, we have to tell
Python to show us results by writing
an statement using the print()
function that shows the response we
want.

Source

"

"

If you write a python script like this: print 2 * 2, and run it in a command window. It will display the result ""4"". But if you write only 2 * 2 in the script, it will display nothing.

"

"

In addition to the answers above, there are a few cases where the interpreter does not print the result of the expression unless it was configured to do so. For example, as far as I remember, it will not print anything after the execution of the function that was not made to 'return' any variable, even though the function does return a variable - an empty one, ""None"". But we could make the interpreter show that ""None"" through the 'print' command.
So, one could consider ""print"" command as one of the ways to end the program. In this case it is ""showing the result of the calculation to the user"". In other cases, it could be ""refreshing the webpage"". It is useful to think of everything else before this command as hidden from the end-user.

"

Thanks for your answers guys.

Maybe it depends on the interpreter you use. I tried two online Python interpreter and one of them gave the result without using PRINT. And now i think its probably because those online interpreters are not actually using standard Python engine and don't act like standard Python.

so to get a correct answer we have to write?

print 2+2
when you type print 2+2 or 2+2, there will be the same result. But when you want to display the result in a variable, str ... You need to use the command PRINT. OK ?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Are you using different email addresses for the separate forums? If so, you'll have to sign out of both the forum (using the 'sign out' link in the top-right) and also your Google account (you can do this within Gmail by clicking on your name in the top-right, then clicking on 'Sign out' within the menu). After you've signed out of Gmail, you can log back into Gmail using your other account, then return to the forums and sign in there.

It's a bit long-winded, but the forum doesn't know that you're one person with two different addresses - it just looks at the currently logged-in user.

data-item.data-item-item:
I wonder if there is a mistake here.

the question says these two strings are not equivalent (the second statement is an false)

s= 'udacity'
s[1] = (s+'ity')[1]

in general the second statement is not true, but since s has a length greater than 1 in particular this is true, am I right?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
In your particular case, they would be the same, for the string s='udacity'.

For the general case where s is an unknown string, though, they are not equivalent.
As he explains in the video, s could be an empty string, in which case it would throw up an error.

When s is an empty string or only has one character, there will be a syntax error when Python tries to access the second character with s[1] (string indexes start from zero).

However, for strings of two characters or longer, just adding 'ity' to the end will never change the second character, so s[1] and (s + 'ity')[1] will always be equivalent.

Because of the problem with the shorter strings, the statement is not true for every possible value of s, so the quiz is correct.

"

Was about to report this question too as being incorrect as both strings would be equal

The thing about first string is a bit of a curved ball as (as programmers) we would have checked that the
first string had a value B4 attempting the concatenation or would have wrapped the line in an error block for eg (try catch)

Soo mayhap it was a bit mean, confusing the noobs like that ""el profesoro"" :)

"
Ron, the LENGTH of the strings are not being compared but the VALUE of the string at a specific point for eg [1]

data-item.data-item-item:
"

The problem starts of with the statement : ""Let S='<--any string="""">--' .. So I took that as a 'given'.

The prof. when presenting the solution makes arguments along the lines of ""if S had only 1 character"" ... but there is a conflicting assumption at the top.

Either that, or please word the problem as , ""given a non-empty string of 1 or more characters""..

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

When he says s='<--any string="""">--' he is not literally saying it is the words ""any string"" with brackets in there. He is saying that s can represent any possible string that you can think of.

In other words, imagine that you are programming for a case where you do not know what s is, but still have to be able to work with whatever you are given as an input for s.

"
I figured that out.. All I am saying is that the question is open to interpretation... Particularly given that we took a lot of care to define grammars and such.
What is the conflicting assumption? You mean because of statements like s[3]? I think you have a point there unless one argues that Error=Error. :)

"

I agree. Perhaps if he took the quotes out of the <--any string="""">-- definition it would be a bit clearer?
I thought the intent was obvious from listening to the video, but I can certainly see how someone could be confused just looking at the question written out.

"

"

He was looking at s='<--any string="""">--' as literally saying that s is being defined as the string <--any string="""">--.

So that s[1] would return the value 'a', the second character in '<--any string="""">--.

"
Gotcha. I thought it might be confusing to some that if s is the empty string, the first statement gives Error for both values.
So Error = Error, they return the same thing :)

"

Yes, I do admit that I got thrown off track - so it was not necessarily a bug? If there was an annotation along the lines of ""(assume that S could be any non-empty string)"" - it would have been crystal-clear.

I took it too literally - my bad.

"
Any string includes the empty string though.
Yup, he says Error=Error in the answer.

data-item.data-item-item: Where do I find the python interpreter on my computer. From time to time the instructor says you can try what he is teaching but I don't get where to try it out?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Do u have a mac? if yes then go to applications->--Utilities->--Terminal
In the terminal type python and press enter.
u can then test by saying print ""hello"".

"

"

Before the video end you have to click on ""Next"" to try..

Prove it!!!

Or you should download and install python also.

"

Go to www.python.org and download a copy of Python for your computer. Use the 2.xx version and not the 3.xx version since the course is based on Python 2.6. Once you download you will have a Python command line application where you can type your programs interactively and experiment with concepts without using the browser based application from the course.

"

Just as @Sudha said, also you can write out the program in a text editor and save it. Then run it in your terminal by typing python *text file that contains the python code* That will run whatever is inside the text file.

"

If you'd like to be able to edit, run and change your programs as with the online editor, also want to save your programs, but don't always want to import .txt files to your terminal, you could download a free editor (e.g. KomodoEdit) and create Python files with it (.py) - it works great for me to test my programs and instantly see the results of any changes. Also it will color your code, which plain text editors don't offer.

Hope that helps!

data-item.data-item-item:

Just a nitpick, but there's a typo in Unit1, part 12: ""Speed of Light"" video where nanoseconds are missing the units:

nanosecond = 1 / 1 000 000 000 s
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: nanoseconds variable assigns to an integer (or, more precisely, real) number, so you can't have letters in it. If you try to execute your code (nanosecond = 1 / 1 000 000 000 s) you will get an error, I believe.
Sorry, my bad. It is a typo, although a minor one.

data-item.data-item-item:
My intention in Udacity is to take all possible courses and learn from the best teachers that illustrate their knowledge.

For this I must have a lot of discipline and make the most of this great opportunity to develop and expand my knowledge. What about you???

That's all friends!

Best Greetings!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
This is my goal as well!

I had the opportunity to take courses on many of these topics while in college, but I'm very excited to learn more about these topics from a different perspective and from better instructors.

It'll certainly be difficult to do when I have to balance it with a full time job, but there really aren't many things I could spend my free time doing that are as interesting or entertaining as this!
To take over the world.

While I agree that taking over the world is a worthwhile endeavor, I enrolled in Udacity for a number of reasons.

  • I never learned to code before, although I have enrolled in other courses online and dropped out because of a lack in interest.
  • Code is so cool! It can change the world.
  • I cohead my schools CompTech club and it would be so cool if I include my own personal experience when describing my travails in learning programming!
  • Programming is nerdy and you get to build cool stuff. I'm a nerd and I love doing nerdy stuff.
  • I never have taken an online course before.
  • I never thought programming in Udacity was this much fun.
  • If I learn one language, I am taking the first step into mastering them all.
  • Programming is one powerful tool and I need to know how to handle it wisely
  • I am not going to let the fact that I may or may not be a minority in the tech community stop me.
  • I want to know enough programming so I can solve this glitch in using the bulleted list option. So many dots and dashes.

My plan is to take a course or two at a time, as my schedule permits, as often as they open stuff up for us.

My reasons... (which I suspect are related to the usual assortment)

Partly, just for kicks.

Partly, I have a web-based business and want to get better at making up stuff for it.

Partly, I know scraps and pieces of programming (found a BASIC manual when I was ~9, have goofed around with mostly copy-paste-tweak jobs for web stuff, etc.) and want to finally get around to assembling what I know into something complete enough to be useful.

Partly, general information-junkie type reasons. Though there have been experiences which were technically informative that I wouldn't have minded missing, I have never regretted having more information about something (exception: realizing where my sister and I came from [my parents did WHAT???] :P ).

I want to make a business about social media marketing, I think lear about programing and python will expand my knowledge about what its possible, with programing different online tools.

I think the Social media will change the world for better. And programing too .
I hope so my friend!!
Great!!! I will try to reach you.
It's true, it'll be difficult but not impossible, I like the way you think...
To build a better search engine than Google trololo
that's what we need, to have fun, and pay close attention to devote to this great advantage called UDACITY

that's the attitude my friend!

We'll Learn if we engage and put effort to learn ..
yours mentality will make you go a long way, I expect to see when your search engine be the best in the world more famous than ay google.

Joking aside, my real intention is to learn something new ( the pytyhon language, how to build a search engine, refreshing my knowledge about the basics of computer science ) Another more important reason is that I do learn from these online classes so much more then from most of the real classes at my university ( I experienced that before the search engine class, it was an online class about machine learning ) Many professors should orient themselves to the way of educating people like the professors from Udacity do!
Uh. Strictly honorable sir. I'll have udacity home safe and sound.

I have a few goals by studying with Udacity:

  • I want to keep my brain active and continue learning new things--
  • I teach computer science to 16-18 year olds and have spent a lot of time and effort (and continue to do so) looking at ways to make my class more accessible, interactive and interesting for my students. So I'm hoping to learn content for myself from Udacity, experience new approaches to explaining different concepts, as well as getting some ideas for effective ways to structure and present material--
  • I have also recently gone back to university part time to specialise in the use of ICT in education. So anything I can experience myself, read in forums, and anything I try to implement myself will be helpful to me in this area of study.

I also have a number of rather advanced students in my class this year...as extension work I am seriously considering suggesting to them to sign up to Udacity too!

"

Gee Brain, What do you want to do tonight?

"

To keep my brain sharp.

In the information age, learning new things is trivially simple. Challenging yourself with difficult knowledge types is the hard part. It's too easy to fall into the trap of only expanding your knowledge on things already within your inherent comfort zone.

As a dyed-in-the-wool marketing/creative/intuitive right brainer who has dealt with coders in various ecommerce roles and found them to be an alien species entirely unlike any other category of human I'd ever encountered, I decided that in order to better understand this bizarre and perplexing group, I must first learn their secrets.

First of all because I have never attended to an on-line course and when I read that was on computer science and programming that are two of my favourite science fields I decided to take part in the course... secondly because I didn't have any experience of programming in Python and on how to build a search engine that is very exciting.... Moreover, I would like to learn new concepts about computer science and new programming techniques....
To gain infinite power!

To learn Python, to learn something about making programs that interact with the web, and to check out Udacity. I have programmed in a lot of languages over the 31 years I have been doing it (I am 47 now), but for the last 15 years I have used mostly C++ (for the last 17 years I have been a college prof, teaching game development). C/C++ are king for real-time high-speed stuff, but I have been pleasantly surprised by how much pure 'fun' Python is.
To build google fling car
I came here to expand my mind learn to better manage, be more efficient, this would go a long way. Thanks MIT and Udacity

"

Several reasons for me:

  • keep my mind fresh and flexible, able
    to learn
  • spend my time on something
    more useful than WoW skills :)
  • learning something new is always
    great :) Especially learning from
    Stanford teachers.

Also for me Udacity is very interesting and promising experiment, an enormous project. I think we all will be u-hipsters some time later - ""Attended Udacity before it was cool""

"
My goal is to gain a basic proficiency in Python. This 'how to build a search engine' focus has already got me thinking about a project I plan to attack on my own at the conclusion of this course.

data-item.data-item-item:
How are programming questions in homework assignments graded?
Are they all or nothing or do they get graded on a scale depending on how good our code is.

For example for the rounding problem in homework one my first answer used stuff we didn't cover in unit one however after thinking about it for a bit I found a simpler way of doing it using what we learned in class. Does it matter which one is my final answer?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: For now they are all or nothing for each question in the assignment. I want to do something like that and it's likely that future assignments will have functionality that you describe.
Agree with you my friend!
My question was about how individual HW questions are graded. I will edit it to make it clearer. That is good to know about the rest of the grading.
Grading homework problems on a scale would probably be a pretty interesting AI project.
I'm also wondering what is up with the gold stars on the last two assignments? Are the last two tasks in the homework somehow graded differently than the rest or are bonus tasks?

After the Udacity server grades the homework how about setting up a mechanism where the top x% of students can volunteer and comment on randomly assigned homework from other students who would like more feedback? So....just as an example....let students who scored higher than 90% on the homework volunteer to be a pool of assistants who comment on homework after grading is complete. These folks could then have access to a page that allows them to pull out homework assignments from students who requested more feedback and then comment on them and send them back to those students.
The way I understood is was that the stars would not affect the grading, merely that the amount of stars represented the relative difficulty of the question.

I think partial credit on some questions would be appreciated. Several of the questions required more than the teachings in class. Clearly the last one (although I enjoyed it)! Personally, I would only give partial credit if the answer involved programming that was not taught in class. A couple of multiple choice questions had one selection that required a little more knowledge than was taught in class. It seems partial credit should be provided if a user struggled with a multiple choice selection that was not covered in class. Just my opinion....you're the professor!

"

@timinmich The last question can be solved using only what was taught in unit 1.

"
I didn't find anything in any of the quizzes or homework questions that required any knowledge not taught within the class itself.

The question regarding partial credit for HW is not relevant. Specifically, HW should
- provide the student with a means to practice their skills as related to course objectives. HW is not a test or quiz, students should be expected to get answers wrong. HW is practice.
- provide students with feedback so that they (the student) can self assess the rate and level at which they are learning. It appears that this will be done by having the answers made available to the HW's after the submission date.
- provide the instructors with formative feedback so that they (the teachers) can assess the knowledge level reached by the student body from the lessons.

If the current format of HW does not meet these objectives than changes in the grading structure or format of HW should be considered.

data-item.data-item-item:
I just completed the Rounding Numbers piece of homework, and tried to bug test it a little bit. I found that if you assign 'x' as a fraction (e.g. 9/5) it will incorrectly get rounded down as it assumes an integer, so the code will produce the answer 1, instead of the correct 2.

If you input the number as '9./5.' it corrects this, and I know that you can use float() AFTER you've assigned the variable to let the program know it will have decimal points, but I was wondering if there were a way to set the variable to have decimal points when you create the variable, so Python doesn't have to guess what type it is, and the user doesn't have to input the number with a '.'.

Thanks for your help.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You can set the var as x = 0.0 and then update it somewhere in the code... Would this have the effect you want? Not sure what you want to do...

"

I want to be able to set x to have decimal places immediately. I don't want to have the input the number with a decimal point.

For example, if in the Rounding Numbers homework I had the user input a number, and he chose ""9/5"". If the code used that exact entry, it assumes the division of 9/5 is an integer, and so with the code I produced it would output 1 as the rounded number.

I have very little coding knowledge, but I believe in C# and other languages you can set variables to be types straight away, as with int, float, var, etc.. I want to be able to do that without having to set x first, then convert it using float(x).

I hope that makes more sense.

"

"

No I don't think it's possible, though you can ask this over at StackOverflow if you want.

Python doesn't bind a variable to any particular type.
You could assign an variable x an integer, and in the next statement assign a string to x.
IIRC, Python doesn't reserve a memory address for a variable. What it does is assign a memory location to the constant values. That is if you assign the value 7 to a variable x, it will assign a memory location to 7 &-- x will point to it. When x is changed, the value in the memory address x was point to doesn't change, but x points to another memory address.

Here, I think this example will make it more clear. # id(x) returns the memory address of the variable x

>-->-->-- a = 7 >-->-->-- print id(7) 25784840 >-->-->-- print id(a) 25784840 >-->-->-- a = a+7 >-->-->-- print id(a) 25784672 >-->-->-- print id(7) 25784840 >-->-->-- a = float(a) >-->-->-- print id(a) 25798144

Hope this helps

"

Wow, that's exactly the answer I was looking for, and more. Thanks for clearing that up!

Would you see that as a flaw of Python or is it more of a non-issue?

P.S. I just noticed there are nested comment threads and the delete button doesn't seem to be working on my other reply.

I would call it a feature.
When taking input from the user, you'll either take a string &-- then parse it or if you're just taking numbers, you can typecast them to float before using them in calculations, so your concerns about problems with user input are a non-issue really.
a = float(raw_input())
or a, b = raw_input()
y = float(a)/b

I believe some of the respondents are understating the difficulty of the last two questions. The last question, in particular, has a couple of holes to fall into if you don't properly test your program.

The last two would be very difficult for someone who is poor at math and has no previous experience programming. Most people (especially those who aren't already in the technology sector) tend to have very little knowledge of programming. Most people haven't taken math since high school or college, and considering the median age in most western industrialized countries is 30-45 years (including all children), most people are going to be rusty, at best.

Oohhh. I thought an empty string was two double quotes. That changes things. Thanks, peeps!

Empty string or any other string is marked with a pair of either single or double quotes.
Just make sure to close the quotes with same quotation mark you used to open it. :)
it'd still be nice to have that clarified officially.
empty string is two single quotes or two double quotes. A single double quote is an error.

"

Single quotes and double quotes are used in order to mark strings that may contain quotes themselves. For example:

string = 'I was once reading ""Dune"" by Frank Herbert'

In this case, if you would've used double quotes instead of single quotes the code would have thrown an error because it would have been interpreted as I was once reading as one string (started by the first ' and ended by the single quote before Dune) and Dune (which would be undefined and throw out an error) and then another string ' by Frank Herbert'

You can also use, if you want

string = ""I was once reading 'Dune' by Frank Herbert""

So, when you want to use quotes inside a string make sure to start the string with the type of quotes that aren't in the string.

You can mark an empty string with either single or double quotes.

"
There are no double quotes in that question.

I missed an item on the quiz about what is a programming language. data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
It is all answered in the video after the question.

But, just to clarify,some programs are able to write other programs, like our Python interpreter takes an input and runs that programs.

"

You might want to look at some of the responses in this thread or this thread for more discussion of this quiz.

"

The same question arose in my mind too! I feel that it's not supposed to be in the right options list, I am not sure though. If someone could clarify, it would be helpful.

Edit : Got clarified now!

The short answer is that most (all?) programming languages ultimately translate what you write to assembler (machine) code. That means that yes, technically, they do write programs.
Check the links Lisa provided for more in depth answers.

"

Interpreted programming languages like Python which is a High-level programming language are excellent examples to demonstrate this. You as the code author writes a series of commands which are accepted and recognized by the Python interpreter, which then rewrites the code in a low-level programming language understood by the computer's instruction set.
This allows you to write a code once, yet are able to run on various Operations systems, configurations and platforms of computers.

"

This may sound picky, but I find the statement that there is no good reason to ever do the following misleading:

print word[:]

Looking at the statement as a whole, I agree that there is no good reason to do this, but this may lead people to think that the expression word[:] is not useful, which is, of course, not the case. It is useful when you want to clone a string, since Python does assignment by reference, which is something that people who programmed in other languages and are new to Python might not expect.

I'm certain you didn't mean it like it's not useful to use word[:], but I felt the urge to point out my discomfort.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

This actually doesn't work for strings but does for lists. To clone a string you have to do something like this:

a = 'asdf' b = ''.join(a)

to shallow copy a list you can do

l = [1, 2, 3, 'asdf'] t = l[:]

Here's some writeups about cloning strings and lists.

"

I have thought about this question a lot since I gave my first answer above which I am now changing -- and have actually redone my own homework answer as a result. But first, in the spirit of owning up -- I'm going to give my answer a thumbs down. (Whoops -- you can't vote down your own post -- so I'm going to delete it!)

The key word in this question is ""any"". Never mind that we are given a specific number to use for x. That word is an indicator that we should throw all kinds of possibilities into x, BECAUSE our code should work for ANY number as well as the value of x that is given.

AND, guess what, using only the material we learned in the unit, the solution is quite elegant! Thanks, Dave, et al. for that question!

"

People, look at the code commentaries at the beginning.

#Given a variable, x, that stores #the value of any decimal number, #write Python code that prints out #the nearest whole number to x.  #You can assume x is not negative.

It says ANY decimal number (assuming x>--=0), right? If our code had only to work with PI, the answer would be

print '3'

And, of course, it's slightly more complicated than that. It took me a while to figure how to do it using only methods and operators seen in class and 'str'.

It says

**

You can assume x is not negative.

x = 3.14159 ->-- 3 (not 3.0)

x = 27.63 ->-- 28 (not 28.0)**

So, it should not work only for 3.14159, that solution is 3 , but should give 28 for 27.63

But should work with 4.91 (5) and 9.007 (9) or any other positive number too.

So, think ....

1) How can any given x number with decimals <--anything higher or equal to 0.5>-- be rounded to x+1 when removing decimals?

2) How can any given x number with decimals <--anything lower to 0,5>-- be rounded to just x when removing decimals

And both 1) and 2) with the same operation

str() doesn't change the value in the brackets, it outputs the result - so you have to assign it to a variable.

For example:
x_string = str(x)

Also, while x_string[0] gives you the first character in the string, that would only truncate and would only work for single digit numbers.
Re-read the assignment carefully, and pay attention to the specifics of how the quiz asks you to solve the programming challenge.

Also see this post regarding possible values of x.

"

x[0] is not a valid syntax as x is not a string, but a number

you have to save str(x) in a new variable first

think about what your code does:

str(x) ->-- convert a number stored in x into a string
x[0] ->-- select the first character of the string x (but ONLY if x is a string, i think)

I believe the instructor's video was more informative. You told us that it hasn't been done (an example would make your explanation clearer). However, the instructor showed that it can't ever be done.

The program might be smart enough to ask for further clarification, but we will just end up defining terms that we could defined in the first place using a programming language.

There are also philosophical, mystical, and religious terminology that computers will have a hard time understanding until we reach the edge of AI. How is the Trinity three but still one? What would be the implications of a world in which logic doesn't apply? If nothing physical existed would there still be a priori knowledge?

Proper parsing helps Siri know what I'm asking for when I say ""Where's the closest Walmart?"" But proper parsing isn't the problem when I ask Siri ""How can free will exist in a world where God's omniscience extends into the future?"" It can be programmed to give answers that have already been given, but it's not possible for it to give original answers in the way that humans are able to, because the logical answer to the question is clear and a human would know that other answers can be given even if they may be logically incoherent.

"

"

But @ari_lev, programs wouldn't be expected to parse questions such as ""How is the Trinity three but still one?"" anyway, right? Or any of the questions you ask...

What I'd think a ""natural programming language"" would be, would basically be something that would read a ""spec"" and act accordingly. It would cut programmers entirely out of the loop, and business people would simply speak what they wanted. Realistically, I think it'd look more like ""I want an agent that crawls a target page by following each of it's outgoing links and searches each of it's contents."" We don't have to go to the realm of the metaphysical really to get into trouble. Even parsing straightforward English would be (or at least has been up until very recently) very difficult for computers. I think the explanation suggests: ""Well, yeah, we could program in natural languages, but years ago, we decided 'God, why would we ever want to do that?' and so we actively decided against programming in natural languages, even though we could.""

Did he really say it can't be done? Besides, I think people would live with a ""natural programming language"" if it consulted a dictionary as he seemed to suggest was possible and it said ""Do you mean biweekly as in twice a week, or biweekly as in once every two weeks?"" Or even a

Traceback (most recent call last):

File ""/tmp/payschedule.eng""

biweekly

AmbiguityError: word 'biweekly' has multiple contradictory senses.

Unable to disambiguate from context. Aborting parse.

I didn't really find that he explained ""that it can't ever be done."" He explained that we wouldn't want to, without hinting that it is a very difficult job to parse human languages. Even without bringing God's omniscience vs. free will into the picture.

"

"

That's all without bringing into it, the fact that artificial languages have always been progressing towards greater and greater ambiguity (and automatic clarification) through the decades, from programming in machine code, to assembler, to 3GL's (fortran, C, python) to 4GL's SQL. I mean, even Scala and Haskell for instance engage in ""type inference"" to infer which type you ""mean"". For that matter, python itself engages in ambiguity by way of ""duck typing. So, I think people are OK with ambiguity and the machine dealing with it as best as it can till it was able to disambiguate.

"
where to watch the explanation videos? i can't find the links. thank you!

"

@Lisa McLean, after you place your answer just click on next and it should take you to the explanation for the quiz.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Q 1 why is ++i not an error but i++ is?

Q 2 Why is ++i the same value as i?

Q 3 What paradigm does python follow?

Q 4 How is it different or better than other web development languages?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

http://stackoverflow.com/a/1485854/805427 <---- This will answer your first two questions.

"

if i = 1 then your ++i will still be one in Python.

There is no ++ operation in Python as there is in C.

the i++ would give an error because Python thinks you are adding 1 and + since the first
plus is taken to be an operator, Python expects the next item to be a number or a variable.

Hope that helps.

"

I think a little googling will answer all four of your questions.

For instance this answer to a StackOverflow question answers your first two questions.

Basically + is an identity operator, not an increment operator, which returns the variable value, so ++i parses +(+i).

If you want to increment or decrement, you'll have to use +/-=

"

"

Q 3 What paradigm does python follow?

From Wikipedia: ""Python supports multiple programming paradigms, primarily but not limited to object-oriented, imperative and, to a lesser extent, functional programming styles.""

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

this is a test and a comment on the FAQ for this Forum.
This Office Hours Question was originally posted as an Answer to this question.

That's right to ask a question I had to post an answer.

My plan is to ""convert to question"" via the more menu after the Answer is posted. Note, however, that as of this writing my kara is 61.

I don't know what that means and I'm only more confused after reading the faq, than appears below

I suspect one of the causes of my confusion is the symbol ""->--"" that is used to indicate, what, I suspect, should be ""â‰¥"" Note: if there's garbage displayed on this line see the entry for &--#8805 on this nifty web page. Inserting a -new line- following the sentence that ends with ""users based on those points."" as shown below:

How does the karma system work?
When a question or answer is upvoted, the user who posted them will gain some points, which are called ""karma points"". These points serve as a rough measure of the community trust in him/her. Various moderation tasks are gradually assigned to the users based on those points.

For example, if you ask an interesting question or give a helpful answer, your input will be upvoted. On the other hand if the answer is misleading, it will be downvoted. Each vote in favor will generate 15 points, each vote against will subtract 1 points. There is a limit of 200 points that can be accumulated per question or answer. The table below explains karma requirements for each type of moderation task.

  • close own questions ->-- 0
  • reopen own questions ->-- 0
  • add comments ->-- 50
  • retag questions ->-- 500
  • edit any answer ->-- 2000
  • delete any comment ->-- 10000
"

data-item.data-item-item: I answered this problem in a trivial way (I use Python frequently), but I fear that's not the way intended. Is this a problem? Should I have tried to use the str function instead of the obvious way that any sane Python programmer would use get this job quickly and easily accomplished?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It'll be graded as correct. But we encourage you to only use material discussed in lecture so far. It should make the problem a lot more interesting!
I hope my friend, who doesn't know programming at all, will join this courses, so I will find how this task must be done. Don't know how to do it, without 'cheat' functions or checking statement.

You should try to solve this using the tools provided. It is an interesting little problem and uses nearly every one of the programming tools demonstrated. While it is probably not the best practice, you can even solve it in one line.

It can be solved using only the material presented in the first unit. It is not the most trivial nor the most elegant way to solve the problem for one who already knows Python. The challenge requires a bit of out of box thinking.

Try working backward from the answer, That's how it finally clicked for me.

Good luck!

"

I don't think the objective of this course is just to get the ""job quickly and easily accomplished"". I think it is more important (here) to try to find other ways to do things and get out of the rut that experienced programmers somtimes get into. I don't know how many times I have heard someone say,""But I've always done it that way!"" and then they overlooked some detail. Just my opinion of course. :-)

"
The solution is delightfully simple, I think. It took me a little while to see it, but once you do, it is oh-so-obvious. And using str() and .find isn't even the tricky part.

I finally solved it using only Unit 1 and str()!!

My solution takes a whopping 20 lines though. I am a relative newby and am curious to see how it in the can be solved using unit 1 in only one line.

My method is probably strange and convoluted, but it works as intended. I don't feel that the answer was obvious, at least not the way I did it. It was tricky for me, but I feel confident with my approach.

Anxious to see the obvious answer so I can do a head slap and say duh. (hope the answer video will show variations if there are any)

I learned how to look at something in a new way. I found three decent ways to do it 'otherwise' or 'obvious' by reading documentation, and I got a solid start in pythonic problem solving...all in a couple of hours.

Oh it'll be so long until next class and the answers......so long.
That's the way to do it. I think the idea is to get us the experiment with the package and get us thinking - so three answers - well done

hope to see your elegant solution, because I managed to do it, but it was a really strange way to do it.

Even though it was anice exercise
Make it four, just submitted my final answer, down to one line like all the hot shots....sigh, my 20 line way was cooler though. I kept a copy of my beastly thing so I won't forget her.
love reverse-engineering. Will try. Thx!
Finally, only 4 line of codes, include print the answer. Thanks for all hint

"

As often happens in programming, you get what you think is a solution, but you are still chewing on it. Some time later, perhaps after sleeping, you find a better answer. The ""after sleeping"" happens rarely, but is quite exciting when you wake up with the answer in your head! That happened with me and the last homework question.

"

"

I think the answer he calls obvious, wasn't covered in unit 1. At least the statement ""I use Python frequently"" implies that for me. On the other hand his name is mathprof so my ""valid"" answer could be obvious for him too.

"

I love the way having any programming experience can put us at a mental disadvantage for this question! I couldn't stop focusing on all the ways I couldn't solve the problem because they used things we haven't covered yet. It would be terrific -- and fascinating -- if this question turns out to be easier for someone who doesn't know anything about programming other than this week's material, and so isn't sidetracked by wanting to use methods we haven't covered.

"

@KenavR, the obvious way would be to use the round() function which does exactly what the exercise wants, but doesn't respect the requirement of using only concepts presented in Unit 1.

"

My first answer was using the native rounding and int casting functions which were not covered in unit 1 but having had a night to sleep on it, I also found the solution to be so insidiously diabolically clever that I also wanted to kick myself when I worked it out.....

While yes it can be condensed into 1 line, I've chosen to split it into 2 lines for readability.

From personal experience I think it's harder for those of us with programming experience to see the simple solution here because we rely massively on the internal functions of whichever language we're working in. When I took off the guru hat and rethought the problem, everything we needed was already taught in Unit 1.

Qudos Peter for making me think outside the box on this one...

The anwers that I called 'obvious' or 'otherwise' involved things not learned in class, the class inspired me to dig further. I have some mild programming experience (mostly Arduino) and knew there would be functions like if() and round() and int(), but needed to look up how to use them.There are a slew of ways to approach this simple problem.

Not satisfied with an easy route, I was determined to do it within the restrictions. I did it, as stated in 20 lines....in a very strange way. But I was within the constrictions, and a solution is a solution, so I posted my pride!!

Alas I was then confronted with many posts that conflicted with the method I came up with so I went back at it, from the bottom up as many have hinted. In fact the answer has been given away in several posts now...at least I feel that way now that I am one of the ones who has slapped my head and said , duh!

So from a relatively inexperienced programmer with no fancy schooling, believe me it is doable in one line...a fairly short one at that.

But I stand by my 'beast' too. Somehow I was prouder of that even though my final submission was the one liner.

sure you can do it all in one line, the same way you can solve a giant equation in one line, without using discrete variables, or taking your time building your solution step by step... :)

but, Python also focuses on readability of code, so I think that should be taken into account. :)

I'm curious to see if there are any easier solutions than mine. can't wait.

Yep,

I came up with the ~20 line code and submitted it because it was my original solution. I hereby dub it the Rube-Goldberg Rounding Matrix. Since then, I had a friend who helped me figure out the 1-2 line solution and it really is a simple math problem that made me slap my palm to my face.

Great Homework problem to show us the importance of breaking down a problem into the basic parts instead of just focusing on the steps one normally uses to arrive at a solution. Very eye-opening. Many people here just solved the same problem with 1/10th of the code that I used. Kudos.
I feel really bad now. I should probably sleep on this and facepalm at the ridiculously obvious code I get.

data-item.data-item-item: When using .find, -1 is returned if the sub-string doesn't exist. Is -1 the standard error return code for Python?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I'm not experienced with Python (or programming at all, for that matter), but I believe that it returns -1 because of how slicing works, not error handling.

For example, if I wanted to gather information from a lot of books, but I didn't want to include anything after the start of the index (denoted by ""<--index>--...<--/index>--""), I could go about slicing up large book stings with something rudimentary like:

book_slice = book[0:(book.find(""<--index>--""))]

Not all books have indexes, but my method of slicing will still work because it will return -1.

If a more experienced Python programmer could validate my intuition, that would be much appreciated.

"

I don't think -1 means an error. It is not an error code. I see it more like a convenient result.

Python uses exceptions for error handling instead of the error code return, typical in C language.

The find() method returns -1 if a substring is not found because, historically, there is no element at the index -1 for a string or an array. Understandably, this causes a fair bit of confusion because you can, in fact, access the element in a Python string at index -1.

"

For example, index method is like find but with exception handling:

>-->-->-- 'abc'.find('d') -1 >-->-->-- 'abc'.index('d') Traceback (most recent call last):   File ""<--stdin>--"", line 1, in <--module>-- ValueError: substring not found
"

solving a problem by cramming what are essentially several logical steps into as few lines as possible may give you a warm and fuzzy feeling about your cleverness, but believe me, writing code that other people can easily understand is far more important.

sometimes it's the case that tight code is actually more readable, but it's usually only when the code in question is a well-known idiom in the programming language. experienced python programmers, for instance, will immediately recognize this one-liner as a way to reverse a string without even thinking :-)

print 'hello'[::-1]

Don't worry too much about converting the number into an int... the print function will convert any input into an str anyway.

The conversion to str() is important so that you can use the .find() function. If you try and .find() on the float you will get an error. But if you str() too early you can't perform any math on the 'number'....

All you need to do is work out how to manipulate the given float to the nearest full integer value..... The rest will fall into place....
Took me about 2 hours but eventually solved it with a one liner and basic arithmetic. The solution I came up with won't work with negative numbers (hint).

"

Conciseness is not important at all. If your short code is neither computationally efficient nor easily readable, it is worth much less than a longer, more easily readable and/or more efficient code. In this specific exercise the challenge was to use a limited set of python instructions to solve a problem. One important point that we can get from this experience is that there is no ""right"" answer, and that you can solve very complex problems even with limited tools if you use your creativity.

"

Code speed is not measured in numbers of characters or lines. Your code is eventually broken down into simpler instructions by the computer. A solution that has fewer lines could end up taking more instructions to complete, which could make it slower.

At this stage though, that's not important. Don't worry about speed.

data-item.data-item-item: Option Fourth s[1], (s+â€™ityâ€™)[1] = two things are same value. But it is showing error when submit.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
If the string has fewer than 2 characters in it, the two expressions will not be the same (see the explanatory video following the quiz).

For instance, if s = 'e' then s[1] refers to the second character in the string. But there's only one character, so it returns an error. But (s + 'ity')[1] refers to the second character in the concatenated string 'eity' which is 'i'.

"

It has to be correct for all possible strings s, so it has to be true for, say s="""" (empty string), s=""a"", s=""to"", s=""cat"", s=""four"" and so on. Have a look at what happens for all of those.

"

"

"

As @ramrunner suggests, it seems practically impossible in an online classroom format to evaluate ""any"" string, which would be in theory an infinite number of possible strings. So, it would be helpful to have some bounds defined for the quiz questions. That said, I did not originally look at this question from the point of view of testing for different string lengths, so I learned something useful, which I assume is an insight valuable to anyone writing code.

"

"

As Ramrunner suggests, it seems practically impossible in an online classroom format to evaluate ""any"" string, which would be in theory an infinite number of possible strings. So, it would be helpful to have some bounds defined for the quiz questions. That said, I did not originally look at this question from the point of view of testing for different string lengths, so I learned something useful, which I assume is an insight valuable to anyone writing code.

"

@katarinavelika You're exactly right that in any situation is it impossible to test the infinitely many possibilities for the string, and that's why we have to consider all the possible cases in a general, more theoretical, way. We need to know that s[0:] is always the same as s (by logical reasoning and not testing everything) so if for some reason we use it, we know it wont break in some cases. We also need to realise than some things will break, like the example we're discussing in this thread, in some circumstances so that we are aware when our code will and won't work as we want.

data-item.data-item-item: Why we count ''0'' for start instead of ''1'' and ''-1'' for the stop instead of ''0''. Seems more logical don't you thing?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Historically, arrays and strings in computer science have been zero-indexed. That is to say that the first element in an array or string is at index zero.

In most programming languages you cannot access the element at index -1. In fact, Python is the only language that I know of to support this feature.

"

Not so obvious that the logical start should be 1:

Why numbering should start at zero, Dijkstra

"

It may help if you think of the index as 'the distance from the start of the string': the first character is at the very beginning, so it's 0 characters away-- the second character is +1 away-- and the last character is -1 away because the indexing 'wraps around' to the end.
Thank you both for your answers!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
The import statement is used to include other Python libraries in your code. For example, if you were working with matrices then you'd want to make use of the NumPy library. To do this you would type 

import numpy

at the top of your script.

Importing modules gives you a lot of extra power to do some really neat stuff. The only problem is that importing would essentially make everything we're doing in this course trivial. That's why we're not allowed to do it.

import solution

print solution

data-item.data-item-item:
"

As we all have undoubtedly realized there are bugs throughout the site. Udacity is a new product and as the essential beta testers of Udacity, it is our responsibility to report these bugs so that they can be fixed in future releases. Furthermore, we needed to have one place where we can keep a list of the known bugs and issues with explanations and more information about each problem. From now on, any bug that can be validated should be added to this list with an explanation on how to work around the bug.

The Canonical List of Known Bugs and Issues


Bug

Clicking next after completing a question on the first homework assignment brings up a video that is in private mode.


Explanation

This happens because the video you are seeing is actually the answer video. It will become available after the homework assignment due date has passed. Meanwhile, simply click the next button again and you'll be on your way.


Bug

Typing a URL into a post renders everything in the post invisible.


Explanation

This can easily be solved by formatting your links correctly. Correct formatting can be found here under the header 'Links'.

Bug

Links in email notifications are broken.


Explanation

The URLs are missing the /cs101/ and /cs373/ links that are required to direct to the appropriate board.

Bug

Answers in previously completed quizzes and homework do not appear to be saved.


Explanation

The answers ARE being saved (or so I hear), they just do not appear to be.

Bugs With No Known Solution


Bug

If you continue to vote on questions/answers then eventually you will start receiving counters that tell you that you have a negative number of votes left.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Disclaimer: It is decidedly possible that they're already planning to get to this in a future lesson.

When writing the code to pick links out of an HTML page, I had a thought. I get that <--a href= was chosen because it's necessary to pick something to look for, but like they mentioned, there could be extra spaces, and there could also be things other than spaces between a and href because there can be properties in a link other than its destination (visual, targeting for frames, etc.) and HTML is not all that picky about the order of most things within a tag, so, finding a way to reduce extra spaces would help sometimes but not always. (href being the first property is definitely the usual way and I can't think of any reason to do it differently, but I want to write code that works right to the greatest extent possible even if the input is weird.)

I also get that looking for http:// wouldn't be any more reliable because relative links always leave that off and lots of people don't bother coding it in since most browsers these days will just assume it.

If we want a simple, reliable string to search for, why not use href= ? It has to come just before the URL so it seems to me like it's the ideal thing to look for. No spaces to worry about. No chance of other properties being in the middle. There is a possible side effect in that things that are connected in a different way, like stylesheets, might also get crawled, but if I were planning to take on Google (...ha...), I'd rather be gathering a little extra information than take a chance on missing things.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: That sounds like a good idea to try when we get to crawling multiple links on the same page.

This may come up later in the course, but keep in mind that this course starts from the VERY beginning. It is made for students with no prior programming experience at all. Best practices don't seem to be emphasized just yet.

You can't search for just href because that is used to reference other elements on a page, like images or videos, which in turn can't be properly followed (and shouldn't) by a webcrawler.

The best solution is to use a regular expression, which would then eliminate to problem of improper spacing in the html tags, but that is a bit harder for beginners to do.

Thanks, I hadn't thought of those.

I still think looking for href rather than a href as a starting point would work, but you're right, there would need to be some kind of cleanup step to keep it from following links that wouldn't be productive to follow.
I know. Just sort of free-associating so that those who have similar ideas or are advanced enough to get it can benefit from a chance to talk it out.
... use regular expressions

This is just an example, not an actual ready to use optimal solution. The purpose is to get you acquainted with CS and the code must be working just good enough to get at least some links.

People who want production code use libraries like BeautifulSoup (or write complicated custom parsers, which would be out of this course's scope)--
neither regexes, nor smarter heuristics like your proposed 'http' or 'a href' work reliably, nor can they differentiate comments and javascript from actual 'A' DOM elements.

"

One thing for finding the tag could be to cut it in two. Look for <--a then for href=. This way you skip any tags between the start of the tag and the actual url.

There is a bunch of things we haven't seen yet, like the fact that we probably have to detect and jump over script definitions (javascript/vbscript/..) because it's not supposed to matter etc..
Your point is good, I'm sure it will come.

Maybe go post something in Extra Project Ideas for Overachievers about it. I added something myself along this way.

Edit I just realized it's also a thread you started.. hehe

"
Do you know of a nice and quick tutorial on regexs?

"

@saynotoqwerty, there's Learn Regex The Hard Way which is very good from what I heard and looking over it tends to confirm that.

"

"

Hopefully we'll also be reminded of using 0==exp instead of exp==0 in conditionals &-- all the other ""best practices"" for coding, as we hit those (I've been programming for 'a while' and am learning python here as I use it in CS 373, crash course in python time! LOL) Reason being that if you drop one of the ='s you don't end up with code that (unexpectedly) modifies exp, in C for example you can do this, even when you didn't MEAN to do it.

Good habits are JUST as easy to learn as bad ones, and don't cause you to tear out handfuls of hair at a later date ""If"" (when) something unexpected happens! Uh, well not AS often anyways.

"

Well, one equal sign is always used for assigning a value, two (or more, depending on the language) for evaluation an expression.

0 == exp is identical cu exp == 0 in all the languages I can think of.

I think you get good habits by keeping the rythm the teachers want you to learn, not running faster.

So my suggestion is that if you are not in a hurry, your better have 7 weeks patience and limit exercises to what they have teached you.

Of course later a good programmer needs to investigate, but we are now building the base, that's why -for example- they want us to round a number with using only str() and find()

data-item.data-item-item: I realize that the exersizes can be solved by only using what was told in the lectures, but CAN we use other python mechanisms such as if-then-else other than these explained in the lectures or these will cause our code to be valued incorrect?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It will be accepted, but it's encouraged to do it without them.
I would best only use the knowledge shown in units-- we are surely thousands and i think that our answers are checked automatically. So it's best to make their task easier

OK this is only my opinion but I reckon you'll be risking being penalised, (UK spelling).

Where there is just a specific single answer to a question you'll probably be OK.

But, remember the Udacity team are dealing with potentially thousands of students and so most of the marking will be computer marked - so if you are using advanced techniques the automated marking system may not understand your workings and will give you a fail.

Also I think that in some ways it's more challenging to try and do the tasks without using the more advanced techniques.

"

To add to this answer, @PeterUdacity says that using only what is taught in the course should 'make it more interesting.

"
Definitely no. I've made all the homeworks without using any conditional statements. I'm sure if you put some mental work on it you will be surprised about how simple the solution are.

In Python there seem to always be endless diverse ways of accomplishing almost anything. That's one of the beauties of this language - it conforms to your thought processes rather than forcing your thought processes to conform to it, as with so many other languages...

"

I answered question 9 using only functions from lectures, cause it was elegant and easy solution, but used 'while' and 'if' clauses for answering question 8. Reason was, that when using loop, you can build more universal module (it's useful even when we have infinite number of 'zip'-s on page, not only two). This way, I can use same module in future, not only for resolving one special case and in my opinion, making such universal module forces me to understand more deeply searching principles, than concentrating to some narrow special case.

Cause there is RUN button, you can check your code with different inputs and if results are right, then I expect, that automatic evaluation system accepts this.

Cause I had little spare time, I read Python manuals from python.org and with adding only 3-4 lines to universal module, used for solving Q8, I managed to make search engine for deriving all links from any given web page (for example, http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs101/ has currently 77 links). It takes only 16 lines of code, so Python is really amazing language. It probably against code of ethics to post exact program code to forums, but if you look at python manual about 'urllib2', 'while' and 'if' clauses plus string finding techniques, described in UNIT1, you have all building blocks what you need.

Learning about Python from manual is quite easy for those, who have basic understanding about programming, but getting broader understanding about search engine building principles is more difficult. So I hope, that David and Peter put up some optional materials about topic, that aren't mandatory for those, who want only to learn programming principles, but helps those, who like to understand better searching engines.

"
Yes we can! But we don't want to.
hmmm..i gave up solving it as required :( .. My code works but its awfully convoluted..

"

My solution solves for both values, but I too was stumped and resorted to using an if conditional after the ternary operator x?y:z form was not in Python, which would be out of bounds too. :-(

at least i got a chance to get familiar with documentation

I await learning the answer to rounding just from unit 1 knowledge.

Ohhhh, a puzzle!

5 hours later after sleeping on it....

woohoo I got it! so stupidly simple, no if then, overthinking needed
sometimes we overlook the most simplest of operators...

"

IF not using the proposed function THEN you don't need to take classes. ELSE you can read any Python tutorial and forget CS101 XD

They do this way because they want you to learn thinking, not finding always the easy way.

Can be tedious at the beginning, but it's part of the learning process to understand the basics.

"

Phppt. Python takes Perl's ""There's more than one way to do it"" and flips it around to ""There should be only one way to do it"". Python is flexible because it is a programming language at all-- aside from that, it isn't particularly flexible as compared to most other languages.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I think the yellow dot means it still needs to be checked. I noticed after they added that, it showed most of my videos from the lessons as watched, but the quizzes were all yellow dots. Yes, the yellow dots in the unit quizzes mean there was a mistake in the answer. If you try them again and get them right, it turns into a green tick.

Don't be afraid to try them a few times - the quizzes are to help us see what we don't understand yet :-)

I believe it's a bug. When you complete the quiz correctly it does turn to a green check mark. Then when you continue by hitting next and it shows you the answer video it reverts back to yellow again.

On Tuesday there were no check marks and now they are there but a little buggy.
If you know you have the right answers just refresh the page.
@AnnW Thanks for clarifying the intent. However, as @NoahM notes, there seems to be and issue with the implementation.
I definitely got the same result: A check mark appeared after submitting a correct answer, then changed to a yellow dot after hitting 'next'.
It works, but obviously not on quizzes from prior sessions-- those seems to have to be redone, unfortunately.
But there are some videos whose links have yellow dots against them (and these are not even the videos with quizzes in them). So what to do then?

"

The yellow dot means you pushed ""Next"" to move away from the multiple choice question instead of pushing ""done"" to submit the question. I did that too. You can go back to the yellow dot questions and push ""done"" and it will change to a green check mark.

"
If the yellow dots really bug you, you can answer the question a second time after which the check mark will appear permanently.

if you homework questions have yellow dots next to them then you didn't press the 'DONE' button and your answers were not submitted.

Go back to all the questions with a yellow dot and re-do them making sure to press the 'DONE' button and not just clicking 'NEXT'.

Hat tip to Chris Walker

"

From there, if I just resubmit my answer and move directly to the following lesson instead of rewatching the explanation, the check mark stays.

"
