I found the conclusion to my problem. After completing, I simply forgot to click ""Done"" instead of ""Next"". So it didn't save my answers, even if I got them right. Hope this helps others! Just go back, take it again, and click ""Done"" instead of ""Next""!

data-item.data-item-item: Can you access the interpreter without being at the end of a course module? If so how?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I don't believe you can via this site, but you can find an online interpreter. I suggest using IDEone. You can find it here-- select Python (Python 2 is what's being used in this class so far).

"
If you use a Mac, just launch Terminal.app, then type 'python' and enter. You'll be in a python environment.

"

The best way to do this would be to install Python on your computer. Like GianlucG pointed out, if you have a Mac then Python should come pre-installed. This is also the case with most flavors of Linux. If you're running Windows then the download can be found here.

After installing Python, all you should have to do to run it is open a command line (command prompt on Windows) and type 'python'.

"

"

Installing it locally on your machine would be the best way out if you are on Windows. Linux and Mac have Python pre-installed as stated above.

BUT if you cannot install Python on your computer due to insufficient rights then you can also use:
Portable Python (http://www.portablepython.com/) which helps you run Python without installing it on the system. You can carry it around on your USB stick too.

Happy coding!

"
The hard way to do this would be to install eclipse (classic) with pydev plugin ))

"

The nicest online python console I've found for simple experimentation is repl.it

"

What James said is correct, however in the command prompt in Windows you would either have to be in the python directory or correctly set the PATH variable so that it knows where to location Python. It also comes with IDLE which you can use as well.

"

I've got Debian Linux running in a Virtual Box on my Windows machine. The environment is simple.
Two windows open: one with gedit (text editor), the other is a terminal window.

Type in your python code save it and hop over to the terminal window and enter ""python find_url.py""
(or whatever you called your program when you saved it).

The same setup would probably work for Windows, using notepad++ and the command window, but I'm not sure.

"
If you have google chrome, you can go to their app store and download one of their apps. It runs in browser and on the current webpage. I downloaded python shell, works as need.

Dear Udacity Dev Team,

Fantastic start!

As a Student, I will find it very useful to have the browser Python interpreter accessible from the COURSE CONTENT tab while watching the Course lecture, or doing the Quiz, or doing the homework, since it is a useful way to try out my questions.

Please add this feature request to your backlog

Crab!

I am going to try both Python Shell and Koding which are both available from the Chrome Web Store. I think for this class Python Shell looks like it should suffice for the lecture quizzes and such, but for any projects we might have in this class and outside, Koding looks like it would be a great way to go as it is an online integrated development environment (IDE) with version control among many other attributes with the added bonus of not having to install anything locally as it is a cloud-based development environment (CDE).

data-item.data-item-item: I know currently Udacity offers a certificate in place of credit. But is Udacity working towards accreditation or recognition by colleges to accept Udacity credits? or is that outside the plans for Udacity?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: No. You will receive a certificate of completion at the end of this course, but that's it.
If your school has challenge tests in computer science, you could probably use Udacity to study for them.

There are a number of initiatives in process to recognize academic activity in the form of certificate or badges. It is an exciting time in education. Brick and mortar have their place but in a world of life-long learners many are seeking and developing solution. I believe that MacFound.org granted $2 million to address this issue.

So yes the short answer is no, but exciting developments are afoot in higher education!
^(blank post)

I think it might be a good idea to talk with your Office of Academic Advising or similiarly related Adminstration Office. Here at my college, some students were able to get some credit from the classes by speaking with people here, and showing them what they did. I imagine you might be able to get an intro to computer science credit equivalent if you try! :)

data-item.data-item-item:
I'll start off by saying I found the rounding problem to be a really great learning experience. While it took me quite a while to come up with a working solution using only what was taught in Unit 1, I was finally successful. Fun stuff.

I've seen quite a few comments on the forums of folks that claim to have come up with a 'one line solution' to this problem. My question is, is this really ever necessary or even desirable?

My submitted solution clocks in at a big ole seven lines and, while I can get it down to one line by eliminating the use of any assignment operators, it really becomes unreadable.

What's the use other than bragging rights?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
You could argue that less memory would be used by removing some assignments though considering the amount and complexity of code we're talking about it's a nonissue.

So yeah, just bragging rights I guess. Damn it, I have it on 2 lines, now I need to see how to compact it even more :D
Use the concepts from the lesson titled Grammar to get it down to one line. But yeah it is harder to read.
Always aim for readability over shortness.

I think some people see it as a kind of extra problem to boil it down as far as possible. But yeah, there's a definite tradeoff between flexibility/maintainability on the one side (ease of reading and modifying due to more variables) and elegance/speed on the other side (minimizing the number of lines and variables). Presumably it's useful to be able to do either, depending on the needs of the task and environment at hand.

I too enjoyed this exercise. I've even got some of the other coders in my workgroup working on it in C# using the very basics that we've already discussed here. After about an hour and a half of going around in circles trying to solve this, all I really accomplished was proving to myself how easy it is to overthink a problem. When the actual answer hit me, it really was a facepalm moment. The answer was laughably simple. One thing I've learned tonight is that, when you're faced with extreme limitations on a project, that should be a huge clue to step back and think of simplest, most basic solution first.

My solution, excluding the print, is currently 4 lines. But I do see how I can shorten it to 1 or 2 lines, if I want to. Honestly, I'd prefer the readability to the compactness.

Excellent job on this homework assignment. I hope they all offer as much challenge.

"

I am a newby, it took me 20 lines, but I am within the constraints set. Bragging rights are all mine!! My pile is bigger, nyaa nyaa.

I really don't get the bragging along the lines of ""I already know everything and my code is awesome' but I salute all those that are bragging 'I learned something, and I am coding....awesome'.

Then again, I may just be playing with strings here.

"

"

""One line solutions"" are almost always stupid.

Nowadays it's less than necessary. All the good compilers/interpreters are designed to optimize source code, so avoiding clarity to (try to) gain a few bytes os memory or processor cycles rarely, RARELY is a good option. Let the interpreter/compiler do it for you. I guarantee it will do a better job.

For small programs, with 1.000-10.000 lines of code, maybe it will look like ""elegant"" for inexperienced programmers, but for larger systems, where tens or even hundreds of people are involved somehow, readability saves A LOT OF time, therefore, saves a lot of money...

"

"

I cannot stress how important readability is. You will not realize this until: a) you have to come back and work on
code that your wrote a while ago or b) you have to work on somebody else's
code.

Unless you are trying to win an obfuscation contest or ""my geek is bigger than yours"", there is no prize for writing code in the minimum amount of lines.

"

I could have easily condensed mine to 1 line, but it would have suffered readability.

As I submitted it, I have it on 3, (76 characters, if you count spaces) and I find it as easy to read as English. I personally won't ever be going out of my way to condense it down to one line, unless I feel it's easily readable and understandable that way.

As the code grows, readability and maintainability is much more important.

"

As someone who has had a bit of programming, I as stuck for a while trying to figure out how to do this without an ""if then"" statement. I way over thought this until I sat back and almost literally facepalmed. What a great final quiz. I can see how you can do this in one long line, but I don't see the benefit of it. I think you should optimize your code when you can, but there is a point that it becomes ridiculous.

"

"

Unless you're on a Code-Golf contest, your code should be as readable as possible, and it should be well commented.

"

"

Indeed a couple of 'me too' is needed here... I saw the answer with other functions as well at first, and it's the forum which convinced me to look at it again.. <--3 the forum! hehe

There is a fine divide between readability, maintainability and compactness simply because they all matter.

Havent done it for years but a one-liner using the pipe command is almost an essential part of Unix shell programming. They arent hard to read once you are familiar with the concepts. That is the same as the way we are all now becoming familiar with the concepts of python.

Now when I do html, I like to indent because it allows me to easily see the start and end tags. That makes for easier debugging because I sometimes miss an end tag. The problem with this approach is it makes for a much larger file which is slower to load and consumes more bandwidth. I dont sweat it because my pages tend not to be that big but it can make a difference. The answer is fairly simple though because there are tools that will strip out all leading spaces, tabs and comments before the file is uploaded while keeping the local copy intact. Easy to maintain and more gentle on bandwidth.

I do agree however with everybody who has supported the readability concept because that leads to maintainability. Always remember that any computer program will have bugs and it may not be you that has to fix them. Write in a way that makes it easy for the person that has to pick-up your program to find that little critter. That way, they can more easily see the program logic.

One tip to this

With one exception, always use descriptive variable names that are consistent. For example, cust works as a short form of customer and addr works in the same way for address. Be consistent in your use of either the short form or the full word. Avoid 1 character variable names like the plague.

Well, OK I did say there was an exception. I personally use one character variables for loop control statements. My style perhaps but the purpose is clear because that is the only time I do it. Many others follow the same approach too so it is easy for them to follow my code

OK enough from me on this, hope it is useful

Thanks for this informative post! I had no idea that indenting and other whitespace makes HTML take significantly longer to load -- but I certainly think the tradeoff in readability is worth indenting my HTML.

"

I found a much simpler approach. There is a simple , readable, one line solution. There are at least two approachs to this problem that work for any value, that use only what we learned in unit one. I think I am ready for the next lesson, just going to play with what I have learned for now. I agree, very engaging educational model. Udacstic!

"

Longer code is not necessarily more readable and in general when your code is shorter (but still readable), there is less opportunity to introduce bugs.

I think a short algorithm is often better than a longer one. An algorithm can sometimes believably fit on one line, but still consist of many components, and you could do the exact same thing but with intermediate variable assignments. For instance, let's say Adam, Barbara, Chris and Dan all have 3 apples and Barbara also has a banana. How many pieces of fruit are there?

One ""algorithm"" to solve the question:

nr_fruit = 4 * 3 + 1

Since there are only 2 real operations (one addition and one multiplication), this is probably the shortest algorithm. And here is the exact same algorithm, but using more code:

nr_apples = 4 * 3 nr_bananas = 1 nr_fruit = nr_aples + nr_bananas

Some will argue that this is more readable. I think it depends on the situation. In this case it might be overkill and the shorter code is readable enough and can be read faster. Also, I made a (stupid) mistake in the longer code.

We could also use a slightly longer ""algorithm"":

nr_fruit = 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 1

This has four operations (all additions), which is more than before, but the code is shorter than my second example, so in this case I would probably argue that the longer code is better.

So why do people ""brag"" about having shorter code? I think it's usually because they equate it with having a simpler algorithm, and that is very desirable because it makes the program easier to understand and maintain. In the above example, someone might be proud that they thought to use one multiplication rather than three additions, because it is simply the superior solution: it's both easier to read and write, because it's quite easy to ""miss"" a 3 in the longer algorithm. In the case of homework 1.9, people might be proud that they figured out how to solve it without using if-statements (as Udacity has stated we are supposed to do).

"
Actually, in real life usage, shorter code usually means a more complex algorithm rather than a simpler one.

I did it in one, but submitted it in two for readability.

However, I think the homework is graded by computer, so, ultimately, the only thing you get out of creating a shorter algorithm is bragging rights.

If we were to program a microchip with a limited memory ,lets say kb, then optimization would be useful, using less variables takes less memory.
Initially I soved the homework with 8 lines of code and then after I read the comments of others I went for the challenge of it and did the same thing in 2 lines. I guess that is the learning process that this exercise is supposed to teach us.

The one-line solution/short solution is a different algorithm to the longer versions. Striving to make it short is to try and get that solution rather than the others, not trying to simply get it on one line for the sake of it which is simply stupid.
:) Woohoo i solved in one line. It is not difficult. Just basic elementary school math. 43 characters including 'print ' statement

"

I would actually be interested to see some statistics on HTML whitespaces taking up noticeably more bandwidth. I don't believe that it makes any more impact on filesize or processing time than using <-- strong >-- instead of <-- b >-- does. All HTML interpreters that I've ever known of treat multiple spaces outside of a tag as a single space anyway. They simply ignore anything after the first space and they look for the next tag or content when they render it back to the browser. And even a text document (which is essentially what an HTML file is) with nothing other than 50,000 spaces or tabs is still only about 50kb, around 1 byte per space/tab. Even in the days of coding for dialup on a Pentium 1, that wouldn't cause a huge delay in loading that file. In the modern internet era, even today's dialup speeds wouldn't blink at that.

The only issue I've ever run into with spaces in HTML is when I've done really tight layouts with tables. Inside a <-- td >-- tag, it WILL render an empty space between open/close tags. So

<-- td >--<-- img src=""blah.jpg />--<-- /td >--

won't give you the same as

<-- td >--
<-- img src=""blah.jpg"" />--
<-- /td >--.

If you have two image slices bumped up next to each other in two <-- td >-- cells, making pretty, readable, line-broken code will cause a pixel's worth of headaches. :-)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Please use the markdown syntax for URLs

[text](http://url.com/)

Or enclose the URLs in the preformatted text tag. Otherwise your post won't display

@casssax, you just need to add python to your system environment variable. To do that:

  1. Go to start menu and type system variable
  2. From that list select Edit the system environment variables
  3. Click on Environment Variables
  4. Under System variables, scroll down to Path and double click it
  5. At the end of Variable value add a -- and then type the path to where you installed Python (for example C:\python27) so that it looks like --C:\PythonXX (or whatever your path is)
  6. Accept settings with OK

Now you should be able to CD into the folder where you have your source files (.py) and do python name.py

data-item.data-item-item:
hi, i have figure out how to solve the problem but i just don't now how many digits after decimal point should i use.
Some guy say 1 but since de variable have 5 decimals, i would prefer to use 5 decimal, so whats the best aproach,

example:

should
3.45 be 3 o 4?

what about
3.445, 3 or 4?

thanks

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: The simplest way to solve it does not require a variable for numerical's after the decimal. If you solved this in a similar form as I did initially then 1 decimal place is sufficient.

Do you mean homework problem 9? Homework problem 8 asks us to print the position of the second occurrence of a substring.

Homework 9 also asks us to print a number with no digits after the decimal point. In your example, both 3.45 and 3.445 should give the result 3 while 3.55 should give the result 4.

You just look at only the first digit after the decimal point. If it is 5 or above you round up. If it is 4 or below you round down.

3.45 you look at the 4, as it's below the 5 mentioned above, you get 3
3.445 gives 3
3.5 gives 4 (round up when it's a 5 or above after the decimal)
3.51 gives 4
thanks i will edit it

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Hi Everyone!

My code works...Why is it considered wrong?

I looked at the 'hint video' after receiving the 'wrong' grade and feel like I missed an important point of teaching.

Please explain why my solution is no good.

# Write Python code that assigns to the  # variable url a string that is the value  # of the first URL that appears in a link  # tag in the string page. # page = contents of a web page  page ='<--div id=""top_bin"">--<--div id=""top_content"" class=""width960"">--<--div class=""udacity float-left"">--<--a href=""http://www.xkcd.com"">--'  start_link = page.find('<--a href=')  url = page[start_link:] print url[9:-2]
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

In your code, url takes the value of everything starting from position start_link, not just the URL you're supposed to find.

Also, on the print url[9:-2], what would happen if the entire page string was longer than it is? Would it still print the correct URL or would the -2 point to a position outside of the actual url string?

You need to find a way to save the url text based on a start and end point (you can base your start point on the start_link variable).

Even simpler, your URL is only the text between the first and second "" after the first occurrence of <--a href=

Better said, your code only works on this particular example, but not on a general case, mostly because of the print url[9:-2] part.

"

the question requires the answer to be stored in the url. So for your answer to be scored accurately, you'd have to rewrited the last line as url = url[9:-2]. Regardless of whether you found the correct answer, they won't score it correctly unless you give the answer in their terms. Don't worry, I made the same mistake at first.

"

There is a full explanation of this question here

"

I think you need to make the variable url = to the actual url.

You are getting the correct thing to print by selecting a portion of the string url.

You should be able to just type

print url

And get the correct text to print.

Very interesting.

Thanks for your response.

"

I NOW know that this is not the way they want us to approach this, however I did meet the goal as defined by the quiz.

""Also, on the print url[9:-2], what would happen if the entire page string was longer than it is? Would it still print the correct URL or would the -2 point to a position outside of the actual url string?""

It would print the correct URL.

"

BTW - I am not arguing for credit on the quiz. I believe the course should be updated at some point in order to lead the student towards the desired result. Basically, the quiz goal should be slightly re-defined.

I was genuinely surprised to see that the approach wanted is much different than what I had in mind based on the content of Unit 1.

"

Keyword: variable. Typing, hardcoding, places like ""9"" and ""-2"" is being invariable. That, exactly, was the point to this exercise, understanding that the source vary -- no web page look like another -- so need you code to be. Those two numbers should be replaced by a code, or produce of a code (re: variable) finding the proper places.

"

"

@Michael Jones, no, it would not print the correct URL. To Demonstrate, go here.

Is the URL correct? All I did was to make the entire page string longer.

"
You are right...I am wrong.
Cool, with a new view on the problem you will see the answer differently!
Thanks for the response. You were right...Very helpful to me.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

i used a different method for finding (and getting) the same answer on the final for unit 1.

my question is as follows: is my method so wrong that it will not yield the same results in a similar situation?

here is how i did it:

start_link = page.find('<--a href=')  url_begin = page.find('""',start_link) url_end = page[url_begin:] url = url_end[1:-2]
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
What would happen if the sample page didn't end right after the link you're extracting?

I think they're looking for a solution that will extract only the first target link on the page, no matter where on the page it occurs.

"

OK, first of all, two problems are obvious:

First,

  • url_end = page[url_begin:]

This says that the URL will end at the end of the page string, which isn't entirely correct. The first URL ends at the second appearance of "" after start_link.

Second,

  • url = url_end[1:-2]

What would happen if the page variable was longer? Would your -2 position still correspond to the end of the first URL? No, it wouldn't, so you need to find a way to define url as a string based on the first and second occurrence of "" after the first appearance of <--a href= in the page string.

"

"

The object of this course is to eventually build a search engine, one step at a time. The first step is to create a function that finds links. We will later use a second function that will let us repeatedly use our first function to find the links.


Imagine trying to use your function on a full webpage. You would end up with a ""url"" that extends until the second to last character on the page.


To fix this problem, I would think about the code you used to find the start of the link and do something similar to find the end of the link. (I can't tell you too much more without giving away the answer!)

"

Just summing it up:

Your code only worked for this very special case, in which the url to find is (coincidentally) the last element in page.
In any (other) case your url variable would contain everything from the first link to the end of the page string.

Hi and sorry if this seems like a rant.
also i regret to post this on a public discussion but i tried to use the proper channel
""report a problem/technical"" and the reply from ""Jane"" seemed autogenerated enough to remind
me of Lisa v0.1(TM) --) .

You have taken the bold decision to provide users with a python vm running on your systems.
that's cool. But why don't you try to lock things down a bit? why do we need to have the ability
to import os and io at least at this stage??? and for god's sake why doesn't the whole thing
run in a chroot??? from my short investigation of your system i think you are using sshd to authenticate the generated users of the lessons and you don't give them a tty. but from reading the passwd , i see that we have shells (why?) , and by having the python vm , we essentially have a shell.
also why joakima has his .ssh/authorized_keys files in my /tmp/xxxxxxx ????

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
OMG! I haven't even THOUGHT of looking at that! o.O
But seriously, posting this code is not good...
I fully support your concerns and think they should be addressed! But why for god's sake are you posting that code ???

"

This is very serious. I hope the admins take a notice of this and put the required security measures in place before someone manages to cripple the system.

@PeterUdacity could you please forward this issue to the responsible person? Thank you!

"

"

The system is secure. You may think you have free reign over the system, but it's just an illusion. As it turns out we are security researchers! If you're interested in some of our work you can check out our personal websites. I'd love to talk about it with anyone interested!

Edit - Removed word ""perfectly""-- Changed tone...drastically.

"
Thanks! Didn't mean to sound disrespectful. We were just concerned, that's all. :)
I'm actually very happy you guys are looking out for us! Great stuff!

Computer security is always a good thing.

However....

Openly highlighting a potential problem is a bad thing

By highlighting the potential problems, you have exposed udacity to anyone who is familiar with the same techniques that you are. The reply probably was just an automated response because that is simply a courtesy from any business to say that your message was received. They probably are getting a lot of messages right now with the courses just started.

If you ever spot a security hole in something then report it but dont publicise it because that allows the bad guys to exploit it.

I'm sure the folks at udacity will be onto it soon and get things sorted.

"

well to chill things down a bit --) we must clarify some things:
a) i never said that you have free reign over the system
all i said was that you unneeded access. we are all on the same side here.
b) i know that you are security researchers
c) ""perfectly secure"" doesn't sound professional though.
as we all know os and io (obviously) give you interface to the system below. but you still have to beat that little linux that's running,in order to cause havoc. for someone who knows, that isn't impossible, but neither it is easy. The system seems to be running in a NATed network which should offer some protection against spawning straightforward remote shells and stuff. But i think that it would be possible to upload files there using python+uudecode --). if you can upload files , you could try some local exploit for the system since you have compilers. also, having /proc there isn't the best idea, that's why if was trying to implement this service i would go for a BSD system 100%.(no flamewar intended/just personal taste.)

so if nobody has done anything like that yet, if the system is patched and we are lucky enough that no bad guy has any 0day exploits for udacitys system , we are all pretty safe... at least let's hope that this discussion introduced new users to security concepts. :) cheers guys.

"

Sure! Would have been great if there was some other channel, but I don't see any other way to let the guys at Udacity know that there is a problem by doing anything other than posting a message on the forum.

I really can't go into details about our infrastructure, but I will say the system that you are seeing is completely virtualized. The worst you could do is prevent yourself from getting the solution correct. It would probably take a couple 0-days to really compromise the system. You would be better off selling those on the black-market for a couple million.

"

@PeterUdacity Why did you say ""The system is perfectly secure"", when this is impossible to prove and you have just thrown the gauntlet down for all the hackers?

"
You're right. It's provably impossible to prove an arbitrary system is secure. It's a problem reducible from the halting problem. Anyway I was just trying to calm everyone down.
Why the -1's. This is important, don't shoot the messenger. Yes it could have been handled better, but so what, issue might need to be fixed
The code is still there, looking at revisions shows the piece of code that was removed from the current revision, I suggest you remove it before someone does something dangerous with it.

thanks mate, i removed it.
anyway i think that somebody who has the potential to harm the system
should find the code more than trivial
and somebody who needs the code can't harm the system --).
a perfect mutex --). thanks for pointing it out though.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Watching young children use the Udacity environment I have noticed a user interface complexity

When you are using the built in Python engine, it uses popups on the top of the editor window to show messages

They have a close box on them so they appear ""modal"" and the young users expect to have to close them by clicking on the [x]

They are thankfully not modal, but do cause some unnecessary mouse movement, and therefore potential loss of thought processes

They could be improved by these two options

  • Fading away after some time, or when another action is performed
  • Having the close box only appear if you hover your mouse over the status box area

Also, the status messages could be down on the same line as the ""next"" button

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: That's a good idea. We are going to be reworking notifications in the near future.

"

The forum actually is for anything related to the course. It just happens to be that the system we are using is oriented to questions. We tried to make this clear in the FAQ, but we could do a better job.
We encourage sharing creative ways to solve problems!
Python is especially amazing in the large number of ways one can accomplish almost any task. I'm often amused seeing ways I hadn't considered of doing something. Often very clever ways at that!
I remember the professor mentioning in one of the lectures that restricting ourselves to a limited tool palette will encourage really cool solutions.
I looked carefully at the question, and I can't see where capitalization is an issue at all. Neither word we were given contains a capital letter, nor is one asked for.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

After we finish each unit's homework, we have nothing to do until the next unit is published. For those who would rather not wait, let's brainstorm a list of ideas here so that those who have the time and inclination can pick the ones they like and do them ""as an exercise for the reader.""

Suggested ideas need not be possible using in-course techniques up to this point, because overachievers are willing to look things up. However, they should require only techniques which someone with only this course up to this point as background could be expected to figure out from a reference manual.

Suggested ideas are fair game for the Udacity teachers to yoink and offer as extra exercises to future classes.

My ideas so far:

  • Extend rounding, using the approach from the solution to Homework 1.9, to other decimal places.
  • Extend rounding, using the approach from the solution to Homework 1.9, to given numbers of significant figures.
  • Make a list of basic conversion factors, in the form of variables with assigned values (such as centimeters_per_inch=2.54). Use these basic conversion factors to calculate lesser-known conversion factors such as square_centimeters_per_acre=[I really have no idea] and convert some real-world measurements into other units.

More ideas are absolutely welcome. If this thread is successful I'll post similar threads after future units (unless someone beats me to it).

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Some of my ideas:

  • Use string indexes to reverse a given string, e.g. ""udacity"" becomes ""yticadu""

  • Write a program which works out how many rolls of wallpaper you would need to paper a room, given the area of the walls and the dimensions of each roll. Remember that even if you use an inch of the last roll, it still counts as a whole one!

  • We know the speed of light and the distance traveled for a given time period from a previous lesson. Calculate how many metres light would travel in a year. The nearest star to our sun is approximately 4.2 light years away from us - how many kilometres is this?

  • Write a program to convert Fahrenheit to Celsius (note: I don't take credit for this idea!)

  • We've been taught how to print out information. Research how to accept input from the user and write a program which asks for their name, then their age. Print this information out in the following format: ""First Name Last Name (Age)"". For extra credit, format it like: ""Last Name, First Name (Age)""

"

@fnenu that would be the second idea in the question, i.e significant digits. I think the first one is for numbers with greater than or equal to 10. Though I might be wrong, but then 1 &-- 2 are redundant

"

Significant figures round to a certain number of places counting from the first non-zero digit where as decimal places round to a certain number of places after the decimal point.

For example. 358273.235 is 360000 to 2 significant figures but is 358273.24 to 2 decimal places.

Another example, 0.0358273235 is 0.036 to 2 significant figures but is 0.04 to 2 decimal places.

Well I decided to look things up a bit and ponder what's next, then dive in.

There is a pastebin of what I cooked up trying to dissect an URL into 3 distinctive parts:
- The protocol (http/ftp/..)
- The site (www....)
- The path (whatever follows the site)

I figured:
- An http crawler won't follow ftp urls right?
- When links are found relative to the site, it'll need the site right?
- Then there is the path, which I'm not sure it will need by itself

Anyhow, it's a start, beyond the current content (functions and if's, not too fancy) but people can see how indentation is important in Python.

data-item.data-item-item: s[1] and (s+'ity')[1] should be the same value, since if there is s[1] no meter what you add to the s string s[1] will be always the same.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: if s='' its not the same!

"

Yes, so if s has a position s[1] (ie, it has 2 or more characters), then s[1] and (s + 'ity"")[1] will return the same value.

s = ""twelve"" s[1] returns ""w"" (s + 'ity')[1] returns ""w""

However!

If s has fewer than 2 characters, then these two expressions won't return the same value.

So if:

s = ""a"" s[1] will return an error (because there's no s[1]) (s + 'ity')[1] will return ""i"".

Hope that helps to clarify.

"

current on Question #3 of the homework.

""Which of the following sequences of statements leaves the value of variable x the same as it was before the statements""

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Hi,

its not a1x = x1a

its a,x = x,a

And if you figure out what a,x = x,a doing there will be no problem understanding why it is done twice

Read this:

*Multiple Assignment*
We can put more than one name on the left side of an assignment statement, and a corresponding
number of expressions on the right side:

<--Name1>--, <--Name2>--, ... = <--Expression1>--, <--Expression2>--, ..

All of the expressions on the right side are evaluated first. Then, each name on the left side is
assigned to reference the value of the corresponding expression on the right side. This is handy for
swapping variable values. For example,

s, t = t, s

would swap the values of s and t so after the assignment statement s now refers to the previous
value of t, and t refers to the previous value of s .

"

copy and paste this into a python console (here's an online one: repl.it)

x = 'x' a = 'a'  print 'x = ' + x print 'a = ' + a print '\n'  a,x = x,a  print 'x = ' + x print 'a = ' + a print '\n'  a,x = x,a  print 'x = ' + x print 'a = ' + a
"
my god I though it was a 1 and not a comma that makes way more sense now thanks

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I am studying young children using the Udacity environment, and there appears to be a lack of quiz (exercises) depth

They are familiar with Khan Academy. In Khan you do a few exercises on one topic, and if you get any wrong you get more until you show mastery of the subject. Effectively there is only 100% as a pass mark

Could Udacity quizzes have more than one problem per topic, and if you get it wrong, present more problems?

I understand this is more complex for Python than for standard mathematics, but for most quizzes something should be possible

e.g. For ""Capital Udacity"" there could be more tests for combining strings and taking parts of different stings by index

This could be an option for younger participants, whom thrive well on simple repetition, and may have less general knowledge to carry them through the tricky bits. Adults may be more inclined to just ""get it"", and move on quickly

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Practice, practice, practice! I agree completely.

I love what Udacity is doing here, and this class as their initial run is great so far, but it also seems as though they are still putting some of the pieces together yet. I wouldn't be surprised to see this course offered again down the road and it to be much more polished. Think of us enrolled in this initial class as a beta focus group, testing it out, giving feedback and hopefully improving it for those down the line, or those of us who choose to take it again.

First write the automated test like Khan and then do the video so that the students can show that they can pass 10 out of 10 randomized assignments.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Things are going well on the final homework. While testing my solution I wanted it to be robust enough to meet the requirement for ""all"" decimal numbers. I have found the str(number) function works well until the interpreter runs into scientific notation.
Up to and including 11 digits before the decimal, str(number) works perfectly
With 12 digits before the decimal, str(num) actually does the rounding
**With 13 or more digits before the decimal, str(num) shifts to scientific notation as the string

In addition to assuming no negative numbers may we also assume no numbers with more than 11 digits before the decimal?

Thank you, J

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
You can actually fix that in a regular python interpreter though it's a bit of a more involved procedure and can't be done on the web interface this website uses.

In short it involves defining a subclass of float which would have an overridden __str__ method built to display the number the way you want.
We'll test the submission on numbers no larger than 10,000. But I'd love to see your robust solution once the answers are released.

Let me say this again: This homework has been truly an eye-opener.

So much face-palming... Now my face hurts. Badly.

Scientific notation does not have to break things, it can be shown as it is. Using only given tools. Took me only three days too:)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Hi Prashant -- unclear exactly what you are referring to. Could you give the number the quiz is assigned in the Unit I list?

The program will present an error. This is because 'minutes' was never actually defined with an integer or string. So for 'seconds' to be defined with 'minutes' means you cannot solve for 'seconds'.

To make it simpler, think of it like an algebra problem.

Solve for y:

y = x * 60

So, if I don't give you the value of x, you can't solve for y. i.e. 'Error'

Hope that helps.

Ian
Also, you can view explanation video if clicking Next button.

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi

I been writing Python for a year (Django webapps), but I never found a good resource for writing code with TDD/Unit-tests. I thought this 101-course might be a cool place to start over and work on my Python foundations.

One thing I really would like to know, is for example how I as a developer would start writing tests for these simple problems in Unit 1? Could anyone give me an/some examples how that would look like and how you think about TDD when you program? How could you think about TDD from a total beginners perspective?

I thought it would be cool to see how it would look for these simple tasks in this first unit. Hoping there is some python nerd out there who can give examples.

-- Cheers!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I don't know how someone can do TDD without even knowing how to define a function.

I think TDD can be presented later, when people have a better grip on the basics, since this is a course for people with absolutely no programming background.

well it seems like allot of people here has SOME python skills or knows some other languages. So I know writing defs would scare the absolute beginner, but for people who come from other languages who do understand methods, I guess writing a test could help them get it right from the start. I know I wish I did.

"

for students who understand a little bit more python, here is a great intro I finally found after some searching: http://blog.extracheese.org/2009/11/how_i_started_tdd.html

"

In all honesty, all the exercises so far haven't been so complex in order to do TDD on them. You'd waste more time writing test cases (with concepts that people who just started programming won't understand - remember, this is a 101 course, which means introduction to) to test only a line of code.

Maybe TDD could be implemented later in the modules, but right now I don't see any sense to use it.

thanks for your reply, well that is exactly why I asked. I dont know when it IS apropriate to use it --) In all honesty, I would guess most people here are not total beginners to coding so allot of people would understand simple tests if somebody actually wrote them and explained why/how it is done. It would be fun to get some data on how many are totally new to programming. Cheers
@mikaofsweden yes, a lot of people do have python skills, but that doesn't mean everybody does, not to mention that the target audience of the course is absolute beginners.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

""write Python code that prints out the nearest whole number to x."" I know that it is little silly question but I believe that nearest whole number to 4.5 will be 5... Is it right? I don't want to loose points because of this.

P.S. sorry for my english

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: As mathematical rules say, 0.5 should be rounded to 1. So, if you have smth like 26.5 you code should print 27 as a result.
It's right. If the first decimal digit is 5 or greater, it rounds to the next integer (4.5=5, 0.5=1, 28.8=29). If it is 4 or lesser, it rounds to the former integer (4.4=4, 0.4=0, 28.2=28).
Definitely round up from 0.5 to 1.
That's because explicitly typecasting to int truncates, ignoring the decimals. It doesn't round.
@8765004, if you want to round using a function then you should use round() and not int, which does something totally different.
There is a funny trick for creating a round function : round(x)=(int)(x+0.5)

"

@Cnudde, actually that would return false because round(x) returns a float while (int)(x+0.5) returns an integer.

But if you wanted to say that round(x) can be achieved by adding 0.5 to a number then yes, you're right.

"

"

As a matter of fact, there are mathematical rules stating that 0.5 should be rounded to 0 (and there are also rules stating otherwise). It all depends on what tie-breaking rule you pick, which is merely a convention.

This is already discussed here.

"
Yes, I was thinking generally and usually, when you want to round a decimal number, it is often to get an integer in the end !
...math makes me crazy sometimes. :)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Remember that Python comes pre-installed with MaxOSX. As an IDE you could install X-Code from the MacOSX DVD install, but I think this would be too much for such a simple purpose. Try textwrangler from Bare Bones Software. It's free, and you can get it from the mac app store.

"

A quick choice is to install Komodo Edit, which is a free and open source code editor that works on Mac, Windows and Linux and integrates nicely with Python.

"

I personally LOVE Sublime Text 2! I'm learning a lot more languages outside Python, and Sublime supports them all and has many polished features and optional plugins to pick from.

Now the bad part, it's $60, but if you just want basic features there are loads of other IDEs.

Aquamacs: OS X port of Emacs. Very popular program, but a big learning curve in my opinion. Free.
MacVim: OS X port of Vim. Another very popular program, but an even bigger learning curve, again in my opinion. Free.
CodeRunner: Available in the Mac App Store for $10, has good feature set and built in compiler.
Coda: $100! WOW! Aimed at professional web development. Very nice feature set and plugins. The CSS previewer and built-in terminal are great.

All of them have trials, except for CodeRunner, that I encourage you to try out. I have a multitude of IDEs installed at the moment that I'm trying out. So far Sublime Text 2 looks like the winner for me. My trial is up soon, and I think I'm ready to put down the $60.

Using Sublime Text 2 on Windows here, and at least on Win there's no limit for the trial-- at some point there's a pop-up asking you to buy it but you can just click on OK and it won't bug you again for some time.

With that said, I went ahead and bought it as the license is per user so you can install it on as many PCs as you own, and it's a really really good editor.

data-item.data-item-item:
Does it matter if the result of homework 9 is a number as a string,
or does it have to be a real number?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

You need to print the result. So it doesn't matter what it will be. And I guess that you will use new function ""str()"" :))

"

If you do it by respecting the requirements of only using concepts discussed in Unit 1 then the only thing you'll be able to print is a string.

Otherwise you can print either a number of a string, so it's really up to you.

"

This is actually a very interesting question because of the way Python's print statement works. The difference is subtle, but important. If you read the documentation for the print statement, you'll notice that is states that anything that isn't a string is converted to a string and then gets written to the standard output.

What this implies is that whether you cast a number to a string is irrelevant because as soon as you type print 9 (where 9 is the integer 9, not a the string '9'), 9 gets converted to a string before it is written to standard output.

"
As the 'print' statement automatically converts numbers to strings before output, I don't think it matters.
Thanks for your help! I think I have the right solution for the homework. I'm keen to get those two gold stars!
Thanks for all the suggestions.....finally I figured it out!
the instructions are, print only 3 (NOT 3.0) it means integer number on string format

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Just for the curious...

Try these two values for x in the python web console. Do your solution show the ""expected"" result?

x = 0.499999999999 x = 0.4999999999999

Floating Point Arithmetic: Issues and Limitations

I hope David and Sebastian are not as accurate --)

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
using the exercise guidlines i do get the expected result no matter what the number will be, if on the other hand you want 100% accurate math then none of my results are any good, but that wasnt the assignment...or should ill go check :D

edit yeah it does :p
NIce. I would like to know why it does that!

oops with 12 9s it doesnt...

i'd like to know why that happens as well

Edit not to take more space : did someone define a full unit say 1m as 0.999999999999 or something?

"

You can find a nice explanation of the multiple errors that take place when using large number in the Why computers suck at math article on TechRadar.

"

Well, I'll try my best without going into details...

Python (and other languages) uses a fixed length format to represent floats (usually 32 or 64 bits, simple or double precision). So the problem comes when you try to squeeze an infinitely real numbers (think about the different real numbers in between 0 and 1!) into a finite number of bits. It requires an approximate representation, such an internal rounding --).

So, internally, you have this:
0.4999999999999 == 0.5

"

Python Floating Point Tutorial

The number stored is an approximation of the value 0.4999999999999 and not the exact value. This is because most decimal fractions can not be represented exactly as binary fractions, as such it is stored in memory as the closest approximation as can be accomplished given the limitation.

"

"

These rounding problems which result from using the binary representation (...100101110...) of decimals can cause some trouble in bank transactions ( and banks are poor these days :-) ). So there are many people researching about ""true decimal"" computations processors to eliminate these rounding errors.
See, for instance, this paper and its references, in case you are interested.

"
Yep, if you need something that represents float exactly (i.e., banks), maybe something like [decimal][http://docs.python.org/library/decimal.html].
This thread illustrates one of the nice features of this class: you can learn many nuances just by reading the forums. For me at least, it's as valuable as the actual course work.
Thanks much for that link, Fuzzmz. Some very interesting reading there for us more mathematically challenged folk!

data-item.data-item-item: how to assign more than one line to avariable in python

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Do you mean more than one line to a string variable? If so, try this:

s = ""Line 1\nLine 2"" print s
"

"

Because Python uses whitespace to delimit code blocks you can't actually assign more than one line to a variable. By this I'm thinking of something like:

random = ""This is a bit of random text           that returns an error""

Now, if you want to add new lines of text to a string then you need to use the \n operator, as @saksham said, which basically tell Python that everything if that string will be printed, everything following \n should be on a new line..

"

"

The above line is kind of long -- suppose you want to break it into separate lines. You cannot just split the line after the '%' as you might in other languages, since by default Python treats each line as a separate statement (on the plus side, this is why we don't need to type semi-colons on each line). To fix this, enclose the whole expression in an outer set of parenthesis -- then the expression is allowed to span multiple lines. This code-across-lines technique works with the various grouping constructs detailed below: ( ), [ ], { }.

**# add parens to make the long-line work: text = (""%d little pigs come out or I'll %s and %s and %s"" %

(3, 'huff', 'puff', 'blow down'))**

gleaned from the google 2 day python course

"

"

@fjordcarver, please take note that indentation is important, and also that the new line must start with a grouping construct

text = (""%d little pigs come out or I'll %s and %s and %s"" %   (3, 'huff', 'puff', 'blow down'))

will work, but

text = (""%d little pigs come out   or I'll %s and %s and %s"" % (3, 'huff', 'puff', 'blow down'))

won't work.

Neither will:

text = (""%d little pigs come out or I'll %s and %s and %s"" % (3, 'huff', 'puff', 'blow down'))
"

"

""""""There's also this

special syntax for

strings on

multiple lines""""""

'''Triple apostrophe strings

also work

on several

lines too'''

"

I don't think we are supposed to directly answer HW questions. To late now though :)
I don't think that was a direct answer to homework and it was quoted directly from the reference.

What it does is takes the variables x,a and assigns them to the variables a,x.

You can assign multiple variables at a time in this way. For example

>-->-->-- a, b, c = ['dogs', 'cats', 69] >-->-->-- a 'dogs' >-->-->-- b 'cats' >-->-->-- c 69

So if you start at a = 1 and x = 5 then
a,x = x,a would assign the x(5) to the a, and the a(1) to the x.

After running this, a would be 5, and x would be 1.

Again, you can test this in an interpreter by running the code like so:

>-->-->-- a = 1 >-->-->-- x = 5 >-->-->-- a 1 >-->-->-- x 5 >-->-->-- a, x = x, a >-->-->-- a 5 >-->-->-- x 1
You didn't give me the answer to the quiz question, so we're good --)

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Sorry, computer science pros, but I am very new to programming, and I have two very simple questions that may appear ridiculous to you.

I'm a little confused about the terminology and the wording of Question 3:

1) If variables are names, and they cannot be integers,

should the last part of Question read, more precisely: ""Assume that both a and x IN THE RIGHT PART OF THE STATEMENT refer to integer values before this code""?

2) In the statements below, variable x does not appear in the beginning of the code. It comes up only in the last statement, so that you cannot compare the x in the beginning of the code to the x in the end.

Does it mean that these statements should be completely discarded for comparison:

  • a=x-- a=a+1
  • a=x-- x=a
  • z=x-- a=z-- x=a

Thank you.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You should assume that the variables have already been defined for this quiz. I think most people probably assumed that, but you're right that it was not explicitly explained.

Hello,

  1. just assume that all of them were
    assigned before. left and right.
  2. i think this is the same as #1

"

Variables can be anything, that's why they're named variable --) For example, if you assign a variable the value 3, then that variable will be an integer, if you assign it the value ""hello"" it will be a string, if you assign it value 3.4 it will be a float and so on.

As for point 2, you need to evaluate if x stays the same no matter what values a, x and z have. Also, you need to see if x remains the same for each one of the options, so it doesn't matter what value x and a have in the first option because they could have another value in the last one.

In short, think of something like:

If a is 1 and x is 0 in the first example, does x remain 0 after doing a = x and a = a + 1? And so on for all the other options.

"

This description what is trying to clarify is that both variables (x and a) are already initialized with an integer value ( no matter what the value).
What is asked is to see which options where the original value of the variable x is unchanged, even after execute that code.

I think part of your confusion is regarding variables and part regarding the = operator. A variable can contain any value and is not restricted to only strings. Also in python the = operator does not mean equals or do a comparison, but rather assigns a value. Think of the = sign as an insert or <--- instead of an = sign.

In this particular question the variables a and x both represent and integer value regardless of what side of the = they are on. So if we assume x is 1 the statement a=x assigns the value of x to a and a now equals 1.

To clarify using an example above.

  • z=x-- a=z-- x=a
  • z=x sets the value of z to the value of x
  • a=z sets the value of a to the value of z (so a is not equal to both z and x)
  • x=z sets the value of x to the value of a (and since a equals z and z equals x x now equals itself making this answer true)

Hope this helps

Thank you very much, friends,

your explanations have been very helpful to me.

"

@kpowney, in your last bullet point, I believe you meant to type x=a sets the value...., not x = z

"

data-item.data-item-item: In the last question of homework 1 i.e, rounding of numbers, what should be the rounding of 3.5 ? Is it 3 or 4 ?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I added a clarification to the question (we won't test that), but most round functions will round 3.5 to 4.

This has been asked several times.
.5 rounds up

"

4

0,1,2,3,4 = 0
5,6,7,8,9 = +1

which-number-are-nearest-to-35

"

.5 can't be assumed to be rounded up. It depends on the tie breaking rules for the given application.

Sometimes it's rounded down.

This is why it needed to be clarified.

That said, I personally assumed to round up, and python's own round() function rounds this up.
I know there are other rounding rules but in this case .5 rounds up. implementing other rounding rules would make the program a bit harder.

"

Indeed, and I agree with you. I'm just stating that without clarification, there was no way of knowing what ""in this case"" was.

The people who have asked the question (several times) have valid questions. It can't be assumed.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
OK, so obviously, commenting one's code is considered good practice in software engineering -- but should we provide comments on our code in our homework, to clarify what we have done, prove that we understood what's going on, etc.?

Or is the homework all automatically graded, such that only the code they're looking for is acceptable, such that commenting my code could actually get me marked incorrect?

-K

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I have no doubt that the homework will be graded automatically. Also the Questions weren't that complex for the comments to be necessary.
I like to add comments it may make it easier to understand, should I read my code a few years hence..

Judging by PeterUdacity's posts on the forum, your comments will be ignored and they shall not add or deduct anything from your grade.
Nevertheless, comments are a great way for a programmer to comprehend quirky code months or even years after it was written. So whenever you feel like adding a comment, don't hesitate to do so :)

(That was all generally speaking, the level of the HW1-code doesn't really require adding comments).

Yeah, I didn't mean for this specific homework, in terms of needing comments, as obviously nothing was especially complicated -- I meant more from a standpoint of whether commenting the code would cause the auto-grader to break.

Thanks for the answer!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I would imagine that Udacity has created a piece of software to extract the code and test it on a variety of input. Of course, this is all speculation. Perhaps @PeterUdacity will have a better answer.

Did you see the warnings in some of the assignments to put all your code below a certain point in the file?

#ENTER CODE BELOW HERE #ANY CODE ABOVE WILL CAUSE #HOMEWORK TO BE GRADED #INCORRECT

Presumably they will just get your code below that point, prepend it with different input and automatically run it. This is fairly easy in an interpreted language like Python. I bet they just have a whole bunch of test input-output pairs that they run against each contribution. Since Udacity employees have said on multiple occasions that you can use any code you like as long as you don't import anything, I'm fairly sure this is the way in which our work will be graded.

It has to!
Nothing else would provide a way to test our solutions. And they will surely run a lot more test values (e.g. <--3.5>--, <--0.01>-- etc. in this case) than shown in the description...

data-item.data-item-item:
Truly enjoyed the course content and Udacity's way of presenting!
After Unit 1, i thought 'programming' is .... much like teaching a machine how to think human, in its own language. What is your idea of defining programming?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
From Wikipedia:

Computer programming (often shortened to programming or coding) is the process of designing, writing, testing, debugging, and maintaining the source code of computer programs. This source code is written in one or more programming languages. The purpose of programming is to create a set of instructions that computers use to perform specific operations or to exhibit desired behaviors. The process of writing source code often requires expertise in many different subjects, including knowledge of the application domain, specialized algorithms and formal logic.

This seems like a good, formal definition to me.
To fix or set the program for a series of activities to a particular purpose.

data-item.data-item-item:
I have a new question for you clever folks who understand floating point numbers, etc. better than I do.

I have observed some (to my eyes) strange behavior in my Python interpreter of choice -- the one accessible from the Terminal on a Mac.

Any time I type in an integer, and store it in a variable, then call the variable again, it presents me with the same stored value I put in, as expected.

Here is an example. I type:Â Â Â Â Â x = 4

storing 4 into the variable x.

Then, when I type in:Â Â Â Â Â x

the interpreter presents me with:Â Â Â Â Â 4

So far, so good, right?

BUT WAIT!

Say instead that I type:Â Â Â Â Â y = 5.4

(ostensibly) storing 5.4 into the variable y.

Now, when I type in:Â Â Â Â Â y

the interpreter presents me with:Â Â Â Â Â 5.4000000000000004

What's going on here? This is especially confusing because when I try out: Â Â Â Â Â y*4

which should yield the value 21.6 (if y were 5.4), or 21.6000000000000016 (if y were actually 5.4000000000000004).

Instead, the interpreter offers up: Â Â Â Â Â 21.600000000000001

This makes no sense! The digit 1 is appearing as the 15th digit after the decimal point, but if it were being rounded off, that digit should be a 2. (Which of course, still doesn't explain where those extra digits came from in the first place....!)

So, something funky is going on, but I'm not sure what! PLEASE EXPLAIN THE FUNKINESS!

-K

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Krishna -- I think it has something to do with decimals and floats in Python and how these are handled by any particular flavor of Python. I think it has to do with number of places Python will spit out. (I mean there has to be a limit for some numbers that could go on forever.) Beyond that, I haven't the foggiest idea!

"

The answer can be found here:
Python Floating Point Issues1

It's basically a limitation on the way a computer represents floating point numbers. There's only so much accuracy you can get when you're trying to represent a decimal number but storing them as fractions.

"

"

This weird behavior is due to the internal representation that Python (and other languages) uses to store floats.

You can find a good explanation here:
Floating Point Arithmetic: Issues and Limitations

BTW: If you want to see more 'weird' related stuff check this out: Going into HW9 in depth

"

"

Ha. It seems my initial guess that this has ""something to do with floating point numbers"" was somewhat accurate. I checked Wikipedia out for info on floating point numbers and got some useful info. It seems that this is a way to calculate operations involving real numbers more quickly, at the expense of some precision.

When doing so, the system can store and work with a much larger range of numbers, by reserving one digit to serve as a ""radix"" (this is like an index that tells the system how many digits are significant).

That said, I'd still appreciate an explanation that goes into more depth, if someone can provide one that is more accessible (read: LESS technical). I'd offer up some ""karma"" for it, as I'm pretty interested in this.

"

"

In the standard internal representation of numbers in computers, which follows the IEEE 754 norm, the smaller number eps such that 1.0+eps != 1.0 is around 10E-16, which is consistent with the ""inaccuracies"" shown by the poster. If Python truncated the number of decimal digits, that would not be apparent.

JA

(corrected bug: 10E-6 was to be 10E-16...)

"

"

Interesting! So it seems that the Mac Python interpreter doesn't round the digits off, displaying the ""illusory"" answer that the above document references, but displays it in much more detail. This is a great document, and explains a lot more about floating point numbers. I'll read it fully (and I recommend others do as well, if y'all are interested).

10 points to you, @dreyescat!

"
Thanks, Mike! You ALSO get 10 points, since your attempt at posting the identical link was in some way stymied by the system!
isn't bribery against the student code of conduct? just kidding :)

In case you didn't catch it, in the FAQ they recommend this wiki site. There is a ton of stuff on there.

"

If you have any prior programming experience (with another language) I'd recommend Dive Into Python. Otherwise, two popular books are Learn Python the Hard Way and How to Think Like a Computer Scientist.

In addition to the books I might recommend Salmon Khan's Computer Science videos. I don't personally have experience with these but I've watched plenty of other videos on KhanAcademy and definitely recommend you check them out. As a side note to anyone doing CS373: If you need a refresher on probability, check these videos out!

"

"

Major props to How to Think Like a Computer Scientist. The great thing about that book is that there are little exercises in the chapters so you understand how the parts relate into a whole.

OpenCourseWare for MIT also has a class called Intro to Computer Science, not unlike this course. An online forum lists the recommended books and many are downloadable as free PDFs.

The resources and Q&--A page is also plenty helpful, and maybe useful if you want to approach Python from a different angle.

Hi,

For those (like me) without any prior knowledge of Python or computer programming, I would point out this free book: Invent Your Own Computer Games with Python (search google to download a free copy). There is also a print version available at Amazon (see the reviews at Amazon).

It's a simple, entertaining and meticulously detailed book (learning doing style). Concepts are fully and repeatedly explained until the smallest detail. Al Sweigart, the author of this book is a great guy.

"

One of my favorites has always been ""Invent Your Own Computer Games in Python"" by Al Sweigart. The author walks you through several small games while explaining Python. There are paid versions of the book as well as a free, older version of the book online.

data-item.data-item-item:
I think I've managed to understand the other questions, but I don't know where to even start with question 9. What am I missing?

Thanks for all the help, but I'm crap at math. I'm feeling really stupid right now.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
That question is designed to be harder than the others. I would review the things we learned in Unit 1 and try to see how you could use those on a decimal number to find the solution.

It will probably take a few lines of code.

You will definitely need to use the str() function, too, that is explained in the preceding video.

If I may suggest, take a few minutes break and let your brain silently think about the question.

I have no prior experience whatsoever in python, and at first I was also absolutely clueless and I just wanted to smash my keyboard with a hammer.
And then suddenly it hit me, and I started to laugh stupidly for missing out on something so easy, that took me only 1 line of code.

To sum it up: don't give up --)
I recommend you learn about Python's built-in functions. This is outside the scope of what has been taught, but it is important to know what these are.
Does it really need NO if-else statements to solve the question?

You don't need any functions that weren't covered in the lessons (except the str(<--number>--) that's introduced in the Homeworks video). My suggestion: think for a minute about how rounding decimal numbers work before even bothering with any code.

It turns out the exercise wasn't that hard at all in the end.
First I had a hard time too solving this without the if statement or any other non taught Python functions.

In the end it only takes the str() function and little bit mathematical thinking.

At least I hope I got it right :D

All homework require only what we've learned in unit 1 (together with the str function of course).
Hence, no need for if statements.

I hope this is not violating the Honor Code in anyway, but all you need to solve this question is:

  • the addition operator +,
  • the indexing operator [],
  • the find function, and
  • the str function.

Hope this helps :)

"

Yes, and the complete solution can be less than 30 characters long !
It's tricky, but once you'll have the solution, you will say ""Wow ! That was so simple !""

"

"

Think about how you can manipulate the original number to get the result you want using basic arithmetic.
You can do it without any conditional statements. The program doesn't need to do any decision making.

Now I know what a Eureka feeling is like. I can't stop feeling stupid for spending over 4 hours banging my head around while the solution was staring me right in the face.
Think simple, and focus on the mathematics instead of the code-- Once you figure out he maths, it indeed is a small one line solution and doesn't need any if/else or inbuilt functions.
My advice: don't over-think it. If you find yourself trying to account for error conditions with if/else etc., find a simpler solution.

I've deleted a comment here that explained step by step how to solve the homework problem. Question 9 is a starred problem, meaning that it is a challenge and not all students are expected to solve it. Please allow other students the chance to solve problems-- in our experience we find simply looking up an answer brings very little value to the student. In the future I'll just edit the post, but I accidentally clicked the delete button. I apologize for that.

Use normal problem solving skills

  • Breakdown the problem in to small steps
  • Use diagrams to show the limits of the problem (what does the question mean to you)
  • List all your current problem space knowledge (Python commands)
  • Assume a simple answer, no new commands required, no cheating etc.

I agree with coldbones I just woke up at 6 am local time suddenly with the answer after ruminating on it for two days . I have to say I am loving this course so far, totally not my field and I feel privileged to be learning from such experts for free. I hope this is the future of education.
my dilemma is how to change a string back to an integer..
do u mind sharing how you solved..

You don't need to do that for this assignment. However, if you want to there is a function int(). It works just like str(). You pass it a number in string form and it will return it as an integer that you can manipulate with with normal math operators.

(bah, removed the example I gave because it doesn't format properly in a comment. I'd have to use a reply)

But this problem can be solved without using anything new.
Why would you want to change the string back to an integer? If you really want to do it, it's by using the int() function.
I used two built in python functions, only took me 100 milliseconds to figure out.
But the fun is to get it to work without built-in functions, and only using what has been taught in Unit 1 :D
Me too at first. Then when I came and read the forums and saw the instructors asking us to try to do it with only the concepts they taught us, I went back and redid it.

Yeah, I just thought this assignment was different were they wanted us to find new ways to solve the answer, but I guess I will have to go back as well and use the combination of new concepts and what we've learned thus far, thanks for pointing that out.

You don't need any new concepts at all.

You can do it using ONLY the few concepts already convered. (Variable assignment, string indexing, find(), str() and print )

There's no need for conditional statements, round(), etc. The solution doesn't require the program to do any decision making.
Thanks Valak, I knew there wasn't need for conditionals, but I thought round() was required, now i'll for sure go back :)
I just write the code version of I wrote on the top.. It is the same.

I tried solving this by using only what was available from the lessons.. my code is a mess but it worked :)

One of the challenges I faced was the fact that I couldn't do calculations with strings without converting them to integers again (is there a way to do this?). I had to build code around this...

I'm curious to see what smart solutions other people came up with for this problem.

You don't need to use int(). If you say y=str(x) where x = 3.14 then y is essentially '3.14' but x is still 3.14. You can still manipulate x but at the same time use y to get the information you need for rounding.

Think about what function taught in Unit1 has the ability to return numbers, including -1. Now, consider the fact that you can convert a number to a string and you can use that function on the string to get the first digit after the decimal point. After that, all you need is a little bit of math and you'll be done.
I am pretty sure there is another way to solve the problem than using if-then statements.
Thank you for your hints. it confirmed my way of thinking, but also made me focus on my missing parts!

The solution to the problem is elegant and simple. All you need to do is implement what we have learned so far + a little bit of math, and of course the new str().
Go once again through the material if you need refreshing, but know that the answer is no more than a 2 line code.
I am new to the programming, have completely different background, no prior knowledge, but I can tell that this course can really teach!! It took me more than couple of hours to find the answer (while I was relaxing), but the satisfaction for doing it alone was more than forth it.
It's not merely to get the answer what is important, it's the thinking we put in, in order to get it, what counts!
Good luck and don't rush it!

"

Good luck! :)

"

After figuring out the answer (which, in hindsight, took me WAY longer to figure out than it should have, but hindsight is 20/20), I can offer this to anyone still looking for help. While the ultimate operation is, in fact, simple arithmetic, it involves a bit of ""outside the box thinking.""

Things to keep in mind, while thinking about the solution:

  • you're being asked to round to the nearest ones digit (which is equivalent to saying ""round to the nearest whole number"", but thinking about it like this helped me)
  • in unit 1 we learned you cannot perform many arithmetic operations on a string (while you can ADD two strings together, or multiply a string to repeat itself x times) when you consider string = ""3.14159"" you cannot use the code string = string + 1 to produce 4.14159 and we were not told how to turn a string [back] into an integer, so any mathematical manipulating of the number must be done before converting it to a string
  • at the bottom of the screen on which the question appears, he does say that they WON'T use 3.5, or similar numbers, to test our solutions, but he also says a good general rule is, when the digit to be rounded is five, round up.
  • truncating the variable x fails to account for the times when x needs to be rounded up.
  • adding 1 to the variable x, then truncating the result fails to account for times when you should round down
  • given that you're rounding to the nearest ones digit, the place you're looking at to determine which way to round is the tenths digit. You don't care how many decimal places there are, it's irrelevant to the process.

This may not help you. For some, my guidelines may make it more confusing (I'm sorry if that's the case!). If, after reading these you don't get a spark of inspiration, just ignore them, and keep plugging away, I'm sure you can do it!

"

My intention is to try to demonstrate that the answers are generally always in front of you ... depending on your point of view!

"

Hi Zahrela,

In Python (as with many other programming languages), we have what are known as libraries, which is code that is already written for you built into the language. When we want to use some of that built in code we need to import it from the library it 'lives' in.

If you are using just the tools they have given us in lectures such as slicing, indexing or finding on strings or creating variables then you are not importing and you are doing the correct thing.

I am sure the good folks at 'Udacity' will teach us about libraries and importing soon.

Hope this helps.
Thanks Dojo42.

Peter Chapman - 01:00:17 AM Feb 21, 2012

Currently the development environment, among other things on the site, does not support Internet Explorer 8. The engineering team is working hard to work out the bugs. Until then, we recommend using either Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Internet Explorer 9.
