data-item-item.data-item-item-item: simply, Thrun

It's great to have a course WELL DONE and with such an easy access available to all of us

thanks to everyone involved ! * 35
I need to add: the success is coming from the previous course AI ,Artificial Intelligence, too
agreed with regard to AI class

First of all, the idea of providing free knowledge for everybody with a PC and a web browser is a great idea. I think many people who are interested in computer science topics, but have another educational background find a place here to give it a try. It is, also, the combination of video lectures (which you can watch as often as you want at the time you prefer) with printable materials and interactive elements such as quizzes and programming assignments using a live interpreter. It is a fun way to acquire new knowledge.

UDACITY resounding success not only because of the courses are free but also by the method of teaching and so easy to make us understand the different issues.

The teachers are excellent, their ideals and also that many people know about them and recommend them as teachers.

UDACITY is great and there are few users who have at present and in fans at the level of social networks.

That's my opinion!

Personally I don't know what any of you are talking about. What success? Sure there's a lot of hype, but there are no statistics to prove that the courses are useful to students after they finish. We don't even know how many people are taking the class yet.

There are metrics against which the success of Udacity can be measured (pass rate, number of users, student retention, etc), but there isn't enough information to justify claims for any of these factors just yet. We are the Udacity beta testers. The success or failure of this company will have a lot to do with how we feel about the course after we finish.
He was indeed the first reason which attracted me here, or should I dare say, his Stanford 'past'.

considering their goal is to democratize education such that anyone with internet access can take the class, i'd say they've already accomplished their goal. ergot success.

no doubt, there are more students taking this class here than are currently taking a similar class at all the brick and mortar IVY league schools combined.
I suppose we could say that their marketing has been somewhat successful, at least, to get the numbers we have so far, but as far as real success? That's yet to be determined.

1. Teachers. Based on Unit 1, Professor David Evans is clearly an excellent teacher. His enthusiastic and articulate style of teaching with appropriate occasional humor makes each lecture interesting and memorable.

  2. Format of the course. It feels personal. Many top universities offer at least some courses online but most of them are mere recordings of the on-campus lectures. It makes you feel like an outsider because the professor in those lectures talks to a group of students in an auditorium, not to you. The format of the Udacity course is completely different. It feels as if the professor is talking personally to you. It makes a huge difference.

  3. It's interactive and engaging. Quizzes after each short lectures and homework at the end of each Unit keep you engaged and interested in learning more.

This is the future of education. I am an educator part time the rest of the time I work in my industry. tech guys get it, they see they can share knowledges easily online and so are leading the way but I honestly believe this is how most people will learn in the future, will it stay free probably not, people need to cover running costs but it will be cheap and open too all the test won't be getting into an institution to learn it will be completion the course, I hope so anyway. I teach at a university and honestly the system is broken it does not fit with our students lives today.
OK. we'll have to wait for all of us to be dead and eulogized to know if we've been successful. --)

I took Professors Thrun and Norvig's Artificial Intelligence class - it was brilliant and made the impossible easy.

I have been waiting for Profesor Thrun's Robotics class ever since he announced it.

This class is even more awesome, I found robot localisation quite hard in the AI class but here it is so very clear.

Professor Thrun has changed my life, I want to be a roboticist, now I think it is possible.

What an incredible educator, the sparkle in his eye makes his enthusiasm infectious.
I think it will stay free for the same reason stackoverflow is free - their business model involves charging money to someone other than the users.

You are right, I think this website will remain free. I was talking about higher education generally . I don't believe the current model where students pay exorbitant fees to keep academics in jobs whist doing little else other than research will stay the same. I think in the next twenty to fifty years we will see the death of the standard model of higher education, we will see specialists sharing there knowledge for free but some price will have to be charged for certification and grading, however it will be significantly lower than it is now.

After I found out about this class and signed up, I checked around on the web and found a video from a talk Sebastian gave at DLD (something like Ted Talks) and it was an exciting talk. I think the most interesting thing he pointed out was, as a teacher who loves teaching, it was far better to teach thousands than 200. The man believes in what he is doing enough to take risks, leave Stanford and start Udacity. If anyone can do this, he can. These are the kind of folks who do indeed change the world.

It is his drive and his conviction that will make Udacity succeed. And the time is right -- the means to reach thousands is available, the open source movement is becoming more known, Eben Upton is releasing a $35 Linux computer to the world (Raspberry Pi), and the $25 Arduino Uno (open source EE experimental board) is everywhere. Udacity is happening at the right time.

And the very interesting thing, to me, is that unlike a brick and mortar university, in this one, students enroll for all of the right reasons. Not because, there is nothing else to do, or because everyone else they know is going to school, or because their parents want them to. We are here because we want to learn what is being taught. That is all it takes to be a good student. I don't know a single (good) teacher who doesn't dream of having a class of ALL good students.

data-item.data-item-item: We are supposed to use srt() function to convert integers to strings, and we should be able to accomplish this without using anything else, but using strings we can't do arithmetic, say i know that i have to round up a number like 39.5 ->-- 40 it is as easy as 39 + 1 but we cant add using strings so how are we supposed to do this?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Somewhere along the lines you have answered yourself :)

Hint: play with the number before you convert it to a string (because, as you've mentioned, after it's a string you wouldn't be able to apply arithmetic actions on the ""number"").

"

you can go up and down, remember.

So the way you are thinking you firt convert to string and the operate, so you wish you could add one because:

39.5 ->-- 40

but you have to rethink a bit because:

39.4 ->-- 39

So you can't extract just the first digits before the number and the add one.

but what you can do is do math and then convert t string :)

Rethink again, but remember that you round up or down depending on the first digit.

hope this helps!!!
You're on the right track.

My suggestion would be to do any arithmetic before converting it to a string. You could also create two variables: one containing the number and another containing the string. Example:

  number = 12.345
   number_string = str(number)

You have to keep in mind that any changes to number will not affect number_string unless you explicitly reassign it. I don't see how the latter would help with this problem, however.

An old maths trick - just add 0.5 to the decimal value, and then pick out just the integer part.

Examples - 3.1 add .5 becomes 3.6, as an integer is 3

5.7 add .5 becomes 6.2, integer value is 6
O.K., now I got it in two lines...
thanks just got it, after all it's really simple
Nobody said you had to START with str().... --)
Thanks for spoiling the answer...

A hint: just think mathematically on how you would define round() as a function of int(), and on how you can emulate int() using only str() and .find(). Once you figure this out, the solution is quite simple and can be done in just one short line using only what was taught in this unit.

I know! that's were i started wrong, i started with the str() function but should have started by transforming the number as an int first, after i got it right e remembered that i had a similar assignment in school a few years a go.

I mentioned in another comment, the difficulty of the quizzes and homework assignments, how they are way too hard for me, and how getting every question wrong is slowly breaking my spirit, making me want to quit this course. It's not because I'm stupid, it's how the questions are designed, they are meant for people with a specific learning style, one which I don't share, so they are discriminative in this way.

A perfect example: The Capital Udacity Quiz. @PeterUdacity I've been working at this question now for several minutes. I tried everything, I couldn't solve it. It was frustrating me. So I skipped it. It turns out the answer requires knowledge that was NOT present in the videos preceding this quiz.

Actually, after listening to the answer, I still don't get it. Should I just quit this course? It says you don't need to know anything to take it, that would be false advertisement. Maybe what it should say is you need to excel in induction to solve the questions, and it should tell us too if we fail the course if we get the homework assignments wrong, cause that's really stressful for someone with severe learning disabilities.

No one at Udacity ever thought that people with different learning styles, and people with learning disabilities, might want to take these courses? I'm not a ""retard"", I'm actually a genius with an IQ of about 200. I just can't solve multiple choice questions that involve choices that weren't covered in the preceding course material. That for me is impossible, physically impossible, neurologically impossible, I physically lack that cognitive ability.

If you tell me that the homework assignments are merely to instruct and won't be graded, meaning that I can't fail this class for getting trick questions wrong, then I will be happy, I will just skip all the questions and get on with the course. Otherwise, I'm doomed to fail, and that's not only depressing, it's stressful. Thank you.

I'm sorry to hear that you're having trouble with the quizzes here. No one absorbs new knowledge in exactly the same way. Personally, I find the pacing of the videos OK, but it may be too fast for an absolute beginner. You may benefit from reading through the course notes and Python reference material, which are linked beneath the main videos in the 'Supplementary Material' area. This will let you go at your own speed without worrying about catching every word that is said on the videos. In addition, there are various resources on the internet for beginner programmers and you can find questions elsewhere on these forums which discuss them.

By the way, you won't be penalised for not completing the quizzes-- however, the homework tests will count towards your final grade. There's nothing stopping you just watching the videos and skipping the tests, if that's stressing you out.

The quiz which asks you to turn 'audacity' into 'Udacity' using string sub-sequences may be tricky if you're new to programming. The tutor, Dave, describes how to extract specific sequences of characters in Section 29, which I've linked to here:

String sub-sequences video

Please note that you don't have to capitalise the 'u' character in 'audacity' in this quiz - you can start with a ""U"" string on its own and then add the last six characters of the string to make the word. Don't be afraid to try out a few things in the Python window - even if you get it wrong, you'll just get an error message and can backtrack and try again.

Here's a little example of getting some characters out of a string:

s = ""test string"" print s[2]   # prints a single character two away from the beginning - the 's' print s[5:]  # prints the string from the sixth character to the end - 'string' print s[:3]  # prints the string from the beginning to the third character - 'tes'

I do hope that you'll give it another shot or that you'll find another resource which is more suited to your learning style. All the best.

"

"

s='udacity'
s[0]='U'
print s

I was trying to re-assign U to s, that is switch the U for the u.. I have a hard time understanding concatenation, though.. the real answer, I forget, was something like 'U' + s[1:], also I know the sequence in the string starts at 0, then goes 1 2 3 4 etc.. but in the string 'udacity' when I select subsequence s[1:] with the semicolon of course, is that ""including"" position 1? is s[1:] then 'dacity'?

yes

but be careful when you have a value in the second position.

"

@antiface - Maybe there should be a note that you need not capitalise the lowercase U. No wonder you were stumped for a while!

You're right, when you select characters in a string, you can think of the index as the 'distance from the beginning' - so the first character is at position 0, the second at position 1 and so on.

Although you don't need it in this quiz, it's worth noting that when you provide a start and end position, as in the following example, the character at the end position is excluded from the result:

s = ""test string""

print s[1:3]

This prints 'es', not 'est'.

"
Cool. I will go there when needed. Thanks.

"

What this unit is really asking you for is to try and use the simple tools. There surely are more complicated ways to do things, but if you look for the easy way it's all in the videos. You'll have a similar problem when you go to question 9 of the HW, as the forum is showing, many, many ones are getting crazy on that because they're looking for the complicated way, but this unit is about make do with what you have, and it's definitely possible :-)

Actually, your idea of ""replacing"" the first charachter of ""udacity"" is not bad at all, it's just that it's not the way Python strings work. It'd have worked perfectly under C, where strings are just sequences of charachters that you can manipulate... 

s[0] = 'U'
would have been just perfect!
On the contrary, in C you can't concatenate strings as easily as in Python, it's a matter of personal taste... no, not really, C is oh-so-hard compared to Python!

I think that if that was your idea, you'd really better NOT give this course up, you might have more a programmer's mind than you think and you might have more success than you expect. Just try to be more confident! And ask for help if you can't figure it out :-)

As for concatenation, it's really quite simple: if you have something like


 s = 'Anna' 
 t = 'Chiara'

then s is a string with charachters from 0 to 3, t is a string with charachter indexes from 0 to 5.
Now, id you assign:

 u = s+t

the u will be a different string, a new one, with the value 'AnnaChiara' and charachters ranging from 0 to 9.

Now, if you extract a string, like 

v = u[4:]

this is another string, again a new one, with indexes from 0 to 5. I'll leave it up to you to figure the value of this string :-)

"

@antiface, the semicolon is a delimitator-- the number or expression before the semicolon means ""from this position in the string"" and the number after the semicolon means ""up to this position in the string"".

Let's take s = ""test string""

So s[1:4] would mean the string of characters starting from position 1 up to position 4, which is est (t is at position 0, e is at position 1 and so on).

If you leave one part of the delimiter empty it means either from the start of the string if it is on the left side

s[:4] means from the start up to position 4, which would give out test

Or if it is left out on the right side, it means up to the end of the string

s[2:] would print out st string

"

s[0:1]

in this case is the same as

s[ :1]

think of s[num1:num2] as if it were saying s[from num1 to just before num2]
and sometimes num 1 and 2 may be left out.

Udacity's aim is to give university-level education - so maybe the instructors are a little biased about learning concepts and styles, because of their previous experience. I get the feeling, that the forum is closely monitored though, and I'm absolutely certain that input such as yours will have an impact on the creation of future content.
However, adapting to different learning speeds or -styles may require reworking the whole lecture. Right now, the course does little to accommodate e.g. the needs of a blind student, because the quizzes and homework assignments are presented in a way, no braille display could ever translate.
But that's what the community is for - students helping each other. Everyone can ask for help and further explanation in the forums.
I also found it gave my confidence a real boost when I watched the videos, did the homework and then went back to the videos just to find, that I understood a LOT more than on the first round - especially that part about formal grammar (BNF) gave me some trouble at first and became quite simple after I'd already watched the later videos with the examples in use.

edit:
Turns out I gravely wronged Udacity with my statement about not accommodating blind users - actually, the lecture notes are a great addition to the video in that regard, and since they are simple pdf files, they should prove to be a great addition to the voice in the video. Only the Homework should be a problem, and I'm sure there are ways to get around these challenges.

I understand the grammar much better now, thanks to everyone's help. Python is actually pretty simple when you think of it, it's much easier than learning a foreign language, such as German or Dutch. I finished Unit1 plus all the Homework, and even went on to watch a bunch of Python videos at the Khan Academy website. Also, I took the teachers' advice, to look for stuff online for beginners. I was surprised to see how much there is online! I'm loving the greater Python community already.. I just don't know if Python is the best choice for what I want to do..

I feel like this question was just unusually hard because he specifically states to use a capital U AND only use the indexing you just learned. BUT until that point there is no mention of the methods to convert from lowercase to uppercase. So you're left with the impression that you've missed something.. when you haven't.

data-item.data-item-item:
I'm new to python (previously programmed using C and arduino code), and I'm stuck with the following:

def move(p, U):     q=[]     for i in range (len(p)):         q.append(p[(i-U) % len(p)])     return q

In the above, what does the % len(p) do? I understand the len(p), but not the % operator. Looking this up, I've seen that its for replacing values in strings, but I'm still at a loss. I've also discovered that if you comment out that part and close the q.append properly, the code seems to run normally. Thank you immensely for your help!

-Tom

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: There is no text in the question. Could you please edit the post and include the text? If you are adding links to your post, please use the link button (globe with green arrow) just above the textbox.

"

Wow sorry!

For the final quiz, I did as follows:
print start_link #I got 89, so...
print page [89:] # I got a pretty good idea of how the url looks like.

start_quote=page.find ('""', start_link) #I got this part from the hint.

Now my question is that if '""' can be used for search, why can't I use 'm""', or for that matter, 'com""' to get the end quote?

Thank you very much!

"

"

@Soundofgeta, because if you search for .com you might find something that isn't a link, or is a link but to an image, or a video, or something that shouldn't be followed by the crawler. And what happens if the link ends with .org, or .co.uk or anything else besides .com?

Searching for "" as the last element of a link when you know that you're starting from the good position (which is, you already found the start of the html link element - a href= - and you found the start of the link pointed at by that html element - the first "") is the safest way to find links in general (in general with concepts we've only been taught so far).

"
Sorry, my comment doesn't show up...

"

You could, but that would make you retrieve only urls that end in "".com"", while no all urls end with .com.

Programs should be designed to work on different data, if you write code to extract a link, you can't make hypotheses on what the link will be like, all you know is that you have a starting tag, and that the link will end with a double quote. Also, you know that the double quote won't appear within the link. Those are the only specifications that you have, and the only ones that you can know of, even if the test page that you're working on has data that you can read.

So the answer is: you could search for ""com"", but you shouldn't :-)

"

"

Please do read this, as an answer to your question.

EDIT Fixed the link

"

data-item.data-item-item:
In AI class it seemed like there was a strict policy about not discussing homework until after its due. I think there was even the threat of being dropped...

Why nothing like that here? There are so many posts with hints about the homework.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

From the Terms Of Service, point 3:

(student) will not share content or solutions to homework assignments or exams--

"
OK, so we do have a policy... But I don't recall ever seeing any discussion of homework before it was due in AI (although i just used facebook not reddit). Here it's rampant...

"

I simplify things by ignoring anything tagged ""homework"" or that has ""homework"" in the title. I'm quite capable of misunderstanding the material for myself ---) I don't need additional misinformation. Clarification should be the province of the duly appointed authorities (AKA people whose name ends in ""Udacity"").

Once everything is graded, I'll come back to the homework posts.

"

"

It is a very important policy well known , usually

Maybe not everyone read the long Terms of service ..

I liked the previous
Honor Code where you had to read a short but significant policy

"

It's a bit unfortunate that Udacity didn't use a similar approach to this that Stanford did: a very short and clear description of what is and is not allowed. I doubt many people actually read the ToS and FAQ, and even if they did, they are worded in such a way that some will think that giving hints is still okay.

In AI class the homework was extensively discussed in the Aiqus forums before the deadline was over, but it seemed that almost everyone was very mindful of the Honor Code. I think almost without exception the discussions were about the questions (and clarifications thereof) rather than the answers. As it should be.

I also took the AI class and, actually, there was as much discussion about homework and, even, exam questions as there is in this class/forum.

I think it's OK to help out people and give hints as long as you don't post the exact answer.

At the end we are NOT in a competitive environment rather in a learning one.

Learning isn't a race.
It's about sharing and learning and sometimes (perhaps many times) helping others improves your understanding of the material.

We are all here to learn. Mature individuals realize that education is the expansion of knowledge to solve a given problem. In this case...we want to learn how to program. We need to think of solutions.

It is not important that the answer to a problem is '4'. It is important to know how to arrive at the given answer! BIG DIFFERENCE!

Those individuals who choose not to understand and merely to satisfy answers to problems will only be cheating themselves and will have learned nothing of substantial use.

I am a little older...and advise my kids that it is far better in the long run - to learn how and why, then it is to blindly solve and regurgitate.

Just my 2 cents...

Learning is about sharing so there should be no issue about students discussing the quizzes or homeworks. I'm happy to do that because it means that sometimes I help others to understand and other times they help me too.

Learning is also about understanding the subject. That is something that only comes from solving problems yourself. Hints from others can act as pointers but understanding comes when you find the answer to the problem.

So keep the discussions to hints to help people and let's all learn as a community

I completely agree with this statement. Regardless of all the discussions going on, we cannot share the solutions, as stated previously in this thread. Sharing solutions and asking for clarification on a concept not well understood are two completely different things in my opinion. Furthermore, learning should be of utmost priority here, not copying the correct solutions to finish the homework.

On another note, sometimes I find that I understand the material much better when I discuss it with others. Through discussion, you start noticing things that otherwise would have been obscure to you.

I have placed a link to this post within the post on Pedagogy for this discussion on Ethics/Honor Code has value to educators looking to design quality learning communities. I love the discussion here concerning competition vs collaboration. It's great stuff. It mirrors the debate taking place in physical classrooms these days... particularly as public schools are trying to reinvent themselves.

I recently watched a video with Prof. Thrun where he was commenting about the experience he had teaching AI Class and why he decided to start Udacity up: he believes in a big paradigm shift from the traditional teaching / grading system into a true learning experience, on what really matters is not the grades that a student gets, but the knowledge he really absorbs in the process. If you are a student and the score you get in an exam is low, he may have failed as a teacher. It may not make sense for him to leave you behind just because of your low scores. He may choose another path for you to learn, as not all people learn the same way. He wants you to learn, not to score high. Hence, fostering collaboration in a forum such as this one to help people learn is not detrimental to an 'honor system'. We have to remember that this is not really Stanford, and that we won't get a degree from it. We will get knowledge, that is all that matters.

Wow i'm surprised by all the answers! I appreciate being able to ask for help on things also. But I still like the idea of having clear guidelines on when to collaborate and when to work independently. Are all of you who want to help each other on homework going to be doing the same on exams?

I think they should make all the ungraded questions open to discussion and the graded ones not. Wait, isn't that what they already did? :)

One who wants to cheat will cheat, there is not much to be done about that. Heck how do you know I am the same person who registered for the course that is posting this contribution? I think its a shared responsibility on the part of the asker and answerer. When answering the aim should be to give props and pointers and as for the asker, if you really want to learn, you will hate to be given the solution to a problem.

Having said that when all else fails, a solution might just be the door opener to ones understanding, but in that case accept that you couldn't solve the problem and wait for the official explanation from the lecturer then get further clarification from peers if its still unclear.

data-item.data-item-item: I want to Practice Python Code, But I Did not find Python Interpretor, where it is located on Udacity Unit 1 section.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I believe it appears at the end of each section which has a quiz. I don't think you can call it up by itself. If you want to have the Python interpreter installed on your machine, you can download it for free from here: http://python.org/download/

"

"

if you want to test python in browser, there are several options. I prefer http://www.trypython.org/

"

"

If you don't want to install python on your machine, you can try it in your browser at Skulpt or, if have Silverlight installed, at Trypython. The latter is a Python tutorial, but you can use it just as a Python console.

"

"

A nicer (and faster alternative) to Skulpt can be found on CodePad and has the advantage of easily sharing the code/running script.

"

CodePad is not client-side, each time you want to execute something, your code is sent to codepad's server, it's actually pretty slow. Trypython and Skulpt are completely in-browser, client side, so each time you want to execute some code it is executed in your browser, with no round-trip to the server, so it's much faster!

I guess my problem with Skulpt is that it loads so slow that it's faster for me to boot a Linux VM and just use the preinstalled python in there.

Also, no sharing runnable code, which is a big downside for Trypython and Skulp, at least for me.

I too cant find a direct link to the python interpretor so as a workaround I open part 6 of unit 1. this gives me access to the interpretor where I can run my test code.
it might come up with the video again if so just click next (as if you were going to answer the question in that module.

hopes this helps.

data-item.data-item-item: Just what it says above. For people with previous programming experience or people who finished Unit 1 already, what did you do when you were stuck and couldn't solve a problem?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I was stuck on the last question for a while. Getting away from the screen and trying to reason it out with paper &-- pencil helped. What should be the first step? What logic or operation will help me execute the first step? Sometimes pseudocode or just a list of steps can be helpful.
Other than asking for help on the forums.

"

maybe the following site can help you:
http://people.csail.mit.edu/pgbovine/python/tutor.html#mode=edit

"

Take a pause, go watch some tv, eat something and then think on the problem as if you were to solve it by hand, again pause and see how you solve the problem manually, what did you do step by step and then you can start thinking on a way to write it in python or any other programming language. Hope this help you.
take a pause it helps
First I am writing the solution in words, then writing the code version. If I stuck somewhere, I am looking some reference and tutorial rather than looking back to Unit1.
I always try to establish a free relationship with the problem at hand. I try to never let any particular methodology crowd out the potential for others.

I agree... also for me the best way is to get away from the screen and to take a break. Very often I am solving problems doing different things like walking, sleeping one night over it or cooking ---)

Happy relaxing,
Zllk

Take a break, relax and try to see and break the problem in a number of sequences or steps.
This way you will have less pressure on your mind and you won't get irritated.
Hope you find a solution to your problem.
I get myself some chocolate (something sweet) or sometimes go ice-skating and you know what? While dancing on ice, I see the solutions :)

If you mean some bugs in the program when you run it, I usually read the algorithms many times and if I can't understand the errors I try to find a different way (often the second way is better than the first one)... Sometimes a short break could help you to refresh your ideas...

data-item.data-item-item:
How many of You are new to Python and are impressed by the user-friendly and powerful nature of this language?
Please feel free to share what you found different and better in this language than other languages like C++, java etc.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I love how simple and highlevel/english like python is. I have programmed in C, C++, VHDL and assembly. The syntax of C and C++ is nice and easy to understand with comments. Assembly is gibberesh to anyone who has no assembly background. VHDL is different to everything in my opinion and hard to compare to other programming languages.

Python feels like psuedocode, which is a very good thing, cause psuedocode comes naturally to alot of people.

Also python has no need for a -- every line!! I have spent days looking for a missing -- in C programs before.

I'm not exactly new to it but it is the first language that I'm really applying myself into learning (I've had some experience in the past with Visual Basic). Python is GREAT for beginners. I also recommend learning Django (a web framework based on python) if you're interested in building websites/applications.

I agree to what you said because I am also from C++, java background..
thanks for posting

There is so much to learn i guess....
I never thought I would get to learn python this year...
But the love for programming and creating something dragged me to learn python....
thanks to Udacity

I have programmed in C and Java before and I agree with your statement that Python feels like pseudocode. One of the things I am still getting accustomed to with Python, though, is making sure I do not place a semicolon after every statement. :P This shows just how easy Python's syntax seems to be.
I personally love the simplicity and easy to understand syntax, definitely a program that anyone should learn.

I'm finding that Python is very expressive, i.e. I can accomplish what I want to do with the minimum of code and in a readable manner. Although we're just starting out, I like the string manipulation side of things, plus the number of freely-available guides and online books means that I can easily research my next topic of interest.

I've used a variety of languages in the past, including C-like languages, such as JavaScript and C#, and Visual Basic and other higher-level languages. Each has its own strengths and weaknesses (I hear Python's performance isn't super-fast because it's interpreted), but it's great to have a resource like this to learn a new one and judge for yourself. I'm a particular fan of the online REPL sites, so you can try your code out without even having to download an IDE or Python distribution! Python lacks static typing, meaning that a lot of errors are caught at runtime, which is a bit of a disadvantage compared to C# or Java-- however, it's so easy to read that it's not a massive issue at the moment.
thanks for sharing..!!

It's an extremely good language for learning. I used to teach people Pascal - and it is better.

C is more complicated and more difficult - but of course the compiled code works a lot faster, which is why it is used in industry.

But from learning Python you should be able to pick up C, Java etc fairly quickly.

I started with C and most of my work is done in C# so I might be biased, but I tend to like C/C++ more than python.

I'm not the largest fan of how it does loops compared to C based languages (can't do the tricks you can do there) nor am I a great supporter of using whitespace for delimiting portions of code.

What it is though, is a great starting language, because it's easy to follow and read, and using whitespace forces you to properly indent code.

same here....I have also worked and made projects with c++ and java.
But this is also an exciting language to learn and this is only the start. 6 Units to follow.

Same here, I'm not liking Python very much, and I don't think I'll use it outside of here, although it'll do its job nicely I guess. The fact that Python is one of the few languages (the only I can think of) that has broken compatibility with itself, that is their designers have considered it necessary to re-define it--I'm talking about Python 3.x vs. earlier of course--is a testament to the fact that it didn't have a proper design.

@XavierP, I'm taking Python more as an advanced scripting languages (and use it as that on my Linux boxes) rather than a full fledged programming language (which it is).

In the end, it all comes down to preference, as Python is a really good language in itself, and all the modules available make it an amazing language for all sorts of tasks.

"

When I need ""scripts"" for sysadmin'ing, I don't usually fret from compiling them if necessary-- I have yet to find an advantage in interpreted languages, or dynamic typing--they sure have disadvantages.

For example because of a recent problem I just made a program that repeatedly pings and requests resolutions from my DNS server, and prints roundtrip times to the console and a file. I made it in C#, which has as many libraries as Python and then some. I remember a program I made before I was into .NET to reverse the sign of one of the columns in a matrix text file: it's 10 lines in C.

And Python has simply ugly and poorly designed features, form example read the ""important warning"" here. Eeew, that's just asking for bugs out loud. And the floating point precision is a joke.

But I'll have a more informed opinion after I've finished these courses.

"

I love Python because it made programming fun again. Because I could create what I wanted without a big fight. Or as a programmer at work says - its just plain beautiful. Been trying to learn Java for a time now, but its a pain to learn. Working with programming, it tends to be a fight until you really become good at it creating stuff you want to build. With python, you can start with functional programming and then convert to object oriented programming (and then later choose the style you prefer or the right tool for the task).
The only thing close to the beauty of Python I have seen until today, is maybe the Google Go language which borrows heavily from the simplicity (greatness) from Python and speed from C++.

"

I think you all will fall in love with the language when you dig a bit deeper. In the beginning it seems like yet another sh scripting environment. But when you start building stuff - that is when you start getting amazed. Getting to goal fast, wow, and even complex stuff compiles on first run. Read this article: http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/3882

"

I find Python quite cumbersome compared to SQL. Then again, I am only beginning to get familiar with it so things will change by the end of the course.

Must be OK as a language though because, along with several other excellent open source products, it has its origins in Europe

data-item.data-item-item: So my question may seem a little monotonous since you may see this type of question all over the WorldWideWeb, but i will like to know how long does one take to master Python? i have heard C++ and java are very complex programs and takes years. Is that the case with python? in less than a month i have learned enough about functions, methods, parameters and i must it admit i learn quick with Python. my other question is how simple is it to learn c++ or java after i master python? only intellectual opinions please.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
U can't master any language unless and until you are completely into it...
C++ and java has libraries(python also has a comprehensive library) and you have to have complete knowledge about the library if you want to master the language.
I am programming in C++ from last 3 years and in java from last 2 years and I am comfortable in these two languages...but still a lot to learn..!!
not much difference between the two but to master a language it takes time and a lot of practice.

"

Depends on what your definition of master is.
According to Peter Norvig, it should take 10 years or 10,000 hours of coding. You can check his blog post on the matter here

Another good post on this topic is Become a Good Programmer in Six Really Hard Steps, posted on gamedev(dot)net.

So get ready to devote quiet a lot of time to coding, if you want to master it.

But if you were asking how long will it take for you to get proficiency in Python, then that depends on how much time you devote to learning python &-- how quickly you learn things, but a few months should be enough, I think.

"
Thanks, very helpful feedback.
Use comments instead of posting answers!

"

I can't answer your first question, since I myself have yet to ""master"" Python. However, to answer your last question, C++ and Java ought to be relatively easy once you have attained a background in Python. Your first language is usually your most difficult, because before that point, you have no clear conception of the mechanisms of programming. But once you know a language, to learn a second language is simply to map the structures of the first into the second. For instance, assuming you know Python's conditional statement, learning Java's equivalent is an absolutely trivial task. Be warned, however, that exceptions to this rule may occur if you are crossing paradigms (e.g. from Java to Haskell).

"

I'm not sure there is such a thing as mastering a language. Even though you may learn all there is to know about the syntax of a language, there will always be things you don't know how to do and must learn about. However these are more about algorithms, data structures, etc. than about language syntax-- once you know how to do something in one language it is often trivial to learn the best way to do it in another language.
The only way you could really master a language is if you were building it from scratch. Of course, this is only my opinion on the subject :)

Like the answers above, mastering is a big word. I'm not sure if anyone has mastered anything in terms of computer programming. :)

However once you get used to Python, learning the syntax, ways to solve problems, etc. It'll be rather simple for you to step up to another programming language with similar syntax. I myself find C and C++ rather complicated over languages like Java, C# and PHP (because these require a different mindset again, even though the syntax is rather similar). But you'll find that even though function names may vary, the solutions will be almost the same at most points.

So long story short, yeah it'll be quite easy for you to step up to another programming language, especially when it has a similar syntax. (am I using the right word here?)
I think you meant other OOP languages?

Well, will tell you about me. I started with C/C++ and started writing code using them during my first year UG. I participated in a lot of coding competitions online, also, solving my homework assignments myself. After three years of coding in those languages, I stumped across a problem in a coding competition, where there is a need to use Python, since C/C++ couldn't hold some big integers (They can be made to do it, but it's a very tedious process, concatening etc.,). Then, using the documentation of python, with in three hours, I wrote the entire code in Python. So, in my view, it doesn't matter which language you start with, but what matters is that you continually code in it solving hard problems. And after some years, if you come across some other language, just the documentation is enough to dive into it and start solving problems in it

Also, the best part about python is it has very less keywords than any other language. So, it's a cool language for starters

No language takes years to master. Of course depending on your definition of mastering, and besides languages there are patterns, that apply to many or all of them--but you get the idea. If you want to learn C++ for example go ahead. If you kept at it really intensively you would be able to code any conceivably thing in a couple of months.
No I mean all the languages that are based on the C-Syntax, I named a few. Most languages nowadays are like that though, but not all :)

Hi,

I am not agree with your solution of the last quiz as many programmers use just the page reference like:
page = 'Company'
so here we are not getting any complete url so our start_link should be from 'a href=""http' and then we can back tack four characters to find the complete url.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
With any programming problem, there will be many different creative solutions that can be found. If what you did worked and is efficient and understandable, then you should be happy to have thought outside 'the box'. Good job.

Ian

"

Actually, if you look at the source code for any page, you'll see that every clickable link translates into <--a href=""http://url.com"">-- and maybe some additional elements in the anchor tag, like title, etc.

As for backing up 4 characters, what happens if the link is on a secure connection and starts with https://, shouldn't you follow those as well?

"

"

""Actually, if you look at the source code for any page, you'll see that every clickable link translates into and maybe some additional elements in the anchor tag, like title, etc."" Not necessarily. You can just out an anchor like .

""As for backing up 4 characters, what happens if the link is on a secure connection and starts with https://, shouldn't you follow those as well? ""
Yes sure we should tackle it to. But my solution will work in that case too, as you just need to find 's' as additional :)

"

I think you're right - there are more internet protocols than just HTTP, which is used for web pages-- there's FTP, HTTPS and so on. However, for this first unit, I think we're just being asked to extract every link which has an HREF, even if our crawler should not eventually follow them all.

Yes, but that doesn't mean that you shouldn't build your code for the general case.

And using what we know, the only way to do that and get only relevant links is to first search for <--a href=, then find the starting quote and after that the first quote after that one.

That at least until/if we learn about regular expression so we can search for links even if the html tag is malformed but still valid, like for example <--a href=.

"

Dear just use my logic. And follow the following steps:

  • Find the string and its index 'a href=""http'
  • Back track 4-characters (to reach at 'http')
  • Find the next index of ""
  • Extract the complete URL

It will not matter if there is http or https. If you want i can give you its complete code too :)

"

Oh, OK, read it weirdly the first time and didn't make sense.

You're right, this would work with only 2 searches onstead of 3.
good to hear that you go the point...

"

@Fuzzmz - I was just trying to say that the OP was insightful because they'd noticed that the URL may be in a form which we need not follow in the future, i.e. an FTP link.

For this first unit, it doesn't matter, though, as our corpus is a single page! Their idea of searching for links starting with HTTP only seems fine to me, as it will catch HTTP and HTTPS and not include FTP or other links (it will also ignore pages relative to the current page, but that's for another time). No, it's not robust, but we haven't covered advanced string matching yet :)

I won't give you the whole solution but the answer doesn't require anything clever like using if and then.

Also ignore str for the solution to the rounding problem - that helps you solve the removal of the decimal places.

You've got two situations

One a number less than .5 eg 3.123 that rounds down to say 3
and a number greater than .5 eg 3.67 that rounds up to 4.

The solution is in simple addition - what do you need to add to eith round the number up or if you add it doesn't round the number up - when you've figured that the rest is easy.

I must admit it took me hours to figure it.

Good luck

You can resolve this problem using only the material in the unit one.
You dont need if or int(), only str() and string operations are enought.

First think about how you can round up a decimal number using only basical math operations.
Later use the str() and watch again the videos about string operations, there is the solution.

I think you already have the solution. The goal seems to be to use the material covered in Unit1 about strings. We are required only to print the whole number, not round it or do anything with it. Or did I misinterpret the exercise?

EDIT: I see, so apparently I had misinterpreted the exercise and I had submitted the wrong solution. I have fixed it now. It was actually quite fun to try and figure it out without using if/else or anything else rather than what was covered in Unit 1.
I don't think so. You have given the entire essence of the answer. Coding is the easy part, figuring out what to code is the hard part &-- that's what you have given out
Hey Paul, posting solutions before the deadline? Not cool, man!

I got to the right solution that uses only material from Unit 1 after wracking my head against the problem for some time. There is a funny way to cheat though and I want to share it just for fun - I don't think it counts as a legit solution.

The solution must not use import, but the round function is a built-in one that doesn't need to be imported. You can use it to get round(27.63) ->-- 28.0.
It's not the answer in any way, so no need to delete it. First lesson didn't cover if/else statements

/facepalm

I spent the whole day wondering what sort of simplification you guys were talking about. And it suddenly hit me! So simple and elegant! :D

I'm at work right now so cant update my assignment but I'm gonna do it as soon as I get back home :D

PS: My initial code catered for -ve numbers as well. Now I'm trying to think up a way to handle -ve numbers in a similar manner

[Update] I think I got the -ve part too although what I've got right now is some redundant coding. If-elseif conditions would have been more efficient I think

@vampiri6ka that doesn't matter. Any program that produces the correct solution, regardless of what statements/techniques it uses, as long as it doesn't import anything is a valid answer.
You could use if/else or loops or other inbuilt functions and it would be correct

Here is a hint (just a little one, because otherwise the solution will be obvious):

How you get it for yourself weather a decimal number is closer to one or another integer? There are 2 halves let's say before 27.5 and after. Can you add or deduct something that will definitely tell you, yep it's closer to 27 (or 28). All you need is this str function and some maths with string operations. No new functions or operators should be used

Well, I actually let it out :) But it's still not the plain answer.

"

You need ""round"" up the number, but only the entire part. The result could be for example 9.132
You only need to do a basical math operation with the number given. you only need to print a part of the result.

"

Not only are you giving a possible answer but suggesting the use of language features not yet covered (string ->-- integer conversion and if/else construct). We should be trying to solve the problem without use of such features, which is certainly possible.
Not related to the question but I think that the choice of username Admin is disingenuous and can mislead others into believing you are connected to Udacity, which I don't think is true.
That was my first solution, but that is not the way to do it using only the content covered in the first lecture.
Actually, it is pretty easy to find a solution, if you carefully read instructor comments :)
Actually that's not a solution as it is clearly stated that the result of rounding 3.15 has to be 3 and not 3.0.
you can use print int(round(27.63)), but that is out of the scope of Unit 1

Round() can certainly be used to get you there.

I used it at first, before I came to the forums and saw the staff encouraging us to solve the problem only with material that has been covered, and nothing new and got the proper answer without the decimal.

But the problem can and should be solved without using round(), or conditional statements like if/else, etc.

data-item.data-item-item: I'm not sure about the level of control provided to the admins by the StackExchange framework, but it would be nice if questions tagged as homework could be protected in a way that only admins can answer them, to prevent other users from giving out solutions to the questions, either knowingly or unknowingly. If the restriction to admins is too strict, then maybe only users with 2k reputation or more can answer.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I don't think that's a good idea, because you can give hints and tips without outright giving the answer away. You can also help clarify certain requirements or explain certain concepts which help in solving the problem, but are not the solution (see the number of questions about whether x.5 rounds up or down).

I think it should be allowed because it is the study buddy concept and, done correctly, that is a win-win situation.

Plus we will only find the actual answers after it is graded so anything posted is only one persons opinion out what that answer should be

With questions like the one being asked in the quizzes here, even a hint can be almost as good as giving out the answer. That + the few instances of blatant answers makes it a less than ideal situation. Though I understand it would hamper other legitimate users, so maybe a lowering of the bar for answering?

data-item.data-item-item: Sometimes, in this forum, the text of the questions and answers do not appear, and everything is blank, with no text. Two of my response to others questions were all in white, I tried to edit them, but it remains blank. And I've seen questions that only the title appears. Does anyone know why this happens and how to fix it?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It happens when the text contains links that aren't written in the markdown syntax [text](http://url.com) or links and html content which aren't properly escaped as `http://url.com` or `<--a href=""` for example.

In short, any time you want to insert a non-clickable link, or html code, use the ` to surround it with, or if you're in the rich text editor press the preformatted text button (ctrl+K) and write the code there.

"
Sometimes it occurs when we insert a link on a post

"

In the non-coding questions, when you are done answering, you should find the ""done"" button and click that. It should be somewhere on top of the video window. If you click ""next"" instead, or just go to another question, I don't think it saves your answer. (Although, even if it does, the boxes will be empty again when you revisit the question.)

"

The green tick means the answer has been submitted. The yellow dot may mean it has not. What can happen is

1) You didn't press done and get the Answer Submitted dialogue and didn't submit or
2) that you watched the video on that question to the end after you'd submitted. The green tick turns back to a yellow dot.. I don't know whether that means the saved answer is still saved or not.

To be on the safe side, I'm making sure all my homework questions stay as green ticks.

data-item.data-item-item:
This course is about learning to build a search engine, but one quick look at this forum makes me wonder if the people taking this course even know how to use one. Right now there are at least 14 different topics about about the last homework question (1.9) about rounding numbers. It almost seems that there are more duplicate questions than unique ones. There is a nice big search bar above every page in the forum that people could use to prevent this and get their answers quicker. Hell, often just looking at the first page of questions will show accomplish that.

All this forum pollution makes it harder to find genuinely good and unique questions and it fragments discussion about one topic.

Should we do something about this? If so, what? Should duplicates be closed, down voted, ignored?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Funnily enough, this has come up before --)

What to do about duplicates

I think that closing the new question and linking to the earlier topic is the way to go, but I believe closing topics is restricted to very few people at the moment, so that may be why dupes are prevalent at this early stage.

As there are a lot of beginners on here, I don't think down-voting would be fair, as this can be quite discouraging. What do you think?

"

"

Damn it. I was afraid this might happen, since it seemed so odd that I was the first one to bring this up. I actually did search for ""search"", but not for ""duplicate"". Well, at least that other topic is a couple of days old, rather than a couple of minutes...

As there are a lot of beginners on here, I don't think down-voting would be fair, as this can be quite discouraging. What do you think?

I don't really know. I'm often baffled by people's (voting) behavior on sites like these and it seems that a lot of people consider downvotes to be really severe while some hand upvotes out like candy. Personally, I think that if you are the Nth person to post the exact same question, you deserve to be punished (with downvotes). This sends a very clear message that such behavior is undesirable and it might create an incentive to look around a bit in the future.

Closing a duplicate question and helpfully referring to the original is obviously the best solution. Especially if it happens quickly enough so that there are no answers yet. But that requires a lot of people to have closing privileges, which is not currently the case. Perhaps it's just a matter of time before that will happen, but (at least) until then I think it would be desirable if most of the rest of the community would discourage posting duplicates (either by ignoring or downvoting).

"

data-item.data-item-item:

it wasnt too bad. hopefully the next unit is more challenging for you.

I've done a little bit of coding before, but I have never formally been taught any computer science. For me, the first unit was not at all wasted. This first unit has pretty much been review for me too. I've never used Python before, but it seems very simple compared to what I am used to (C++ and C#).

I have no idea how to write something useful in Python though. Nor do I know how to make a search engine. So if this class teaches me those, I will consider the time on the videos and assignments to be well spent.

If you already know Python and how to make a search engine, then there is a chance this class is not advanced enough for you. That doesn't make it a bad class though.

It was useful for me since I won't have to learn Python for the Car course !

What surprise me is that all the courses I saw begin from scrath (more or less) : IA, Search Engine, Car.

In IA, they explain probability basics very well, and it is done again in the Car lesson. They do the same thing again and again, instead of making a system that manages requierements.

But there is one really great thing : They show an incredible integration of applied theory. A bit more solid theory and it would be perfect.

You can always audit the course... It doesn't cost anything. Instead of playing a game online, take a moment to stimulate your brain cells in a different way.

No one programmer has the perfect solution or way of doing things. Yes, there are accepted methods and standards, and to get a professor's view is always helpful - even if it does nothing more than confirm what you have already been doing.

Having taught computer science myself, one of the primary goals and challenges for the instructor is to stimulate the minds of the students to think in the right direction. When a topic generates a lot of conversation within the class, the students start teaching themselves and often go beyond the designs of the course. That's when the curiosity and creativity start taking over and when it becomes fun for all levels of learners.

While I've been programming professionally in R and already know this section of Python, I even learned a few things. But if you find something boring because you know it already, that's great. It means you have that knowledge as it stands =).

From a programming perspective, yeah you may not learn much of anything from this course. That isn't why I signed up for it. I signed up to learn about how to create a search engine, of which I honestly don't know too much about. Right now the foundation is being set, so just give it time.

Having taught absolute beginners in computing and programming this is exactly the right way to do it.

The fact they are teaching beginners to do something powerful, like a search engine, will build people's confidence.

They've also tackled the syntax and grammar of a computer language at an early stage - so excellent work.

Anyway its easy to skip sections - but I betting you jump something important on the way.

I chose the beginning course because I have zero previous experience with Python and my overall programming experience is pretty limited, so I wasn't comfortable jumping straight into the advanced course...that said, there is a ""somewhere in the middle"" that a lot of us probably fall into. When you have a class whose target audience is people who are interested in programming, you're going to get a certain amount of people who already know a little and could skim at first.

Video lectures are good for their purpose but are inherently non-skimmable-- the medium takes the time it takes to play. What if there were also an edited, illustrated transcript, for the people who want to skim the topics at hand? It would also be useful as a reference for everyone and those who feel a need for a textbook could print them out and staple them together.

I realize it's a non-essential feature -- the course does work as-is -- so it won't be added soon, but I think it would be worth considering, to help out with varying learning styles and background knowledge.

"

"

I can understand that you would like to have a more advanced class.
However, you have to consider the aim of this class is. It says on the homepage ""This course expects no prior programming experience"" so as I understand it the target group are basically people who have nothing to little programming experience. If you have a look at the forum you can see, that there are already people struggling with some questions. So it seems as if the level is certainly not to ""basic"" for some of the beginners.
If you take a Business Spanish class on beginners level even though you have a intermediate level already would you complain if the first lessons are spend on basics of Spanish language? I hope not.
However, I hope that - as the class advances - you will find interesting aspects for you as well.

It's always good to begin with the basics. Whether it's your first language, or your ~20th, little differences in string and number handling and how the functions are expressed will still catch you if you don't pay attention.
Similarly, if you have only programmed apps, how the web works can be full of surprises when you start to put significant work together, so it's important to build soundly and not leave doubt.
I think they are right on target here.
For those of us who are more experienced, we can also learn how to teach well, and to then share knowledge with our more junior colleagues.

data-item.data-item-item: Can anyone give me an easy way to remember why it is the selection of the former one instead of the latter one?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

The indexing of a string starts at 0, not 1.

An easy way:
let's say we have the string ""space"",

s is 0

p is 1

a is 2

c is 3

e is 4

Hope that clears that up =]

P.S. - [2:3] means that it starts at the 2nd position and stops just before 3rd (that's why only 1 character is taken).

"

"

Because the first index is inclusive, and the second index is exclusive. And indexes start from 0.
Let me show:

s = ""Udacity"" #    0123456  are the indexes of the above string t = s[2:3] # means: extract charachters from s, starting at char 2  # (which is the third letter, 'a')  # and up to char 3, but excluding it

So you are selecting only one char, the third. Hope this is clear enough

"
Actually it doesn't. If string indexing was one relative, [2:3] would select the 2nd character.

"

Thank you but sorry it's not what I mean.
What I want to ask is that why, if taking ""space"" as the example, [2:3] can only select out ""a"" but not ""c"".
Thanks anyway.

"
I meant 2nd position as the 3rd character, please explain yourself.
@xiaoxin I explained that in the P.S.
First number is included but second is not. You start indexing from 0. So u get 0,1,2. [2:3] is read as [2:3(-1)]. I hope it helps

Some languages (Python is one) are zero relative (indexing starts at 0) while others are one relative (indexing starts at 1).

So the expression [2:3], which means select all characters, starting at position 2 and ending before position 3, would return the 3rd character in a zero relative language or the 2nd character in a one relative language. There is no scenario where it would return the 4th character.

"

Gotcha! Thank you it helps. But may I ask, why ""the first index is inclusive, and the second index is exclusive""? I mean it must have a kind of rule to determine. The inclusive, exclusive thing is still easily exchangable if I try to remember.

"
Have seen it. Thank you.

"

@xiaoxin No, it is not exchangeable, it's really just the rule of the language: from the first, inclusive, to the second, exclusive. In any language or string library that I know of, this is the way it works. When you program with string-splitting it's helpful though: if you know that you have to extract n charachters (let's say 4) from a string and you know that it starts at index i (let's say 3), the math is really simple:

s = ""---2012---"" #    0123456789 i = 3  # starting index n = 4  # number of chars for year year = s[i:i+n] # i + n is 7

Since last index is exclusive this will extract only the portion that you're interested in.

"
This is exactly what I look for! Thanks! No more question to bother you.
Thank you for the knowledge. I think I've got what I want to find out in the selected answer.

It's just the way the language designers chose to do it. Other languages do things differently, with some like Python selecting from position n to position m (or m-1 like Python), while other languages might select from position n for a length of m. The syntax of how this is done also varies from language to language.

I'd recommend using a stand alone client like mIRC though.

Here are the instructions

"
Could you please let me know a bit more detail on how to create an account and connect to IRC if its not very tedious for you to explain!! Thank you!

"

I'm assuming you already downloaded IRC. There are different versions (called clients) of IRC.

For Windows, the most used is mIRC. It's a good client, with the only possible problem being that when you open mIRC it always asks the user to buy a $20.00 registration code after an evaluation period. But this is not mandatory, and if you wait 5-10 seconds you will be able to click the continue button on that initial prompt window.

After that, a new prompt window, mIRC Options, pops up. Alternatively, you can click on Tools, then options, located in the top bar. Within the connect category, type your nickname to be used on servers, and an alternative in case someone is already using the first name. Click on the server sub-category (located within the connect category in the left side panel). This is where you choose a server to connect to.

This class channel is located on the freenode server. Look for it, double click on its folder, and double click on the server inside it,likely called random server (servers often have many sub-servers within it). If freenode isn't there, click on Add, then within the Description bar type Freenode, and within the IRC server bar type irc . freenode . net (don't put spaces around the dots. I'm doing that because you can't write out links in these forums). Then click Add. Then double click on the new freenode server in the list.

That will bring you back to the connect category. In there, click connect. Alternatively, you can click on the lightning symbol, located in the beginning of the second bar at the top. After connecting, you will get an mIRC favorites bar. Type the name of the channel, in this case ##udacity-cs101, and click Join (make sure to type those hash/number symbols in front of the channel name).

Also, you can read this: Getting Started with mIRC

to get a more graphical explanation of what I just said above. My explanation is just there for those few people (some of which I've met) who don't like to click on links in forums.

There is also a text based alternative to all this that can be used on any IRC client. At the bottom of all clients there is a bar to type commands or messages within a channel. All commands begin with the / symbol, which tells the client that your entering a command instead of a chat message. Make sure there are no spaces before the / character.

Enter /nick nickname to set your user name (replace nickname with a name of your choice).

Enter /server servername to connect to a server. In this case, type /server irc . freenode . net (again, don't put the spaces around the dots) to connect to the server where the udacity channels are on.

Enter /join channelname to join a channel. In this case, type /join ##udacity-cs101 to join our cs-101 channel.

Or as an another alternative to all this, just click on the nice web interface link in the post at the top of this page.

"

Thanks for your post. I agree engaging the material as you describe is essential. I'm only just beginning, so I have some practicing to do :-). It is kind of cool that one can try a course like cs373 and kind of gauge where they're at in terms of Python/math skills/computer science skills. If you find you aren't skilled enough to handle the course, and you have sufficient time,motivation, etc., you can acquire what you need and try again at relatively little cost.

CS373, however, is more than understanding loops and control statements. It's also about implementation of some of the underlying theory and implementation of the math involved. Some of the execution may be simple arithmetic but the underlying theory itself is not. And I'm just thinking of Bayes networks and probability theory for the basic arithmetic.

If we start talking about using n-camera computer vision inorder to generate 3D maps of the world (for example), things can get complex pretty quickly. Understanding the underlying mathematical theory can help you understand how to do an implementation. So I disagree that you don't need prerequisites to understand the theory.

@melodybliss
The prerequisites are made up of two: math and programming.
I was referring only to the latter.

(i.e. if I finish CS101, am I ready for CS373 Python-wise?)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

From PEP 8 -- Style Guide for Python Code

Maximum Line Length

Limit all lines to a maximum of 79 characters.  There are still many devices around that are limited to 80 character lines-- plus, limiting windows to 80 characters makes it possible to have several windows side-by-side.  The default wrapping on such devices disrupts the visual structure of the code, making it more difficult to understand.  Therefore, please limit all lines to a maximum of 79 characters.  For flowing long blocks of text (docstrings or comments), limiting the length to 72 characters is recommended.  The preferred way of wrapping long lines is by using Python's implied line continuation inside parentheses, brackets and braces.  Long lines can be broken over multiple lines by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These should be used in preference to using a backslash for line continuation. Make sure to indent the continued line appropriately.  The preferred place to break around a binary operator is *after* the operator, not before it. Some examples:  class Rectangle(Blob):      def __init__(self, width, height,                  color='black', emphasis=None, highlight=0):         if (width == 0 and height == 0 and             color == 'red' and emphasis == 'strong' or             highlight >-- 100):             raise ValueError(""sorry, you lose"")         if width == 0 and height == 0 and (color == 'red' or                                            emphasis is None):             raise ValueError(""I don't think so -- values are %s, %s"" %                              (width, height))         Blob.__init__(self, width, height,                       color, emphasis, highlight)

Edit: almost forgot, this is not recommended, and they don't show an example, but it is possible to escape a line break with a backlash like this:

if a = True and \    b = False
