data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Just use the str() function like the nice professor in the video said

This question has been answered many times. You may solve the problem using techniques outside what has been taught in the class so far. However it is possible to do this with what the class has provided.

Two hints may help. First, don't do the rounding as you would be doing as if you are doing it by hand. Second, since you can't do much after you've converted the number to a string, the rounding (or part of it) should be done before the conversion.

You don't even need to do a string conversion, because if you solved it with an if-else statement then you already rounded x there, so just do a print x at the end of the code and you're set, because the print function automatically converts it's non-keyword arguments to strings.
Im afraid that itis the str function that caused the problem. Thanks. What is happening here is I cange the number to the rounded number then change that to a string.

heh i know i had trouble with str() too i had to re-watch a few lessons to figure out what i was doing wrong you need most of what we have been taught so far. From what you said i'd say you are doing it right, maybe you just need to try different syntax?

The key here is to think of rounding as truncating... there is more you have to to answer the question, but all you have learned in Unit 1 is enough to do the job..

..in one line of code, no less.

Yup, one line will do it! But don't think you're not any good at this if you need more than one line. Learning to program by first taking baby steps is the best way. Then, later on, you can start combining things.

Using only what you learned in unit 1, think about what you can do with the digits after the decimal that would change the digits before the decimal if necessary. Since you'll only be printing out the digits before the decimal, it doesn't matter what happens to the right of the decimal.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

In unit 1, relationship between the speed of light and ghz of a processor is mentioned, but I don't understand this.
In a pdf external document of this unit is written:

""A processor has to be small to execute programs quickly. If your computer's processor were any
larger than the size of a dollar bill, then you couldn't even send light from one end of the processor to the other before finishing the execution of a single step in a program"".

Then, if I have a 2.7 Ghz processor: one cycle is executed in 1/2.7 nanoseconds.
In 1/2.7 nanoseconds, light travels 299792458 * 100 * 1.0/1000000000 *1/2.7 = 11.1034243704 centimeters.
What happen if my 2.7 Ghz processor is more than 11.1034243704 centimeters.
With that I just explained, it seems that there is a relationship between size of processor and speed of light.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: There indeed is a relationship between speed of light and size of a processor. In order to function, processor needs to send signals from one part to another. This signal needs to arrive on time as part of a cycle. In case a processor would have been big enough for even the light not able to travel the distance of the signal being sent, you can be sure that the signal would not arrive on time under no circumstances. This is vastly simplified explanation, but it shall work to answer your question.

"

Thanks for the reply Mareq.
But when you said: ""processor needs to send signals from one part to another""-- a signal may travel a distance less than the size of the processor.

I have no idea and maybe that I just said is something crazy.
Then, even if my 2.7 Ghz processor is 12 centimeters and light travels 11.1034243704 centimeters in a cycle of this processor, if the signal travels a shorter distance of 12 cm, my processor could be 12 cm and signal would arrive on time.

Sorry for my poor english.

"

As I wrote, it is vastly oversimplified. Electrons carrying that signal probably do not travel the speed of light and the distance they need to travel is not the straight line across processor, since they travel through the processor's circuitry.

In order to accurately answer your question, lots of (quantum) physics and also processor architecture would be involved. Since I am not an expert in neither of those, I do not aspire to give you the full detailed answer, which would actually get pretty complicated.

However, to simplify it, let's say that during one cycle, the signal needs to travel from one circuit to the other. Overall distance of the path, this signal needs to travel during one cycle (thus the size of the processor itself is again big oversimplification, but it illustrates the point) definitely needs to be shorter than some number like 12cm (another oversimplification), because then it is impossible (at least according to our current knowledge) for the signal to reach its destination on time.

The clock signal also travels at the speed of light. But propagation delay is probably not as important as transmission line effects. The study of electromagnetic phenomena shows that distortion of signals can occur when the transmission line is longer than about 1/4 of the clock period X c.

I think the materials just tried to explain how mind bogglingly fast CPUs are these days. If they were more than 12 cm long, they could still function, but the engineers designing them would have a lot more trouble accounting for the significant delays in signals.

Think about satellite calls, and the hassle that latency creates.

I think you guys are going off on a tangent here. Eduardo noticed it. The speed of a processor (i.e. 2.7 Ghz) is the internal clock frequency. You can say that the higher the freq. the faster the processor as long as you are comparing the same processor. The speed of light may be important in processor design but not necessarily related to how big (physical dimensions) a processor chip is. Depending on the packing density of the chip and the architecture, you could build very large chips and still have no problems. That is because, as Eduardo stated, signals only have to travel between 2 elements and not from one end to the other.
I hope this is understandable. I just wanted to give a short answer without going into CPU design.

Speed of light is constant.

All processor's internal components have to work synchronously.

Information delivery cannot be faster than speed of light.

Duration of one cycle is defined by the clock speed.

During one cycle the information can be delivered to a limited distance only.

Processor cannot start new cycle before all components end processing of the current one.

Maximum processor size is limited by the processor speed, or

maximum processor speed is limited by the processor size.

In other words:

Slow processors can be large.

Fast processors must be small.

"

All of the musings on this topic are worthwhile. I was privileged, about 30 years ago to attend a lecture given by Admiral Grace Hopper when she was about 75 years old, and she did, indeed, hand out wire ""nanoseconds"" to make her point that light travels quickly and that computers operating at Megahertz rates (at the time) had to take signal delay into account. Here's a short explanation of her motivations from techtarget . ""Admiral Hopper believed that by providing the learner with a concrete analogy already in their frame of reference, it was possible to absorb and even understand an abstract concept that might otherwise be too difficult to comprehend. Towards the end of her life, when asked which of her many accomplishments she was most proud of, Admiral Hopper replied, 'All the young people I have trained over the years'.""

"

Just to clarify a side concept, not to answer the question, which is already answered. The speed of an electric signal and the speed of the charged particles traveling are completely different, because of the same reason why electrical resistance exists. The speed of the signal is the speed of light, or more broadly of electro-magnetic fields (of which light is composed as well), but as for the speed of electrons in copper for example I think I read somewhere you could pretty much outrun them in most typical cases. Particles are colliding with atoms every little while and that slows them down-- only in superconductors they move more efficiently.

The signal doesn't have to wait until the electron from one end of the wire travels to the other end: there are always free electrons all along the whole wire. When you apply the voltage the electrons on the sending end start moving towards the receiving end, but the ones that were already just on the receiving end before the voltage was applied are feeling the same force (field), and don't wait for their buddies to start moving. It's this field what's propagated at the speed of light. And of course new electrons will be entering the wire from the power source/sender, and the ones exiting the wire from the receiving end will be entering the load/receiver.

The current starts moving along the whole conductor at the same time (almost instantly--the field propagates at the speed of light), but the current itself is pretty slow. Think about having a pool of water on a table, and then suddenly you tilt the table: does the water on the downslope area wait for the water upslope to start spilling?

"

I am not an expert on this topic either. Thanks to @Mareq and @Alter Hase for your answers.

"

I was never a fan of how Python does this.

"

Well, I suppose to some extent these kinds of design decisions are arbitrary. However, it's a common programming task to say something like, ""give me the first 10 characters of string x, or whatever's there if x is shorter than 10 characters"". It would be a nuisance to have to check your string first to see how long it actually is. On the other hand, if you really do need exactly 10 characters, then you could check the string length. I guess the general design philosophy is, have your operators and functions optimized to make it easy to do the more common tasks (and less common tasks might take a few more lines of code).

"

If you ask python for a specific part of a string and the part you ask for doesn't exist the program doesn't know what to do and quits.

If you ask for a range it gives you every thing in that range weather or not the end points of the range are valid.

s = 'hi' print s[0] #works there is a something at 0 'h' print s[1] #works there is something at 1 'i' print s[2] #doesn't work 2 isn't a valid input print s[:2]  #Prints every thing between the start of the string and 2.   'hi' print s[2:4]  #prints a empty string because it doesn't care that the end points for the range aren't in the list ''

data-item.data-item-item: So, to get credit on problem 9 of the homework we can only use what was covered in unit 1? Or are we allowed to use other commands to get the answer? I found a way to do it in one line, but I don't understand how to do it with str(). What am I missing?

data-item.data-item-item: I found a solution to question 9 using the str() function and what has been taught in Unit 1. It rounds numbers up and down correctly, however the result is a string. Is this considered correct or should I find a way to convert the string to number?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: The assignment is to print it, so it doesn't matter whether it is a string or a number I would say, as long as it looks the same.

I used a string in the program I submitted.

There is a built-in function called eval that can convert a string to a number, but it hasn't been covered in the lessons and I would avoid it in a project like a search engine (it's a potential security risk - if somebody crafts a web page to exploit a bug, they can trick your crawler into running their code.)
You should use the int() function if you want to convert a string to an integer. You want to avoid eval at all costs.

I didn't know about eval() or int(), I was trying to figure a way to do it with the information given in Unit 1. Basicaly I wanna know what is the question asking for, because I may be trying to find a better way for no reason.

"

In the comments it says to print a 'number', so it still is unclear to me. If a string is an acceptable answer I suggest that you add this information to avoid confusion.

EDIT: Firstly I didn't understand why you said that it doesn't matter if it's a string or a number because we print it anyway, I get it after reading Fuzzmz's explanation too. Thanks.

"

Short answer is that it is correct, you'll end up printing a string.

As a sidenote, the print function automatically converts everything to a string in order to print it, but this is besides the point.
Your sidenote is what makes it clear for me. I didn't know that print converts everything to a string. Now I understand why there is no point to find an actual number. Thank you.

When printing it out, all numbers are converted to a string automatically. A statement like:

print 15

will first convert the number 15 to the characters '1' and '5' (in decimal notation) and then print out those two characters.

In fact, there are more steps: Since the characters you typed into the editor are in fact characters and thus form a string, the interpreter first has to convert this string '15' into a number in binary representation, and will only convert it back to a string when the print statement is executed. But this is not so much part of the program, but part of the way it is interpreted.
i think we can print it as string as other functions hasn't been covered yet.

"

@rhasarub Sorry, I started editing my comment above before I saw your post. Thanks for the explanation.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I did not understand the explanation of why s.find("""") always returns a zero. Why is an empty string found in a string such as s = ""string"" and why would the index position be zero?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I think that a string in Python is a concatenation of empty string with other characters.

"

Every string of any length contains an empty string, so it will always be found. This has been discussed previously here:

Empty string ambiguity

"

The index position is 0 because what is to be returned is the value of the index when the search first succeeds, searching left to right. Since the null string is postulated to be a substring of every string, and since the first character in any string is itself a string with zero as its index value, the search succeeds immediately, as soon as it is begun, and zero is returned.

Python2 or Python3?

This course may be about computer science and programming but I find that actually working through some of the code with a pencil and paper and actually doing the computations helps a lot in understanding what is going on. data-item.data-item-item:
Hi there,

Was going to ask what many may think is a stupid question, but I'm curious

How are homework assignments actually marked?

Given that there are so many students in the course, I think they are likely to be marked by a computer program based on the final output.

However, that alone might not accurately determine if the answer is correct or wrong. Since one could just print out the correct answer and gets it correct which is what I have tested in the quizzes. So if a full computer based marking solution is required, it may mean a need to check for intermediate correct steps as well which could be difficult and still cheatable as there are so many ways to reach a solution and what if it got marked wrongly? Is it capable of knowing how good one solution is?

So to me a 100% accurate marking is probably not possible but a question of making it very reliable for the vast majority and making very obvious cheating methods fail.

So wondering just how far do the marking systems actually go to ensure the answer given is as correct as possible? Would be interested to know the challenges involved in computer grading systems.

P.S In the unlikely event if the homework assignments are really handgraded, please let me know too --)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
The homework assignments are computer-graded, tho I don't know the exact algorithm.

Udacity has tons of students, I sure wouldn't won't the homework to be handgraded --)

I assume that they are, however, changing the initial variables while grading. That's why we need to enter code under certain comments, so that later it would be easy to reuse it with a different set of initial variables.

"

I'm also 99.999% sure that the homeworks are graded via computer. Put in probability terms ... P(computer_graded) = 0.99999 --)

But just printing out the ""correct answers"" probably would fail the test. A simple method for them to check the programming homework would be to substitute new data for the header portion.

If you noticed (for example, homework 1-9) that they said ""ENTER CODE BELOW HERE ... INCORRECT"". Above that section is the variable assignment to x (3.14159). By removing up to that comment and inserting a new assignment to x, they can test to see if your code is robust enough to handle different situations.

x=99193? yup. x=99.123456? yup. etc.

If you just put a print statement with the correct answer to the problem as given then the answer would never change everytime they introduced a different x. Also if you (incorrectly) modified things above that comment line where they said not to make changes... then the program will likely fail. In either event, an incorrect answer or a program failure should be detected as a failure to the grading system.

"
So with that probability, if there are over 100 000 students, 1 student might be lucky and get their homework hand graded? --) Pick me! Pick me!
I completely agree with you. This may be the way they grade the homework. With so many students, hand-grading is just not feasible. Furthermore, remember this is a free class.
I think they're using Mechanical Turk to grade the exams.
Wow this Amazon Mechanical Turk seem interesting

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi, I could not understand how an empty string is always found in a string as explained in video 33 of Unit 1.

Could you, please help me ?
Thank you.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Empty string is simply nothing, i.e. zero. Just as you will find empty set in any set, you can find empty string in any string.

Indeed, you can find empty string in any string, but not just at the beginning (as shown / asked on quizzes), but between every single character also (actually, you have an infinite number of empty strings between two characters, but this is irrelevant). You just need to remember that you can have an empty string before or after every character in a string!

Yes, I remember every set contains the empty set, but this .find function seems to be asking something different. .find is used to locate a position. How can the empty sting have a position. Clearly, the non-empty string starts at zero-- the empty string is there, but doesn't really have a start position. It seems to me that the empty sting is just assumed to start at the first position. There's no real logic going on here. It's just part of the language we have to accept. If there is logic here, someone please explain.

"

Example: ""hello""

between the 'e' and the 'l', there is an empty string. at what position does it start? It starts at position 2. Then how is it possible that l also starts at position 2? Well, the length of the empty string is 0, i.e. it takes in 0 positions. This explains it in my opinion. Same as with 'e', it starts at position 1. Why does 'l' starts at position 2? Because the length of 'e' is one. You just have to see the empty string as a string of length 0, or a single character, and the length of that character being 0 (this is actually the underlying case in most of the programming languages, but this is once again irrelevant)

"

"

As BFC stated, there are infinite number of empty strings in any string and they are just about everywhere. Let's think about sets and let's make a string to be an ordered set of characters. Then, let's have e.g. string s = ""foo"". Then, you can imagine that string like this:

s = { <--infinite number of empty strings>--, 'h', <--infinite number of empty strings>--, o, <--infinite number of empty strings>--, o, <--infinite number of empty strings>-- }

Thus, anywhere you try to search, you will always find an empty string. It is the same as if you were trying to find empty set (e.g. ""set of no apples"") in and ordered set (e.g. { <--green apple>--, <--yellow apple>--, <--red apple>-- } - you will find an empty set in any place in the set you are searching in:

A = { <--infinite number of no apples>--, <--green apple>--, <--infinite number of no apples>--, <--yellow apple>--, <--infinite number of no apples>--, <--red apple>--, <--infinite number of no apples>-- }

This is just a try to visualize what BFC had already written.

"

It's just by definition. No matter how many rationales you come up for it and how good they are, the method could have been defined otherwise. People often don't realize how many things even in mathematics hold simply by definition, like in set theory, or (-1)Â·(-1)=1
Yes, but the definition is formed by logic, and we try to explain that logic

Definitions are utilitarian, that is the ones that result in the most powerful/useful algebras. You could come up with a new algebra and define a set called fancypants numbers. But if they're not as useful as complex numbers for example, nobody will use them.

In this case I'm sure computer scientists have their reason for this, because Python isn't the only language that does it. For example string.IndexOf() in .NET behaves in the same way. Another option could have been throwing an error (.NET does if you pass a null reference instead of an empty string), I'm not sure why they thought this was better.

If I am not mistaken, the + operator can be used to insert the null string anywhere in a string, or at its beginning or end, without changing its length. Moreover, a comparison of strings before and after insertion of any finite number of empty strings would find them to be equal. If you can find a way to insert an infinite number of null strings, still equal :) This construct called the empty string seems to have the same function as zero has in real-number arithmetic with respect to the + and - operators.

Hi, many thanks for everyone who help me to understand this concept.
Kindest regards.

Yes. This behaviour is not logical.
e.g.
''.find('') return 0
'hello'.find('') return 0

Then, according Python empty string starts at the zero position.

data-item.data-item-item:

data-item.data-item-item:
How can s.find('') always be zero, no matter what the string s consists of?

Yes, I remember every set contains the empty set, but this .find('')function seems to be asking something different. .find is used to locate a position, which is associated with a specific value. How can the empty sting have a position? Clearly, the non-empty string starts at zero-- the empty string is there, but doesn't really have a start position. It seems to me that the empty sting is just assumed to start at the first position. It seems there's no real logic going on here. It's just a convention of the python language we have to accept. If there is logic here, someone please explain.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Example: ""hello""

between the 'e' and the 'l', there is an empty string. at what position does it start? It starts at position 2. Then how is it possible that l also starts at position 2? Well, the length of the empty string is 0, i.e. it takes in 0 positions. This explains it in my opinion. Same as with 'e', it starts at position 1. Why does 'l' starts at position 2? Because the length of 'e' is one. You just have to see the empty string as a string of length 0, or a single character, and the length of that character being 0 (this is actually the underlying case in most of the programming languages, but this is once again irrelevant)

"

"

Probably the logic is in how .find() is actually implemented. Most algorithms when searching are optimistic and say: I'm going to compare characters one by one and if I don't have mismatches then I found it. If there are no characters to compare, then, well, there are no mismatches and they just skip to the ""I found it"" part. Pretty much like innocent until proven guilty I guess.

"

IMHO, there is a consistent logic behind it:

  • assuming that empty string is every where in the string eliminates special behavior for empty arguments in most cases. this means less conditional, which is a good thing most of the time.
  • empty string is not at the beginning, it is just everywhere: s.find('') is 0, s.find('', 3) is 3.

"

The empty string can be ""found"" between every pair of characters, and ""between"" the beginning of the string and the first character. The result of the ""find()"" method gives the location of the character after the found string. Since the first instance of the empty string is at the beginning of the string, the result is the first character, character 0. As slow down mentions, if you specify another starting location for your search, you will immediately find an instance of the empty string.

"

data-item.data-item-item: A plan for a search engine contest was mentioned at the end of the office hours video. Did this pique the interest of anyone else as much as it did for me?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It was announced here.

"
Yes it's very exciting!

Since I first saw the video I have been wondering how far we'd be in the process of having a real good knowledge of the processes when the contest kicks in.
It hopefully won't stop people from helping one another, but I am personally looking forward to it.
I am really excited about the contest!

It's just and idea and I am not even sure whether it is in line with rules of the contest, but it would be interesting to create an open source project with a group of people involved (collaboration is just more fun than solo-ride) somewhere e.g. on github or so.
totally agree
well, it was exciting for me. but it wont drive away my interest of helping others out..:)
I will probably adapt it and try to index the data of my website, but i don't think I will try to compete in the contest.
I would love to start a project with some other students.

I have been looking into how search engines work since I read there was a contest, and it turns out they are are actually quite complicated. I wrote a small program using some of the code we learned in the lesson that just goes to a website and extracts all the links on the page (I used the urllib2 library). This is surprisingly difficult because the href tag often appears before broken links and invalid links. On the one hand, broken links can easily tested by just trying to go to the broken website. On the other hand, invalid links are very hard to identify. They often appeared muddled up in javascript but sometimes completely isolated.

I'm very interested in the contest as well. I think this is very exciting.

I'm also interested in natural collaborative efforts that might come to fruition due to this course. Really, more interested in long-term projects of interest than specifically the contest, but who knows? It may all work out. I have a feeling that if a small group was to come up with something truly innovative based on these courses, that group might find itself in Palo Alto visiting Profs. Evans and Thrun --)
Interesting idea. But I'm not sure that the project would stayed alive longer than a few months.
I am actually looking forward to the contest. It will be fun either to work as a group or even as individual. At this point we still don't know the contour of the contest. I am eager to plunge in.
Best improvements to the search engine - Does that mean all will be given a basic search engine to improve? Or will we have to make one from scratch?

There are a lot of boutique search types that are desperately needed and could be useful to humanity.
Crowdsourcing the construction of one could be very interesting, especially coming from a bunch of fresh thinkers who aren't caught up in certain execution dogmas.

Goog has way too much influence.
You'll be building one during lecture.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

After crawling the web trying to answer this question (for myself) I stumbled upon this recent article which pretty much sum-sup the power of Udacity.
Enjoy!
How Udacity's Greatest Effect ...

How do you think Udacity will impact your learning experience, in and outside institutional walls and into the web?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I've seen the future, and the future is now!

I've been teaching lecture classes for decades, and now can see my own obsolescence-- good thing it's almost time to retire! But there is much institutional resistance.. I myself taught an online math course a few years ago, and allowed in all who wanted to take it (instead of the usual limit of 35). I ended up with about 100 students, which doesn't seem like anything compared to Udacity enrollments. But 100 was a sufficiently high number to incite the ire of our dean (though it cost nothing more that it would have had I only allowed in 35 students). C'est la vie.

It would be wonderful to have Udacity-like mathematics courses too!

"

MIT Mathematics Online

When it comes to computer programming/hacking I'm mostly self taught. This is my first online class. Besides that, I took a class on db design at my old university (I'm not a CS major... I just like computers/programming alotta).

Since everything is online I feel like I don't have to pay to go to the university and sit in a class to learn to do programming. I can jump online, read some program documents and forums to learn to do something, and then I can go on with life. Homework is nice and working in groups is fun too, but that can be accomplished (bare bones) online as well. I understand that interacting personally with individuals builds good social relationships and make good connections... but I feel that as these courses become more and more refine, online learning will surpass anything our current institutions can provide.

Perhaps this generation that witness the online class revolution (and who are heavily in debt to school loans) will tell their children that paying $$$,$$$ for school is not worth it. If you want to learn, learn from online... the community will be there.

I also think that if institution want to compete with the online class they will have to offer/provide the option at a much much cheaper price or free(??).

I've been tutoring math and physics for sometime... I get all my material from different sites... pick out problems that I think the student might learn from, key concepts, etc. . With all the resources I have amasses I feel like I can start my own online class!!

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

At DLD 2012, Sebastian Thrun poses a challenge to education: How can you make a personal experience with 160,000 students? He posts an email from a student claiming: ""[The course] feels more intimate than most of the lectures I attended in the past. I felt that you were both personally tutoring me."" So... after one unit of study in CS101, what are your thoughts/experiences on this question?

Would you argue that you feel a closer connectivity to the instructor in CS101 compared to traditional classroom lectures?

It is a presentation worth watching if you are interested the future of education/universities: link text

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Yes, I think it's an incredible teaching method, it's almost like one on one tutoring. I teach at a university and I have been disillusioned for some time about how the whole system works. I love open courseware and think it is amazing that the worlds leading institutions share content for free online, but Udacity is a real leap forward and I think we are witnessing a real change in education. I can't Thank Sebastian and Dave enough.

Personally:

  • Big Picture: I enjoy the project-based, problem-based, collaborative approach to the course. It is truly 21st Century learning. We feel like are are building towards something... that learning has a purpose.
  • Lectures: I do feel a sense on intimacy... and that surprises me. I am not sure exactly what it is, but there is something about learning in small steps, with quizzes that check for understanding, with the ability to replay when necessary, with the ability to view the lecture anytime, anywhere... it gives the impression of personalization (despite the fact that thousands of others are going through the same process.) Brilliant.
We are constantly interested in getting student feedback in order to make the experience here as good as possible. We love threads like this and share them around the office.

My thoughts exactly.

What I like most, above all, are the video lectures. The way everything is explained so clearly and concisely is very effective. The quizzes are very useful, too.

In a traditional classroom,

  • you cannot see the face of a teacher this much closer.
  • you cannot hear him this much well
  • teacher most probably not as good as Dave or Sebastian

The idea of online learning is your own pace and you're not under any pressure from classmates as well as teachers. At home you have the ability to come who you want to be thanks to the worldwideweb anything is possible. When you watch online seminars the ability to re-wine something when you don't get it the first is almost magical in a sense.

I am going to go with no here. I don't feel a closer connectivity to the teacher with online courses because here I can't literally go to him in order to ask questions after a class, or set up an appointment during his office hours to brainstorm ideas for a project.

That is a much more personal experience, interacting live with a teacher and having a back and forth that isn't available online, where it's never one-to-one, it's always one-to-many.

Maybe I've been just lucky to have amazing and dedicated teacher who always had time for student questions and never refused to meet with students, be them individually or a small group (during group projects), and at times even after office hours.

I've taught college mathematics lecture courses for a quarter of a century. It's becoming quite clear that there is a much better way to teach than the traditional lecture class format. Udacity and Coursera demonstrate much more effective ways to facilitate learning. In a lecture course, often there are surprisingly few students who comprehend the lecture material, which zips by too fast (for math classes anyway). The pace of a live lecture course is determined by the amount of material that must be covered and the limited days available in which to cover it. Unfortunately, students can only absorb the material at their own pace, which varies considerably from student to student. Since students can rewind the lecture, or view it multiple times, the lecture class is inherently rather ineffective. The advantages of this online format are obvious and profound-- students can go at their own pace, and can pause and rewind lectures, and watch them multiple times. And at home in pajamas even! :-)
Thank you for offering a differing point of view than the majority opinion. Your ideas are valuable.

"

""The pace of a live lecture course is determined by the amount of material that must be covered and the limited days available in which to cover it."" You've touched upon a key shift in our thinking as educators. I think we are moving from the idea of ""covering"" content to ""uncovering"" content.

"

I can't say that I necessarily feel that there is a closer student-professor connection than in a live class, but I certainly think there is a more active community than you would find in a lecture setting. In many cases, the only times you'll work with other students are when you are forced to work on projects and assignments in a group. The support and assistance from members of the Udacity course is not something you will ever find in a classroom of 30 students. I will say, though, that while we are not getting assistance from Dave, Peter's presence in the forums has been extraordinarily helpful, and that is far more than I have seen in regular college courses.

Even though this course is virtual, it has a couple dynamic aspects missing from many lectures. I really am enjoying the frequent opportunity questions, which keeps me engaged and testing my skills (I know that many in-person courses are now starting to adopt this). I'm also really enjoy seeing the lecture written out, rather than have my eyes glaze over while watching a boring slide deck.
Can't say at this stage. The fact that this is just a beginner level course similar to something I have already undertaken in C makes it harder for me to judge

The instructor is very personable. This helps me to enjoy and learn as opposed to an instructor who might grate. The same would be true in a classroom environment. Regarding the same instructor teaching me in a class full of people or through online videos, I must say I prefer the latter.

It's not about feeling a connection to the instructor, but rather convenience and my pace of learning as you pointed out. Concentrating on a stream of information given at a classroom lecture while trying to take notes and not miss any important points while at the same time trying to assimilate the info in a concrete way meanwhile you are thinking about the crucial concept that was just mentioned and another is being thrown at you, but darn, I missed the start of what he said because I was thinking about the previous thing). The previous sentence was long to help illustrate the problem of information dumps at lectures.

With online videos, pacing is under the control of the student. Even better, this course's videos are not hour long marathons, but bite-size videos of a few minutes long. This gives me the opportunity to reflect a moment on what I have just learned and consider whether I should click forward to the next video, or replay to ensure I've fully absorbed what was said. If a student finds they absorb information better at a particular time of day or night, online videos are perfect.

I haven't attended a college, but I've watched some college lectures online. Some had bad audio, some were of a low resolution which made reading the blackboard or slide shows difficult. I much prefer Udacity's bite-size, high quality method. Even the gadget the instructor uses to prevent his hand blocking what he has written adds that extra bit of helpfulness to remove any obstacle from learning. I hope to successfully complete this course and choose a second class that will further my understanding of Python and computer science in general or maybe my math skills so that taking CS373 might be possible as a third course.

Ahh... you have raised two great ideas that I didn't even consider:
1) a more active community than you would find in a lecture setting
2) Peter's presence in the forums

So, to summarize your main points:
1) personable instructor
2) student-determined pace
3) student-determined timing
4) bite-sized videos allow for reflection
5) high quality audio/video

"

This is true. However, the online forums fill much of the gap! I'm amazed at how quickly questions get answered there. In fact, I've TRIED to be the first to answer a question, hitting ""newest"" and when a new one appears, typing frantically to submit it before someone else has answered it, and all to no avail- someone beat me to it. The quality of the answers is often surprisingly good, and I've learned much from reading threads (even though I consider myself a pretty good Python programmer). So here the community can more than take the place of those rare ""office hours"", when you're lucky enough to find your prof actually there, and lucky enough to have a prof who isn't annoyed having to deal with a student. All in all, I strongly believe that 99% of the time this online format is more effective than the traditional lecture class. In those rare instances where a prof happens to be a brilliant lecturer and educator, shouldn't their gifts be shared with thousands of students per semester, rather than 35?

"
I don't feel a closer connectivity to the instructor in this way of learning, but I do feel a closer connectivity to the materials covered in the course.

I love the way these courses are run. I do feel a real connection to the lecturers. I enjoyed getting the emails congratulating me on having completed the homeworks - I knew that they were going out to tens of thousands of people, the letter even acknowledged that, but it didn't make any difference to me. I really like the on-going quizzes, which show me where my gaps in understanding are.

I teach middle school robotics, and a year and a half ago, I started using screencasts for one of my units. It was mindblowing to see my students watching the screencast, then ALL BY THEMSELVES writing a little program in Smalltalk. My smarter students just love speeding ahead at their own pace, and I am available to work with the slower students who have a harder time understanding a few concepts. I am about to add the on-going quizzes to some of my courses.

I loved being able to watch the videos in ai-class and here over and over again, in case I missed something. I think that this is the future of education - in fact, I am about to ask my principal if I can have a random sample of low math students in my plan period next year. I propose to have them use Khan Academy, with me there to help. I am so certain that they would be more successful on their comprehensive assessment tests than the students in the regular intensive math classes.

I can see myself becoming completely addicted to Udacity. I had planned to learn Python this year anyway, so this course is ideal, and I am looking forward to the Web applications course later. I nearly applied for the Technical Writer position, just so that I could be part of this new approach.
Ha! Now that's insightful. It's a better way of phrasing my question as well.

@rockradio... I agree with you. Today, I decided to print out the course notes in order to tackle the homework and what a difference. Perhaps it is my learning style, but seeing the coursework on paper changed everything to me. That said, my favorite part of this course so far as been the video lessons. Hmm. That's a contradiction, isn't it?

The experience with CS101 and the AI class has been great-- I feel very connected. I have finite time for class, and this format lets me work my way forward incrementally. Sometimes, it is 15 minutes before I go to sleep, and sometimes 4 hours continuous. Our teachers have been great, about the best I ever had.

I have to say that this is one of the better online courses I've taken, but it still doesn't replace being able to go to the professor's office hours or to schedule an appointment with him with email. I know we're only in the first week and I'm already finding it challenging (that's a great thing!) but I wish there was some way of reaching out to a professor or a tutor for assistance.
You got an email congratulating you on having completed your homework? I don't remember getting one of these.
^ Books are helpful (:

"

And you cannot ask teacher to repeat something over and over again until you ""get it""

"

"

Questions asked in this forum get answered VERY quickly. This makes up for a lack of ""office hours"" IMHO...

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Observed Behavior

So I was watching the video on 'Extracting Links', video number 38. At this point in time, I had already completed the associated quiz and had been awarded a green check mark.

After completing the video and clicking on the next video, 'Final Quiz', my green check mark was replaced with a yellow circle. And to make the matter even more interesting, after leaving the course content page and coming back, the yellow circle has been replaced by a green check mark.

Expected Behavior

My intuition is that the green check mark would never dissapear after being earned, unless perhaps if this action was explicitly instructed by the user. Maybe, in the future, it will be possible to reset earned yellow circles and green check marks in order to make re-taking a course easier.

Also, I just want to say thank you for creating this website. It has truly reigniting my passion for computer science, which had dulled somewhat after graduating school and starting work. I truly believe in the goals the Udacity team is trying to achieve, and I want to acknowledge that the team is doing a superb job. I cannot wait to take all 10 courses planned for 2012.

"

Calling all you Utterly Udacious Udacians !!!

Discussion groups (on Facebook) CompScisters and CompSciblings are entering their second semester of operation.

If you are interested in gender-related issues, and are taking the free on-line courses offered by Udacity, Coursera, or MITx within the STEM (1) departments, please consider joining us !

These groups are not specifically study groups, (although there are certainly sometimes study-related discussions and threads in them ) - they are more oriented to being a place for discussion, support, socializing, networking and occasional generalised hi-jinks!

So if you are interested in how gender issues relate to STEM (*), and would like to network with others with similar interests, come along and see us today!

CompScisters Women only please :) (2)

CompSciblings All genders welcome! (male/female/trans/other)

CompBros - doesn't exist yet, but if any of you XY types feel the need or desire, go ahead and start it! (feel free to choose own name of course :) )

(1) STEM = ""Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics""

(2) Formerly AI-Systers

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Much appreciated. Not for me but maybe others will be up for it :D good luck!

"

We really do not know why the numbers are as low as they are, but we do know that discrimination, at least in the USA, has little to nothing to do with it. It seems to be a choice that girls and women have been consistently making, and this is despite the fact that over 50% of medical school applicants are women..
In STEM, just as in AI Class, there were only 10% of us, and that was the reason we formed these two groups.

CompScisters is a place to hang out and be with others who have had similar experiences, much of the talk is technical and professional, but it is super nice to interface in an environment with so many peers. It is primarily a social experience for women. I can't tell you how exciting it is for me meet women from Pakistan, Katmandu, Madrid.. all over the world - and we all share the exact same experience - for what ever reason our numbers are very very low.

But CompSciblings is where the real work is being done by both men and women.. looking at studies, trying to figure out what exactly is causing those numbers to be so low. We were honored this week for Peter Norvig to join this group. Both Sebastian Thrun and Peter Norvig have acknowledged that they themselves have witnessed this issue, and are concerned about it. Sebastian made mention of this topic at DLD, he feels strongly that he is ""missing half of the population"" in the field of AI (and Computer Science generally).
So, join us, we would genuinely appreciate your contribution - and have I mentioned, Wendy Langer bakes a really mean chocolate chip cookie ?

"

Support for cs373 can be found in the Facebook group : ""Programming A Robotic Car - Taught by Sebastian Thrun""

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Google's back-end processes are programmed in C and C++, but Google uses Python for a great deal of their work. They even teach Python courses to their employees.

The basic answer is for simplicity. Python syntax and form is much, much simpler (and easier to read by humans) than C or C++. On a course that has no prior knowledge of programming as a prerequisite, Python is by far the best option.

data-item.data-item-item:
Since apparently this isn't as obvious to some people is it is to other, I think a few things need to be mentioned.

EDIT: I've created a Forum Etiquette community wiki and have moved all of my suggestions there. Read on.

Please use some common sense when you post. We have a chance to create a great community here and you don't want to be part of the group that messes that up, do you?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I agree. One more addition to the etiquette would be to use proper spelling please! In Chrome, at least, there is even a spell checker built into the dialog box.
+1 for pointing out Chrome's built-in spell checking.

Although I do agree with what you say and that there is no reason for abbreviations such as u for you to be used, I hope that no one will be discouraged from posting by thinking they can not write good enough English to do so.

Presumably you have to set Chrome's built-in spell checker to English from whatever your native language is?

I didn't mean to imply that people who don't speak good English shouldn't post, only that obviously blatant disregards for the English language (such as substituting 'u' for 'you') should not be made.
thanks for this post. That was exactly what I was thinking!
Somebody needed to do it. :P

You were faster then me :)
I was keep telling people in their posts to search first!
But thanks for the great post, I think we can do a wiki post of it, what you think?

"

Community Wiki for Forum Etiquette:

1. Write in plain style If English is your first language, please do not butcher it. 'U' is not a valid substitution for 'you', you don't need to type in all capital letters, and one exclamation mark is plenty.

2. Make the title a good summary When you ask a question, put enough information in the subject line. If someone can guess if he wants to click just by reading the subject line, that's nice. Never write it all in uppercase letters. Don't put words like: urgent, very important, read, etc...

3. Avoid creating new tags For classical situations, the best is to use the most popular ones. It helps people looking for answers. If your question is about homework question 3.2, do not put simply 3.2 or 32 as tag but hw3.2 . If you must create new ones, avoid abbreviations and acronyms.

4. Vote for good answers. Try not to duplicate If you wish to answer a question, please read through the previous responses FIRST. If somebody else has already given the answer you have, do not repost it. Instead, upvote that person's response so that it may rise to the top of the answer pile. If you realize that your answer was a duplicate and does not bring much new, you can choose to delete it. You can even earn a badge that way.

5. Search and look before asking The search feature is there for a reason, so use it before asking a question. Chances are your situation is not unique and the question has been asked -- and answered -- before. Try using search by tags and search by most voted.

6. Study solution videos Before asking a question about a quiz, try watching the solution video.

7. Do not use answers for simple comments or thanks To assure the integrity of the forum, please don't post an answer that doesn't provide anything helpful. A good example of this is answering a question to respond to another answer saying 'Cool, thanks'. This is what comments are for.

8. Upvote and accept answers to your questions If your question has been answered to your satisfaction, then accept the answer(s) that you found satisfactory. This will help the people trying to help others by answering unresolved questions.

9. Use comments and edits to refine questions When asking for clarifications of an answer or a question, use comments instead of posting a new answer. Also, if you have to add more to your question/answer, edit it, don't post a new answer.

10. Use the 'code' button when giving Python examples When posting code, make sure to format it correctly, with the indents you used. It will make the code readable &-- easier to understand. For a guide on how to format your code, check this post.

11. Redirect duplicate questions Instead of answering blatantly duplicate posts, ask the OP to search the forum (or provide a link to similar, existing question if you can). - (I know this might be a little contentious, so please post your views on the comments and if the majority feel this is too restrictive, then it can be deleted - @elssar )

"
I like the idea. The wiki has been created.
me wondering about the same stuff.. thanks for clearing it out
like my post then :))) hahaha
You got my last upvote for today.
ha. pimp :)

While I can understand why these things might be important, shouldn't we be more concerned with the content of posts? I don't really care if someone uses abbreviation or reposts something if they are broaching an interesting topic. I also think that as a place of learning, we should first and for most encourage participation. In order to have a great community, we must have great big open doors. Isn't that the whole point of Udacity?

I agree, but only to some extent. Yes, we need to encourage other students to ask questions, but a question that has been answered doesn't need to be answered again. The great thing about sites like this is that answers can be edited and improved over time. It is therefore the responsibility of the user who posts an answer to make sure their answer is as accurate and covers as many cases as possible. If we agree that the answer-er has this responsibility then it seems ridiculous to also force onto them the responsibility of doing this multiple times for what is essentially the exact same question.
This has actually gotten to the point where it's incredibly annoying. I've seen at least 6 people ask about the first homework assignment.

"

One thing that would be helpful to the forum would be a ""Sticky"" function. This way answers to popular questions could be posted at the top. This would make common issues easy to find and cut down unnecessary posts. It would also give an area that is easy to point to as a reference i.e. ""your question is answered here <--link to="""" sticky="""">--""

"
This would quickly bog up the front page. A similar alternative could be to link to frequent questions in the FAQ and make the button to the FAQ more noticeable.

"

You could also add a button to the top like the ""active,newest, hottest,most voted"" but make it ""know issues"" or ""FAQs"". Don't get me wrong, I like the way this forum is designed. Most people won't search before they create a new post or ask the same question right below the answer. There is really no way to stop this behavior except to educate on etiquette, which I thank you for doing. If this post was more visible to the community, it may be more effective.

"

"

I actually just added an almost identical suggestion to the suggestions community wiki found here.

"
Very cool. That is a good suggestions wiki.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Hint: Try not to solve it in a programming sense but rather a math sense and transfer it to programming.
The best hint I've read so far is that the conversion of the number to a string comes almost at the end of the program. You need to find a way to make the number either stay the same, or round up.

If the digit after the decimal point is more than 5, the program must round up. For example
3.14 --->-- 3
BUT
3.54 --->--4 and 26.76 --->--27

You will know you have the correct code once you test your program by inputting random decimals.

Hope that helped.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: The contest is about improving a search engine. So it seems to me that a badly-coded brilliant/original idea will win out over a brilliantly-coded bad/derivative idea. After all who cares about an implementation of autocomplete that takes 3 less lines of code? It's already been written many times.

Well, we could restrict the content of the search engine code entries to what can be found in this course. I think it would be an exercise for experienced programmers to restrict themselves to certain ways of doing things that are not part of their already-pruned-and-optimised repertoire. Or perhaps we could have divisions corresponding to skill level, which may be determined by how well you do in the course. The top students get to knock their noggins against each other, and the intermediate students, etc. And we could have a special division for students who have a knack for using novel ways to solve homework problems, handpicked by the teaching staff themselves. Of course, this would only be useful if we can distinguish exceptional novice code from exceptional code which is exceptional because it uses industry-standard techniques perfectly.

Heck, I was apathetic to the contest before typing this out: now I'm thrilled for it!

"

We don't need to worry about any restrictions, because as @robrambusch mentioned, a ""badly-coded brilliant/original idea"" can be the winner.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Hi

The find function returns a -1 when it doesn't find a sub-string in a string. My question is if there is a string say ""west"" and we find for t (""west"".find('t')), then it will return 3 as the position. But can it return -1 as well s it is the last position in the string ?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
No, find will only return positive values.

I think you were confused by the use of negative numbers in the selection of sub-sequences to denote starting from the end of the string-- the fact is that the position of elements in a string are always positive and the use of a negative number as a position limit does nothing to change that.
find() returns the position from the left, not from right, so the returned value is possitive always if found, or -1 only in the case the string is not found.

You're of course right that both indices would give you the same character, but the find() method has to return one of them. Characters in a string are identified by their positive 0-based index. You can think of s[-i] as shorthand notation for s[len(s)-i].

Take this function, it returns true or false depending on whether subs is contained in s. In other words, the expression after the return in the last line will always evaluate to True:

def contains(s, subs):     i = s.find(subs)     if i == -1:         return False     else         return s[i] == s[i - len(s)]
Thanks for the explanations everyone !!

data-item.data-item-item:
Bug?
The computer returns

print 299792458*100/1000000000 as wrong

print 299792458100(1.0/1000000000) as right

They are the same under any calculator. Wrong in Python??!!
Why?
Please would you amend my error then?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: in the first expression every number is an integer, in that case python uses integer division. i.e. 5/2 = 2. in the second expression one of the terms is a floating point number (1.0) and therefore python does the traditional division and returns a floating point number.
Ok, so the error was in just getting the integer 29 and not 29.9blabla, not the division itself. Thanks!!

Just to clarify, in the second case I presume you mean:
print 299792458 * 100 * (1.0/1000000000)

(i.e. with a multiplication operator between each part)
implicit type conversion i.e automatic type conversion by the python interpreter.
Yes, of course. Thanks

data-item.data-item-item: Please can any one help me understand the speed of processor topic and the relationship of speed of light and speed of processor better.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

You can find a good explanation here.

"

In the development of computers, physical limitations have eventually become significant.

The speed of light is as fast as anything can go. There is nothing faster. So if a computer is to be made faster and faster, then at some point the amount of time it takes to communicate internal to the computer becomes a limitation.

Current research is trying to get past these limits in two ways:

  1. Computer elements at the atomic level
  2. Parallel processing of computer elements

Hope this helps.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

From the terms of service:

student conduct policy.

To the extent a Student is registered as a student in an accredited institution or educational institution with its own policy regarding student conduct or an ""honor code,"" those terms shall apply to any such Student. Additionally, unless the following conflicts with such a policy or honor code, a Student of the Online Courses agrees that he or she:

  • ...
  • will not cheat on any homework assignment or exams for the Online Courses--
  • ...
  • will not share content or solutions to homework assignments or exams-- and
  • will notify the instructors immediately if he or she becomes aware of any other Student cheating or breaching the Terms of Use.

This was discussed in this thread but the problem is still rampant. The solution to Prof. Evans' two-stars problem is still popping out again and again out there--It's posted publicly again right now! I have reported all those answers, I'm not sure if these reports go to Udacity staff only, they can't obviously cope with this on their own, and we don't have near enough community moderators. Maybe Udacity is more worried about the few remaining bugs, but I think this is as important a problem, and then some if it's going to continue every week.

I think the main problem isn't bad faith, but that people haven't been told about the honor code, Udacity should have known that few people read legal TOS documents, and many people may not be familiar with honor code arrangements in colleges.

I would even call on the staff to find a way to make it known to every student what's permitted and what's not. I'm confident after people are told they will behave in good faith. I'd also suggest them to lower the karma requirements, at least for the first weeks, because there are many users with over 1,000 karma telling people to delete their posts with the answers, but they're powerless to do it themselves, despite having such high karma at this point.

"

I think it's great that people are excited about the coursework and want to share what they are learning! The problem is that when someone posts the answer before grading is complete it devalues the honest effort that other people put into their homework.

The intro AI class had similar problems at the start but after a while people learned the fine line between helping others figure it out on their own and giving the answer away ""for free"". I hope the we find that balance here as well.

"

The founders of Udacity are applying their accumulated knowledge, experience and some additional conjecture about learning and learning outcomes to the structure of this class. I want to benefit from their approach, so I hope others will stop posting solutions to homework on this forum. I hope it is just a misunderstanding. I also want to fully participate in this forum and don't want to avoid reading someone's posted question out of worry that a homework solution is included. These are problems that I believe the combined efforts of the Udacity team and our student community can solve together. I'm here to learn!

I suggested in a thread that questions tagged as homework be locked &-- only be answerable by admins or people with a certain amount of karma or reputation. I believe this is possible in the StackExchange framework

"

Yes, someone suggested to read the wikipedia article on rounding. I read the article again and again before (after 24 hours) what it meant finally came to me. I think using the internet for research is all part of the learning process, so I don't feel that suggesting some reading was giving away an answer. The suggestion encouraged me to keep thinking instead of giving up. I have studied education, and we refer to these little ""helps"" provided along the way for those who struggle as ""scaffolding"". As the learner improves, he or she needs less and less scaffolding. But without scaffolding, learning may halt completely. Is this course intended to help students learn or simply to show who's the smartest?

"

It's of course OK to help and be helped, that's what these forums are for-- as long as you don't give away the solution, because it's in that case that you'll spoil the learning. As long as Udacity doesn't publish a more specific code, I'd say if anyone sincerely thinks he's not cheating he most probably isn't.

This was completely different, it was the exact code that was posted.

"

Maybe it's difficult to monitor. But if you translate the top post (Unit 1 Question 9 Homework Tips) you see that it's more than just tips. (http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs101/questions/2212/arabs-d)

@Admin please do something about it

We need a ""report breach of the honour code button""

"

It is always going to be a difficult one but I definitely agree that answers should not be posted until after the homework deadline. I'll hint at where somebody should be be going if they have a question but I will never give them the answer.

Education is about learning and nobody can achieve that if they are simply told the answer to a problem. Give somebody a pointer to where they could look. That way they explore the problem themselves and learn more as a result. That is important as we move further into the course.

I'm looking forward to seeing what Dave, Sebastian, Peter and others from Udacity have to say after the homework deadline has passed

"

We will never be able to stop people from sharing solutions to homework problems. The same thing happens in a classroom setting. If a student has some buddies in the class who are willing to share solutions, who's going to stop them? We can hope that people are honest, but realistically there will always be people who are not.

I don't think we need to place so much emphasis on the honor code. Most of the bullets in the student conduct policy are incredibly unrealistic. E.g. ""I will not cheat on any homework assignment."" How would Udacity ever be able to enforce that?

I think we need to shift the focus to finding the fairest way to test a student's mastery of the material. The online platform of Udacity will make this difficult, but I am excited to see what they do about it. At the end of the day, if a student really wants to learn the material, he/she will learn it. That's what is great about Udacity - providing free education to people that are excited about learning.

"

@LizP I've seen answers that give out the code/algorithm in a step by step fashion with explanation to boot. Or there are answers that give out the key details. That's the kind of answers I have a problem with, not ones that suggest you look elsewhere on the internet.

I took two online courses last semester and people maintained the will power to keep discussion to a minimum.

I'm sure one of the goals of the course for Udacity is to test hypotheses on learning which will be measured by how people do on various homework questions. They will be able to use machine learning algorithms to evaluate this data. Keeping the data clean will result in better course design for future students.

It would be nice to be told what cheating is as well

Answering someone's question and in the process giving may be a bit too much information does not make you a cheater in my book.

It is not pleasant to be branded like that and it makes you think twice before trying to help again
i think any hint is too much. Everyone's opinion will be different.

"

May I am wrong but if you were in a real school (or at work) and a classmate/colleague ask you a question would you simply answer as vaguely as possible or instead try to guide him?

in the latter isn't it called a ""hint"" ?

In the end as mentioned somewhere else if one intend to go through this training by relying on others' answers then I don't quite see the point of doing it at all.

You might as well save yourself some time and do something else.

"

Nobody must be branded when his intentions were good, it would be counterproductive. If your hint's considered too big, inspired by the same good faith you'll know better where the line is for the next time.

Where the line is, it's subjective of course. However when in any doubt about a hit I'd take it down a notch, to be on the safe side.
This course is every bit as good as the Stanford courses offered last semester, was put online in amazing time and deserves the respect that students gave those courses.

data-item.data-item-item: In Unit 1, Homework 8 David said in ANY string! Did he mean to Say in A string?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: He means that the variable text can refer to any possible string and your code should still work correctly.

data-item.data-item-item: what is the difference between [S] and [s+s) ? are they the same

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
In general, no. Let me elaborate.

[s+s] means the concatenation (joining) of two strings, without a space between them. If we assign s='a lowercase string', [s+s] will be a lowercase stringa lowercase string, as shown in the python interpreter snippet below:

>-->-->-- s='a lowercase string' >-->-->-- print [s+s] ['a lowercase stringa lowercase string']

You should also remember that in python, as in many other programming languages, variables are case sensitive, so S is not the same as s.

There IS a unique case when s='' (empty string), in which case [s]='' and [s+s]='' as well.

data-item.data-item-item:
Hey everyone.
I don't understand the behaviour of .find function with two parameters when the second is a negative number. For example:

'hello'.find('o',-1) return 3

'hello'.find(l',-1) return -1

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
When you pass -1 to the find(), you're telling it to start searching from the last character, which is 'o'.

Basically when you use negative indexes in Python, you start from the back of the string/list.
-1 is the last character, -2 the second from last, -3 the third last &-- so on.

Also, the function will return 4, not 3 when searching for 'o', starting from -1.

"

@Eduardo Bpe, besides what @elssar said, you need to know that find always searches forward, so that's why it returns -1 in the second case. It'll start from the last character (o) to look for ""l"" forward, which is nowhere to be found because you're already at the end of the string.

If you want to find the second l in your example you should use the rfind() function which returns the highest index (so the most forward position in the string) of the substring you want.

""hello"".rfind(""l"") would return 3 instead of 2, because the second l has a higher index (3) than the one before it (2).

"

1st will return 4 &-- not 3, while the 2nd find command has a quote(') missing * will thus return -1 whereas 'hello'.find('l',-1) must return 1.
But, i guess we have a problem which I can't understand. 'hello'.find('l',-1) is returning -1.

"

@Ashish Nitin Patil, no, without the ' it will return an error.

Otherwise it will return -1 because it will look for ""l"" starting from the last character onwards (to the right of the ""o"") not backwards (to the left of the ""o"").

"

But, how does it explain the '4' for the 1st one i.e. 'hello'.find('o',-1) ??
Even 'hello'.find('o',-2) returns 4!! Please explain!

"

@Fuzzmz please reply to the above posted question -
But, how does it explain the '4' for the 1st one i.e. 'hello'.find('o',-1) ?? Even 'hello'.find('o',-2) returns 4!! Please explain!

"

"

@Ashish because 'o' is at the 4th position in the string. h-0 e-1 l-2 l-3 o-4.
The find function returns the position where it first encounters the searched string. So had you searched for l, it would've returned 2, but had you done this - 'hello'.find('l', -2), it would've returned 3.

"

"

@Ashish Nitin Patil, because it starts from that element forward.

'hello'.find('o',-1) means search for 'o' starting from the last position in the string, which is exactly where o is, so it returns 4.

'hello'.find('o',-2) means search for 'o' starting from the second-to last position in the string (so, from 3, 'l'), and starting from there, the first 'o' it finds is at position 4 (the only 'o' in the text.

Now, if you were to do a 'hello'.find('l',-1) you'd get -1, because there isn't any 'l' after the last character in the string (after the last 'o').

But if you were to do a 'hello'.find('l',-2) you'd get 3, because starting from the second to last element in the string you'd find 'l' (which is exactly that element).

"

To type this here as well, the find function only work forward through a string.

In the first example, 'hello'.find('o',-1) it will start from the last element in the string and search for 'o'. Because the start is inclusive it will find 'o' at position 4, which is exactly the position of the last element of the string.

Now, if we do 'hello'.find('l',-1) it will try to find 'l' starting from the last element in the string going forward. Because we're already at the last element, there isn't any other character in the string after it, so it won't be able to find the 'l' and so it will return -1.

If we were to do 'hello'.find(l',-2) it would start looking from the second to last element in the string, which is exactly 'l', and it would return the value 3.

If we were to do 'hello'.find(l',-3) then it would start looking from the third to last element in the string moving forward in the string (so, from the first l towards the o), and the first 'l' it would find would be exactly the one at position 2 (or -3 if you want), so it would return 2.

You need to understand that the find function always moves forward through a string starting from the position you give it (so it'd go from h to o if you were to tell it to start from 0, and it would go from l to o if you told it to start at -2).

Giving a negative value doesn't make the find go backwards in the string!

I was wrong, sorry. I wanted to say:
'hello'.find('l',-1) return -1

The post will not display if:

data-item.data-item-item: Why is -1 the index of the last character of a string, as in s[:-1]? Doesn't -1 come before zero when counting positions from left to right? It seems to me that -1 would be the index of character before the first one, which is zero. Since this has no meaning in relation to a string, I would expect an error. However, this isn't what happens.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
It is defined by the language that every negative number equals the positive position, starting backwards. This means that -1 is the last position, -2 is the position prior to the last, and so on.

Now you could ask yourself: The first position is 0, why isn't the last position -0?
That's easy: -0 = 0 (not always, but for a compiler it is). So when typing page[-0], the compiler would read this as page[0], and you would get the first position. This is the reason why they start from -1.

I know, this may not sound very logical from a mathematical point of view, but it's just the way indexing is defined in Python

If something isn't clear, don't be afraid to ask!

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I joined Udacity (cs101) a couple of days ago and I really liked the idea of making a web crawler, so I thought of creating a basic implementation. (I am not very new to python (around 1 month experience))

Note :-

  • The code was written in like 2 hours and so, its not at all even close to a real web crawler. so, don't expect it to be something magical. Its just a hack and I wrote a lot of dirty code, basically the script was written just to give an idea of a web crawler.

  • The code uses a external python library named BeautifulSoup which i find very useful for HTML and XML parsing.

I named it Hacky Crawler , Please follow the link as i cannot post a write up of my code here, due to formatting issues.

Questions :-

  1. Relative links

    I have implemented a basic relative link handler using urljoin, but I still need to find a better way to ignore hyperlinks like <--a href='javascript:void(0)'>-- etc.

  2. Memory

    The code at present can run out of memory if used for a large scale purpose, the idea using ""lists"" in python is quite rudimentary and thus can be improved a lot.

  3. Logging

    I have still not researched on the logging functionalities of python, but the code still uses a rather silly way of logging using files. Which can be improved.

  4. Handling errors

    The code is not designed to handle unexpected errors which need some work too.

  5. Libraries used

    Is BeautifulSoup best for the crawler or can it be replaced by something better?

[EDIT] : Some of the questions were addressed in the Office Hours 2 , Thanks a lot to Professor Evans and @PeterUdacity :)

[EDIT] : A better version of this crawler will be submitted as my submition for cs101's contest, Stay tuned.

Thanks a lot

"

A simplistic logging solution would be to output to the standard error device (sys.stderr in Python). This gives the end user of your program the ability to split and direct streams as they choose to the files or output destinations they desire (e.g. /dev/null if they're not interested in error messages at all).

Take a look at pythons-print-vs-stderr for inspiration.

I think that this model works with any population that has ""good independent study habits"".

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

You should say what' the last think you understand, and what's the B step where you were lost.

I think you understood the find method, and you were lost when extracting links, right?

Basically think a html website source source looks like.

<--html>-- <--body>-- <--p>--Hi, I like <--a href='http://www.google.com'>--Google<--/a>-- <--/body>-- <--/html>--

From the above example you want to get 

http://www.google.com

So, you have to use the find() method to know where <--a href= starts, so :

 first_ocurrence=html_source.find('<--a href=')

But in webpages there are more than just one link, and if you want to find the second ocurrence you must start the search after the first ocurrence position, so you must provide an starting position

second_ocurrence=html_source.find('<--a href=',first_ocurrence+1)

Hope this helped you

"
