data-item.data-item-item: when i tihnk i have the solution i notice that if the number is for example 3.47643 my code will return 3. but the answer,doing this with the rounding method by hand,its incorrect . it should be 4. because rounding 3.47643 gave me 3.5 and after running the code this should be,as i said,4. but no,the possible solution i think i have ( the only one i reach) works only from 3 to 3.4 and from 3.6 to 4 (using as example this values of x). so im really stuck at this point. :S

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Sorry to hear you're stuck on the homework.

3.47643 is less than 3.5, so should round down to 3. This is true whether you're doing it by hand or using the computer. Any positive number with a decimal part of less than .5 should round down-- numbers with decimal parts of .5 or greater should round up.

There is a solution to the homework which works for all numbers, but you'll have to use a bit of arithmetic as well as string manipulation to get it to work. Best of luck!
It can be assumed that anything =>-- .5 is rounded up and anything <-- .5 is rounded down. So 3.474477474 should be rounded to 3.

3.47 is lower than 3.5, so should give 3 as result

3.50 or 3.51 should give 4 as result

Why? because 3.47 is closer (0.47) to 3 than to 4 (0.53) ...

3.5 is just in the middle, at 0.5 distance, but rounds to 4 by convention.

And I cannot give more clues or I could be killed.

It appears you are rounding multiple times. Don't do that :P Instead just round the first digit after the decimal. i.e. - .4 not .47 You are rounding the 7 up which rounds 4 up to 5 and then rounding 5 up to 0 making 3.47 a 4 answer. Round once and dont round the 7.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Peter wrote: ""In Khan Academy you do a few exercises on one topic, and if you get any wrong you get more until you show mastery of the subject. Effectively there is only 100% as a pass mark. Could Udacity quizzes have more than one problem per topic, and if you get it wrong, present more problems?""

I think homeworks should offer to students the opportunity to try a lot of exercises untill they get the mastery of the subject, and not have a submmit-your-answer-and-get-your-grade style. Putting time and effort (and request help from others if needed) untill the student get mastery of skills and knowledge -- not grades -- should be the focus. The grades only gain importance if, after many opportunities to try and after the deadline, the student the student is unable to perform the task.

The actual format of homework makes sense for the purpose of certification without cheating (preferably, with a presential test or an online test which occurs in a way that make it difficult to cheating). This new format (education for millions) should focus on collaboration and creativity (eg a student providing an alternative explanation to another student). The fact that you'll be evaluated on homework generates a great motivation for collaboration through the exchange or conference of answers to homeworks, but that goes against the rules. Well, I think those rules should be amended because the paradigm here should be another. In this open online format, where thousands of students can freely exchange answers, it's more important have persistence, punctuality and effort (number of exercises solved, for exemple) to gain mastery. Still there would be criteria for assessing highly talented students (if it's a necessity): they could get more badges or, the best option in my opinion, they could provide at the end of the course creative solutions to real problems (""What are your ideas for solving these problems involving the today search engines?""). In a class of 100,000 people, this is perhaps the best way to find the next Alain Turing. Does anyone else think similarly?

I wish much success to Udacity! David Evans is a great professor, very, very talented!

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I agree apart from the finishing tasks earlier. The personal circumstances of people taking the course are very different as are time zones. It would be unfair to penalise someone who is working full time and has to do things last minute compared with someone who has far more free time and can do the work the moment it's produced.

If you meant having a timed exam, and give scores depending on how much time they spent on a question, again, that's a bit risky with connectivity issues and so on. Sure in some parts of the world we have good connections and it's not really an issue. Maybe it would work, but I think there is quite a bit that has to be considered before introducing time as a variable.

There are many goals of a university, but three main objectives that jump to mind for me are:


  1. promoting scholarly research

  2. educating students

  3. certifying that students have mastered a curriculum

Udacity, at this early point in its existence, is focusing on point 2 above. I think the quizzes and homework should be structured in a way that best promotes learning. The quizzes seem fine to me--they help reinforce the material that was just presented and let the student repeat it as often as necessary. For the homework, I'm not sure. I'd like to see quicker feedback, but I realize that there are certain compromises being made there. I think there should also be a programming project in addition to the homework, but perhaps the later homeworks will grow to essentially become just that. The overall class still has fixed starting and ending points, so it's not really paced to match individual students, but perhaps that will change over time as more courses are recorded and can be replayed as needed.

I think the best way to handle certification is to totally separate it from the learning process, as these goals are not exactly compatible. There could be separate exams that students could sign up to take once they feel they've mastered the material, similar to how some technical certifications are handled. If Udacity matures to the point where employers are using these certifications for hiring and promoting, then these tests could be proctored locally to avoid fraud.

The goal of promoting research is something that online classes haven't really tackled yet, but I think it's potentially a very interesting area. Physicist Michael Nielsen and mathematician Tim Gowers have both promoted the use of online collaboration to conduct research, and I think online schools like Udacity can play an important role in this.
I agree completely with you.

"

I am placing a link to this discussion on the post called ""Educators (Pedagogy)""... it is a worthy thread.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Think about nesting one 'find' in another - the first giving the starting position (+1) of the second.

Suppose s is a string with multiple occurrences of 'b'.

s.find('b',s.find('b')+1)

will find the second occurrence of 'b' in s.

The grading does not include the quizzes, only homework and final exam.

From the FAQ: How will my final grade be determined?
Your final grade will be determined 50% based on the homework assignments and 50% based on the final exam. For the homework assignments, your lowest homework score will be dropped. The remaining five homework assignments will count equally, as 10% of your total grade each.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Assuming: var1 = ""dinner""

print var1[7]
returns the error message: ""IndexError: string index out of range""
(OK, I understand that)

but
print var1[:7] + var1[7:]
returns no error message
WHY NOT?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Python handles split sequences of a string / list gently. That means it won't raise an error, if the split sequence required is out of bounds. It will just return an empty list / string instead.

On the other hand, if you index a single character, this index has to exist, otherwise you get the out of bounds error.

EDIT:

This also means there's a difference between the following two statements:

print var1[7] print var1[7:8]

The first one will raise an error, the second one simple outputs an empty string.

This is a rather tricky part of code in Python: You actually CAN'T seem to get index out of range errors when using the colon (:)

It seems like Python considers the code as follows:

var1[:7] ->-- Every location, starting from the beginning, and ending at 7. The interpreter doesn't mind if location 6 doesn't exist: he will just use the empty string for this.

The same with var[7:] ->-- Every location, starting from 7, ending at the end (the end is rather abstract here, but don't worry about that). Again, the interpreter doesn't mind that location 7 doesn't exist, he will just use the empty string for this. As he encountered the empty string, he will stop iterating, and you will return the empty string.

Just remember this: You can't get index out of range, when using colons!

Feel free to ask more questions!
Thanks for the last tip. It could be useful for avoiding an error.

It certainly would be interesting to know the Python developers' reasoning when they did it like this.
I guess I'll just have to learn to live with it!!
Thanks for the feedback.

data-item.data-item-item:
Hello,

Is there any suggested preference for using Python 3.x or 2.6+? As the focus of the course is to teach computer science through the Python programming language, it might seem correct that the latest version of the language should be adopted. However, with my limited exposure to the language, and through friends, I've come to know that most of the widely used frameworks and libraries work well for 2.6+ versions, and are being ported to 3+ version, but still have compatibility issues.

So keeping the practicality of using Python in the future, which version would be fine for us?

Thanks,
Anirban

from India.

ps- i can't begin to thank Team Udacity enough for this great effort!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: We are using 2.6.6 for this course.

So far there's still a lot of things not implemented in Python 3, and linux implementations usually still come with Python 2.6 (Debian) or Python 2.7 (Ubuntu) in their stable distributions. I had to reinstall Python 2.5 lately for using the NLTK Natural Language Toolkit.

It seems to me there's still some way to go until Python 3+ can be used cross-system, so I think the 2+ branch should still be the preferred choice for teaching.

Of course, if you mastered Python 2.x, it will be easy to lean Python 3 in one or two days, and you could use that for your own productive tasks later.
Python 3.3 is close to being released-- it would be better to have a selection button along the side like ideone.com

Hello!

I have both Python 3.2 and 2.7 installed here, in my Windows. I'm using 2.7 in this course. Python 3+ has a lot of features, but some aren't still fine. Besides this, code examples are straightforward in 2.7 version than in 3+ (See print examples...).

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Python makes you fly!

Python conforms to your thought processes, instead of requiring your thought processes to conform to the language. At least that's relatively true, as compared with other programming languages I've used. There are so many ways to do things in Python, one of them probably reflects the way you happen to think up for solving a problem.

"

Makes you print Hello World! by just typing print ""Hello World!""

Dam you c++ and your complicated ways.

"

"

For the curious.

"

Python is a fascinating language for a variety of reasons. As @mathprof points out, Python was made to be a very intuitive language, as opposed to some others that aren't. Furthermore, the language is very powerful, not to mention syntactically beautiful. Intuition, power, and beauty aren't something you generally find in the same language.

That said, it should be understood that comparing some languages to others isn't fair, particularly because the languages were designed to solve different problems. Take Python and C for example. C is a low-level systems language whereas Python is a high-level scripting language. These two languages have very difficult goals. Python was invented with intuition and rapid prototyping in mind. C, on the other hand, was designed to be very, very fast. This difference is important because it's one of the main reason why programmers have to handle memory in C, but not in Python.

Every language is attractive in its own way. If you were working on a concurrency problem you might think Python was the ugliest thing in the world. A much more appealing language in this situation might be Erlang.
Not really yet, but i'm starting to forget the Java bufferedreader...

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Can you post your entire code?

"

You can't tell the computer that the variable is equal to 

\<--any number>--.
It doesn't know how to handle general things like that. It only knows how to handle specific values.

When you see something with <--any number="""">-- or '<--any string="""">--', it means we don't know exactly the value, but that we want to know what is going on in a general case. Will the following things always be equal so we can safely use one instead of the other, or will them sometimes break?

If you want to test it, you're going to have to pick your own values for s, t and i. For example, you could try this to see what happens.

s=""hello""
 t=""lo""
 i=3
 print s[i:].find(t) 
 print s.find(t,i)

but don't just try one value, try different ones to try to understand what is going on and to try to see if you can find some values for s,t and i so that you don't get the same as s.find(t,i).

"
have you tried not using the carrots? --)
Sorry about the \ in front of the <--. I don't seem to be able to get rid of it without having other junk appear.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Maybe in some cases, if your actions dont cause damage to other people. But its a pretty broad question, hard to reply really..

It is easier... but is it right? Very radical example: you could give someone a punch in the face, and ask for forgiveness later.. They will do this after some time. Asking for permission to punch in the face is plainly stupid: they will never give you permission.

So I agree that it is easier, but you have to consider the situation, and take note of the consequences

Well, the statement is true in all cases.

To answer your question. Yeah, if it's worth it.

"

Maybe it should be rephrased then to read something like ""Don't ask for permission if you know you are doing the right thing"".

"
Hey, sometimes asking forgiveness is a hell of a job, not always so easy I would say...

"

If what you are doing is not unethical - if you are pursuing what you think is right - then you should probably do it.

If other people or institutions put barriers in the way, then - as per your citation - it is almost always easier to defy and dodge rules than have them changed. Alert your opponents and the authorities, and you will be stopped before you get anywhere. Only once - through demonstration and acceptance by people around you - others also accept your conduct as ""good"", will rules be changed-- forgiveness is possible.

Examples: a woman who drives in Saudi Arabia, working an illegal abortion clinic, selling recreational drugs, defying over-bearing regulation to run a business, distributing condoms in AIDs stricken countries (against Catholic church demands), marrying somebody unpopular with the family, finding a more productive way of performing your job or testing an autonomous car on public roads without complete legal clarity.

If you think what you are doing is right, and you think that people can slowly be convinced of the fact, silent perseverance is both moral and pragmatic.

We might not all agree - but the possibility that we are wrong demands that we be tolerant of other ethical stances, and that so far as possible (except in areas of serious conflict) we uphold individual liberty in such matters.

"
Thank you for such a comprehensive answer. I have even awarded you some reputation points for it.

While in the military, I used to use this phrase all the time. Today, in the civilian environment, I don't think it is applicable. Perhaps it applies in situations where initiative is highly praised, and not in environments where conformity is more praised than initiative.

"

True, but is easier than asking for permission most of the times.

This is the way I see it. And I'm sorry if this is hard to understand, but truly there is no easy way to answer this question.

First let's rephrase what she said into something similar. ""It's harder to ask for permission than to ask for forgiveness."", most of the time when people ask for permission is because what they think they will be doing is wrong. But of course, there are also times when asking for it, is for something minimal (like permission to go out, or permission to be excused from work). For the sake of keeping this reply short, let's assume that the main reason you are asking permission is because you think your actions will be unethical. That your actions will break the rule in some way.

Now, lets say that even though you know what you will be doing is unethical, you still ask for permission whether if you can do it or not. What do you think the answer is going to be? Most likely no. Getting someone to think that what you are doing is ethical will be hard.

And now, lets say that you have done what you wanted to do without asking for permission first. People will look for an explanation or forgiveness for your actions. You can explain, but remember, the main reason you didn't ask for permission was because is was hard for people to understand your point. So what do you do? You ask for forgiveness. The easiest thing to do.

"
OK, I am with you now. Thank you for the explanation.

Easier? Probably yes.

Right? No (especially if you know you were supposed to ask for permission).
But what I think is not unethical might be percieved unrthical by others. So, i am not so sure if I am unboard with your argument!

"

Well...the ""right thing"" isnt an objective concept...even the most bloody dictators were convinded they were doing the ""right thing""..

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Before you learn how to use a language in a project, you must be sufficiently familiar with its structure, rules, etc. This course will do just that. After that, you will have to:

  • Take advanced courses related to the particular field you are interested in (e.g. DSP, DIP, etc)
  • Look for relevant libraries and sample code and tackle it yourself



    As for me, I'm an electronic engineer with majors in Comm, Networking and DSP. My SDP was on Wireless Sensor Networks and it involved a lot of coding concepts in C (data structures and OS internals to be specific) which me and my group learned (mostly) ourselves
Totally agree. One of my summer projects in Medical Imaging required lots of coding as well.

Most of the time when doing work with EE, ECE or any other engineering course you tend to use languages that are really close to the metal, such as C.

Python, and this course, can help you think algorithmically on how to solve programming questions which can then be applied to any language you chose to use, as well as good techniques on breaking down problems into different sub-problems, solving those and putting the pieces back together (divide and conquer for the win).

"

I got an idea for a challenge and thought i might share it (to be honest, i still haven't found an elegant solution).

As you can see on the Johnny Cash entry at DuckDuckGo, the page includes a snippet of its Wikipedia entry. Looking further, let's say the Udacity entry, we can deduce that DuckDuckGo extracts the first sentence of the Wikipedia entry and sometimes tweaks it a bit (the birth and death dates are removed from the Johnny Cash entry).

The Challenge:
Using the tools covered in Unit One, write a program extracting the First sentence of a given Wikipedia entry (the source of the webpage is assigned to a string) and print it.

Notes

  • That would be nice if we could come up with a solution together, so don't be shy to post your code and ideas here.

  • I don't have a background in programming so i'm not sure if it could be done using only the tools of Unit 1.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

My observations have lead me to believe that this code should reliably extract the first paragraph of a Wikipedia entry:

#Put the source between the """" page=""""""Webpage source"""""" openingP=page.find(""<--p>--"") closingP=page.find(""<--/p>--"") rawText=page[openingP+3:closingP] print rawText

The problem i have is to reliably extract the first sentence... if i do this:

firstSentenceEnd=rawText.find(""."") print firstSentenceEnd firstSentence=rawText[0:firstSentenceEnd+1] print firstSentence

I get a truncated sentence when a dot is used within the first sentence. As in:
John R. ""Johnny"" Cash (February 26, 1932 â€“ September 12, 2003), A.K.A. ""The Man In Black"", was an American singer-songwriter, actor,[2] and author,[2] who has been called one of the most influential musicians of the 20th century.

How could we solve this?

Also, what would be the best solution to remove the HTML markups within the text?

"

"

I absolutely love the idea of a ""User-generated Challenge"". I doubt I have the skills to do it, but love seeing the community uncovering the content!

"

New to Python, but what about find(""<--whatever the="""" endofline="""" character="""" is="""">--"")? or a linebreak tag maybe? I am on a tablet and cannot/don't know how to view the source from here, but felt inclined to speculate. I like the challenge, just not at the right machine to play currently.

"
That formatted neat!! hopefully you get what I was trying to say

"

Good observation. This is not a trivial issue, though. Recogizing sentence boundaries is a common problem in Natural Language Processing, and there are several issues to overcome.

One simple approach would be to examine the characters immediately before a '.'. If it is

  1. a single alphabetic character
  2. a number

you can usually assume this is an abbreviation or ordinal numbers and look for the next dot. In most cases this will improve your detection a lot, although it's possible that you have a number of the end on the sentence or a sentence ending with an abbreviation. You can also check, if the next word after the dot starts with a capital letter, as on a new sentence.

You cannot catch everything this way (""It was due Friday by 5 p.m. Saturday would be too late.""), but it's a good start.

For implementing this in you code, you will need some more python, like IF statements, comparisons or regular expressions. But we should see all of this soon in the next lessons.

"
This is great!
Thanks for the comprehensive answer, that helps a lot. I'll test it!

You could do a simple but lengthy search for a capital letter by using find before the period to look for A, then so on through the alphabet, adding the returned reslult to a sum, and then add 26. If you found a cap, you will have a value of one left over. This would be pointless, but you would not be using anything new to do the search itself, and it sortof works like a true false. Then you could add the sum to your end of sentence, search again for a period. If the charater before the period was indeed a capital, then the search would find the next period, otherwise it would rediscover the same one.

Just thinking out loud though, i think that it is probably best to wait till they teach us properly. This thread just got the juices flowing. Sorry for the typos, tablet.....

if (rawText[i+1] value is ""SPACE"") AND (rawText[i+2] is an Uppercase letter))
i is the position of the end of a sentence But that does not cover the abbreviations like John R. ""Johnny"" Cash
}
}
else{

}
i+1
}

One very simple way to get rid of the tags would be to strip out everything between a <-- &-- >--. It's not the most ideal way, and could lead to some non markup text getting left out, but should work well enough

Assumptions:
UPDATE: This uses the Johnny Cash wikipedia source as mentioned above.
You have the wikipage source code.
You know how the first sentence looks like (meaning: you know where the HTML begins and ends).
You know when the first sentence begins and ends.
Basically, you know everything about the wikipage and first sentence.

Using just the code we have observed in Unit 1


 wikipage = webpage source
 start = wikipage.find('<--p>--<--b>--')                 #INDEX_NUM: 11827
 end_1 = wikipage.find('<--/b>--', start+5)          #11854
 first_read = wikipage[start+6:end_1]
 print first_read           
 
next_1 = wikipage.find('<--sup', end_1)         #11969
 second_read = first_read + wikipage[end_1+4:next_1]
 print second_read
 
next_2 = wikipage.find('sup>--', next_1)        #12082
 next_3= wikipage.find('<--sup', next_2)         #12098
 third_read = second_read + wikipage[next_2+4:next_3]
 print third_read
 
next_4 = wikipage.find('sup>--', next_3)        #12211
 THEEND = wikipage.find('.', next_4)               #12293
 first_sentence = third_read + wikipage[next_4+ 4:THEEND+1]
 
print first_sentence

As mention above, the assumptions must be satisfied in order to perform the operation. The comments hinted above there is no way to know exactly how each webpage source looks like. And so webcrawling has to use more sophisticated python code and user algorithms to extract the desired outcome.

Nonetheless, this was a fun exercise utilizing code from Unit 1
P.S. This was very tedious!! but can be done.
P.S.S. apologies for the variable names! It was confusing for me too!

You don't have to use regular expressions, it's just so much more comfortable. Everything a regular expression match does could in theory be replaced by a for-loop or recursive function with just some basic list operations and if-clauses.

Most programming language (and especially python) do have packages with full HTML parsers, of course, which just read the file and return an easily traversable content tree to you. The challenge here is to only use the material learned so far in the class, which makes some things really hard.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
When you declare an integer, you just put 

i=3

It works for your strings s='<--hello>--' and t='<--hell>--' because it treats <-- and >-- as strings. If you do 

print s

you'll see it prints out <-- and >-- around the hello.

"

In the course, s = ""<--any sting>--"" is just a notation to make clear that the variable could take form of every string possible, it's not literally ""<--any string>--"". For any value of an integer and any string, you just will have to test different possibilities!

data-item.data-item-item: I've got a 2nd grader and I'd love to get her excited about learning to program. Does anyone have any experience with a programming project that such a young child got excited about? python seems like a good language to use, but if anyone has had a good experience teaching young children to program in another language, I'd love to hear about that.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
LOGO.

Edit: Dear Logo-hater, please elaborate about your downvote.

"

@larry96 This opinion I'm about to share is kind of old, so it might not apply today. But, back when Doom was a big thing, and you could script Doom, I thought that was a good way to get them excited in programming. These days. I don't know what the popular games are.

I'm actually, really not sure that python is the thing for children. Children today are not like children when I was growing up (not in any sort of judgemental manner). Just that when I was growing up in the 80's nearly nobody had a computer, and so my writing my crappy little tic tac toe program after having seen WarGames was just plain awesome. But, these days, I'd imagine a child would compare their work to one of a thousand professionally written games and think (rightly) ""Oh, it took so much effort to make this?!"". Kind of like the first chair a carpenter makes. It's likely not going to be a fantastic chair. It's probably going to be a crappy chair. (Or a crappy ""search engine"")..

So, here's my idea: What if you used something like Processing or POV ray? I think (Tho, hopefully one of the ""comp scisters"" will chime in here) it has the further advantage of being a gender-neutral activity, especially, because you mention it's a her. She'd also get immediate feedback of the things she was doing.

I'm interested in this question as well. I have lots of nieces and nephews. (Well... I guess what is normally called a ""first cousin once removed"" or some such, but I call them nieces and nephews.)

"

I think it is very hard to enjoy POV Ray or Processing if the child does not have the concept that the computer takes orders and executes them, one by one, exactly as we tell it to do. Once this is figured out - and it doesn't have to take long - the kid can move on to any language of his/her liking.
Mindstorms are how I started programming.

"

Alice is a program developed at carnegie mellon to teach kids programming
see link for more info

"
scratch created by MIT for kids

I wish there was a way of downvoting comments. Why wouldn't we talk about educating children? I felt horrible at the plight of those two 11 year olds with the legal language on udacity. (Although, I get why the legal language is there...)

"

Invent Your Own Computer Games With Python should be good for her age.

"

Hm. I like the idea... But it seems a little overly complicated. Relatively, it seems easier to (easily) make (say) a sphere in either processing or in povray. But, I do like the fact that Alice (and Scratch mentioned below) both seem to be specifically directed to children, in a way that neither povray nor processing is. (I'm going to play a little with Alice to see what it really is like, and how I would use it with a child.)

sigh /tmp/Alice/Required/jogl/lib/linux-i586/libjogl_drihack.so: wrong ELF class: ELFCLASS32

I'm guessing that's because what's bundled is a 32 bit lib, and what I actually have is 64 bit linux.

"

Well, this is my personal take on it, but at such an age, inspiration is a prerequisite for someone to do anything. And what is more inspiring at that age than stories? Do you tell him/her bedtime stories? Tell him anecdotes about Alan Turing or at least, his Turing Test. Have you read the story of Zach Barnett? Google ""a senseless conversation"" and go read up on the first link. Or perhaps you could tell him Asimov's The Last Question short story. Or give him science fiction books about computers like Rainbows End by Vernor Vinge or Neuromancer by William Gibson. Want a bit more meat? Try GÃ¶del, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Brain by Douglas Hofstadter. Sure, some of these probably will be a bit above his/her head, but they're cool reading nonetheless. Get him hooked to the so-called hacker culture. Point him to iconic Usenet convos of the past, or to the Jargon File. Get him into the ""hacker"" mindset, even if it's a just a bit of a sophomoric image purported by the other types. Basically, put him in an environment and disposition such that he will choose to learn programming himself.

Or if you want to get a bit more forceful, you could search for applied behavioral psychology techniques like how to condition someone (look up Reinforcement on Wikipedia). But that's up to you -- personally, I wouldn't go so explicitly through that route.

Edit: put him/her in something like this.

"

I really dont understand how that would work, because I found that book diffucult as an adult and my friend read a couple of pages and then thought it was too difficult for her too. (Both have some programing experience from before). Greate idea, guess the implementation is just way too difficult of their idea.

I would go for... lets say - building webpages with Django. Building something slowly, together - pair programming it. Take the kids favourite game/group or whatever and then start from scratch and program something useful they actually can use.

Programming quickly becomes too abstract in the beginning. So get going with something that kids can use. Kids I guess have about 5 minutes untill they start jumping around so getting to results that are fun/useful I would guess would be a huga advantage. Ask them what they would like a webpage to do for them. I think building web-pages are great in the sense that they can build GUI-interfaces without getting into heavy GTK/TK. Maybe you could look into PyJs and build games with that? But you need a solid understanding of python yourself first to do something like that.

"

Rather than providing insight about teaching children, I would like to provide insight into my experience learning programming as a child.

I found there are (on the most basic level) two types of programming students: those inspired by computer hardware and students inspired by computer software. Children inspired by computer hardware love everything about computers and want to learn Comp Sci as a more intimate way of interacting with computers. Some computer specialists and repair shops offer after-school or summer classes perfect for these kids (though she may have to wait a few years). Children inspired by computer software tend to want to combine math/logic with aesthetics or build and release applications. These children are easily deterred from programming if they never get to create anything.

My suggestions for sustaining their interest:


  1. Teach your child how to make Flash animations. They're fun and give the sense of accomplishment necessary for motivating further learning. You can slowly begin teaching your child ActionScript (very similar to JavaScript) to make progressively more complicated GUI applications. This can be coupled with HTML programming (technically not programming, but it to a child still feels like programming and feeds the same interests). Soon your child may be able to apply their Flash scripting knowledge to HTML through JavaScript.

  2. Don't teach your child an educational language (ie Scheme). Everyone in my scheme class hated using it. Because you can't use an educational language outside of that class, students all agreed that the class was a waste of time and felt unmotivated to apply too much effort.

  3. Java is a relatively simple language if you teach it slowly. You can create a self-contained program within a single Class file and make really simple text-based interactive games using System.out.print()/System.out.println(). You can use a simple compiler targeted at children, like BlueJ. Eventually she can work up to building multi-class applications and developing GUIs.

  4. Every student in Algebra or above is required to buy a TI-83 calculator (or similar calculator depending on their school district). These calculators allow you to write programs in BASIC. BASIC is very easy to learn and can create very convenient programs that she can run on her calculator. Kids used to make programs to cut out tedious steps in math and science classes or just write fun ""Choose your own adventure"" type games. She could probably learn BASIC at a very young age.

Flash would be easy enough to start from her age--I used Flash in elementary school but did not learn to apply actionscript until later. Otherwise, I think a lot of even the simplest programs require at least a firm grasp of multiplication and division. Still, I would definitely suggest teaching your child programming from a young age. Programming will literally make your child smarter. I know a few kids who learned programming from a young age, and they all scored programming internships before leaving high school-- one of them (still in high school) already moved beyond his intern status and now writes applets for the same company part-time from his home! Additionally, all the students who learned Comp Sci early on already gained an intuition for the subject. I found the biggest complaint students had against programming was debugging their code. Students who learned earlier didn't have to waste as much time debugging and got to spend more time finding solutions.

I don't know what the best way to teach your daughter, but I hope my experience as a young comp sci student can inform your decision.

"

"

I bought a book called ""Objective-C for Absolute Beginners"" by Gary Bennett. The first part of the book uses Alice for trying to get object oriented concepts across. It didn't work out as a useful book for me, but I used the Alice program and some exercises in the book to show my 8 year old daughter that programming can be fun. I think it's a great language for kids. I read about Scratch and tried to get her interested in it, too but it was over her head. I think Alice is much more approachable for a younger kid. Good luck to larry96 and bnsh!

"
Can children also just be children for a moment?

I'm homeschooling our two kids (8 &-- 10). I'm going to show the kids several of the class vids, but I question if this is your interest for your kids or their interest. If programming is your kid's interest, they MUST have a great math foundation. I would suggest you work with them on singapore math. I realize we underestimate what kids are able to do in general, but power pushing them into programming before they understand basic logic progression might dim their interest.

??? Are you suggesting that learning to program is somehow akin to making children work in a coal mine?? At least this programmer began when he was 13, and really enjoyed it, and didn't feel deprived of childhood at all. 30 years later, I still enjoy programming, and often don't feel like I'm working at all.

"

-1 Logo is a lot of fun, and great for kids to play with. It is confusing for slightly more advanced programs, and does not build on knowledge useful for BASIC, Python, Java, C# etc. I have used Logo to teach children about computers for over 30 years, I have never used it, and would not recommend it to teach ""children to program"" as per OP

"

My fifth grade students picked up scratch on their own and now love using it to make animations and games in their spare time. I don't know much about programming itself, but by letting kids drag and drop commands into scripts, they learn that coding is just giving the computer a series of simple steps to follow. I imagine this would be a good fundamental understanding to have before getting bogged down in writing the code itself. I think kids younger than fifth grade can play around with scratch and glean some benefit from it. I've heard good things about Alice as well.
There is still a huge difference between a 2nd grader and a 13 year old.

"

I looked at ""Invent Your Own Computer Games with Python"", and it seemed fairly simple. I think with it AND an adult who knew a smidgeon of programming, you should be able to teach programming to a 10-12 year old child.

I highly recommend teaching kids programming by programming either games or multimedia. Start with a few basics, and immediately use those to make simple ""geuss the number"" games etc. Make a short ""choose your own adventure"" game. Then add sound and graphics libraries, maybe with some wrapper classes/functions, and get them moving images around and playing sound FX and music.

Very few children will find making ""a search engine like Google"" interesting, but most children would find making ""a game"" or ""a program that tells a story with pictures I drew"" fun. Programming requires logical thinking and focus to do-- children[1] won't focus and think hard for very long if what they are making doesn't interest them.

[1] for children, substitute ""almost all of us""

"

"

I agree with Tom: if they don't have any interest, don't push them. Best way to start with a 6-7 year old is by making Flash drawings with them, then animating those for them, then working them up to making their own animations...all without using ActionScript. Only then show them really super-simple animation with ActionScript, simple 3 liners etc. At 6, they love to ""colour""-- work off that.

"

"

The Raspberry Pi computer goes on general sale

A credit-card sized computer designed to help teach children to code goes on general sale for the first time today.

Read more here.

"

What I personally think is the best for a young person who wants to program, is that they can see the results immediately. I haven't got experience with many different cases but I know BlueJ is a good way to become familiar with programming. For example you can make a turtle draw a square by giving it instructions in code.

From there you can move on if she still likes it :)

I personally started with HTML when I was a lot younger, which isn't really a programming language, but rather a markup language. The pro is that it shows immediately what you want to put on screen, it's fairly easy, and that it'll come in handy later on. The con is that it's not a good start to continue with Python, Java, PHP, C, etc.

I really don't know what age group a 2nd grader is, but we should remember that when programming we work with math and numbers constantly, even though we might not realize it. It can be very troubling to get through, especially when they are not at all interested :)

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi,

Sorry if this questions seems to be so naive, but I am not sure what the following statement means:

a,x = x,a

Could you help on this, please ?

Thanks,
Augusto

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It's explained in the python glossary which you can find in supplementary material under Course Content. Check out the second page under Multiple Assignment.

"

That statement swaps the value of the variables 'a' and 'x'. So if the value of 'a' is 1 and the value of 'x' is 2, after the statement the new value for 'a' will be 2 and the new value for 'x' would be 1

In Python, when you perform the operation a,b = c,d , you are assigning c to a and d to b. A longer way to code this would be
a = c and b = d
Although, if you code it like that, in some cases it is not equivalent.

True, but I just used it as a quick example to clarify on what the operation meant. For a,b = b,a the right side is essentially a tuple in disguise so when you assign b to a, the a that is assigned to be will be the previous a and not the new one. So if a = 3 and b = 7, then a,b = b,a would result in a = 7 and b = 3, not a = 7 and b = 7.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You can solve this problem using only what was covered in Unit 1. This does not include conditional (e.g. if) statements.

But think about the if statement you have in mind and try to make it a basic arithmetic operation. There's one operation that will lead to an exact result in every case.
There is a solution using arithmetic, a little thought and what we have seen throughout the first unit.

  • finding strings in strings

It just took a little thinking

Come to find out, this really can be done with everything we learned in unit 1. Sometimes you have to add some extra functionality in order to find the simple solution. My original solution used int(), a few more lines of code and dealt with negative numbers. It was an amazing feeling when it dawned on me how to do it without int()! The annoying part for me, was breaking the rounding of negative numbers...

Overall, I enjoyed the challenge!

There is another discussion going on regarding this 'for the final quiz in CS101 rounding to integer'
Yes we can do this using only str(), find() and simple arithmetics.

After attempting many more complicated and difficult approaches. I found the answer was not very complicated at all. Yes I wanted to use If-Then and other programming approaches, but the answer is not that difficult. Like a few other posters have mentioned the answer is found with one arithmetic function, plus the string work we have been practicing. All you need to do is put in half the effort to get there.

"

@PeterUdacity Hope this clue doesn't give the answer outright-- please do delete this answer if it does.

In hindsight, I should have thought about this in the following manner:

  • I can find the whole number before the decimal point using str() and find().
  • What can I do to the number (basic arithmetic) before using str(), so that the whole number before the decimal point equals the rounded number?
"

"

My solution is less than 30 character long.

As it was said, rounding can be done with a arithmetical ""trick"".
You just have to understand what you could do with the ""str()"" function.

"

At first I was stumped, but after following a reference link and kicking myself in the butt I realized just how simple the problem is. And how the simplest of arithmetic and only the concepts treated so far in Unit 1 is required with no need whatsoever for conditional logic. I think the goal of these exercises beyond testing understanding is to expand our thinking. An attribute that proves invaluable beyond the interpreter.
the trick is casting of data types like using the str() function you can use the int() function to truncate the number in question to a whole number
I would strongly recommend using x=9.5 and x=99.5 as test conditions, if you'd like to make sure your answer is correct.
I did it with basic arithmetic and using only what we've learned so far, it took me 11 lines and the method is actually very simple but it demands a little bit of thinking outside the box :)

"

There is another fun way of doing this using only the tools learnt - the only clue I'll give (which shouldn't spoil anything) is to consider what the possible results of the find function on a 1-character string are :) It's overly complicated compared to @domshyra , but fun nonetheless.

"

"

As other have stated, there is a simple arithmetic operation that will do the trick in this question.
I found the inspiration to the answer in this Wikipedia article in the first paragraphs in the chapter about Tie-braking. This is not the solution, and if it doesn't ""give"" you anything don't read too much into ut, but that's how it popped into my brain.

Also, the fact that the solution only works for positive numbers is a big hint.

"

Points 1,2 and 4 suffice.

"

Update 2/25: This question is resolved, but is being left intact. I submitted it before I understood the scale of Udacity and their automated assignment grading system. Seriously, people: It's a two-line answer. Read the code and don't be a jerk, please. Your option, of course.

I'm trying to submit the following code-- however, I'm getting the error ""Your submission was incorrect. Is your sumbission [sic] a valid Python expression? Just enter the word ""print"" followed by an arithmetic expression.""

I believe that, if I submit a correct answer, I should receive credit. Further, I believe my answer is correct. I understand and accept that I can just type ""print x""-- however, I believe the current submission model is flawed and discourages new programmers from enthusiastically trying to do their best. Please correct me if I am wrong.

Here's my code:

# Greg K. # Feb. 21, 2012 # # Udacity - CS101 # Week 1, ""First Programming Quiz"" # # This program calculates and displays the number of minutes # that makes up a traditional seven weeks of time. # # It is also my first program in Python. # Advice will always be appreciated. #  ##### Begin Classes  # Abstract base class, representing an integer # class Integer(object):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.value = initialValue         super(Integer, self).__init__()     # Property: value     def getValue(self):         return self.__value     def setValue(self, newValue):         self.__value = newValue     value = property(getValue, setValue)  # Represents a number of seconds, the atomic unit of time in # this program # class Seconds(Integer):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.seconds = initialValue         super(Seconds, self).__init__(self.seconds)     # Property: seconds     def getSeconds(self):         return self.__seconds     def setSeconds(self, newSeconds):         self.__seconds = newSeconds     seconds = property(getSeconds, setSeconds)  # Represents a number of minutes # class Minutes(Seconds):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.minutes = initialValue         super(Minutes, self).__init__(self.minutes * 60)     # Property: minutes     def getMinutes(self):         return self.__minutes     def setMinutes(self, newMinutes):         self.__minutes = newMinutes     minutes = property(getMinutes, setMinutes)  # Represents a number of hours # class Hours(Minutes):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.hours = initialValue         super(Hours, self).__init__(self.hours * 60)     # Property: hours     def getHours(self):         return self.__hours     def setHours(self, newHours):         self.__hours = newHours     hours = property(getHours, setHours)  # Represents a number of days # class Days(Hours):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.days = initialValue         super(Days, self).__init__(self.days * 24)     # Property: days     def getDays(self):         return self.__days     def setDays(self, newDays):         self.__days = newDays     days = property(getDays, setDays)  # Represents a number of weeks # class Weeks(Days):     # Constructor     def __init__(self, initialValue):         self.weeks = initialValue         super(Weeks, self).__init__(self.weeks * 7)     # Property: weeks     def getWeeks(self):         return self.__weeks     def setWeeks(self, newWeeks):         self.__weeks = newWeeks     weeks = property(getWeeks, setWeeks)  ##### End Classes  ##### Begin Main Program Block durationOfClass = Weeks(7) print durationOfClass.minutes ##### End Main Program Block
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
This class is designed for beginning programmers. For obvious reasons, that code is way beyond anything covered in the first week.

I would even argue that it is incorrect, as it makes the task far more difficult than necessary.
Only answer with the content they have given to us.

I'm going to correct you, because you're wrong. As rakedu said, this course is designed for beginners. The employees of Udacity have put a lot of work into making this course a reality and you don't have the right to expect more of them. Furthermore, I somewhat agree with rakedu. While your answer might be correct (I emphasize might because I haven't actually read the code), it is incredibly un-Pythonic in that one of the main goals of Python is to make easy things easy to do. You've put way too much noise into what should have been a very simple matter of assigning values to variables and printing text to the screen.

Furthermore, and possibly more importantly, you need an attitude check. I get the feeling that you think a little too highly of yourself. If you wish to be among more experienced programmers then head on over to the CS373 forums.
Guys, this is obviously a joke...

I'm a beginning Python programmer, and I was trying to teach myself the language. I apologize for any newbie mistakes, sincerely.

For obvious reasons, that code is beyond anything covered in the first week. And it gives the correct answer.

My thoughts were that I would explore Python be creating a simple date/time style class-- maybe I could expand it further, in the future. I dunno, man. Is your proof that I'm wrong anything more than a lack of imagination?

Don't mistake my challenge for a lack of humility. I am just a new guy talking, here.

I'm not out to prove that you are wrong. While you did give a technically correct answer, he asked for the answer using a simple print statement.
You went well beyond that, and generated the same answer. So, just don't be too surprised when the interpreter they have set up fails to recognize it as a correct answer.
Quizzes aren't graded anyway, and you know that what you did is correct syntactically, so what is the issue?

Greg --
I also tried to elaborate a bit with my code (I am really in this course, just learning Python for the first time). However, when my attempt was rejected -- I understood why. Perhaps it is because I also teach.

With a class this size, careful structure is required. Especially in the beginning. Build as we are taught, and expand later when it becomes possible AND desirable.

"

I corrected my submission and gave a simple print statement answer. I'm fine with that, completely, given that I'm in someone else's environment.

The question, for the quiz, was ""Write a Python program that prints the number of minutes in seven weeks"". Maybe the question should have been ""Write a one-line python program to print the number of minutes in seven weeks""?

"

For sure, Clair. Thanks for the response.

I think I got frustrated when I realized there wasn't going to be an actual instructor giving me feedback.

I think that using a single print statement was implied, but either way, you were probably correct (I havn't tested your code), and you presumably learned something about Python in the process.

I'm just not surprised that the quiz didn't accept your submission, and I don't really think you were either.

"

My first thought was to create a foundation class, using dates and times, and save that for my own personal use. How could I logically think highly of myself when I haven't even written a ""Hello, World"" program?

It's a free class offered by altruistic people, I'm sure they made sacrifices to start Udacity, and I appreciate being in this class. It's interesting, and I like the video presentation style.

I'm just expressing frustration that the scale of the program seems to prevent the instructors from personally-grading all of the quizzes. That's all.

There's a lot of emotion in your response-- it would have been a better one if you had made your point a little more delicately.

"
I was surprised, initially, but I got the idea when I finally noticed the error at the bottom.
The size of the class is just something you'll have to deal with. Thrun's Introduction to AI course had over 160,000 students registered and I expect Udacity will have even more.
That's nuts, man. I honestly had no idea about the size of this program. I see now where my confusion came from and how it ultimately led to frustration.
I've updated the grading code in that question to handle class definitions. I'll be honest-- I wasn't expecting anyone to do that. Your submission should be correctly graded now.
Thanks, Peter. You're awesome!
Is it? I think the question provoked positive change. I asked because I didn't want this to happen to someone else, and Udacity changed the code. No bullying or laughing was required.

"

This isn't directed at James Brewer, as much as it is directed at the people who are up-voting: Do you really think the two lines durationOfClass = Weeks(7) and print durationOfClass.minutes are the wrong way to write this program? Keep in-mind, the question literally tells you to ""write a Python program"", then gives you a functioning interpreter that accepts and runs this answer, with the correct output. This isn't a bust on Udacity, or anyone who thinks I need an attitude check-- it is, however, a scolding for those who feel that students shouldn't be encouraged to be creative and seek out their own knowledge. Let's be honest: If someone really wants something, they'll go and get it. If they come back with something more than you did, especially if you just waited for it to be delivered to you, then that is no reason to put them down. This code has exactly two lines of object-oriented Python in the main program, and a very basic class library. Think about that. Maybe the grading code could be corrected to look for the correct output range, say +/- 1.0 (and the quiz directives could specify an exact output)?

"
Thank you for your feedback.

I'm all for creativity and branching out, but I am also for keeping it simple. The quiz was a very simple one and didn't call for the unnecessary amount of effort you put into it. I think it's great that you did and you probably learned quite a bit from it, but don't bust the balls of Udacity for not planning for something like this, because who in their right mind would submit something like that? If I submitted that answer in one of my college courses, it would have been marked off points or possibly even counted wrong entirely purely for the inefficiency involved in the answer.

"

When is reusability considered inefficiency? When does the simplicity of a question prevent someone from giving their best answer? I actually code for a living. That doesn't make me better than you, by the way. But, is not the ultimate goal of college to get a job? So, then, if I give my ""first instinct"" answer, from the perspective of being a beginning Python student who already has a job as a programmer, am I not speaking from the very experience level that all college students are seeking? I understand that I can submit an answer within the limitations of Udacity's grading system, and I did, but I say this: Any learning environment that cannot tolerate a range of answers, from beginning to advanced, is lacking. Especially if the environment's user interface doesn't have a warning, saying so. In the professional world, there is no excuse for this. Apparently, in the university world, there is. I could be a jerk and say ""Hey, when you get out of school, why don't you come work for me?"" but I don't believe that. I want educational institutions, of all varieties, to put the best programmers that they can into the workforce. The skill of the workforce is what matters. Programmers either know that already, or they're destined to find it out. So, the answer to you question (""Who in their right mind would submit something like that?"") is: A professional programmer. Isn't that what you want to be?

"

Isn't part of good coding to use the most simple and cleanest code that meets the requirements? It should be easy to understand, maintain, and meet the requirements. At this stage of a class for beginners, and given the pattern of previous quizzes, a solution should not take more than a few lines of code. That seems like a reasonable, but unspoken norm.

I also imagine the challenges of grading more complex solutions from so many people.

You could think of this as analogous to writing a paper. It is one level of difficulty to write a clear, concise and persuasive 10 page paper. It is much harder to reduce that paper to a 1-2 page executive summary structured for decision.

Thanks,

MBF2234

"

Part of professional programming is reusability. Part of professional programming is simplicity. Part of professional programming is writing code that is easily understood. For reusability, I wrote a class library. For simplicity, I made my main program block two lines of code. For being easily understood, well, here are the two lines: durationOfClass = Weeks(7) and print durationOfClass.minutes ...Now, when I first read the directive of the quiz, write a program in Python that prints the number of minutes in seven weeks, as a professional programmer who didn't know Python, my mind saw those two lines and I looked up how to write them. I thought my answer would be graded by a programmer who would be holding me to professional, post-college workplace coding standards. Sincerely, it was my misunderstanding. Remember, the code you are referring to was written by me, for my first quiz, when I didn't understand the reality and scale of Udacity. I don't write ""what I would do in the real world"" anymore, for Udacity, because I understand the limits of their environment. Do you disagree with me that my program was reusable, simple, and easily understood?

data-item.data-item-item:
"

In the explanation of the correct answer for the quiz, I felt like the statement that ""the two that are the closest are the first and the third"" was incorrect. It seems that, if s.find(t,i) â‰  -1 (i.e. s is non-empty, i is within the proper range, and t is in fact found in s), then the first option s[i:].find(t) will always return 0, which is rarely the value of s.find(t,i). So I wouldn't say that the first option is very close. However, this shows that the third option is close, as 0+i = i.

On the other hand, the fourth option does work except in the special cases where s.find(t,i) = -1. Yet in the explanation video, there was absolutely no air time given to explaining why it works in most cases but not the special cases.

Was the explanation video (a little bit) deficient, or is it my own thinking?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: The explanation, and the question in general, is designed to illustrate that while some expressions may seem equivalent and in some cases may yield the same results, if there are any situations where they do not, then they are not in fact the same.

I answer your the second question. The fourth is surely wrong, because we find variable t not t[i:]. Only in a few situation, the forth will be equivalent with s.find(t, i). But the quiz's requirement is 'always'. You can use pen taking few examples to look.

My comment/question is not about whether their answer is correct, but about how good the explanation was. I understand the answer. However, there was no comment made about why the 4th answer was incorrect. I think it's an answer that at first seems to work, and it would have been nice to have some comment on it in the video rather than none. Neither of these responses addresses my question.

Hi!!

Do you know how python takes special characters suchs as Ã¡Ã³Ã­ ???

I have: 

#coding = utf-8

s= 'AldÃ³ Smith'

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Yeah I think it does count Ã³ as two characters.
Tried searching for A, l, d &-- Ã³. Got 0, 1, 2 &-- 3 respectively. Search for whitespace(' ') &-- I get 5.

Did some digging around &-- found this article -

Thus was invented the brilliant
concept of UTF-8. UTF-8 was another
system for storing your string of
Unicode code points, those magic U+
numbers, in memory using 8 bit bytes.
In UTF-8, every code point from 0-127
is stored in a single byte. Only code
points 128 and above are stored using
2, 3, in fact, up to 6 bytes.2, 3, in fact, up to 6 bytes.

So a utf-8 character can contain more than 1 byte &-- hence will count as more than 1 character.

EDIT -

Found a way to make unicode strings in Python.

Just do

>-->-->-- unicode_string = u'unicode string Ã±ldo' >-->-->-- print unicode_string unicode string Ã±ldo >-->-->-- print type(unicode_string) <--type 'unicode'>-- >-->-->-- print len(unicode_string) 19 >-->-->-- s = 'unicode string Ã±ldo' >-->-->-- print len(s) 20 >-->-->-- print ord(u'Ã±') 241 >-->-->-- print ord('Ã±') Traceback (most recent call last):   File ""<--stdin>--"", line 1, in <--module>-- TypeError: ord() expected a character, but string of length 2 found

Same string, but when typecast as unicode, the length changes. And the ord() function returns a value when passed a unicode character, but throws an error when that same character is not cast as unicode.

"

Hmmm when I tested I did not get -Ã³- as 2 spaces. My blank space returns 4. And 'AldÃ³ Smith' gives me indexes from 0..9 I'm not sure what is different, but it sure looks for you 2 spaces for me is just 1.

That explanation of UTF-8 bit is true, but I I'm not sure if it pertains to this certain situation, since the special characters Ã³, Ã®, Ã¤ etc. are all in the 1-byte ascii chart.

Trying to get the ASCII value of Ã³ produces an error.

print a

Ã³

"

Which version of Python are you guys using? It's working fine for me on 3.2.2

>-->-->-- s= 'AldÃ³ Smith' >-->-->-- s[0] 'A' >-->-->-- s[1] 'l' >-->-->-- s[2] 'd' >-->-->-- s[3] 'Ã³' >-->-->-- s[4] ' ' >-->-->-- s[5] 'S' >-->-->-- s[6] 'm' >-->-->-- s.find('m') 6
Working perfectly for me too on Python 2.7.2 !!!

"

It is a matter of encodings and Unicode. Likely @ienakiko is not using unicode string and a version of Python using the 'old style strings'.

Working with 'old style strings':

>-->-->-- s = 'AldÃ³ Smith' >-->-->-- s 'Ald\xc3\xb3 Smith' >-->-->-- print s AldÃ³ Smith >-->-->-- len(s) 11 >-->-->-- s.find('m') 7

Working with unicode strings:

>-->-->-- s = u'AldÃ³ Smith' >-->-->-- s u'Ald\xf3 Smith' >-->-->-- print s AldÃ³ Smith >-->-->-- len(s) 10 >-->-->-- s.find('m') 6

BTW: I also recommend the Joel's article on Unicode that @elssar suggested. Is old but quite descriptive and useful today.

Weâ€™d like to apologize for any confusion that this has caused. We want to ensure that none of our students are unfairly penalized for this mistake so we are extending the due date for the first homework to Wednesday at 23:59 UTC. This extension applies to the first homework only!

Future homeworks for CS 101: Building a Search Engine will be due on Tuesdays at 23:59 UTC. New homework assignments for CS 101 will be released on Tuesdays at 23:59 UTC.

data-item.data-item-item: what are seed pages? what does it do? i didn't get it clearly in the lecture.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You have to start with a web page to find links to other pages, then you can search these pages to find yet more links. The starting page is called the seed page. The problem is that not all pages are necessarily connected to eachother, some may be in a closed loop, so you may need more seed pages and you never know if you have them all.

A 'seed' is a term used for a variable that initializes an algorithm or system. In the case of a web crawler we need a website to crawl and each link we find we in turn crawl again. A bad seed would be a website with no links! That would mean we don't crawl any site except the initial seed. A good seed may be a giant list of websites and seed the crawler with a bunch of pages.

"

Our search engine will follow links to find other pages, that will contain links that will aim to other pages that will ...

First page is the seed.

If you start crawling in your personal website, and it doesn't include any link, or if it only links to a page without links, your search engine will consider the whole internet only has 1 or 2 pages.

If you want to have a good search engine it must have indexed as many pages as possible, so the seed page is very important. I guess something like http://www.Dmoz.org is a good starting point

"

data-item.data-item-item: What kind of storage capacity is required to experiment on this course. Like to build a corpus for research.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I assume the course will only require a small amount of storage in a simple format such as a plain text file. If you want to do a large corpus and really build on it-- I would start with a simple storage system using a plain text file and convert to a database system later.

"

Maybe there is already a question that addresses this problem, but i could not find one. It seems that python automatically rounds numbers with 12 or more decimals. If for example x is 33.49999999999 python automatically round it to 33.5, i guess this would be a problem for most of our submitted answers. Did anyone deal with this problem or should we ""ignore"" it for the assignment?

to test it
repl.it

edit:
Or does this the conversion into String when printing it out?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I personally asked a similar question regarding this internal rounding. You can find it at Going into HW9 in depth

"

"

I think the robot which will evaluate the answers will use something like this logic:

if |student_answer-correct_answer|<--1E-6 : print ""Correct Answer""

So it seems people shouldn't be concerned about the issue...

Hope this helps...

"

While the rules may be a little different here in an academic setting, but in the real world, if you have concerns about what's going on 12 places to the right of the decimal point, you probably shouldn't be rounding to the nearest whole integer!

Perhaps more important is the fact that you know the limitations of your solution. Too often people develop 'solutions' without adequate testing and get surprised later on...

You're talking about the possibility that 4.4999... would round up to 4.5 and affect the accuracy of the solution?

That tendency to round up is interesting and something I didn't know. Seeing as I wasn't aware of that issue, I ignored it. I appreciate knowing it now though.

Yes, I'd say this is a great question. I submitted and an answer but last night was thinking that my solution has this exact problem. If the number is 4.4999 then my solution will not work. Although an alternative solution might, but I dont know how to code it.

data-item.data-item-item: Even not like Google, Bing or Yahoo, will we able to make a search engine which will be able to return simple search queries?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: According to the title of this course, we will.

"

As @KenavR said, we will based on the title of the course, but based on the discussion of seed pages in the Office Hours, and the fact that there is an awful lot of stuff which would need to be indexed on the web, it'll likely be a search engine for a small subset of the Internet, which will return results of simple queries.

"
I think we can do it. The search engine might not be that elegant
Something like a localized search engine could actually be awesome. There's a lot I could do with having a search engine designed like only for my home city.

"

Just be aware of your definition of ""locality"" - the index we will create will be based purely off a root node and the pages connected to it through a chain of links. I would suggest that there would be a large amount of additional logic to connect the homepage of the Redingensians Rugby Team (based in Reading) with the BBC Berkshire local news, whilst excluding the BBC London local news (for instance). It's quite the interesting field, if I'm honest :)

Locality in the sense of ""near each other through links on the Internet"" - that's easy --)

"
Yeah. Definitely an interesting field. That's actually what I had in mind when I signed up for this course.
