data-item.data-item-item:
I know there are people in here that are already comfortable with a lot of the stuff that has been presented so far, and possibly that will be. For me not everything was new. But surely, on my own I wouldn't even have gotten so far as the full contents of this first lesson! I always wanted to learn code, but never did for a sort of 'block'.

Maybe it's a spurious question, but I'm just curious to know from some of you what you think are the chances of learning decent programming once you start quite late like me... And maybe some tips to facilitated this 'cultural shock'! :)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I'd wager that you might be at an advantage for starting later, under the assumption that you'll be more dedicated to learning than a teenager might be. I'd guess that people under 30 change their minds a lot more often than those over 30. Of course this isn't always true, but I think it is in most cases.
dude knowledge got no age limit ... keep learning ...

Do you think of yourself as someone who can learn new things easily? For some people, it comes naturally. For others, not so much. I think it is certainly possible to learn anything at any age, but it is really going to depend on your abilities.

Now, will you ever get a job programming? I would say probably not. Most shops are looking for people right out of college, or someone with a relevant work history. I won't say it is impossible, but I would say unlikely.

If you just want to learn it for fun, or to develop your own ideas, the worst that can happen is you waste a few weeks then decide it isn't right for you!

Congratulations!
I'm not yet in 30s, but it's really nice and inspiring to see not only young people wondering and learning. :) Good luck and don't give up!

30 is definitely not too old to start learning anything including programming.

My one bit of advice is the not get discouraged, there are tons of ways to arrive at the same solution and tons of jerks who think they know everything. I do this for a living and still find new and better ways of doing things all the time.

Fortunately for this class the python docs are pretty good and there are a lot of good python examples out there.

Also, Google is your friend.

I was 30 nineteen years ago. Memory not what it used to be. Now, if only I could remember what the question was? . . . . kidding! Does that make me some sort of 'outlier', though not a glamorous one? I am armed with curiosity and a rekindled interest in CS - something I could not pursue in my youth. I feel frustrated at times when I find a situation where a piece of customised code would elegantly address issues in day to day work on my Mac. I must confess I've never seriously used AppleScript or Automator but the type of work(flow) I'm talking about may require a little more sophistication/flexibility in scope. I feel confident I will cope with this course, with a little help from all of you, my fellow students and the teachers.

"

I'm 27, and apart from C++ I've never learned any programming language.
Now I decided to change it, I'm following some online courses (this, codecademy) and studying at home for learning at least the basics of some language.

So no, I don't think 30 is too old for learning.
As long as you keep the will to improve and to learn (and, of course, your mind can follow your desire... I think to my grandpa, for example, he won't be capable of learning it, nowadays), there isn't any ""too old to learn"".

"

Well, I'm 68 -- and over the moon about this course. Cut my teeth on BASIC, Pascal, Fortran back in the early '80s. Taught myself perl and php several years ago, lost both from disuse because I was in a different line of work. Did some junior programming in C and hated it. I'm thinking this one will stick -- not because of the language, but because I'm so interested in the search engine idea. And, just plain processing text is appealing to me. (That's what I used perl for.)
its never too late to start, no matter what your dealing with. dont let that thought hold you back.

"

I didn't start programming until I was 24 (right after I got a BA in anthropology). After fumbling around for some time I made an effort to focus on learning the most popular new ideas: Agile, TDD, SOA and use modern frameworks and good tools to solve my problems whenever possible. Pretty soon I was building awesome webapps that were better that what my friends were making who were younger and several years into a CS degree.

There's a catch-phrase in Agile development called ""premature optimization"". That's exactly what modern education is. I guarantee you can be developing useful, high quality software in less than a year if you just follow closely in the footsteps of whatever are the newest highly regarded frameworks. Any time you come across something that's baffling, just go to stack overflow and fill in your knowledge gaps.

Tips:

  • IDE's are hard to use when you're first starting. I highly reccomend everything by jetbrains
  • You will constantly come across things that seem to mysteriously not work. Learning to stay relaxed while you trouble shoot is 50% of becoming a good programmer (in my opinion)
"

"

You have nothing to worry about. I am sure you can learn any language you put your mind to. I also suggest learning Python. Not only does this course use it but it's a powerful language and to put it another way-- it's simple but not in a negative way. It's a very expressive language and powerful. It's used all over the industry as well!

There are many free resources for learning Python as well. Here are some I suggest:

Repl : Free web-based interpreter

Dive into Python : Free, complete book.

Learn Python the Hard Way : Another free book.

"

"

@rakedu: I have to disagree with you on the right out of school line. Hiring kids right out of school really isn't what shops want. A lot of those kids don't have the right skills yet. Perhaps as an intern, yes, but as an actual employee -- don't be too fast.

I'd also have to say it depends entirely upon the person. You have these kids who start talking about how they can do this and they can do that and when you go to actually test them in the interview process, either they get scared and leave or they fail miserably. A solid foundation from school or wherever is good, yes, but a lot of times you'll get the ones right out of school who knows all the right words to say, yet their skills are shot when it comes to the real world.

@GianlucaG: If you really want to learn, you can do it, but you have to have the patience to be able to do this kind of work. One small character out of place and it can throw your entire script. You need to be able to have fun doing it, too. I love my job. I love programming. I don't work, I play. But, to get to that point, you have to be willing to put forth the effort. It's not an over night process by any means and there will be times that you want to quit, but you just need to remember to walk away for a while and come back to it later.

Also, just as a tip, the best way for you to learn is to have a project with a deadline. If you give yourself deadlines, you won't be be as inclined to slack off.

Don't lose track of the finish line.

"
My first programming course was in Turbo Pascal 3.0, and that was back in the mid-80s! My bones may creak, but my mind doesn't (yet)! Just take it a lesson at a time, and you'll be fine.

I turned 30 a few weeks ago, so you are not alone!

I work in the IT industry but not precisely with code/software development, so this is as new to me as it is to you! Good luck mate!
never too late to earn knowledge .

I use Python every day, so I just do this course for fun. BUT - I started learning Python when I was 30, so it is definelty possible.
In the beginning python felt kind of useless - because its not used to make flashy games. BUT - for the things I do - webapp development - python is like heaven. AND webapps is the future right now. What so cool about it in my eyes is how easy it is to get started and the language builds on you once you start building websites with it - I use Django a python framework to build backends for webpages. I kind of wish frontend Pyjamas (GWT) had a course like this, but I guess Ill have to make that one myself --)
my father(56) is learning cs373.

I am 33, I work in IT but not programming. I played with basic as a kid and did have a bash at learning python about 5 years ago, but didn't get very far.

I like the style of this course and video tutorials are my preferred learning method.

As long as I stick the course out and find a project at the end to further my skills I cant see a problem with me becoming half decent at Python. Programming does suit my brain type, I am just not sure if I can / would dedicate enough time to it to become good enough to program for a living.

If you are completely new to programming, I would recommend following other guides ( I've seen many mentioned in this forum ) at the same time to reinforce the concepts you are learning. As we move on a little bit you will want to go and look up some of the things we are learning and play with them. You can try to get them to do more complicated stuff and use them in different ways. You should end up with several little 'programs' that you can keep improving / expanding as you learn more concepts.

Your age will not matter, if you do not learn as quick or struggle to understand anything then you will just need to spend a little more time in other resources until it becomes like speaking English :)
I'm 36 years and just started with python, hope I can manage to learn this language.
Me too! But it looks like fun! :)

I'm in my 30s too, and I'm just getting started with Python - I've been toodling around programming for about 6 months, and know a few bits of Perl and Javascript here and there (I'm also doing Code Year-- must be a glutton for punishment).

I'm of the opinion it's never too late - I'm hoping to find a more technical job than the current admin-stuff sooner rather than later, keep learning, and eventually become $awesome_developer!

So, there you go.

I don't think age has anything to do with learning to program. Many pioneers of CS were older and from another profession when they started. @rakedu, I think someone coming from a different profession who learns how to program has a better than average chance (though somewhat dependent on the profession) at landing a ""programming job"". The ideal example is physicists, but just about every discipline needs people writing code. They accept CS-only candidates only out of necessity.

As an example there's a crafter that sells his work via a blog post. Typically they sell out within minutes of posting it. I am 40 and just finished a BS in Computer Engineering. I am taking this course (and cs373) because they are interesting topics that I wasn't able to learn in school. I also have limited experience with Python, so the additional programming will help there as well. I am searching for an engineering job now, but there is not a lot available locally. I am hoping that my age will not hurt too much, but I can't answer that yet.

I realized when I started looking for a job that I really hadn't programmed much in the last couple of years (mostly EE courses at the end), and I am definitely rusty. I wrote my first Hello World in my first CS class about 5 years ago, so I am definitely a novice programmer. I had an internship at a game studio, but I did very little coding there-- just a couple of months of shader programming. It is strange knowing that I can figure out anything I need to figure out for a job, but at the same time being less than confident in proving what I know while trying to land the job.

I am hoping to have a job before the end of this course, and I think the knowledge and experience gained here will definitely help with my job search. I have read a few posts of people complaining about how easy this course is, and I am not sure why. I don't expect a programming challenge here, but I have no idea how a search engine works, and I want to find out. As far as a beginner course, I think this is perfect. Python lets new programmers make something interesting very quickly. I really think that a great first introduction to CS. I enjoyed my first CS course (in C++), but a lot of people absolutely hated it. If they were able to quickly see the results possible, as with Python, I think more of them would have continued on past that first course. I am really looking forward to the future courses to see how they are presented.

Learning new things in your 30s is not hard. It is actually a lot of fun, and in some areas, your life experience is a benefit. I think I know why things work a lot better than most of the students I went to school with. I am old, and I am interested in he details, so I learn them more. Some of the younger students don't care why it works, they just accept that it does, and whip out the code to implement it. I have to admit to being a little jealous of this ability, but I just don't have it. I will get it done, and probably have a deeper understanding of it, but I will probably always be a little slower at cranking out the code. Some of the ""kids"" :) at school already had 10 years of coding experience before they got there. They were impressive.

What were we talking about here? I may have rambled off topic a bit. lol I wouldn't change my decision to go back to school to learn this if could. I think these free courses make it a no brainer for learners of all ages, but especially for adults looking for a new direction in their careers. If you are curious, now seems to be a perfect time to learn.

"

I know people who are still in college at age +30. I wouldn't worry, I don't think you are starting late at all. People have an average of 5 careers over their lifetime. I think the more skills you have, the better. Age really is just a number. I read some comment about companies wanting to hire people just out of school. Trust me, I think companies want more mature people. I can't believe some of the resumes I read from younger people. I am 31 by the way...started with HTML/CSS and now moving on to this. I started working in the web design/development world about a year ago.

You are proof of how life should be lived.
The only boundries are the ones we place on ourselves.
I also do web development. Also for me, coding in python is heaven compared to programing Perl, PHP , or any other language.

I'm 27, almost 30.
I studied physics, so no, there was no official python or modern programming for me.

I really DO think you can learn Python. You only need to keep coding. Code simple stuff. Code for fun. Love coding. The more you program, the better you get at it. Programming can make your job, whatever job you do, better.

Please, keep it up!

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi guys ,

I have recently started using wolfram alpha along with google. There really lies a great difference between google and wolfram alpha. As google provides lists based on page ranking. the W.A will compute the result. I expect to know indepth difference of them . Is there a hybrid search engine possible by combining the good aspects of both search engine.

bharath

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It is, but it's hard to do.

Google already does parts of what Wolfram Alpha does (you can for example do simple math in Google just by typing it as a query).

In the end it all comes down to the fact that each of them try to achieve different goals and being the best at doing that. If you try and mix things you generally have to make sacrifices from one area or another, which means you won't be competitive with another website that does just one thing, but does it well.

And in all honesty, Wolfram Alpha is more of a Mathematica website based frontend than a true search engine.

"

It is true. But now google is offering a different services eg. Google scholar. I think they can try it as a another service. It is just another thought I got. I may be not aware practical problems rising inside the system.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Hello,

I decided to try and make this robust by having it function for all real numbers (negatives, small numbers and numbers over 100,000). Has anyone been able to do this successfully? so far I have negatives, small numbers (0.000000000009) and a sort of working scientific notation for large numbers but am having trouble with 12 digit numbers ending in .49.

As a challenge, I want to put a list of ""vandal"" numbers out there that you can use to debug. These are the numbers that have given me trouble.

  • negatives (-2.87615)
  • very small (0.0000000000009)
  • very large (999999999999999.0)
  • 12 digit with .49 (99999999999.49)

I have found that last one to be the trickiest. It has to do with how scientific notation in the str() function rounds numbers itself before converting them to strings.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: This is not possible. It's just the way computers do maths, it's not very accurate. The reason why this is is because of the limitations in computer architecture, but it is not possible

I think that's do-able. Stop thinking of things in string alone. Maybe store the digits in a list which has the number of elements = number of digits and then check the parts of that list.

Preferably make two lists of decimal part and integer part. You are anyways going to take the input number as something valid in a data type.

I think it is doable as well.

The trouble that I'm having is that once it becomes a string, the rounding error occurs and it is indistinguishable from 100000000000.0.

I have had some success with doing math (ie. subtracting .49 from all entries) but I will need a way to distinguish the problem number from other numbers ending in .49

@BFC: It is possible. You might argue that factorial of numbers >-- 1000 isn't possible either. However, there are methods(computationally expensive) which allow you to do so.

Its another reason why you should give a try to Project Euler problems. Some of the problems actually require you to deal with large numbers/very small numbers etc. All you need to do is think of a way to represent the number in a suitable form.

"

@WMcLeod:

The str() method does not round the number before converting it into a string. The problem you are encountering is that the number (99999999999.49 for example) can not be represented by a 64 bit binary fraction, as such it is represented to the closest approximation as the system can provide (99999999999.5)

For example see this code

"

Yeah. That's true. A more precise understanding based on number systems.

However, python's long data type by itself has no number restrictions.

I understand what is causing the issue. What I am trying to figure out is if it is solvable.

This is the only set of values for which this function will give the wrong answer and I want to see if there is a workaround.

Again, that's what I am trying to tell. You should no longer view such numbers as representatives of a data type. Stop thinking of them as float or int or double or something. Instead think of them as arrays(you can have arrays(lists in python) with 1000 digits which in turn act as number while printing out in a row). Most of the problem in such problems comes from the data type limitation which isn't necessarily the computer's limitation.

Think of it this way:
You can't have a single variable of data type A with 1000 digits. It is however very easy to have an array or a list with 1000 digits. This is inherent from the way memory is allocated by the compiler. So store a single digit in each location of the array. For example, the 1000 digit number can be stored in lets_array[0:1000]. Then perform the same round off analogy over here.(increasing i+1 bit when ith bit is >--5 and put that in a loop making this happen until the decimal point) This solves round off problems accurately for however long a number is accurately. It might not solve round off problems very efficiently though, since it does not involve any speed methods(parallelpiping might be useful here as well).

Email me if you do want clarifications on the same.
those shouldn't be any harder than something simple like 1.4

"

@EternityPala

I did want some clarification (as it seems that the act of converting to a string truncates and I don't know how else to get a number treated as a list or array). Is there a way for me to private message or email you?

"

EternityPala is on the right path to a solution, I did something similar with large numbers in a C programming course at my university. Although that assignment was to implement a function that could calculate the exact factorial (meaning every single digit) of really large numbers (anything larger than 20! doesn't fit in a 64 bit unsigned integer).

@eadlam
Try it.

In your HW solution put in 99999999999.49 where pi is now. You will likely get an error where it rounds up instead of down.
Yeah. Add me on gmail/skype. nareshshah139

"

@WMcLeod

Typecasting the float to a string does not cause the truncating error you're experiencing. Storing the value in a binary fraction is causing the problem.

The solution you're looking for involves never having stored the value as a binary fraction. You can't store the value as an approximate representation and then typecast it into an exact representation, the exact value is lost.

For more info:
computer math
decimal arithmetic

"
It's quite possible. My TI-89 does decimal arithmetic, and last I checked, it is a computer.

"

Here is the documentation for a python library that handles decimal fixed point and floating point arithmetic.

decimal

"
Thanks, but I was trying to solve it using only the tools provided in class

"

Here is an example of using the Decimal library.
code

Note that the exact value is not lost as is the case with the non-decimal code
code

"

data-item.data-item-item:
I noticed that for HW number 9 numbers over 100,000 need not work (which is good because scientific notation in str() makes this very hard). But I also noticed that very small numbers can cause problems. Numbers under 0.000000000009 or with 11 digits of leading 0s will cause a similar scientific notation error. The question doesn't explicitly say we don't have to solve this, but my guess is that the teachers won't be taking off points for this. It is an interesting error and one that can be solved for too.

Has anyone else accounted for this? Do you think it will be considered in grading?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

@PeterUdacity said that they'll only use numbers no larger than 10,000.

As for the problem with numbers with more than 11 digits, it's been discussed here on the forums (unfortunately I can't find the link to it) and has to do with the way floats are represented internally by the CPU and the limitations fractions have when used to represent floats.

Edit: Found the thread talking about it.

"
They mentioned at the instructor comments at the bottom of the homework video that they won't be testing the algorithm for numbers >-- 100,000 or for numbers like 3.5.

No they will not consider this, as this is an error on the computer architecture, some ways of representing numbers account for very small errors (talking 10^-9). You maybe could work around it, but it will never be totally correct! So don't worry about it!
There are ways to make it highly accurate using linked-lists. It can be highly accurate in those methods, though sometimes computationally expensive.

"

One of the threads discussing this topic: Going into HW9 in depth

"

data-item.data-item-item:
When solving quizzes, homework, are we supposed to use only Python code that we were taught up to that point?

Thanks.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Preferably. Its far better to understand different techniques than to use shortcuts just because you know them.

Think of programs over here as math questions. There is no single way of solving them and putting limitations on your methods to be used could help you discover 'for yourself perhaps' a new algorithm or work method.

However, it isn't a requirement for this course in particular.

You can use any Python 2.6 code, but it is highly encouraged that you use the commands we've learned so far.
(Some hard problems become ridiculously easy if you use Python code we haven't learned yet, and I assume that you're here to learn, not to see a virtual pixelated check mark)

data-item.data-item-item: where is the course content?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Its above the video on the course page. Its a Tab link

"

Course content can be found here

On the right side, you have a navigation panel, where now resides Unit 1, Homework 1 and Office hours. You can click the ""+"" sign to expand these!

"
In the first one, Python will look at 1234 as numbers where when you make it into a string like the second one, it reads it as if it's letters. Sorry, I don't know if I explained that well.

"

None I think...
Add to that p=""1234""

"
There is no difference. In both cases, n is assigned the string '1234'.
as @jasa says, there's no difference between them. Both are saved as strings.
That's not true. The first one is a string as well. (the numbers are quoted)
I think you're wrong. n is a string. If you want to use it as a whole number you have to resort to int(n). E.g. print int(n)+10.
Ahh ok. I had assumed that you had to add the str to make it a string. Good to know. Thanks.

"

Just to beat a dead horse: ""1234"" == str(1234)

"

"

All 3 of these are the same. You can tell they are a string because the result is enclosed in quotes. 

>-->-->-- n = '1234' >-->-->-- n '1234' >-->-->-- n=str(1234) >-->-->-- n '1234' >-->-->-- n = ""1234"" >-->-->-- n '1234'

If you want n to be an integer:

>-->-->-- n = 1234 >-->-->-- n 1234
"

"

I would add that

n = '1234' (single quoted string) n = str(1234)

and

n = ""1234"" (double quoted string)

are exactly the same string.

"
yeah, that's actually what I meant to type. Fixed. Thanks!

They are equal for this case
However:

n = '123456789012.0'

will give 123456789012.0 as a string

n = str(123456789012.0)

will give 1.23456789012e+11

str() creates sceintific notation for very large and small numbers with decimals

"

Although in your example n will always be the string ""1234"", the second assignment is not as good as the first one because you call a method that casts your int into a string. Your computer needs more time to do this than ""simply"" assigning a string to n.
You will not notice it of course since your calling a small method, but you might remember it later :-)

"

n = '1234'

Variable n is pointing to string '1234' which is stored in memory.

n = str(1234)

Variable n is pointing initially to a number which stored in memory, but str() converts it to a string, so numeric value is gone and n points now to a string.

So eventually in both cases variable n points to a string.

I don't know why but that doesn't always seem to be true. I just tried it with Python 2.4 and here is what I got:

print str(123456789012.0)

123456789012.0

Any ideas?

data-item.data-item-item:

We have done our best to make these videos understandable to everyone. The two main things you can do if you are having trouble following the lectures:

  1. turn on closed captioning in the videos by pressing the CC button at the bottom right of the video window.
  2. Look at the course notes. You can find them in the ""Supplementary Materials"" tab when viewing course content.

We hope this helps!

"

data-item.data-item-item: The output of my program is a string. But it must be a number, mustn't it?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
It should be a string.

They introduced us to the str() function which will take a number and convert it to a string.

They haven't yet introduced us to functions to convert strings back to numbers (such as int() and float() so you can safely assume the final answer printed will be a string.

"

Thanks!
Also, you wrote that: "" As well, ""print"" only prints strings.""
What do you mean? If I write ""print 3 + 1"", it will print 4. It adds 3+1 and then it prints the string ""4""?

"

Yeah, I removed that because while it's true, I knew it would cause some confusion and it's not so much related to the question you had.

But yes, it adds it and casts it to a string, then prints it.

I'm cooking lunch at the moment, I'll come back and try to clarify it.

"

It's probably beyond the scope of the first unit of the class, but I'll refer you to:

2.7.2 documentation for the print function

3.2.2 documentation for the print function

But, to summarize from both of those ""All non-keyword arguments are converted to strings like str() does and written to the stream""

"
And to make my question more clear: the variable that gives me the answer is a string variable, not an integer.

Yes, you don't have a choice if your solution is correct, and if you only used concepts covered in unit 1.

The reason is, they've shown us how to convert from a number (ints and floats) to a string. They didn't show us how to go from a string back to a number yet. So, your final variable has no choice but to be a string, assuming your solution is limited to concepts covered in unit 1.

I haven't seen your code, but the sense I'm getting from our conversation is that you have a solution that works, and you understand the material.

"

the important thing on the problem is, the output must be a number with out decimals. must be ""3"" not ""3.0""

"
Yes. My program gives always the correct number, but in a string.
So, you think that my string - answer is wrong?
You must print your answer.
I print it! But the variable I print, is a string, not an integer!

The problem says: Given a variable, x, that stores the value of any decimal number, write Python code that prints out the nearest whole number to x.

My interpretation is that it does not specify that the answer must be a number object.

"

If your string is ""3"" then it's correct. If it's ""3.0"" you might want to look at it again. They did specify that the answer does not include the decimal.

"

"

It is ""3"". No decimals!

"
the answer should be number object, computer is doing everything base on true or false

"

Online interpreter can import all modules and user can execute comands on server

import os

print l

will print info about network interfaces on server.

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi,

I am just trying to figure out where I stand in terms of experience and aptitude compared to who else I see in the forums. There are some pretty advanced questions and answers that I see and I wanted to get a feel of how many people where completely new vs how many have some experience, vs how many would say they have a lot of experience.

I am a mechanical engineer that is also taking an intro JavaScript and intro Java class. I have some experience with MatLab and have seen Fortran before but am otherwise completely new to real programming.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

My wife and I are taking the course. I am experienced but not with Python. My wife has no experience.

The first time one encounters this kind of material, it can be a mental shock. Our course skipped over some conceptual material that is assumed, for example:

  • The notion of a symbolic name for computer memory data
  • The notion of moving computer data from one location to another without changing the original
  • More on how to understand Python coding in BNF form

My encouragement to you is to constantly ask questions. Never let yourself say ""I just can't get this.""
Rather, ""I don't understand . . . ?"" Fill in the question.

"

I'm completely new. I son't work or study computer sciences or engenieering, I 'm taking the course because I loved computers all my life. I rememeber I was 20 when I got my 1st computer, but I took Apple II, Basic and other courses as a child. Then, I decided I only wanted computers as a medium and decided not to study computer sciences at university. But I always loved it. So, his last summer I got into some google searchs for doing things for my smartphone and recovered my old passion. I think the course may help me because now I'm in education and new technologies, but most of all is that I can feel that I can do more things, get into challenges, get the reward when I do an excersie correctly, and so on. So I don't know anything, but I guess I know more than yesterday and that if you really wish, yo can do it!
I'm pretty new. I've been messing around for years but not really doing anything productive/constructive. So - perhaps not 'starting from zero' new, but definitely 'starting from 1.5ish' new. :)
Completely new here (sociology major)! The last two homework questions were a big challenge, but I managed to obtain the desired results in the end. Can't wait for Unit 2.

I would consider myself a beginner - I don't have a college degree, and have no academic credentials/industry certifications in computers. However, I have always had a bootstrap mentality when it comes to computers and software, am an avid user of help tools and instruction manuals and a pretty good googler so I've always been able to teach myself what I have wanted. I taught myself SAS many years back, and the logic of programming (once you've got the language/syntax/grammar figured out) really appeals to me. So maybe not an absolute beginner, maybe an advanced beginner?

Most of this is completely new to me. Some experience with VB in Office environment for macros etc.
Fortran class about 30 years ago

"

I read Code by Charles Petzhold and then started going through ""The C programming language"" in January (great book!), but otherwise I'm completely new.

"

I'm a beginner. I have written some macros in Office, also. I took a beginner programmer class when I was younger and dropped it because I found it irritating that the professor began to teach less towards beginners and more towards the twelve professional programmers in the class. In fairness, advanced programmers comprised the majority of the class. In unfairness, the programmers who worked together took turns doing the assignments and had their secretary change the variables so the prof wouldn't know (yet they bragged about it before class...irritating).

I'm a projects manager, regularly deal with the alien species known as 'coders' in terms of sourcing projects, but myself have no coding background.

This course is very fascinating and I feel like I'm learning a lot but now that I'm in the middle/late 20's lesson range, I'm finding the teaching style is substantially reorienting itself towards people who have a code background and it's a lot harder to keep up.

A lot of the terminology could be simplified, even if a person has to relearn it at a later date. Also, I'm not a fan of the teaching style that employs intellectual abstractions to convey applied concepts. That works great with people who have that Aspie personality type (which is essentially all coders) but not good methodology for teaching John Q. Public, starting from scratch.

I'm a social scientist and completely new to this field. So far, I found the first homework to be challenging but I think I did well in the end - I was actually surprised because reading about the experience of (what it seems) most users was a little intimidating at first..
Now I'm looking forward to unit 2, hoping that it won't become too difficult too fast.
I'm in the second year of a Computer Engineering course and there i learned some programming with C, C++ and hardware descriptive language, Verilog, and that's it, now learning python here!

I'm not even remotely new to programming, but haven't coded much Python. Mostly wanted to observe the course (one gets few chances to see intro courses in action-- one usually doesn't even take intro courses in one's own major) and use it as an excuse to brush up on my Python.

I am an English teacher and am completely new to programming. Recently I completed the AI course taught by Norvig and Thrun, which has inspired me to build a foundation in CS. My work schedule is busy, so I hope to carve out a couple of days each week to focus entirely on the class. It is already a brain tickler, so I'm looking forward to the challenge.

I'm an Industrial Engineer by education and have been programming for 5+ years and have been in the IT business for 22+ years. So, for most of my career I've been faced with some form of programming and other IT challenges. And, about three years ago I took an entry level Python course so up to this point it has been going fairly well. I really like this class and I'm looking forward to Unit 2!

Psych background here.
I read a C+ manual 10 years ago cause it was there.

I'm currently unemployed but coming from a clerical/accounting background. This is my first time taking a programming course. I'm very excited! I've previously learned basic HTML from w3 schools and played around with visual basic and java. I think this course will be great because Python is a relatively simple yet powerful programming language and I'm very interested in going on to learn Java, CSS and PHP.

I'm quite new to programming. I've dabbled (read: self-taught in my not-so-ample spare time) in python before, watched the Khan Academy videos. I've also taught myself enough HTML and CSS to code basic, static sites, and understand some of the fundamentals of JavaScript enough to plug some borrowed code into a site. I'm thoroughly enjoying this class so far and can't wait to get more!
It's good to see another liberal arts oriented teacher here! I teach elementary school and want to learn the basics of computer science so I can help my computer-oriented students learn more.
I have no programming experience at all. I do know a lot of programmers, but I don't think that counts :)
Hi I have to say new to this although I have played with html c# and vb. But no formal training but I think I can learn anything. Google makes learning easier. :)

Liberal arts background for me. I currently work with HTML/CSS every day, but I want to make web pages more interactive and maybe create simple web apps. The length and scope of this class seems like a perfect way to dip my virtual toe into the deep programming waters.

I'm an utter beginner. got a BA in English, an empowering achievement I thoroughly flaunt at my dead-end office records processing job. wish I pursued something like this in my first go-round in higher-education, but now I'll be paying off school loans until I'm a bitter septuagenarian.

so, overall, I'm psyched to b here.

I 've been trying and experimenting with PHP and C++ for some time now.
Before that I worked with some HTML and CSS in building webpages.
Everything non-professional and not in depth.
I believe Python is the really flexible.
I am new to programming in that Last time I did it it was in basic and the year was 1976.
i m new to programming i have no background in programming

data-item.data-item-item:
Hello
I am not native english speaker, and i cannot fully understand task 1.9
Could you guys help me?

My question is:
is it guaranteed that initial x have decimal dot? or x can be pure integer?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It is guaranteed that x will have decimal dot.

x can be a decimal number or an integer number.

But not negative, and not huge.
I don't know if its guaranteed but the lecture showed a method how to convert a Integer into a Decimal number.
ah, you are right!

"

My answer was voted up by Peter Chapman and it was voted down few minutes afterwards by Tom Vandenbosch. I think that Peter knows better and I was working on assumption that it is guaranteed to be decimal number (not that such assumption matters much, but it is another question).

Anyway I do not want to disinform someone, therefore, Peter, can you please look at it again and either approve or disapprove (or delete) my answer explicitly? Thx.

"
It irrelevant, otherwise David would have mentioned it. Don't answer homework! You potential incorrect answer could fail someone!
Tom the problem was to round a decimal number to an integer. How can you round an integer to an integer. To me it doesn't make much sense.

I am definitely not answering homework, that is why I originally did not mention relevancy of that question. But, apparently, Cannabinoid, who asked the question is not very good English speaker (he has written that directly in his post) and he did not understand the question fully. That is why I answered and also that is why I answered in that fashion. - I think it is completely all right to help clarify requirements of homework and since it does not make much sense to round an integer to an integer (as Alter Hase already stated), I was working on assumption that x is decimal number by definition, which I stated in my answer.

Yes, you are right, the variable x stores the value of any decimal number.

My solution seems to work for decimal numbers as well as integers. But not for negatives and not for huge numbers. I hope this helps.
@Mareq You are right, I have now cancelled my downvote. My solution works for decimal numbers as well as integers. Sorry about that confusion.

"

@Tom: You believed that you are right as I did, so there is no need for apologies :) I am myself not very sure where the truth is, now. Let's wait for Peter Chapman's answer and in case I am not correct, I will just delete this post...

"
why cant it be a huge number?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Yeah, finished it today. Some questions were very hard, especially the last one (2stars), the rounding stuff. But I remembered the trick as I dug deep in my school knowledge. :-) Of course I'm interested in what comes next! Can't wait to crawl the web and so on.

Just finished it (which is exceptional for me as I tend to be a serious WCLM (West Coast Last Minute).
Some of the lecture and quizzes on find were tough for me, because the embedding gives me a headache.
I'm really excited about what comes next.
I found it simple, that is despite not having much of a programming background. Only a bit of C and Assembly language programming.
it was entertaining. The last exercise was of thinking but wasn't difficult

I agree with you, the most challenging exercise was the last one. I have found the course easy but interesting so far, and I hope it becomes even more exhilarating when we start with the actual project of the web crawler.

yeap took me 1 night and the next morning.
well it will sound odd but the theorical questions were harder than the programming, including the last quiz (2 stars) i believe that having programming experience gives you an advantage only at the practical part.

of course! i can't wait for Unit 2!
Agustin.. I agree!! previous experience in programming doesn't help with the theoretical questions!! they were somewhat of a challenge.. i cant wait for unit 2..
I like it, i did it in one day. I am impatient for the next unit.
I did. the first 9 questions were simple, but the last was a bit tricky.

I've enjoyed the course so far. I had a lot of trouble with the last exercise because all the answers that came easily to mind required parts of the language that weren't allowed yet. I finally figured out the answer after much head scratching. The rest was pretty easy.

I completed the homework today. Now I had an easy solution for the last homework question, but I am not certain if we are allowed to use it or not. The section was pretty easy and I am waiting for the next one :)

I completed the homework over the weekend. The last two questions really made me think about how to approach a problem and break it down into simple, logical steps, which seems to be one of the keys to successful programming. I am very much looking forward to the next units.
In the weekend i finished the lessons, but until today, i finished the Homework.
I finished it already having a lot of fun. The last exercise was tricky because I realized that I will find a solution sooner or later. But I don't know at all if it is a good or elegant solution...
It took me two nights and now I'm ready to start the second unit that I think will be even more interesting.... obviously the nÂ°9 was a little bit tricky...

Finished Homework 1 just today. The last 2 questions were tricky. Most thought provoking ones are the theory/conceptual questions. I usually have to exhaust all the possible valid inputs to get the answer right.

For the last Double Star Question, I used a function in the Python Library not yet mentioned in lecture so hopefully my answer will be valid. I am looking forward to the next units and the next classes that Udacity has to offer!
I think I used 4 lines of code.
I broke it down did the simple math then called str() method and find() I didn't use round()
I finished the homework today and I agree with agustin. The theoretical questions were the hardest. Although, I kept getting the find position backwards ie [1:] vs [:4].

I did. It was fun.
I had a hard time with the last one of homework though(the rounding one).
Congrats :)
I did it in three hours on Sunday night, from start of the course to finishing the homework. This is totally new territory for me and I loved the mental exercise. I'm excited to see what's next!
Loved the last homework excercise :)

Frazzle. It took me a little while to figure it out.

Amazing how easy it is to over think the question.
I started the lectures last night and finished the homework this afternoon. I struggled a bit with the final quiz question. I can't wait for the next set now.

Yeah it is, especially when you have prior knowledge of programming, it can lead you to thinking of solutions the instructor didn't intend. I had to remind myself to only use the information that was presented.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I think most of us don't know the meaning of ""Udacity"".

Can you guess what does it mean?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Udacity is a made up word that is a combination of ""University"" and ""Audacity"" -- at least it seems so.

From website ""http://aessa.edublogs.org/2012/01/21/udacity/"" I found the following definition:

""Udacity is a bold experiment which promises to test, if not shatter, our deeply held beliefs about learning. Ventures like Udacity will accelerate the inevitable market disruption in education.""

"

Good question! I'd like to know as well.

+1 and *

"

My guess is that U stands for University/Edu combined with the word Audacity which is the ""Willingness to take bold risks"" implying that their goal is to be a vanguard for improving higher education.

"

auÂ·dacÂ·iÂ·tyâ€‚ â€‚[aw-das-i-tee]
1.
boldness or daring, especially with confident or arrogant disregard for personal safety, conventional thought, or other restrictions.
2.
effrontery or insolence-- shameless boldness: His questioner's audacity shocked the lecturer.
3.
Usually, audacities. audacious acts or statements.

I am guessing that other universities thought badly of these guys for starting a FREE university, and so, taking money away from other universities. I.e.: 'How can they have the audacity to do this?' But, really, they have vision to be able to do this.

"

""Udacity"" originates from ""audacious"". ""Audacious"" then stands for something that is fearless and courageous, something that is daring or bold. We could assume that it refers to the project itself which is courageous through its goal (providing quality education to masses for free with the help of modern technologies). According to Sebastian Thrun (co-founder of Udacity), Udacity stands for ""we are audatious, for you, the student"". This is an audatious step. The above is a quote from his personal homepage.

To me, U da city also refers to ""YOU - The City"", an intimate citywide play for an audience of one. In Udacity, many ""audiences of one"" actually make up a very big audience. But that's just my personal take on this.

"

You could write several lines of code.Only difference is that if you use print statements, they will be interpreted immediately unless they are in a loop or another conditional statement.

For example:

x = 1
while x <-- 5:
x +=1
y = x

print y

5

One way, follow the instructions in the first few sections of learnpythonthehardway <--dot>-- com, that'll get you set up with gedit and powershell - you write your code in gedit, save it as a .py somewhere then call it in the shell.

Being a frequent SQL writer I too was looking for something where you put your code in the top, Execute, and then see results in the bottom. Researching various python IDE's none really gave me what I was looking for, the gedit/save/shell method works well enough once you get used to it.

One of python's actual advantages is you can watch your code work as it works. I don't know why would you want it in any other way. If you really want to code block by block, use a text editor and paste stuff onto the IDE.

You can run individual lines of code on the interpreter window by typing ""python"" on the command line and then typing the code line by line. Each line will be evaluated when you press enter. data-item.data-item-item: Why is it that in Python we count positions from left to right starting with 0 and from right to left (negative numbers) with -1? I understand -0 would not make sense, but why start with zero in the first place?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It is common practice to start with 0 in (almost) all programming languages (e.g. it is not true for Pascal, reason being simplicity, but such languages are in vast minority). The meaning behind zero instead of one is that the index is actually ""number of steps from the beginning"" you need to take in order to get to the element you want - this is literally true e.g. in C (and its pointers):

As for negative numbers, as you said, it would not make much sense to write -0 and it is again consistent e.g. with C++'s iterators, where you have begin iterator (pointing at the first position, i.e. index 0) and end iterator, pointing to the position right past the last element of the array. So in order to reach last element, you need to go exactly -1 position from the end iterator. I suppose, this is very same in most languages as well.

"

"

You could look up on wikipedia about the same. It lists several reasons why indexing with 0 is preferred in most languages.

Link:
wikilink

However, most likely those with experience in assembly programming would understand this.

"
I understand negative indices as syntactic sugar: instead of having to write something like x[-1 % len(x)] as in other programming languages, you can simply write x[-1].

"

It's just being Geekish

For a ""close to the metal"" language like C, it sort of makes sense, but still

Will interpreted languages it's just weird, and confusing

With any language, when interpreted/compiled the index is multiplied by the array pointer or object size, and used as a direct address offset from the start of the array, so that is where zero is used to address the first item (zero byte offset).

Interpreted and high level languages can do what they like when interpreted/compiled, so zero then becomes just a bit geekish, and no real meaning. As it would work just as well with 1000 as the first index too!

"

One of the reasons is that in mathematics we denote ranges using the notation [0,n) instead of [1,n] as it is easier to denote empty sets this way. So while calculating addresses, we use (starting address)+n(number of bytes) instead of (starting address)+(n-1)(number of bytes).

But this isn't always necessary. Fortran arrays start at 1 by default though they can be overridden to start from 0.
And don't forget Basic too :-)
I haven't worked on Basic. I started with C then C++, Java, Matlab/Octave and Python. I remember Fortran because of work related to some legacy code :D

data-item.data-item-item:
Seeing as how this is a beta, I am sure this course will receive numerous amounts of suggestions and criticisms. So, feel free to use this post as a consolidation of these. To start, one suggestion I have is to add a check mark after I view a video, that way when I leave and come back I haven't completely lost my place. I know the site just launched and you have bigger fish to fry, but hopefully this post can save you a little bit of a headache, or it may cause you more. Who knows!

NOTE: Please read the Wiki answer before adding a suggestion to see if that suggestion has been made. Thanks!

"

This could be considered a bug or maybe is my browser. But every time I click on ""Class List"" on the main website, the list goes behind the video that I am watching at the time. I think it should go over it.

"

"

It would be best to have all of these ideas rolled into a single community wiki, so here we go:

Website/Videos

  • Pop-up Python interpreter to follow along with the code in the videos.
  • When watching a video, if you click the ""Class List"" link at the top of the page, the list is brought up behind the video.
  • Showing the length of each video would be helpful in that it would allow students to allocate their time more appropriately and know how many videos they have time to watch. Also, showing the total video time for a given unit would be nice.
  • Having the introduction video start each time I load the ""course content"" page is very annoying. This should be changed so that the first video brought up is the next one I need to watch (or the previous one I watched, if I didn't finish it) and even then the video shouldn't start automatically.
  • Show the number of students registered for each course.
  • Localized times visible so people in different coutnries know when new lectures will be posted and when assignments/tests are due in their time zone.
  • Better instructions on how to access and complete quizzes. Quite possibly a full step-by-step tutorial would make the process easier.
  • An optional auto-play feature that will go from one video to another without user interaction.
  • Reference numbers for each video so that they may be easily tagged in questions on the forums.
  • Expected hours of work required for any given unit.
  • Summary video/section for each unit.
  • It would be nice to have an email sent out to all students when there is an important update to the site, such as a new homework assignment being posted.
  • When doing quizzes you are immediately given the answers if you get the question wrong even one time. This should be changed with an option to view the answers.
  • A more visible link to the forums is desirable-- perhaps next to the 'Progress' link?
  • The importance of case (upper/lower) and white space in Python is not discussed.
  • Progress bars and game-like mechanics (see KhanAcademy) would be cool.
  • 'To learn more'-type link at the end of a video for those bold enough to want more.
  • Mobile support, make the site more accessible for mobile devices.
  • A calendar for each course would be really cool. Populate it with the dates of homework assignments, new videos, tests, etc.
  • Because the videos are hosted on YouTube, they are unavailable from more than a few countries. How about a mirror site where the videos can be downloaded?
  • The emails sent regarding updates in questions contain bad links.
  • PDF version of homework assignment similar to that of the course notes.
  • Khan Academy style quizzes/homeworks. This stems from the idea that mastery is better determined by continuing to do problems until you get enough right, as opposed to simply getting a homework questions right or wrong.
  • Different video speeds are a great idea. Not everything will be new to all students and some students may need to go slower than others. The ability to play the video at 0.75x, 1.00x, and 1.50x speed would be very useful.
  • A list of software that would be beneficial to students taking the course (such as where to download Python 2.7 and which IDE to use) would be tremendously helpful to new students with little programming background.
  • Until the answer videos are actually available, the 'Next' button should take students to the next question.
  • Links to additional exercises would be good for students who want to go above and beyond.
  • A single account for the main website and all forums would be ideal.
  • Fractional answers to quizzes/homework should be accepted.
  • In addition to auto-play, an auto buffer next video, if current has finished buffering option, if possible would be nice. With my slow internet, I'd have to open the next video in a new tab for it to start buffering after the current one has finished.
  • Add some (more)text in the instructor comments. The summary of the video from the units lecture notes would be just fine. Would give people with a slow internet with something to do while the video buffers. Though if you take a look at the Tangle javascript library, it would be nice if you could incorporate that into the instructor comments. Would make for nice, interactive notes that would add to the experience of learning.
  • Make it possible after due date to view the answer one submitted to the homework (to see if one forgot to click submit, or to see if maybe some modifications were made after due date which make it impossible to see why the homework was graded incorrect in retrospect)
  • Re-do the video lecture on TraceRoute (4.17) as there were many mistakes (192.168.1.1 being described as local host, not realizing that traceroute shows roundtrip delay, etc.) Re-do the homework question (4.4) that asks about latency to Cambridge from Palo Alto. Routers don't cause as much latency as the question assumes. The question and ""right"" answer are invalid because they are based on the misunderstanding about traceroute and roundtrip time.

Forums

  • More intuitive formatting. Making this list caused me a great deal of annoyance.
  • Provide an option to show which courses a user is currently registered in/has previously completed.
  • The ability to message other users on the forum is definitely needed.
  • Optional subscribing to threads as opposed to the current auto-subscribing.
  • Actually limit daily voting. I currently have -2 votes left for today and can still vote on posts.
  • Make the FAQ button larger and more noticeable. Perhaps stick it on the bar with the links 'Questions', 'Tags', 'Users', etc.
  • Attempting to sort questions by 'hottest' gives a 504 error.
  • Community wiki's aren't editable by another other than the creator, despite karma. A short explanation should be given. - [This appears to be false]
  • More than one answer can be accepted for any thread.
  • Karma is not rewarded when your comment gets voted up.
  • Suggest the use of standardized tags for commenting on homeworks/quizzes such as HW1.9, to help avoiding the multiplication of same questions on the same topic.
  • Consolidate forums with other courses?
  • Enable sticky posts for currently frequently asked questions, so the forums aren't spammed with 100 variations of the same problem.
  • There should be options to flag a question as 'Non-constructive' and 'Possible duplicate', in addition to the already available options.
  • A separate forum should exist for threads of general, non-course related discussions. This will have the added bonus of not clogging up the course forums with irrelevant material.
  • Having the formatting details shown when writing comments would be helpful.
  • Rather than requiring a separate account for each forum, link forum access to course enrollment and maintain posting statistics across courses.

Recommended additions to the FAQ

  • Why was Python chosen as the language for CS101?
  • The Canonical List of Known Bugs and Issues
  • Etiquette/Netiquette on the forum
  • Formatting your Python code

NOTE: If a Udacity employee wanted to contact me in some way to let me know which of these changes have been made, then I would be glad to remove them from the list.-

Having taught computing at a lower level - eg pre-university can I suggest that there is a little more explanation on variables as I know some students have trouble with variables and the use of the equal, = , sign to attribute values.

The way I used to teach was that variables were boxed and described the process of attributing as a four stage process.

eg items = 5

1) Process the expression on the left

That is get the number 5

2) Store it in a temporary box

put 5 in a temporary box

3) Empty the variable on the left

Set items to zero

4 Then move the stored result in 2 into the variable

Put the number 5 in items

I would then go through the process with more an more difficult situations

items = 5 + 6
items = items + 1
items = items + stock

Can I also suggest that you do not use the less than symbol <-- when explaining the variable concept as
some of your potential students will have had bad experience of maths and introducing other maths symbols can get very confusing.

Content / Teaching suggestion -- a topic that was not addressed in Unit 1 that may need to be is how to test code. For example in HW 8, we are to find the second occurrence of zip in a text string. Thus, for testing purposes a student should test the following conditions to endure that his/her program works:

'' (empty string)
'all zip files are zipped' - 2 occurrences
'all zipzip files are zipped' - 3 occurrences but embedded within same word
'all zip files are' -- 1 occurrence
'all zip files are zipped zip' - 3 separate occurrences

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I was reading this article on techcrunch http://techcrunch.com/2012/02/23/the-trouble-with-non-tech-cofounders/ about ""the trouble with Non-tech cofounders"" and I'd love to get to know more about this comment:
""But youâ€™ll quickly learn that all developers are not the same, and thereâ€™s a range of skills: front-end, back-end, UI, UX, design, etc. Becoming familiar with them all will be time well-spent"".

How do we differentiate between front-end, back-end, etc. and between all these types of programmers?
Are they differentiated by skills, programming languages known, etc. ?

Thanks a lot

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Well front-end designers are those who design the interface. They should have interfacing capabilities as well as some programmatic rigor.->-- C#, Visual Basic etc.

Back-end designers are those who deal with querying a database, managing a database, developing search algorithms etc.->--PHP, MySQL etc.

Design, well they design the aesthetic looks of the webpage and the tools provided.->-- XML, Html etc.

They are typically categorized by the languages they use.

"

There are simply lots of things you can program. Just few examples:

  • operationg system (e.g. Linux kernel)
  • back-end system (e.g. mail transport agent delivering e-mails, i.e. core functionality not directly seen by the user, even though he uses it)
  • internet appliacions (e.g. this forum or freemail's user interface, sometimes referred to as front-end)
  • automated car production line
  • robotic car :)
  • infinite number of other examples

Each of the programmers, working on his task needs different set of tools as well as motor mechanic needs completely different tools than the guy who repairs water pipes. However, do not think about such categorization to have strict thick lines drawn between the groups - they overlap.

""Hardcore system programmers"" will use mainly C (although this is really huge oversimplification) and will know operating system form inside out, better than their shoes. Programmers, who implement internet application will use Python, PHP, Perl, Java and similar languages.

Also, it usually does not suffice to know a programming languages, which suits the task. For example, in order to implement some banking application, one needs to understand also the banking business (or at least the small part of it, application will be used at).

There are lots of programming languages out there and usually many of them are well suited for the given task. It usually helps to learn more than one language and preferably languages using different paradigms (structured, object oriented, functional, ...). It widens your perspective and adds to the tools under your belt.

"

There's a big difference between front-end developers and back-end developers (front-end being the aspect of an application presented to users, and back-end being the software that is presented by the front-end).

Front-end developers need to think about the users, how what they make can be as userfriendly and fool proof as possible. This progress includes designers too of course. So the key is interaction in this aspect, which is a very challenging feature to think of as us IT-guys generally can find our way in any system without much help, while the average Joe might have trouble with this. So the questions they have to ask themselves: would John Doe understand this, how can we make this as easy for the user as possible, how can we make it look neat and polished, etc.

Back-end developers are generally less interested in how a solution is presented, but instead how their system will work most efficiently, and without mistakes. Their task is logically challenging, they need to ask themselves questions: what can I do to make this part faster, how much memory, security, etc.

Back-end developers tend to forget the users when developing, while front-end developers might think too much about the users and too little about the possibility and the back-end developers. It's safe to say that these two groups normally need a mediator so that the software will have best of both worlds.

So in my opinion it's not about how many programming languages you know, or which ones you do, but it's the mindset required.

Thanks a lot guys!!
These were all very informative answers.
I really appreciate it.

At this point, if you are taking CS101 to learn the basics of programming, you really don't need to worry about the different types of programming roles. Think of it like doctors or lawyers: you go to medical school/law school to learn how to be a doctor or lawyer, then you specialize for a while in some certain niche area, like heart surgery or criminal law. Some doctors become GPs, others brain surgeons-- some lawyers become family lawyers, some become prosecutors or corporate lawyers.

Right now, you don't need to worry about what type of programmer you want to be-- learn to be a programmer first, then look at what you have decided your interests lie in. You are in first year med school/law school right now, decisions can come later :)

I completely agree with you.
Mine was a question that had mostly the goal of understanding what one can do with programming than what type of programmer I might want to be. That, as you say, is way down the line.

But it might be useful to know all this stuff to have a more global view of things. Sometimes it really helps to understand the big picture and I feel this is particularly true in the case of programming, which at first might result a bit abstract. That's why I am loving udacity, which has very defined goals for the course and really helps understand where we are going.

Yes, very true. I think back to when I dropped out of CS in university, because I liked computer programming in HS, but in University where we were programming FORTRAN on punch-cards, it wasn't any 'fun', and I couldn't see myself doing that as a career. A couple of years later I get back into computer programming because I see that there are careers in it that ARE fun...so knowing about the different types of careers going in can be useful. Good answer!

"

This is actually how I started getting into programming:

I asked a simple question of my friends, and forums, ""What is a good language to teach myself-- I want to learn programming?""

They all replied, ""It depends on what you want to do."" And then they rattled off a list like that. Here is a breakdown of what that list means and how they are different (as far as I know). I'll use the Udacity website as an example (and put relevant languages in parens):

1. Front End

The Front End is a term that generally describes browser side of things. More formally it is the set of concerns that gather information from the user. The guys who program this are concerned with the user interface and cares about design, experience, ease of use and some security and efficiency. In Udacity, the Front End is what you see and how the web site is set up (HTML, CSS, JavaScript).

2. Back End

The Back End, in opposition to the Front End is where the ""heavy lifting"" is done behind closed doors. In a website this usually refers to things that are done server side. It is concerned with databases, searches, and the things that we have focused on so far in this course. The guys who program this are concerned with efficiency, robustness, security and data management. In Udacity, the Back End is how all of our names, grades, and progress are stored and computed and how hal sends out those emails (PHP, Python, C, Java).

3. UI

UI stands for User Interface. This is explicitly what the user sees and how he navigates. We have not done any UI work yet since we have been working in the terminal. You what know what a user interface is when we start doing it (if we do), but it is the difference between a program that is all letters and numbers typed in and one like a browser, that has images and uses the mouse. UI programmers are a subset of the Front End to some degree. In Udacity the UI is your browser (any, in a web app like Udacity its probably largely JavaScript).

4.UX

UX is a bit of a squishy term as it is not fully baked yet. It stands for User eXperience. I'm a Product Designer by schooling and a few years ago this was a term applied to our industry. A good way to understand it might be to use an analogy from my field. Think of an Ipod VS a Zune. Motly they are the same devices, but their success is wildly different. This difference can be summed up as a difference in UX. Everything from the sexy substantial box that an iPod comes in to the exclusive feeling when making a return in an Apple store is part of the total experience of the user. To apply this to Udacity might make me think of their mainpage

""We believe university-level education can be both high quality and low cost. Using the economics of the Internet, we've connected some of the greatest teachers to hundreds of thousands of students all over the world.""

To fit that goal, our user experience is somewhat of a designed hybrid between a traditional University experience and the kind designed by Sal Khan at Khan Academy.

I hope this helps give some idea of the landscape. I am new at this and probably have some of these descriptions wrong. Please make edits to improve the quality.

"

Great answer!

Hi, in question number 8 it states i should write my code in the ""below section"" or it wont be graded correctly....i have a concern about the text variable which is declared above the below section...should i redeclare it? or write my code that handles the text variable and not worry about it?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You shouldn't have to re-declare it to get the answer

You don't have to re-declare the variable. It still remains in the same block of code as long as you don't change the indents.

As for writing the code in the 'below' section, even though it isn't necessary for the program to run(Because only comments exist separating the 'below' section from the 'above' section having the text variable.), it is suggested to do so so that the code makes more aesthetic sense.
Don't redeclare it! That's exactly what will get your code graded incorrectly.

data-item.data-item-item:
In the variables vary segment, I was surprised to see that print when used with an expression that is a formula does not solve the formula based on the most recent values assigned to variables.

    So when you run this:      1 speed_of_light=299792458 #meters per second      2 cycles_per_second=2700000000.0 #2.7 GHz      3 cycle_distance = speed_of_light/cycles_per_second      4 print cycle_distance      5 cycles_per_second=2800000000.0 #2.8 GHz      6 print cycle_distance  You get  0.111034243704 0.111034243704  and not  0.111034243704 0.107068735  unless you repeat step 3 between steps 5 and 6  (cycle_distance = speed_of_light/cycles_per_second)

When I thought about this in terms of execution of steps, I finally understood that if you assign a new value to a variable then you have to add a step that resolves the expression using the new value - the print step will not do that for you.

So is it correct to assume that print will only resolve to the last CALCULATED value of an expression that is a formula (meaning it holds in memory the result of the last calculation that was executed as a step in the program even if new variable values were assigned, until a new execution step is added that repeats the calculation after those new values are assigned).

As a newbie, I realize I am not explaining this at all well, so feel free to ask questions that may help you answer my question!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Correct. You din't call the formula again so the expression wasn't ever calculated. You have to call the expression to calculate it.

Note: Calling the expression = typing it as of now. Later when you deal with functions and such it will become even clearer.
The variable cycle_distance was set equal to that quotient, but isn't bound to the values of the numerator variable and the denominator variable. So you would have to recalculate it to update it.

"

Thank you - I ""got"" it when I looked at the steps and thought about their execution - just wanted to make sure I ""got"" it in the abstract as well. And thanks for the argot lesson (calling the expression), that sort of thing is very helpful. Have a great day!

"

Yeah, that is correct. An assignment just makes the variable on the left of the '=' symbol equal to the computed value of the expression on the right, it doesn't store any reference to the original formula. The value contained within the variable won't change until you explicitly assign it a new one.

And print just shows the result of whatever you put after it. If that something is just a variable, it will resolve to its value.
Also very helpful - thank you!
