data-item.data-item-item:
Can someone clarify the python data types for me? I'm familiar with the basic java data types--char, string, boolean, int, double, float--but i'm confused about the python data types. As far as I've inferred, Strings are actually primitive data types in python and chars don't exist. Additionally, I don't understand how you know what kind of data type a number is if you don't declare it. Someone please explainâ€¦
Thanks

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Basically, you have strings, lists, and numerical types, and combinations of those. That's so awesome about Python: you don't have to worry one bit about types, the interpreter will fix this all for you! On the other side, this freedom comes with great responsibility: you will have to be very consistent, and have a lot of discipline, else the result won't be what you want... At all!

"

Have a look at this link over here

data types

Also python automatically sets data types to whichever one is applicable. You'd almost never have to allocate memory etc. for data.

"

"

Python is a dynamic language. That is the interpreter figures out dynamically what is the data type of the value assigned to a variable. Actually the variable has no data type, what it does is holding the memory address of the ""object"" where the string or number is stored, the object ""knows"" it's data type. So the data type is within the object, and is being figured out dynamically by the interpreter.

Java C/C++ pascal/object pascal are typed languages. The programmer in advance before compilation defines the data type of the variable like int x for instance. If x would be assigned with string and not an integer the compiler will complain...

Since in Python, data types are figured out by the interpreter dynamically according to the value assigned by the programmer, care must be taken for consistency between variables and values assigned to them along the entire program.

"

"

Python 2.7.2 data model from the official documentation.

"

"

In python, a variable isn't given a fixed memory location. When you assign a value to the variable, that variable points to the memory location that the value is stored in. When the value of the variable is changed, instead of the value in the memory location being changed, the variable instead points to another memory location.
Here, this will make it clearer - 

>-->-->-- a = 5 >-->-->-- print id(a) 41636408 >-->-->-- print id(5) 41636408 >-->-->-- b = a >-->-->-- print id(b) 41636408 >-->-->-- a += 7 >-->-->-- print id(a) 41636240 >-->-->-- print id(5) 41636408 >-->-->-- print id(b) 41636408 >-->-->-- b = 'change' >-->-->-- print id(b) 139941692058768 >-->-->-- print id('change') 139941692058768

So a variable can be assigned a value belonging to any data type in python

EDIT

More details, from this answer on StackOverflow

Values/literals are objects, so id()
will always return a valid result for
them. Beyond that, in CPython integer
literals from -1 through 256 as well
as short string literals are
interned, so they will have a
constant ID after they have been
accessed for the first time.accessed for the first time.

A little off topic, but still good to know.

"

Additionally, I don't understand how you know what kind of data type a number is if you don't declare it.

An interesting question. Once you start programming larger programs, you run into this difficulty. What I do with scripting languages like Python is that I use variable names that suggest what they contain. For example, instead of using n to store the number of elements in a list, I'd use numberOfElements.

"

You can use type() to see the data type. Here's a simple example:

x = ""asd"" y = ""a"" z = 5 k = 5.55 m = {} print type(x) print type(y) print type(z) print type(k) print type(m)
"

data-item.data-item-item:
It seems that by default, Python outputs a space between printed variables. For example, the following code outputs:

x=7

y=9

print x,y

OUTPUT:

7 9

Is there a way to get rid of that space so that the output becomes:

79
?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Convert them to strings and then print concatenation of those two strings is what comes to my mind first, but as I do not really know Python very well, there might be better solution (e.g. some printf-like function, etc.)

"

You could have a look at various way to do that at

Print

"

"
>-->-->-- x = 7 >-->-->-- y = 9 >-->-->-- print ""%d%d"" % (x, y) 79
"

>-->-->-- x=7 >-->-->-- y=9 >-->-->-- print str(x) + str(y)

works for me. (I had to convert it to a string because print x + y would result in 16, while when you make strings of them, it'll just concatenate them.

"

Or the new recommended string formatting vs the old string formatting

>-->-->-- x = 7 >-->-->-- y = 9 >-->-->-- print ""{0}{1}"".format(x, y) 79

A matter of taste...

"

"

You can use format strings

print ""%s%s"" % (7,9)    # this prints 79

Or you could use the write function

import sys sys.stdout.write('7') sys.stdout.write('9')

Or concatenate the Strings, as Mareq suggested.

print str(7) + str(9)

In python 3 print is actually a function and you can choose the separator character you want (even an empty one). To use it on 2.7

from __future__ import print_function print(6,7, sep='')
"
Thanks! I didn't know about this method of formatting

data-item.data-item-item:
Hey fellow students!

I have a quick question that I wasn't able to find an answer to.
In the final homework question (rounding), how many numbers after the decimal point do we have to take in account when rounding? Just the first or all of them?

For instance: if I have the number '42.39' do we round that to '42' (considering only the first digit) or to '43' (considering both digits).

If professor Evans is reading this: maybe you should clarify this in the question text?

edit: so I won't come across as a complete idiot I'd like to add this here: it's been a long time since I've been in school and I've been living in the word of (Math.)Floor()s and Ceil()s ... so you can probably see where the confusion came from :) Thanks you all for the answers!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: you need only consider the first digit, rounding up with .5

42.4999 still rounds to 42. You don't round digit after digit. 42.39 rounds to 42 regardless of how you look at it. If the first digit after the decimal is less than 5, round down. Otherwise, round up.
Do you have a source or something? I really can't find anything about this anywhere :/

Remember, as Angela said, you only need to consider the tenths place when rounding to whole numbers. If a number is X.0 to X.49, it gets rounded down. If it's X.50 and above, it gets rounded up. 42.39 is less than 42.5, so it gets rounded down.

I think AngelaTLC answered your question well (+1).

I'd just like to add that rounding with the second digit would result in 42.4, which still rounds to 42 (there's no way to get 43).

--James
A number of the form XX.XX will be rounded off to (XX+1) if and only if XX.XX>--=XX.50. Going by this, 44.49999 will still be 44 and 44.50 will be 45.
well I guess that would depend on what rounding algorithm you use :) Could be I'm out of school and in the programing world for too long now and can't think in elementary math anymore :P

I think we supposed to round to the nearest integer.

Kindly see the instructor comments beneath the question.

Rounding Rule:

We will not test submitted code on a number such as 3.5, but as a general rule most round functions would round 3.5 up to 4.

Hope this helps :)
yeah you are right, it's late (where I am), can't think straight anymore. Also see my comment to Drew's answer ...
There are other methods, as in the banking method. However, if you check the instructor notes at the bottom of the lecture screen, they mention the .5 rounds up rule explicitly.

I think that in this exercise, the number is 3.14159,( x variable) so I wrote 5 numbers after decimal point. And works fine!

If you want, you could include +/- ten numbers after decimal point.

That result isn't changes.

(excuse my poor english level) =)

a
'all'

if a string a is immutable how can I reassign it to a subset of itself?
Thank you

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You are not reassigning it to a subset of itself. Remember, 'a' doesn't 'equal' that string, but rather points to it. You are simply changing where 'a' points, creating a new entity 'all'

"

You reassign a different string object, newly created, to the variable. The old string object remains discarded in memory with no variable referencing it (garbage), until it's collected and thus its memory freed.

In languages that allow pointers such as C, you can really touch the characters in memory, which can be terribly unsafe and forces you to be very careful-- it's up to you to know how much space you have allocated in memory, and to avoid writing too long a string outside of it. In Python and others, what looks in code like a modification is a creation of a new object (if necessary copying every character but to a different memory location), the old one remains immutable, until the garbage collector (that runs in parallel in the background) acts and simply destroys it altogether if no variable is referencing it any longer. C is probably the only language that makes you manipulate strings as raw pointers-- other systems programming languages, even if they allow it, have other preferred wrappers to make strings.

String immutability doesn't mean you're limited in what you can do. Your code does what it says, and you can picture the abstract idea that you're changing the contents of a string variable. This is only what happens under the hood.

Of course for the runtime having to allocate memory for each string object separately (even when a lot of their content is the same) can slow the program down. Actually repeatedly performing string concatenation inside a loop, specially cumulative concatenation, is one very common cause of poor performance. But Python users in general don't care about performance a whole lot. In C you could program the routine so it would be much faster, and if you were really careful you probably wouldn't cause a buffer overflow, but you could never be sure that you had made no mistakes, because the language itself gives no guarantees. Other languages, even if they're safe and have immutable strings, have special ways to carry out string concatenations with good performance (.NET example).

"
When You assign a the second time you are storing a different string.(meaning the original string no longer exists).
So what is an example of what you can't do because of immutability. What are its consequences?

"

Quote from here:

In Python the string object is immutable - each time a string is assigned to a variable a new object is created in memory to represent the new value. This contrasts with languages like perl and basic, where a string variable can be modified in place. The common operation of constructing a long string out of several short segments is not very efficient in Python if you use the obvious approach of appending new segments to the end of the existing string. Each time you append to the end of a string, the Python interpreter must create a new string object and copy the contents of both the existing string and the appended string into it. As the strings you are manipulating become large this proces becomes increasingly slow.

And one more link answering the question why...

"

"

The string ""Now is the time for all good men"" is immutable, and it is still there somewhere in memory.
What you have done is to point the variable ""a"" to a slice of the string.
If you later point ""a"" to other object, let's say an integer, the memory manager will delete the string forever, as it's not referenced anymore.

Hope it helps.

[Edit: sorry I thought I was being original. I am really slow typing...]

"

When you type a=a[20:23], you evaluate it from right to left. So first the 20-23 positions are taken and then assigned to a. This has nothing to do with immutability. You can always assign another string to a string variable, because the variable a simply points to a string. It is when you try to change the string that you will get an error. For example, if after assigning a string to a, you try something like a[1]='b', that will not be allowed because strings cannot be changed.

Hope that helps :)

"

As far as I understand it, each time you create a string (or any entity for that matter), you are creating an entirely new object in memory. Thus if you assign a = ""Hello"", then a = ""Apples"", ""Hello"" is not simply destroyed but rather left unassigned. If you then assigned b = ""Hello"" python would not have to create a new object in memory but rather point b to the already existing ""Hello""

"

Apparently You can do anything You wish. the only consequence is the overhead of storing the object in memory say
a_string = 'How Are You Today?'
now if I want a substring from this string i need to either create a new string to hold the substring or overwrite the old one but if i keep this up then I will use more memory if that makes sence

"

It has no consequences in that limiting respect, its main consequence is making your code safe by preventing violations such as buffer overflows.

You needn't worry about it at all. But if you're interested, if you run

 s = ""A"" + ""B""  s = s + s

You have just created four string objects in memory: ""A"", ""B"", ""AB"" and ""ABAB"". Each will be allocated in a different place in memory, but you needn't worry about it. At any time the three of them no longer referenced by any variable (all except ""ABAB"") will be destroyed by the garbage collector that runs in parallel in the background, and their memory will be freed.

"

"

You cant do this with a string a[3]='b' you can do a[3]=""foo"" with a list-- At least that works in my interpreter

"

Immutable types behave much like the number types, so it's pretty difficult to explain the differences until you get to know the mutable types. It has to do with how variables are stored in memory, and the way certain operations work.

Immutability definitely definitely does not mean that you can't change the value of a variable, even to something that is a part of its original self.

"

you can't say a[2]='t' but with the list a=[""foo"",3,""bar"",3.6] you can say a[3]=""baz""

"

"

Hi, I couldn't understand why at the last step of the final quiz 1.39, when we write:

url=page[start_quote+1:end_quote]

<--end_quote>-- doesn't include the <--"">--, but <--start_quote>-- does.

=/ Can anyone explain?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: In python, A[3:7] starts at A[3] and goes up to A[6], but doesn't include A[7]. That may help!

"

**In general for any expression,
string[a:b], here b is b-1.

In final quiz
url= page[start_quote+1:end_quote]
In both we are not including<--"">--. we are just finding the first occurence of <--"">-- and taking it as start_quote. so the actual url begins at start_quote+1. and again we start searching for the closing<--"">-- . This is found from the position start_quote+1. so it will encounter the next closing<--"">--** which is end_quote. and how we evaluated end_quote you can see the above general expression

so in above program <--start_quote+1>-- begins after <--"">--, and <--end_quote>-- ends before<--"">--

"

"

Here's some info from the official Python tutorial which you might find helpful...

One way to remember how slices work is to think of the indices as pointing between characters, with the left edge of the first character numbered 0. Then the right edge of the last character of a string of n characters has index n, for example:

 +---+---+---+---+---+  | H | e | l | p | s |  +---+---+---+---+---+  0   1   2   3   4   5 -5  -4  -3  -2  -1

I find that thinking about it this way makes the inclusive/exclusive thing easier to understand.

For example, print ""Helps""[1:4] would give ""elp"" --- which includes the ""e"" at position 1 but not the ""s"" at position 4.

"

"

That is because, similar as in C++ (and its end iterator), end_quote points right past the last character of the chosen string. Therefore, the chosen string will not contain the quote indexed (or ""pointed to"") by end_quote. See also here.

"

Hi Mareq. I agree with your point about C++ iterators in general, but I don't think it quite applies here. After all, the end_quote index actually represents a position just before the closing quote, not after it.

"

@Forbin: You are absolutely right, we are just looking at it from different perspectives (I am working as C++ programmer for several years, so I might have slightly ""C++-ish"" look at things):

The string which is being cut off the original one starts at the character indexed by start_quote+1 (which is the one right after the quote, because start_quote ""points"" to the quote character). You can look at this first number before colon as if it was C++ begin iterator.

The end of the string being cut off the original one ends, as you said, just one character before the character ""pointed to"" by end_quote index. Or, in other words, end_quote ""points"" at the first position, which will not be the part of the string being cut off, just as I said. You can look at end_quote as if it was C++ end iterator as I do - or you can look at it in many different ways, which are more intuitive for you.

As you can see, both of us are speaking about the same thing, just from different perspective. Thanks for pointing it out though, as it is important to look at things with your own eyes, otherwise you will not understand it. So, do not be too influenced by my ""iterator theory"" and feel free to find perspective which best suits yourself.

"

Maria,

When I was first learning Computer Science, as an undergrad, there were times I questioned why a language did a thing this way or that way and to answer your question briefly...

The designers of the Python language defined it that way and so do other computer languages but NOT necessarily all. You just have to look up how this functionality, known as creating a substring, is defined in a given language.

  • Let x be a string
  • Let start_index and end_index be positive integers
  • x[ start_index : end_index ]

It will always INCLUDE the start_index, and EXCLUDE the end_index.

"

""It will always INCLUDE the start_index, and EXCLUDE the end_index.""

That clears things up man! Thank you so much! :) :)

"

"

Interpreted or compiled is a property of the implementation. Python's glossary describes it as an interpreted language, however the code is compiled into bytecode and executed in a virtual machine. CPython is the most popular implementation. There exist others, like PyPy which is Just In Time compiled, Jython which compiles to Java bytecode and runs on JVM, IronPython which runs on .NET DLR, there's a compiler that compiles it to C++ called ShedSkin, and a bunch of others.

You can see the programming paradigms describing Python on its wikipedia page.

As to Python being a scripting language, I think it's more of a matter of opinion and context you use it in. It has certainly been used for big projects as well as administrative tasks or glue.

Either way, rakedu has the good link. Arguably LPTHW is the easiest to start with.

To everyone thinking conditionally:

'.51'['.51'.find('.')+1:'.51'.find('.')+2].find('6') is -1

'.51'['.51'.find('.')+1:'.51'.find('.')+2].find('5') is 0

-1*0=0

While googling about programming &-- self learning, one gripe that keeps appearing (in blogs/forums) from good coders/professionals is that many (not all) self taught programmers (i.e. with no formal training) don't follow good programming practices. Their code might get the job done, but it suffers from many shortcomings. Poor choice of variables, poor commenting, consistency, code structure, etc. etc.

I like that in the videos, there are comments about some of these practices. Already, in the first 2 units, we have heard Prof. Evans comment on variable names and structure of codes and how appropriate/inappropriate they may be. For example, a code syntax might be valid, but Prof. Evans also mentions in the same breath that its syntax means it works, but you wouldn't write 'good' code like this.

Every language will have its own standards and practices, but there must also be universal good practices regardless of choice of language. I hope whether it be in videos/notes/pdf, lots more guidance is given to us all before the end of the course. I hope to learn more from upcoming udacity courses (provided they continue to be FREE :) ). This course is a great help to get an introduction to the world of programming. Any tips from Prof. Evans on how we could grow as programmers after the conclusion of this course? How do we introduce some structure, some blueprint that can guide our self learning after the completion of this course? I know we should read books, code a lot, read others code etc. I read Mr. Norvig's advice on ""Teach Yourself Programming in Ten Years"". With all sorts of languages, compilers, IDE's etc., it can be a daunting task to take the first step. This course is hopefully a vital first step, but how can the amateur self learner sketch some sort of road for learning the art &-- craft of programming?

Thanks

"

From a theoretical point of view rounding 2.5 to 2 or 3 is arbitrary. The convention is that .5 rounds up.

Here is a possible practical explanation. I was told that random number number generators truncate to the last digit of precision. Suppose that we have 6 digits of precision and that we are given a ""true"" random number of 2.5000000000000001. Then, the random number generator would give 2.50000. But we know that the ""true"" number should round to 3.

On the other hand suppose the ""true"" random number is 2.49999999999999999999. The the output would be 2.49999. Either way, it would round to 2.

If anyone has better/more information on the issue I would like to hear it.

"
WOW! very good answer! Thank you

The number in the tenths place (rt. of the decimal) is the only one that matters in this problem because we are supposed to round to the closest whole number. At first, I thought we needed to round from the furtherest position to the right. In other words, all the 9s to the rt. of the 4 (in 2.4999999999) would make the .4 round up to .5, thus rounding to the whole number 3. I was able to get my numbers to round only in reference to the tenths place (.5 or above rounds up, .4 or below rounds down). I thought this was not sufficient, but a friend told me this is exactly the type of rounding the question asks us to perform.

I don't know what do you call this in programming terms, is it good to use the same variable over and over?

Say for example:

x = <--{some number}>--
then convert it to

x = str(x)

using the variable X multiple times in the code?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: You can do it, but it's not a good practice because you eventually start to loose track of which variable you need or which variable you are working with. Also it will save you a lot of trouble when debugging a big piece of code.

You can use it, but generaly you will use x for some value and other variable for other value. So you can't get confused.

But of course is very common to reuse a variable, for example to count things or to know how many times you have done some part of the code.

I haven's seen using x for a number and then for a string. And I won't use it that way. I will sure get confused in the future with both assignements.

But if you are carfull there shuld be no problem.
Well, you need to keep track of the variable. For example, you don't want some part of your code to change the value of your variable to some garbage value.
Just edited my question. I would go with the best practise. Is this called over-loading or is it a different term all together?
Thanks Gustavo!
Thanks Mukil.Will avoid this thought :)

"

As a rule of thumb I try to keep the variable true to it's own meaning.

So if you've a variable called 'first_name' and 'last_name' I wouldn't use them to hold the 'full_name'.

But you could easily do something like (to keep from examples present in unit 1)

first_name = 'pedro'
first_name = 'P' + first_name[1:]

Also, at least while learning I would advise to be as verbose as possible. 'x', 'y', 'z' all are a little bit criptic and you've to map things on your head.

Also - a little bit unrelated - I highly recommend people to watch this talk from Bret Victor

It does not talk much on variables, but rather talk about all those abstractions we do while coding :)

[]'s
Pedro Markun

"
Overloading applies to operators and functions, not to variables.

"

It depends.

The variable name is just that, a name. It tells the interpreter to look for that name and assign data/values to it. Generally it is considered bad practice to re-use the same variable over and over since this makes code harder to read and might introduce errors where you switch ""x"" to represent a number, then a string, then back to a number, and lose track of what it should be. On the other hand, you can reuse variables that are defined in functions because of scope (variables declared in a function are ""local"" - see Unit 2), or variables that are meant to be used as temporary storage of data between operations.

I would suggest you keep coding and trying little exercises, and if you find yourself not remembering what ""x"" does, use a different variable. In case you're really serious about this, try reading some programming language style guides.

"

If you want to be sure you remember which variables go together, you can always adapt a particular naming practice. With your example, you could use something like the following:

x_int = <--any number>-- x_str = str(x)

I personally prefer that as it's easy to find which variation you're working with at any given point. It also eliminates the chance that you'll end up using one version when you mean the other.

It is actually quite a common programming practice ti use the letters i and j as loop control variables. You can use any letter but the beauty of this approach is that it only takes a single character in the loop control expression

Here's a suggestion: Any time you're asking someone to re-word something, don't just provide a reference, but also provide the text. That would help me here as I don't know exactly what you're referring to. I suspect you're talking about Homework Question 3

Which of the following sequences of statements leaves the value of the variable X the same as it was before the statemens. Assume that both A and X refer to integer values before this code.

A=X
A=A+1

A=X
X=A

X=X+1
X=X

A,X=X,A
A,X=X,A

Z=X
A=Z

Is this the right question?

If so the question is checking to see if you understand the concept of variables and how the values of variable can and does change.

Sometimes it's helpful to use the word ""gets"" when assigning a value to a variabl-- viz. A gets X-- A gets A plus one. Has the value of X changed after executing these two statements?

"

What I mean is that a=10 is a statement that assigns a value--in this case ten--to a variable--in this case the variable a.

It might help you to appreciate and understand the assignment of value if, instead of saying (out-loud or in your head) a equals 10 you said, a gets ten or a is assigned the value of ten.

Similarly, the statement:


i=i+1

assigns to the variable i the value of i plus 1

If you said, i gets (assigned the value) i plus one.

Variables--the entire notion of a variable might be foreign--provide a way to store values and are a central component of computer programming. Some programs store values such as FirstName, LastName, StudentID, EmailAddress, PhoneNumber, and StudentPhoto. These values aren't written in stone and are may be modified many thousands or millions of times during the operation of a program. ""Writing these values in stone"" is achieved by writing values to a file for later retrieval.

The difference is similar to that of a word processing program: the text you type is a variable, call it DocumentContents and this changes as you change the contents of the file. The file is ""written in stone"" when you save the file and ""read from stone"" when you open the file.

But we're not writing to stone, rather we're writing to a magnetic disk that can easily and quickly be re-written and re-written and re-written.

I hope this is provides you at least some assistance.
Please let me know either way.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi, i'm totally new to writing code and i have no previous experience. I finally completed the last quizz question which really took me a while and ended up laughing at myself because of the simplicity involved in the answer. I'm loving this course so far!

So now my question, is it better to compress the code all in one line or define different variables and end up with 3 or 4 lines?
I'm asking this because on the homework i found myself wondering if i could compress all the lines into just one. When i saw i could, i then thought that it would be too crowded so i erased it an wrote it in 3 lines again.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Good question to ask yourself is: will anyone else understand your code without you having to explain what it does?

It's to do with readability. If it makes it much harder to read, then it's better to have it more spread out so there is some sort of balance between keeping it short and keeping it readable.

Remember you write code for the person who will have to read it after you (which may even be an older you), and maintain it and not just to make the computer do what you want.

This topic is mentioned in Unit 2, answer to quiz in video 15.

Since you are a beginner, I don't feel this is the right time to shorten the length of the code. It doesn't matter if your code is longer as long as it satisfies all the conditions of the question and you aren't using any bad programming practices. But, after you write the code, you figure out a shorter way of doing it then use the shorter one. Hope that helps :)

Given the same choice you had, I would have done as you did and erased the single, crowded line and gone with the three line answer.

It's important for someone to be able read your code easily as a general principle. If it looked clunky to you now, imagine what it would look like a few months from now.
Thanks for the answers!! I/m starting unit 2 tomorrow :D

when you are learning new code, it's better to keep it broken out. Trying to make it extremely concise, and only one line is good, but if something breaks, you will have to dissect what you have, and figure out which part of that was broken.

Keep is spread out, so you can diagnose problems, and make it more readable.

data-item.data-item-item:
A small question/correction:
In the solution to CS 101's Unit 2, question 6, we were not allowed to include the comma, yet it's not written into the function underneath either. I know this is a small point, but I like to have my few good habits reinforced --)

A huge thank you to everyone who is making this class possible!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

The question used to have one single box where ""url, end_quote"" was the correct answer, but after I had multiple fails on the input and complained about it here, Peter thought it would be best to switch to 2 boxes. As such, I'm guessing he removed the need for a comma, and because when the video was shot they were doing it for a single box, no comma was written on the screen.

Yeah, confusion abounds.

"
I was trying to make it easier. Was the single box better?
No, I think this was fine enough, Peter.
Stay with two boxes. An image edit to show the comma would help
It should accept and require the comma, one way or the other, since that's the necessary syntax, and it wasn't already provided by the video question.
I wish it were that easy. The creation of that image is entirely automated.

"

Hard to say. I think the two boxes are easier and less error-prone from an automated checking point of view, but it needs that comma between the boxes to keep the syntax consistent.

On the other hand, if you can check using regular expressions for url, comma and end_quote in one single box, and allow variations like 

""url,end_quote"", ""url , end_quote"", ""   url     ,end_quote""
, then that might be better for the students.

"

"

Make the ""image creation automation fixing program"" the next user challenge!

"
I can't change that box to run an arbitrary evaluation without taking the unit down at this point.

Peter, I'd vote for either a visible comma between the two boxes or a single box requiring the comma to be typed. I know people will feel it's finicky, but we've all got to learn about proper syntax sometime and the earlier the habit gets reinforced the better.

"

How about adding a little note in the Instructor Comments box under the video along the lines of, ""Assume there's a comma between the two boxes. Enter only the variable names to be returned.""

It cost me only one resubmission, but I suspect it might cost anyone who's less confident in their answer a few extra submissions, thinking they chose the wrong variable all together.

Also, I hope it does allow for changing the sequence of returns, i.e., end_quote, url.

"
maybe u could add a third box that is a little smaller between those tow boxes just for the comma. It would have helped me ---)

"

Then it would probably be best to add a hint to the ""instructors comments"" box. Anyway, think it isnt a major hurdle and everyone should get it after the video..

data-item.data-item-item: This is getting way ahead of what we are covering in this section, but I just went through the review to question 15 and I'm wondering whether there is any performance difference (e.g. number of required operations or allocated memory) between the two example answers that Dave described?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Memory is usually taxing, I personally avoid using variables which won't be used more than once. Unless the code is getting unreadable, I find it more efficient.

This is something that made me laugh in unit2, David demonstrated almost all my answers as alternative, shorter ways :)

"

Thanks @Angel! I'm still curious though, are you speaking about programming practices generally or particularly about Python? The reason I ask is because it seems like the interpreter might have a significant impact on how well optimized the final operation is (much like a compiler would in other languages), and since there seem to be quite a number of Python interpreters out there, I am wondering if there are any set rules about best practices, or if it's a grey area dependent on CPU, interpreter, etc.

"

This is a more generalist answer, I'm not proficient with Python in any way, I don't know how the interpreter works internally. This is a good question I believe. I wish my conception was good for Python as well. Maybe someone can answer this from a deeper point of view, Python-related.

Actually, I originally wrote the procedure the same way he did in his first example, and it took a few seconds to run. I then optimized the procedure by getting rid of the variables and just nesting the finds. It executed much more quickly.
you should focus on code readability-- any modern compiler (say c++) would create the same output for all the three examples he gave.

"

One of the most valuable resources is human time. If you got better readable code, then this is more important, than one small variable. Most of interpreters and compilers have built-in ""garbage collector"" functions.

Optimizations should be done in places, where they really matter. For example, frequently used loops with many iterations and big variables. One of questionable procedures IMHO is 'page = page[end_quote:]'. This means that variable 'page' has doubled for some time. Because web pages can be quite large (even MB-s), and this assigning process happens many times (after every found link and links can be thousands on one page), then, when we add parallel execution (different threads searching many web pages on same time), it can make quite big overheads to computer. I probably prefer approach, where I load webpage at once to variable 'page' and then just move pointer from one link to next one. But to be sure, then for production systems is best to test both approaches and check real life performance.

"
I really wish someone knowing the interpreter could answer this...
I agree, Dino. In this case, on the website, python is interpreted, so the code could have a significant impact on execution speed.

"

I couldn't avoid to check theory and as soon, as I finished Homework 2 and other important things, I start testing. Test conditions: to avoid Internet speed influence, I downloaded test material to 542kb file with 1379 links. Source http://www.heathrowairport.com/flight-information/destinations-and-airlines. Then wrote search modules, first with loading page to memory and then just changing position, at which to start searching next link. Second version uses method 'page = page[endpos:]' (cutting small chunks from 542kb variable and then assigning cut version to old variable name) described on Unit2. Results were quite interesting. Pure search (url-s assigned just to variable) take with first method 0.00518306097563 sec, with second method 0.297533625084 â€“ first method was whole 57.4 times faster!

At another perspective, when I let to print all those links to Python shell, first method takes 12.4751860921 sec, second method 12.7709261931 â€“ so printing to shell have so big overhead, that 57.4 times faster code gives only little over 2% speed improvement for total procedure.

I can't post code to forum due to Honor code, but if Udacity team is interested of checking calculations I'm happy to send code to some Udacity e-mail, to eliminate possibility of some stupid mistake in my test.

"

data-item.data-item-item: I think returning page[end-quote:] would have been a bit cleaner than returning end-quote. end-quote is only used inside of get-next-target so its use isn't as clear from the calling code. Also page is already a known variable and if updated and returned, eliminates the need to repeatably update it in the calling code.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Wouldn't this also change the index numbers of the found links to make them all variable depending on the changed starting position?

If you snip out a big chunk of the full page, the second AND first link might be both returned in your program at position 5 which would make operations on page analysis confusing.

Absolutely not. Returning anything from 'page' would bounce around a really large mount of memory.
Keep in mind that end_quote is just a number, while page[end_quote:] is the whole page but the part that's been processed. The caller already have all this information (original 'page' variable)

I thought of that too, but I was just thinking of it from a purely theoretical point of view not really considering memory management. Also manipulating page outside of the function has the same problem.
I like to think that you should always keep transfers at a minimum. Moving along an index is faster than a long chunk of text, also specially redundant if you already have it.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I think the problem is the order of your input variables. In the text, it says source and target, I think it wants

def find_second(source, target):

which means when it runs the tests on your code, it's inputting the variables the other way around.

"

"

If you were just writing the code for you, it wouldn't matter which way around you wrote the inputs, but because it's being tested, it has to be the right way around according to the way the inputs are given.

data-item.data-item-item: Can I safely assume the input given is only a decimal and not a whole number?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It says x holds a decimal number. So yes, you can safely assume that.
Thank you, though i could get the answer using the inbuilt functions provided by python, I'm trying to do this by only using those construts taught in class
If you use the inbuilt function then it doesn't matter if the number is decimal or not --)
That's a clever response!
:D I did think of it when I was implementing it

if you wanted to be sure it has a decimal point, i would think you could just say x = x * 1.

then if x = 3, then 3 *1. = 3. and there is your decimal
Why did I not think that, good one.
I can't see a reason one would round a whole number to itself- x is defined in the problem as having a decimal though, it should be safe to assume that.

true you wouldn't in the real world round a whole number but this is an exercise to think outside of the box. and something that you will learn as you program, the fastest way you can come up with a bug is to assume a user 'would never do that'.
think about it like this
if we had our little algorithm that rounds x, and the user gets to define x before its run through the algorithm, we cant assume that user would put an a decimal in the number. and when we turn it into a string then the string.find wouldn't be able to find it and we get either an error or the wrong output. always assume the user will try to break it.
of course if we really wanted to round we'd just say round(x) but that's getting a bit ahead of ourselves. but for something like this its always good to get into the right habits from the start. and one of those habits is user-proofing.
point taken and lesson learned (mercifully before I'd end up learning it the hard way.)

don't feel bad. i learned it the hard way and i still forget every now and then. I write software that controls rice mills and sometimes I'm amazed at what people do that i wouldnt have even thought of. When I test i go by WWMMD (what would my mom do) lol
Either way it will end up being a decimal, integer or not. --)

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I have been having fun with the course material so far, and learning Python as I go. Like many people, I bet, I got excited when I saw the professor use a 'get_page()' function. Of course, I tried it, and it didn't work for me, there is no such built-in function. So, not to be deterred, I started looking around for one on the internet. It turns out that writing get_page() is non-trivial, at least if you want to take into account things like JavaScript pages that are created dynamically in the browser. So, I did a little more searching around, and found that Qt (which has Python bindings) has got something called WebKit now, and WebKit can render web pages, both to html (thus rendering any JavaScript in the page to actual html code) and graphically-- it can actually display the page.

You will have to install python-qt4 for this to work. I originally used urllib2 to load the html from websites, but that left me with the JavaScript problem. WARNING: don't use this indiscriminately, as we haven't learned how to handle robots.txt files yet, and some folks won't appreciate students running web-scrapers on their sites!

Here is my code so far, which is hella fun :)

''' Created on 2012-02-28  @author: Darren Reid ''' import sys   from PyQt4.QtGui import *   from PyQt4.QtCore import *   from PyQt4.QtWebKit import *  def get_next_target(s):     start_link = s.find('<--a href=')     start_quote = s.find('""',  start_link)     end_quote = s.find('""',  start_quote+1)     the_url = s[start_quote+1:end_quote]     return the_url, end_quote  def print_all_links(page):     while True:         url,  endpos = get_next_target(page)         if url:             print url             page = page[endpos:]         else:             break  class Render(QWebPage):     def __init__(self, url):       self.app = QApplication(sys.argv)       QWebPage.__init__(self)       self.loadFinished.connect(self._loadFinished)       self.mainFrame().load(QUrl(url))       self.app.exec_()    def _loadFinished(self, result):       self.frame = self.mainFrame()       self.app.quit()  if __name__ == '__main__':     url = 'someurl' #replace someurl with an actual url      r = Render(url)       html = r.frame.toHtml()     print_all_links(unicode(html))      app = QApplication(sys.argv)     web = QWebView()     web.load(QUrl(url))     web.show()      sys.exit(app.exec_())
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Thanks for the interesting info! I'd be worried about the performance hit you're going to have if you try to scale this up to crawling large numbers of pages, though. You probably want to do as little processing as possible on each page, ignoring things that don't ultimately involve links. But I agree that this is a non-trivial problem. For example, should you ignore links that appear within commented-out code?

I suppose you could also question whether you really want to interpret the Javascript or not. Links that don't appear until after the Javascript runs are sometimes things that the web designer is deliberately trying to hide from webcrawlers, like email addresses. And any decent web designer is going to know that, from an SEO perspective, if there's something you want visible to webcrawlers, you're going to make it as easily accessible as possible.

data-item.data-item-item: Why is print considered a side effect and not an output? Aren't you still receiving information from compiling the procedure?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It depends on how you frame your inputs and outputs. But the principle reason is that you should be able to chain true functions together by their inputs and outputs. Namely factorial(squared(x)) should return (x^2)!. But if squared's output was a print statement, you can't easily do that.

Another way to think about it is that an output is giving something someone, while printing is shouting something at him. With an output he gets something physical which he can then manipulate further, while with shouting he just hears something over which he has no further control.
The term 'output' is very specific here. The output is the value returned by the procedure. This will make more sense when we begin assigning the returned values to variables.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Every character is counted. Blank spaces are also treated as characters. Hope that helps :)
There is a difference between '' and ' '. The first one is a blank character and the second one is a space. The first one is not counted and the second one counted. Hope this helps.
yes Mukil, that's what I thought. thanks

"

In addition to Mukils answer, there's in fact plenty of other 'characters' that one would maybe not think of, like the newline character '\n', the tabulator '\t', the backspace '\b' and the bell '\a' (yes, that's the beep your computer might do when it's switched off or something). The backslash '\' shows that it's a special character that cannot be printed on the screen.

There are different character sets that can form a string, and the default one is the ASCII range 0-127, but python has Unicode strings, too, for representing languages other than English. A String is basically a sequence (or list) of numbers (!) which are mapped to the characters from the corresponding character table. The character 'A' is represented by the number 65 for example, and the space by number 32. So when you deal with strings, you always have to keep in mind that for the system it's only a list of those numbers or symbols. Of course there are build-in methods which help you find out if some character is a letter, a number or 'something printable'.

"
You are welcome :)

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Is it possible for a web page to have <-- a >-- tags such that there are more than one space between the character ""<--"" and the character ""a"" OR between the character ""a"" and the word ""href"" OR between the word ""href"" and the character ""=""?

In such a case, our getnexttarget(page) function would skip those tags, and we should probably use regular expressions.

I suppose that although the files in the web server may contain the spaces mentioned above, when the browser requests the web page, it removes the unnecessary spaces. Anyhow, I'm not sure.

Does anyone have an idea?

Thank you in advance,

          Angel
"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It doesn't work that way. <--a href is a part of HTML which is also a language and you can't change its syntax. You can try it out here and see for yourself : link w3schools

And once you detect <--a href then you can search for 'http' and avoid the space between href and =
Hope that helps :)

"

"

Spaces between '<--' and 'a' are not allowed but you can have any amount of spaces between '<--a' and 'href'. Also, href might not even be the first attribute. If you look here clicky you can see that there are many possible attributes for the 'a' element and all of them can be legally positioned before 'href' and have unlimited amount of spaces between them.

"
Wrong, href is not specified to be the first attribute after <--a. Also HTML ignores whitespace and does not differentiate between one space, 400 spaces or even a new line.

Nonsense. There are a lot of ways that this can be emitted from an editor that will still parse in browsers. There are a lot of broken pages out there boys and girls, and the browsers coddle them rather heavily.

For valid HTML tags, or XML entities, there cannot be any space between the opening <-- and the 'a' or character representing the tag. Likewise there cannot be spaces between the attribute, the assignment operator (=), and the value. The whitespace between attributes can be one or more spaces.

A space between a and href won't change the output. I missed that. A space between <-- and a will not display the URL. But URLs are specified as <--a href so I didn't follow what you meant by href is not specified to be the first attribute after <--a. Is there another way of representing URLs in HTML?

"

Unfortunately, using this '<--a href=' isn't so straightforward, like it seems at first glance. I did small search module for deriving links from webpages and when I tried it on 'http://www.udacity-forums.com/cs101/questions/' (the main udacity CS101 questions page), I got with '<--a href=' only 43 links and missing all question links on page. Then I look at page source code and find such lines:

'

Would 2.5 round Up to 3 or Down to 2?

'

When I drop '<--a' and used only ' href=', were results much better - 231 links from page and all questions are now included.

"
Look at the link i posted below. You can put any of the listed attributes before href and it is still 100% valid HTML.
Now that I didn't know. Thanks.

Very soon I am sure they are going to teach you guys Regular expressions in python. Using them, you can solve all these problems. Stay put --). Or else go to docs.python.org and learn stuff on your own, like I did a few years back..
You're welcome :)

"

It would seem obvious to use regular expressions for this since our function would miss completely valid anchor tags such as or . However, I'm not sure if using regular expressions would be too advanced in a introductory computer science class. Also, using regex to parse HTML/XML is painful, citing from the last paragraph from http://docs.python.org/howto/regex.html#greedy-versus-non-greedy:

""(Note that parsing HTML or XML with regular expressions is painful. Quick-and-dirty patterns will handle common cases, but HTML and XML have special cases that will break the obvious regular expression-- by the time youâ€™ve written a regular expression that handles all of the possible cases, the patterns will be very complicated. Use an HTML or XML parser module for such tasks.)""

"

"

I think what we made was just a simplified version of how it would be in the real life, but you can easily apply the techniques explained to avoid those problems.

By that I mean you could use an algorithm such like:

1.- Look for a '<--a'
a) If there isn't any, end program (cause there are no more links)
b) Otherwise go to 2

2.- Look for a href between the found '<--a' and="""" the="""" coming="""" '="""">--' (asuming the html is well-written and there exists such final '>--')
a) If it isn't any href between '<--a' and="""" '="""">--' go to the next link (i. e., search for a new '<--a' by going to 1)
b) If there is href got to 3

3.- Look for the "" after href. The link is between it and the coming "". Then, go back to 1.

This way, you can continously ""narrowing"" until you reach the desired piece of text, that is, the link, and then you go on for the next one.

Hope it helps :-)

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Why do we prefer explicit string parsing in this class?

According to HTML cpecification, anchor element can contains a lot of addition attributes. Not only href. They can be arranged by different ways. Link extraction for every possible attributes combination can be very difficult.

Thehe are more suitable approaches. for example there is regular expressions. We can define search template with a single string of code matching all possible link definitions.

Also I wonder, what to do whith invalid HTML page?
For example <--a href=""page1.html>--page1<--/a>--...<--a href=page2.html"">--page2<--/a>--

If it were valid, then url should be ""page1.html>--page1<--/a>--...<--a href=page2.html""

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
As you said, HTML you are parsing is not guaranteed to be valid (given you want to implement robust crawler), thus it makes usage of grammar very difficult. Also, few quizzes in unit 1 were directly crying for usage of at least regular expressions.

But, as you noticed, import command is forbidden. That is because this is basic course and I think that primary objective is to learn Python itself. So, given that, you will naturally start with easy basics like find, not with grammars, XML parsers and regexps.

The course is a 100-level introductory class, so programming concepts are being introduced gradually. You are correct that an HTML parser should be more robust, but I assume the primary reasoning behind the exercises is to solidify students' string handling knowledge and to get them used to the coding environment and so on. I don't think introducing regular expression syntax at such as early stage would be right - it's not straightforward and absolute beginners may be overwhelmed.

Besides, while regular expressions are incredibly powerful and useful, they are not answer to every problem. Simple one-line Regexp can be very demanding for resources - while at the same time, specifically written 500-line mess of a parser, which does exactly same job, can be much faster.

Lets say its faster by one whopping microsecond. Isn't much, unless your goal is to crawl through whole internet, and doing so faster than your next-door-neighbor.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Sometimes it is difficult to find related questions about the same question creating a bunch of questions asking the same (for example, the pervasive homework 9 of unit 1). This is a lot of noise sometimes.

I was wondering if we could agree on a tagging etiquette at least for the lecture slides and homework exercises to help people find them easily.

UPDATE: After some debate and a considerable retagging work of some classmates (i.e. the trending tag hw1.9) we have agreed on the following tagging conventions:

  • Homework 1 question 9 ->-- hw1.9
  • Unit 2 section 1 ->-- unit2.1
  • Python (general questions on Python) ->-- python
  • Programming (general programming quesions) ->-- programming
  • Office Hours ->-- officehours
  • Administration (deadlines, rules, ...) ->-- cs101
  • Technical issues, bugs ->-- bug
  • Suggestions ->-- suggestion
  • ""Cafe lounge"" (little off topic threads like thanks, T-shirts, brown-haired groups, ...) ->-- offtopic
  • Important information posts ->-- sticky
  • Questions on ifs (including a if x else c expressions) ->-- conditionals
  • Questions on while, for, etc. ->-- loops
  • Mistakes in and queries about grading ->-- grading
  • Anything about this forum itself ->-- meta

These conventions do not exclude you to tag questions with other tags than the suggested here. However, complementing your tags with these additional ones helps finding related questions easier.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Seems like a very good idea. I like the abbreviated ones more.

I agree on the abbreviated way of tagging. However there is a lot of question which are being asked that are general in nature and yet do have some play on the course. I don't know if we can work on a complete abbreviated logic for the same to cover the gamut of discussion points. Any one has a another answer??? .
I only ask for an agreement on the Homework and Lecture related questions. Of course it is not intended to find a rule for the general questions. I don't even think it is appropriate --)

"
Me too. Let's keep it simple --)

A suggestion for the forum administrators: even if you don't want to lower karma levels for closing and editing questions, I think there's a separate level that can be set for retagging questions. It might be good to set that fairly low so that most active members will be able to retag questions as they appear in the list.

Also, it was really helpful in terms of getting tagging in order last semester in the AI Class and the aiqus.com board when links were added to the units on ai-class with suggested tags to be used on aiqus.com.

"

Second try, including also some other tags, created as merge of mine and Mortazavi's suggestions from his thread. I tried to reuse already existent tags, which are most widely used. However, it is work of just one guy and it definitely can be improved, so feel free to do so.

  • Unit 1 Homework 9 ->-- hw1.9
  • Unit 2 Section 1 ->-- unit2.1
  • Unit 2 Question/Quiz 21 ->-- q2.21
  • Python (general questions on Python) ->-- python (this one already exists)
  • Programing (general programming quesions) ->-- programming (this one already exists)
  • Office Hours ->-- officehours (this one already exists)
  • ""Administrivia"" (deadlines, rules, ...) ->-- cs101 (most used existing one, which seems to be usable for this purpose, however, it might not be the best one after planned merge of forums)
  • Technical issues, bugs ->-- bug (already existent and used one)
  • Suggestions ->-- suggestion (already existent one, though it is not used very much)
  • ""Cafe lounge"" (little off topic threads like thanks, T-shirts, brown-haired groups, ...) ->-- offtopic (this one does not exist, feel free to suggest your ideas, especially here...)
"

"

I totally agree. I'd be interested in retagging a few posts that I've come across, and I've got a long way to go on the karma scale, as it currently stands (especially after I ""awarded points"" a couple of times!).

"

I merged off-topic and social considering that social questions are really off-topic --).

Although I haven't asked questions directly related to course content (specific videos, quizzes, or homework), I WILL adopt these tag conventions and use them if needed. Thanks to everyone in this question who put these together.
The capitalization of HW, Unit and Q are not used in most threads, so I think we should stick to lower case as suggested in OP.
Good point. I edited my post to use lower case letters, to be in line also with dreyescat's post, who got it right.
I turned this question into community wiki. So feel free to edit it directly.

Unit 2 question/quiz 21 ->-- question2.21

- me (@dreyescat)
- @fnenu
- @Velak
- @Angel
- @solarbike

If I missed someone feel free to participate too.
Also this is open to everyone else that thinks a better tagging can improve the way we help each other.

"

I think keeping them separate would be better, so that people can search for exactly what they want. If the course website is separating them into course presentation, question, homework, and solution (I assume separate videos would be provided for homework solution), I think the tags should reflect the same.

Also a look into earlier threads before they were retagged shows there are threads that has something to do with the lecture, while others deals with the quiz. Having them seprate improves searchability.

But a lot of the videos dealing with the lectures also deal with the quiz. There isn't a fast line between them, or at least not one that I understand. I don't think it does improve searchability. I think it reduces it. If I want to ask what Prof Evans said on unit 2.5 do I put that as question or unit? Do I have to decide at exactly which point it goes from new information to question to determine which tag to use? If it's 2.5, that should be sufficient to find it, but we need unit on the front to distinguish it from homework.

unit2.5 or hw2.5. That's it. Nothing more.

I can't conform to a standard I don't understand.

"

alright, unit and hw it is. However, I think a separate tag for ""solution"" should be in order to differentiate questions to the lecture/quiz themselves and the solution video.

I can't conform to a standard that's overly simplified.

data-item.data-item-item:
In fact, this issue may not be called a bug.

In lecture 25's quiz, I wrote a while loop which is a infinite loop. So, I won't get a result in browser. I think my program may execute for a long time in server, then this causes a problem. I believe as so many people using the online Python interpreter, other people may also write a infinite loop sometimes somehow(or intentionally).

So, I just remind this, in case a infinite loop program will execute for a long time in server, and administrator doesn't think about it before.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I think there is a max execution time or something like that. If not, you will notice it... xD

Infinite loop can cause problem but the degree of problem purely dependent on system resources.If we have a larger main memory then on some extent we can run our infinite loop program but have to make sure that externally we have to perform a break else after a threshold time system will be out of memory and can crash. This type of problem is similar to STACK overflow problem.

"

In the videos, Prof Evans mentions that our code will not run forever in the browser which is why he uses the python shell to show us what happens when we don't put something to stop our code. See lecture 23, answer to quiz question.

If you put an infinite loop, the response from the code is ""Try again"", with no output, even from print statements within the loop so it can be difficult to work out what is going on. I accidentally tested this quite extensively last night, and without the output, it was hard to workout what was going on.

After I got the 'Try again' I had to reload the page as even the correct code wouldn't work after that.

Edit: Looks like I was wrong. It's going on and on and on today and just says ""Working"". Maybe the ""Try again"" was just coincidence.

"

what the python web-thingy does is it interprets the code, and when everything is done it'll output whatever should be outputed. There's a reason for that, which has to do with the way web-pages work, but I won't go into any details on that. Of course after a while it'll just time out to protect itself from using all the resources and crashing the server :)

Locally it'd be different because you don't have the restrictions of a web-page. That's why the instructor used a local interpreter instead of the web interpreter.

"

@fnenu It seems like it's been said in lecture 23 indeed. I think I missed that.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Can someone explain the difference between this program:

def factorial(n):
(1tab)x = 1
(1tab) while n >--= 1:
(2tabs) x = x * n
(2tabs) n = n - 1
(1tab) return x
print factorial(4)

And this one?

def factorial(n):
(1tab)x = 1
(1tab) while n >--= 1:
(2tabs) x = x * n
(2tabs) n = n - 1
(2tabs) return x
print factorial(4)

I'm having trouble figuring out why 1 spits out 24 and the other 4.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: In the first example you return the outcome AFTER the loop is finished. In the second one you return the outcome the first time you go through the while loop (so DURING the while loop). As return ends the procedure it'll also cancel the rest of the while loop, thus giving a different solution than the the first example.

"

the YouTube video completed fully (screen with ""replay,"" ""like,"" ""share"") and did not display the check boxes until I clicked on the ""?"" mark next to the unit lesson list. At that point, my answers were accepted and correctly scored. (Platform: Firefox (v10) + Windows 7).

"
You need to click the NEXT button to move onto the quiz.

Hello,

I use Firefox 10.0.2

I also haven't been able to pick the correct answer. Is it a combination of selections?

Thank you in advance :)

Let the video with the quiz finish and then click on the next link or click the small icon next to the quiz name in the video play list. Either of these methods will bring up a new screen with questions that can be selected. This works for me (Chrome + Windows 7).

"

I think the main problem is that the quiz expects more than 1 answer, but in asking the question in the video, it says, ""there is definitely more than one correct answer, but try to choose the best answer"". This had me thinking that the quiz only wanted me to put in one answer, so maybe that needs to be rephrased. Of course getting used to the quiz structure in later quizzes, it becomes apparent that one a quiz expects only one answer, the quiz uses radio buttons instead of check boxes, but early on, this was not obvious.

"

"

As Canuteson so appropriately noted: the video claims ""there is definitely more than one correct answer, but try to choose the best answer"" but the only answer that the quiz seems to accept is all of the answers selected.

It should also be noted that this quiz has overlapping answers and as such should be able to accept the more all-encompassing ones without the lesser ones being marked if this is the intended solution.

"

"

Ok! Finally got the answer correct! The main point to the quiz was I suppose ""the computer is a universal machine, it can do anything!"" :)

"

"

While the computer is a universal machine, I think it's key to remember that the language you are programming in (in this class, Python) is acting as an interpreter. The program is being ""described"" to the machine and then written/compiled by the computer into instructions it can understand.

But, yes, it was a very tricky question! :-D

"

"

I've seen the instructor's justification of his answers, but this quiz still feels like a game he is playing rather than an honest attempt at instruction. Saying that programming languages can be written by computers to be read by humans is similar to saying that walking is something one can do on the Moon. It's possible in theory and may be done in advanced practice (e.g., expert systems code), but it's not a level of understanding to be expected from beginning students on their first day. It nearly contradicts the explicit lesson that Python's purpose is to translate human-readable code into machine-executable code. Instead of reinforcing that lesson, the official ""right"" answer is one I would expect only from a student who wasn't paying attention.

"

"

Yea, the issue is that it states ""choose the best answer."" And in the answer it even directly states what the best answer was, when it was expecting all to be checked. Obviously the first four are true, but that was not the question or task. choose the best answer was the task, not ""choose every true statement.""

"

data-item.data-item-item: which IDE tool is better for practice python

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Default IDLE is quite acceptable.

linux

  • eclipse with python plugin
  • gedit (just a easy texteditor)
  • gvim (the way i do)
  • idle (builtin with python)

windows

  • eclipse with python plugin
  • notepadd++ (just a texteditor)
  • edit komodo (free) or komodo ide (27 days free)
  • gvim
  • idle(buildin with python)

vim/gvim is a awesome texteditor in my opinion.
The start isn't very easy.

"

I started using SPE (Stan's Pyhton Editor) today, not bad at all so far for simple programs.

"
On top of the ones mentioned here, there is Eric IDE if you are on Linux.
I prefer to emacs with python mode.
Every IDE is good to get practise with Python, it depends on you...the most important goal is to create efficient algorithms...
I use PyScripter, its very good!)

at first a text editor with highlighting is enough like gedit on linux or notepad++ on windows in order to get use to the code.

then u can use ude like pydev plugin over eclipse or aptana for linux and windows

Aptana Studio 3 (standalone) comes with the preinstalled PyDev plugin, and it will take just a few clicks to turn Aptana Studio 3 into fully ready Python IDE. In fact you'll just need to turn on the Python perspective. You'll also need to install Python itself previously. Aptana 3 is available for free, it's an open source project, and besides being the brilliant Python IDE, it's also the brilliant IDE for web development (both HTML/CSS/JS and server-side PHP). So if you have the plans of dealing with web development it will be your good friend there also. At least worth to take a look.

If you're beginner I definitely recommend you to get yourself Aptana Studio 3 standalone (not as an Eclipse plugin) as it's easy to install and setup after you've dealt with Python interpreter itself.

"

From a beginner perspective the best of the lot mentioned will be one that does not do a lot of ""magic"" for you. The simpler the better so that one can concentrate on actually learning the language and the science behind it. Then once you are pretty ok one can then explore the full blown environments since they have their merits too.

"

"

I use Geany. It's just a text editor but it's good enough and has some kindly features.

"

"

I already used most of the editors people mentioned in previous answers, but in the end I resort to SciTe, which is available for Windows and Linux alike.

In Windows, if you have python installed and the python directory is in the PATH, you can run easily the scripts inside the editor without further configuration. In Linux obviously you already have python in the PATH so SciTe use is immediate...

I think SciTe is such a good choice that I couldn't avoid posting this answer :-)

Emacs forever, SciTe for-now :-)

"
Textwrangler is a good option for anyone using a Mac.

Wing IDE is an option, works on all platforms and it's quite simple to use:
wingwareDOTcom
PyScripter is a good small footprint open source alternative to Eclipse on Windows.

Anyone that works for you.

I personally LOVE Geany, because it not only works with Python, but with many other languages.

You can also user NotePad++ (only Windows), which is basic, but is very good.

On Windows I generally use Python's IDLE, since it is easier to code &-- run.

Eclipse is good but is very slow and uses lots of memory in my [old] computer.

Netbeans it is a REALLY amazing tool. It is faster than Eclipse, but equally as powerful. If you have a fast computer, use it!

I don't recommend Aptana. Aptana is based on Eclipse, so I suggest you to use Eclipse instead. [Also full Apatana costs, while Eclipse is 100% free]

And, when everything else goes wrong, you can use VIM on a remote computer.
I use Eclipse

"

Some guys at work love Python Tools for Visual Studio (Windows only)

"

data-item.data-item-item:
As in last video i.e answer of the Print_all_links video, David have used a function get_page(),but he didn't talk anything about that.When i try to do the same on my python editor that gave a error get_page not defined.
So, i guess that is a custom procedure? I am wondering how to implement that so we can apply to initialize the page variable.
anyone please answer

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Yes, get_page() is custom. We probably write it later. If you want to test your code you can try to initialize page like this:

some_page = """""" <--html>-- <--head>--<--/head>-- <--body>-- <--a href=""/first"">--first link<--/a>-- <--a href=""/"">--main<--/a>-- <--a href=""/index.html"">--index<--/a>-- <--/body>-- <--/html>--""""""  print_all_links(some_page)

If you really want to load real web pages you can read about python module urllib2 for example. But I think we'll write this code later.

UPD. Get it! If you have your python interpreter and urllib2 module you can write get_page() like this:

import urllib2  def get_page(link):                f = urllib2.urlopen(link)        return f.read()
"
A urlopen and end function without a close? Is this valid?

I'm no expert on urrlib2, but yes, all the examples I have seen work that way, and my own code when I tried it seemed fine. The open() function just establishes the address etc I suppose, and the read() actually connects a socket/fetches data/closes the socket all in one go. Just my guess.

Yes, this is actually more precise than my answer.
I guess you should just recap what you learned in unit 1 and hope it'll spark up some idea.

It really is much simpler than you think it is. Just think of how you round in your head and try to put that into a mathematical equation that would give you the correct number every time. For example if you were trying to see if a number was even or odd you would divide by 2 and see if there is a remainder right? How would you find out if a decimal after an integer is higher than 0.5? What could you do to that integer when it is higher than 0.5 that would not affect it if it was lower than 0.5? It is entirely possible to solve this problem with the tools given, I have solved it and it took much fewer lines than the examples I have seen that use tools not give. Good luck!

Guys, I think many of you are missing the point of this exercise. It looks like we may have a lot people here who already have some background in coding. We looked at this exercise and knew right away how we wanted to solve it. Like a coder. I think this was the trap many of us fell into. And whether it was intentional or not, this was NOT a code problem. I beat my head against the wall trying to solve this problem within the bounds of Unit 1, and just when I was about ready to give up, the answer was staring me right in the face. I showed this problem to some of my coworkers and other coders I know, some very smart people. I gave them the limitations, and only one of them came up with the correct solution in less than 20 minutes. The others were incredibly frustrated until they saw the answer. Then they were floored with how simple it was. I predict that tomorrow, when they put the answer up, there is going to be a lot of head-slapping and a big, collective Doh! As I said earlier, the lesson I took away from this exercise was DON'T OVERTHINK A PROBLEM. Often, the simplest answer is the correct one.

"

I went overboard with this problem initially.

I basically divided the problem into two parts (NOTE This is a really bad way to solve the problem. the solution is much, much simpler, and beautiful) :

a) The number following the decimal is <--5

# .0  t0=s.find('.0') st0=str(t0) y0=-1*st0.find('-') z0=t0*y0 output=output+s[0:z0]

I made 4 more contiguous blocks like this for 1,2,3 and 4.

b) The number following the decimal is >--5

# .5 t5=s.find('.5') st5=str(t5) y5=-1*st5.find('-') z5=t5*y5 b5=str(x+1) output=output+b5[0:z5]

Of course, this left the case when the number didn't contain a decimal. In that case, I used a ""practical"" approach:

# no decimal point zn=z1+z2+z3+z4+z5+z6+z7+z8+z9 zn=zn*500 # if no decimal point was found, zn would be 0 output=output+s[zn:]

In any case, this was a lovely problem, and I've learnt my lesson: Simplicity is beautiful!

data-item.data-item-item:
It's about the 4th choice:
a,x=x,a
a,x=x,a
Do I understand it correctly because it doesn't make any sense.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Exactly no sense at all!

First it evaluates the values on the right side. So it determines the values of x and a. Once it has that, it assigns those values to whatever variables are on the left side which in this case is a and x.

Then, if you do this again, the values are switched once again putting the original value of x at the beginning of the script back in the variable x at the end of the script.

The key to understanding this concept is to remember that the interrupter evaluates the right side before ever paying attention to what's on the left side.

EDIT:
For clarification:

a = x x = a

is NOT the same as 

a,x = x,a
Check out the Unit 1 Python Reference (one of the 'Supplementary Material' items): on page 2 - Multiple Assignment
Thanks! :)
Or you could also look at Unit2 ->-- 27. Multiple Assignment.
Thank you for the explanation. Basically a,x = x,a swaps values and using a = x\n x = a will throw away the original value a. Does that sound about right?

It has some sence. It shows you that when you use x,a=a,x you don't loose the contents of x. The assignation is done at the same time. If you have x=1 and a=2 and you do x,a=a,x you'll have x=2 and a=1 (inverted values).

But if you do x=1 a=2 (assignment) and then you do x=a (x will be 2 now) a=x (a will remain as 2), you'll have lost the value of x.

It's about the 4th choice: a,x=x,a a,x=x,a Do I understand it correctly because it doesn't make any sense.

In Python, you can switch the contents of two variables with just one statement:

a,x = x,a

This can also be used as the following:

a,x = 1,7

That will make the variable 'a' to contain the number 1 and variable 'x' to contain the value 7

Now, Imagine the following:

a,x = 1,7 a,x= x,a

If you print the contents of 'a' or 'x', you'll see what I mean. 'a' will have the value 7 , and 'x' the value one

If you don't believe me, try running the following on Python:

a,x = 1,7 print a print x a,x= x,a print a print x

I have created this collection How to become a great programmer of useful info about programming. This collection contains books and info I consider to be very useful for all those who want to be programmers.
