data-item.data-item-item:
"

Coming from a C programming background, it appears that python variables are in fact pointers behind the curtain.

Question 1) are they implemented as pointers?
Question 2) if so when does the memory of what they are pointing to get released? In other words I have a variable a=['abc'] then I assign a = 15 the memory was allocated for ['abc'] must get released sometime, is this done by a periodic ""garbage collector"" or is it done immediately.

I know these questions are a little advanced but I was hoping a pthyonista could answer.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I can only answer question 1 with certainty from having looked at the analogous video on the MIT open courseware site.
1.Yes, the variables are pointers.
2.My understanding is that as the program obtains a new assignment for a variable, it changes in real time where it points to.

But I'm a nube

There's a good way to test whether it's stored as a pointer (like JAVA does) or not (like PHP, C, C++)

x = 2 y = x x = 3 print y

If y prints out as 3 it's a pointer to x, if it prints out as 2 it's not.

So let's see what it does:

>-->-->-- x = 2 >-->-->-- y = x >-->-->-- x = 3 >-->-->-- print y 2 >-->-->--

There's our answer: variables aren't stored as pointers.

EDIT:
The garbage collector question, I'm a Python newbie but I just searched and it seems that there is no simple way to put it. If you look at Google you see different answers. People who call the garbage collector themselves, and use different interpreters. I think that Python does have a garbage collector, so for basic programs you don't have to worry about much. As soon as you start on larger programs, it might be a good idea to read in to it. Please do correct me if I'm wrong btw.

Something else actually happens there:

px = new Number(2)-- py = px-- px = new Number(3)--

py still points to the object 2, while px points to the new object 3.

Note: Garbage collection or reference counting is not included in this example.

1 As i imagine that, variables are pointers (or references) to heap objects, in sense that every variable is allocated on the heap and is tracked till it references counter becomes zero and it is deleted in garbage collection round. But for the programmer they behave as types/objects. But one passes arguments in function by reference, but any operations in functions do not affect values of variables. But, of course, variable can chage their type | value many times in it lifecycle.
2 As i know (i can be strongly wrong) garbage collector delete objects and restructrize heap for avoid fragmentation in garbage collecting rounds, they occurs periodicaly (or in case when heap size is greater than some threshold), but between rounds it don't delete objects.

1) Python variables are references with no type associated to them.
The example that @Asperitas suggest only works because numbers are immutable. There are other types that are mutable and can behave in a different way. For instance:

>-->-->-- x = [1, 2] >-->-->-- y = x >-->-->-- x[0] = 2 >-->-->-- y [2, 2]

So you are changing y using the reference x that points to the same memory than y.

2) Yes, there is a kind of garbage collector that automagically manages the memory. It uses reference counting to know if a memory chunk is not needed any more. It depends on the implementation, so this is the way CPython uses.
This is incorrect. This only works for immutable items. You could have the same code in Java using integer primitives. See dreyescat comment.

Dear Dlask,

As far as I know pointer in C is that it points to a memory location. So in my example above if the variables were pointers, X would point to a memory location, and is directly filled with 2. then the variable Y would be initiated and pointed to the same memory location as X. Therefore when X changes, Y would change as well. Or am I not correct on this one?

Variables in python are pointers in the sense that they (point) store an address of an object in memory.The object contains a typed value like a string, number, list etc...

As opposed to c the variable has no type, it stores a memory address which points to an object. Initiation and memory allocation for the object is done by the interpreter.

When a variable (pointer) does not point any more to an object, then this object is redundant and is candidate for the garbage collection which is controlled by the interpreter.

Thank you for asking this question. The idea of passing the entirety of what could be a really enormous string ('page') as a parameter struck me as very odd, so I got that first quiz question wrong, because I just couldn't fathom passing ALL of 'page'.

In C programming you get pummeled with the idea of only passing by reference, because passing by value is an enormous waste of resources.

I guess he just assumes that you know you really aren't passing this whole huge object around, but only a pointer to it.

"

I think the better way to see what is happening here is to think about values and not about variables.

When you assign a variable (e.g x=2) it will store the memory position where the value '2' is stored (OK, it is a pointer to '2').

Assignment tracks the values and not the variable names. That is, if now I write y=x what I'm doing is ""attaching"" the variable y to the value to where x is pointing ('2' in this case): thus, y will contain the memory position where '2' is stored, which is what x holds when the assignment occurs.

So, if in the aftermath we write x=3 this doesn't affect y, because y is pointing to the value '2' and it is not a clone of the variable x which now has changed and points to the object '3'.

By the way, when using garbage collectors, such as python does, one of the key problems is dealing with circular pointers and releasing the pointed objects when the pointers are deleted... But I'm no specialist in garbage collection.

"

@Asperitas: Actually, as dlask's example shows, you don't change what's in the memory address that x points to. Instead, with x = 3, you point x to a new memory address containing the value 3. Since y still points to the previous memory address, you can still access the value 2 in the old memory location.
allright, that makes sense. I have much to learn :)
As do I :)

I think that everything in python is an object. Therefore, everything is is a reference.
There are some of these objects that can be copied by reference [like most objects][these are mutable], and some that can be copied by value [called inmutable]. Numbers , strings, tuples, bitearrays, frozensets are inmutable. And everything else is mutable.

data-item.data-item-item:
Given a string s, it seems very unusual to me that s.find('') will always give 0.

Eg if s = 'hello'

then s[0] is h
but now the empty string '' also has a position of 0. How can it be that they both occupy the same position? Do I just accept it as a Python quirk?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

It's not a quirk. Like it was explained in the unit 1 videos, an empty string is everywhere in a string. It is a little hard to grasp

If you did

s.find('',2)

It will return 2

If anything, I'll call it a computer science theory quirk. Or a set theory quirk.

EDIT

To make it more clearer, in set theory, the empty set {} is a subset of all sets.

Also, in The Theory of Languages, an empty string is a subset of all strings, except for an empty language.

"

"

Here is your answer mate Click Here

"

It is like asking python to look for empty space in your body. It will always return true.
Â¿Why? Because we are mostly made out of empty space.
The distance between electrons and atomic nuclei is made up of, you guessed it, empty space.

There is always empty space before and after characters. It is invisible.

The same way that for every number, there is a magical 1 multiplying it :P

5 = 5 * 1

data-item.data-item-item:
"

User kive said this, in response to my thread here about a way to interpret JavaScript pages before parsing them:

""I suppose you could also question whether you really want to interpret the Javascript or not. Links that don't appear until after the Javascript runs are sometimes things that the web designer is deliberately trying to hide from webcrawlers, like email addresses. And any decent web designer is going to know that, from an SEO perspective, if there's something you want visible to webcrawlers, you're going to make it as easily accessible as possible.""

This seems like a good question, and I suspect he is correct that it is usually not productive. So here is the real question: does Google render JavaScript before crawling a page?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I'm not sure but wouldn't that be dangerous? Running the javascript might cause all sorts of security issues, while just interpreting RAW HTML wouldn't be able to do much to Google's servers.

If Google does run Javascript I'm very curious on how!

"

The ""how"" would be pre-rendering the page to HTML via something like WebKit (I'm sure Google has their own version high-speed version, a C/C++ version of something akin to Google Web Toolkit for example). Doing this in a sandbox/virtual machine would be perfectly safe.

I demonstrate the ""how"" in the link I provided in the question.

"

"

Google does crawl JavaScript/AJAX, as well as PDF, Flash, Word files, and many others... Just search Googlebot.

Here's a self-made ""experiment"": link text

Googlebot does even load facebook comments and index them: link text

How it is crawled and how much it is weighted is just another topic and I'd guess a very complex and interesting one.

"
I think they just execute the ajax (http) request/response, but do not render the site at all. In my opinion it's way to expensive.

Way back in the day, Bots (including Googlebot) didn't crawl JavaScript. That is really no longer the case, as they have developed ways of crawling through and understanding pages that make heavy use of Javascript.

When someone searches, they want information, and they generally don't care about the technical details of how that was stored. So keeping that in mind, with the heavy use of JavaScript in applications like Facebook and Twitter, for Google to continue providing good search results (and stay in business) they would have to crawl the JavaScript as well.
Thanks! It is interesting to note that, according to that experiment, Google didn't use the JavaScript-generated text for search relevancy calculations. Maybe it crawls it for links though.
Thanks for the thoughts, it makes sense when you view it like that.

"

Well I think they do. The problem with the self-made experiment I see, is that he used words that are very infrequently and not part of any natural language. Since Google has to deliver very high-quality search results, they run a lot of natural language, classification, and bunch of other algorithms. That said, in my opinion it's really difficult to conclude from the ""experiment"" above that they do not use JavaScript for search relevancy.

"

"

Good point. maybe one hit on a JavaScript page for a word seen nowhere else on the web is just marked ""who cares"" and ignored, but a more popular term might be included for indexing.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I had the same issue and would have posted this correction had you not gotten to it first. After all, without the comma, technically, the answer is wrong, as it would not run correctly in the interpreter.

I got it wrong as well, but I am going to assume since they asked explicitly for the names of the expressions we were meant to return, that since the comma isn't part of the name that including it is wrong. There SHOULD have been a comma however drawn by the instructor between the answer boxes however. This would have eliminated any possible confusion.

data-item.data-item-item: How long will Udacity keep their content available? Is the plan to turn it into something like Khan Academy where the courses will be always available to anyone at anytime?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
UDACITY wrote this:

In the hectic days prior to launch we had some internal miscommunication about homework due dates for CS 101. This led to conflicting information presented in various course documents.

Weâ€™d like to apologize for any confusion that this has caused. We want to ensure that none of our students are unfairly penalized for this mistake so we are extending the due date for the first homework to Wednesday at 23:59 UTC. This extension applies to the first homework only!

Thanks Bulletproof, but I think I was unclear. I'm asking how long with the video and supplementary content remain available, irrelevant of when the Homework is due.

More broadly, I was wondering about Udacity's overall vision- is it for courses to remain available at all times to everyone (similar to the Khan Academy) or for only specific periods of time.

data-item.data-item-item:
Hi

I just saw the 21st video in the second unit talking about the Turing test and Alan Turing in person. Just thought it would be interesting for people who does not know how un-fair this important guy was treated back then.

The fact is that he was gay, and because of that he was arrested since homosexuality still was illegal in the UK. He then had to choose between chemical castration and prison, and he choose the first. Two weeks before his 42:nd birthday, he took a bite of a cyanide poisoned apple, and committed suicide.

Without Turings work on the Enigma and other works, UK most probably would have lost the battle against the nazis. How we live today might have been very different.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: All those facts, among others, are well explained in the notes for the second unit (pages 12-13).

Hola!

Just wanted to add that this is the origin of APPLE logo. (=
No it's not.
Just kiddin', m8 (=
I have never understood much of the Turing test and the turing machine in my automata classes.. Hope i would get myself clear from this tutorial :)

"

If anyone is interested, then TuringFilm is making a documentary on Turing. The teaser for the documentary is here, and the trailer is here.

And there is a full length movie on him on available on youtube called Breaking the Code.

More information on him and his work can be found on alanturing(dot)net and for more general information on the Bletchley Park code breaking efforts you can visit the Bletchley Park website.

"

@smartmuki A turing test is a test in which a computer program must make a person chatting with it believe that it a human &-- not a program.

A turing machine is a theoretical machine which is capable of performing any computation that a computer can perform.

You can google both the turing test &-- turing machine for more information

I'm 28 years old and just finishing my 2nd year teaching English in South Korea. I have a degree in Accounting and was a practicing accountant for 2 years before getting married and moving here. I'm leaving Korea in 2 days though and heading home to go back to school and begin work on a 2nd bachelor's degree, this time in Computer Science. I've been using many sources to teach myself skills in Python, HTML, CSS, Javascript and higher math. For those of you looking to expand further I suggest checking out some of these sites:
Khan Academy - Great videos on math, science and a series on computer science featuring Python!
30 Days to Learn HTML and CSS - The instructor goes pretty fast, so rewatch videos if you need to. W3 Schools - Well written tutorials for many languages used on the web. And lastly, Google Code University - Again, they have courses for many languages. Google's 2-day Python course was what got me started on this journey. I wish everyone the best of luck in this course and going forward in your computer careers.

Ian

data-item.data-item-item:
On Question 24 I wrote my program a little differently than in the answer key. It was marked as correct but I keep getting all of the values until the number (n) and then I get 'None'. Can someone tell me what is actually going on and where I'm wrong in my thinking?

def print_numbers(n):

i=0 while n>--i:     i=i+1     print i

print print_numbers(9)

returns
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
9
None

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Well the ""None"" you get is simply the result of your function...

You see the function ""print_numbers(n)"" does exactly what it is supposed and prints out the numbers 1...n
but it doesn't have any RETURN on it...
That means that when you asked to print the result of the function by calling:

print <--function>--

it printed exactly what it received: ""None"" (a way to say nothing, or that the function doesn't give an value back)

Basically since the printing of the numbers is already inside the function (and the function is correct, that why it was marked as such) you just need to call it and not print it.
The print will just show the value of the function that it gets back (in this case nothing = ""none"")

Hope I made clear... or else I can try again :)

"

print_numbers(9)

Yo have to put just print_numbers(9), without the print because once it finishes executing def print_numbers, then it tries the print and as print_numbers doesn't return anything it prints none.
Thank you both I can see my redundancy. This makes a lot of sense.
or you can return single quotes ---) , so it won't print anything

data-item.data-item-item: I am possibly handicapped by prior Fortran programming experience, but I find myself wondering if Python allows creation of common areas of storage for use by multiple functions. If large arrays are passed as function arguments and you cannot pass the address, only the values, seems a lot of inefficient copying is getting done as various functions or procedures are executed on the same array. Is there any way other than passing parameters by value that procedures can communicate with each other?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Large arrays (or perhaps large lists, or simply any lists) are not passed by value in Python. Look at this example:

def modify(x):     x[0] = 100  d = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] print d modify(d) print d

The output is:

[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6] [100, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

Actually in Python there is no such a real distinction between passing by value or by reference, or at least I never do such distinction. Everything is passed by value. Don't get scared yet --). What Python passes by value is the reference itself and not a copy of the object pointed by this reference.

What really matters when you are inside the function is whether the reference passed to the function points to a mutable or an immutable object. If it points to a mutable object (i.e. a list []) then you can modify the content of the object within the function. Otherwise, if it points to an immutable object (i.e. a number or a string), you can't.

"

Also keep in mind scoping rules. If you only want to read a global variable but don't want to modify it, you don't do anything special. However, if you DO want to modify it, you need to use the 'global' keyword, see this example.

"
Oh, and as a side note to PHP programmers, this is different from PHP, where you cannot even access the global variable for reading unless you use the 'global' keyword.

data-item.data-item-item:
Two of the answers contain the word 'outputs'. The last answer does not. Though it is not the right answer, the last answer does describe exactly what has happened within the Python interpreter. If you test this with code, I believe this answer is also right.

I'm a great stickler for the meaning of words, and to me this statement was not ambiguous at all. The fact that it doesn't contain the word 'outputs', for me, makes it a correct answer. Just because we can't see something, doesn't mean it hasn't happened!

Mind you, I am writing this without having looked at the explanation video yet!! (I may be back later to update this -- lol)

10 Minutes Later: I still agree with what I wrote above.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Well I guess if you think about two variables:

'number1' and 'number2'

and you pass them to your sum function you will receive at the function just a copy of the value. So a='number1' but 'a' is NOT the variable 'number1'.

Maybe if you think of the part it says ""first input"" as the variable 'number1' the last one is not correct since the variable didn't change and just its copy.

I think it makes sense or doesn't?

"

"

The key is that there is no return statement.

This explanation attempts to address your argument about semantics:

In unit 2 section 6, David explicitly defines the output. He states that outputs are different than side effects. Side effects are those things that are not ""returned"" (those things that we cannot see). According to this explanation, side effects are not outputs. And things that are not seen are not outputs.

Perhaps a better explanation is to introduce local and global variables.

Inside of a function (sum) a is not the same as the variable a outside of the function. It is a local variable and is only valid inside of the indented space that defines the function.

Outside of the function, only variables that are set as outputs (returned) are valid. These (and all variables set outside functions) are called global variables and are valid everywhere (except inside functions, unless they are inputs).

"
exactly! But the fourth option for an answer says nothing about outputs. It merely describes a process.

I felt the same way about the wording as being ambiguous, but as fdiez explains, the input is the variable you're passing into the function. That variable does not change after you run this function. You said that testing the code shows the last answer to be correct, but actually, not if you test building the function and not just testing that a = a + b.

In other words, if in the interpreter you define a and b as variables, say a = 1 and b = 10, then define the function with arguments a, b, then call the function with variables a and b, you'll find your variable a has not changed after running the function - this is because this variable a is the input, it isn't the placeholder for the first argument, a.

Within the function, yes, a is now 11, but that a doesn't actually exist outside the function. If you add a return statement 'return a' to the function, you're not changing the variable outside of the function, you're just returning some output .

Try this in a python editor to convince yourself:

a = 1 b = 10  def sum(a,b):     a = a + b     return a  print a        # this will be 1 aas defined above print sum(a,b) # 11, as the output of a function passing the variables a,b print a        # this is still 1!

"

@clair

Responding to your comment:

Yes, and you are correct in saying that this would not be an output. however have you tried writing this code and testing your hypothesis?

I think that you would be surprised to find that a = nothing. A more illuminating example may be to type this:

a = 0     b = 10     def sum(a,b):     a = a+b print a

a will equal 0, not 10. Why? because you set a = 0 OUTSIDE the function and never returned any values. The important take away is that the a inside the function could be named anything and is not related to the a outside the function.

try this in python

"

"

Yes -- I did fiddle with this in Python -- and still, I feel I cannot base my answer on 'output' that is not ""put out"" when output was not part the possible answer. And, in my original question, I was directing my question of ambiguity to the wording of that fourth answer, not to the code. It's an English language thing here, not a Python code thing! lol

"

I did monkey with this, as you can see I came back an amended my original post. And now, I think we should all have a beer with this one! At least the beer will likely be unambiguous (unless it is either Coors or Bud).

"

Agreed. The interpreter definitely doesn't do ""nothing"".

Within the procedure, it assigns a+b to the input variable/ parameter 'a'. The input variable/ parameter variable a is local to the procedure. Changing the value of the first input variable/ parameter doesn't affect anything outside of the procedure, but that is not the same as ""does nothing"". So I think that the 4th option is the most accurate answer.

Now... if optimization is later explained, ""does nothing"" could be re-stated as ""no effect - optimized away"", then maybe it would be a different matter :)

"

"

i agree with clair-- of the four answers available, the fourth answer is the best.

â€œwhat does the sum procedure do?â€
it â€œtakes two numbers as its inputs, and changes the value of the first input to be the sum of the two number.â€

that answer says nothing about an output, and as claire points out, the function does do something, so â€œnothingâ€ really is not, imho, the right answer given those four choices available.

more importantly though, and what i believe others are trying to point out, the explanation david gives in the answer is actually more important than the question itself, as it touches on something called scope, which he explains in concept and in practice with this question.

"

data-item.data-item-item: Let's say <--T>-- is    i != 1 and <--S>-- is    if i == None: i = 0   print i   i = i + 1  if you do  while i != 1:   if False:     break   if i == None: i = 0   print i   i = i + 1  you get printed '0', but with  while i!=1:   if i == None: i = 0   print i   i = i + 1   if False:     break   if i == None: i = 0   print i   i = i + 1  you get printed '0' '1' '2' ... forever  And so is proves the last answer is not right

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I think you haven't implemented the last answer correctly. The 'if False: break' should not occur in the last answer. The part 'if T: S else: break' of the last answer seems not to be implemented correctly in your code, I think.

It may be better just to think about it abstractly. I pasted your example in paste bin with this tag and it seems to work out o.k. - 9dTq6UiW

I think that links get deleted from comments but here's the whole link - pastebin(dot)com / 9dTq6UiW

Posting what I put in paste bin to learn about forum formatting...

I think that you're asking about the last case:

while <--T>--:     <--S>--     if <--T>--:         <--S>--     else:         break  with <--T>--     i != 1  and <--S>--     if i == None: i = 0     print i     i = i + 1

So in the basic form:

while <--T>--     <--S>--

is:

while i != 1:   if i == None: i = 0   print i   i = i + 1

Then in the last form:

while i != 1:     if i == None: i = 0     print i     i = i + 1      if i != 1:           if i == None: i = 0         print i         i = i + 1     else:         break

If you initialize i, the two should be equivalent.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

On a daily basis, I use a lot of Excel for my work and I was wondering whether there are any ways to make use of this great new skill that we are learning (programming in Python) to improve efficiency of excel (for example, miming VBA's functionality, speeding up calculations, etc.) ?

I'm eager to start using Python for my ""real life's problems"" as this will make it easier for me to learn it.

Thanks a lot for your help.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Yes, Certainly speed improvements

But really you can do anything you can think of

It is possible to import different types of files into Python. The excel type is essentially a comma separated value (CSV). This means that it can be treated as an array and all kinds of operation can be sped up on it.

This website has some useful packages:

"

"

Well, even if there is no direct possibility to integrate Python into excel, there are different possibilities to use your new skills:

  • The concepts of a programming language are mostly similar (at least in case of VBA and python) - so you just need to learn the VBA syntax (which isnt very complicated) and should easily be able to use VBA as a powerful tool!
  • You can even use Python for
    calculations, data analysis and so
    on, for example by processing csv
    files. There are already many
    statistical Python libraries out
    there, which will add some ""excel""
    features.. Expect Python to be much
    faster when working with big
    databases than Excel!
"

VBA is built into Excel, and has direct access to the Excel spreadsheet object model as it runs in the same process space. This makes is reasonably fast

If you use ANY other language to access the Excel spreadsheet, it requires the other language's compiled code calling into another process (Excel) to transfer commands and data. This is significantly slower

The fastest way is to export the Excel data into a simple format (CSV etc) and process that directly, or to use the .xlsx format directly in your other language. Microsoft provide the System.IO.Packaging libraries for .net languages like c# and IronPython etc

from http.client import HTTPConnection  def get_page(link):    start_url=link.find(""//"")+2    s1=link[start_url:link.find(""/"",start_url)]    s2=link[link.find(""/"",start_url):]    con=HTTPConnection(s1)    con.request(""GET"",s2)    data=con.getresponse()    text=data.read()    con.close()    return text

data-item.data-item-item: I know that functions are typically associated with C, JavaScript &-- PHP, and methods are associate with C++, Java and Objective-C, with the difference between the two being that methods operate on objects. Basically though, aren't they all the same thing? Wouldn't it be good if we called the the same thing across all languages to help avoid confusion? I'm interested in your feedback.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

No because, basically equals, there is differences between functions and methods: how to use then, access to the ""actual"" object inside of a method (whit this, self,...), where you can defined them,...

An languages like PHP, C++, Objective-c have the two types: functions and methods. VB6 had procedures (without return value), functions and methods

"

"

Lua unifies functions and methods in a nice way.

The method call

o:method(x)

is only a syntactic sugar for

o.method(o, x)
"

Function and procedure in this day and age are quite comparable. Typically you will encounter programmers that will use the terms interchangeably. However, there are a few programming languages still used today that use the two terms for specific meanings. Those meanings being a function returns a value, a procedure does not.

However, you won't often encounter programmers that will use the term method for a non-member function.

Both of the programing language groups that you mentioned have both functions and methods. Their functionality is different, but that doesn't make any confusion if you are not already confused by object oriented programing or OOP !!! :D

In every documentation for Python that I have read it always describes, what is described in the video as a procedure, as a function.

Why is it being called a procedure instead of a a function I think is the real root of the question.

From wikipedia:

In computer science, a subroutine (also known as a procedure, function, routine, method, or subprogram) is a portion of code within a larger program that performs a specific task and is relatively independent of the remaining code.

Unless the language specifies a differentiation in terminology between function and procedure, the two are considered interchangeable terms.

Wikipedia again:

In object-oriented programming, a method is a subroutine (or procedure or function) associated with a class.

While Wikipedia may not be the best reference, it often is the best place to start looking for simple answers.
It seems to me that the professor is calling it a procedure due to personal preference. Thanks Gibgezr

Yes. I tend to call them functions, probably because when I first started using them it was in C and that's what the books called them. Also, 30+ years ago the term function was a lot more prevalent than the term procedure, or at least it seemed that way amongst the people I hung out with.

If I had been a better Basic programmer, I might have called them subroutines...but when I learned Basic, I used gotos instead of gosubs , so if anything I should have called them 'spaghetti-os' hehe.

Dave doesn't like using the term function because he doesn't see them equivalent to mathematical functions (which is true since many of the functions you write in this class have side effects and associated costs). He talks more about it in the unit 2 notes. I use function and method interchangeably because I grew up learning C and Java. We are aware that certain languages have certain terms, but don't be surprised if we overlook them.

"

It would be helpful if a whole lot of things were standardised across the ""languages"".
There is a large core of each language (really more like dialects) which is common to all.
Python seems to get rid of the unnecessry and inelegant far more than most.
Computer scientists seem to use / misuse English in a very weird way even to English speakers that makes things far more difficult than they need be - a huge waste of the World's time and energy. Microsoft using the ""Start"" button to close down the computer is one of the more famous ""annoyances"".

"

"

hum.. I can interpret your question in different ways. You say that you are an autodidact.


->-- If you are asking what course to take after cs-101 in an autodidact way, absolutely take 'algorithms and data structures'. Udacity is announcing that will have such a course soon. This course will take you to the next level.. use of stacks, queues, heaps, trees, complexity analysis, introduction to P vs. NP programs, sorts, graphs.. the bread and butter of CS.. an absolute must. If by some chance you cannot take the class, pick up the ""introcduction to Algorithms"" by Cormen et. al.


->-- if you are asking what languages to take, then that depends on what to you want to do. Java is the battle horse for everything internet and mobile. C/C++ is for everything that have to do with big projects, e.g., military, government. Matlab or Mathematica are great for prototyping. XHTML, CSS, Javascript, php, and sql in if you want to go the way of internet site design.



->-- if you are asking for classes to take you to the 'next' level in the long run.. then your physics background gives you a great start. Take algorithms and data structures in CS. If time permits, you will find numerical analysis and computational geometry fairly versatile.. they help with a lot of things. Then take your pick on the specialized ones: computer graphics? AI? machine learning? natural language processing? multibody systems? it all depends on what you want. In Math, your physics major should cover all the calculus, diff. equations and linear algebra courses. In addition, if not required, take probability and if possible statistics. In EE, if you want to go the path of Sebastian and build autonomous systems, take computer vision and courses in robotics, both those that deal with mechanisms and the ones that deal with planning and control.



All this said, achieving your goal of writting useful programs is a matter of trusting in yourself and devoting time to your passion. I am certain that you could already contribute (or soon will be able to) to many open source projects. Consider contributing to a project at sourceforge, or something like mozilla or libreoffice. Your efforts will have an immediate effect on hundreds of people.


Good luck

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Hey classmates. I thought some code would solve the question assignment for rounding.
EDITED
However I am getting an error:

decimal=x.find('.')
AttributeError: 'float' object has no attribute 'find'

After searching a bit I saw that some commentators related this error to having an older python edition - however, I ran the code within the compiler provided within the web browser and within 'Reinteract' on my Ubuntu machine and both gave the error anyhow.

I am not totally sure this is the correct answer, but I would like to check it out and I cant seem to get past this first problem.
I am convinced it has something to do with the str(x) command.
Any assistance would be appreciated.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
Your are right, it has something to do with str(x). And no, there isn't a python edition error. You are over analyzing.

My suggestion is to read the error message again, think about what you are doing and what the compiler is trying to say to you with this error message.

Small tip: look at video 16 once more.
Just a note: You should not share source code for homework assignments before the deadline.

Homework questions should not be discussed like this.

Though the answer to your problem is that str(x) does nothing to x, it returns a value of x as a string.

here's an example why: 


     >-->-->-- x = 20
     >-->-->-- str(x)
     '20'
     >-->-->-- print x * 5
     100

as you see if I do print x * 5, it'll print the outcome of the calculation
if you make a new variable called x_str for example and assign it str(x) you can use that for further reference as string.
Like this:

     >-->-->-- x = 20
     >-->-->-- x_str = str(x)
     >-->-->-- print x_str * 5
     2020202020

I hope this helps
Thanks I watched the video a few times but I didnt realize that str(x) wasnt actually acting upon x to change it as a variable. thnx

I would say to ignore the compiler error completely because you're trying to solve the question the wrong way. You don't need to use any python functions that weren't already introduced during the lectures.

You cant divide an integer thats part of a string apparently which makes sense.

I copy
def sum3 (a,b,c):

return a + b + c

print sum3

and it says it is incorrect. Why? I copied it exactly as you had it.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
The function needs 3 parameters: a, b and c. Because this you need put three numbers (or numerical expressions) when you call the function.

e.g.:
print sum3(3,4,4)

Do you use Python IDLE and copy the code to the Python Shell window?

  • Go to options ->-- Configure IDLE,
  • On the General tab select Open Edit
    Window in the Startup Preferences,
  • Now go to File ->-- New Window, type
    your code there and hit F5. You'll be
    asked to save your code and then
    it'll execute.

No, I don't think I need to download IDLE, I just use the interpreter on the screen. I do other stuff in that and it works, so why not this?
I copy exactly as the instructor showed.

Can someone explain why, when I do Unit 2, question 13, it is called 'wrong'?

I write:
def sum3 (a, b, c):
return a + b + c <----4 spaces at beginning
print sum3

It says the line def sum3 (a + b + c) : has invalid syntax

you have to both define and call the procedure with commas between the arguments (the a, b, and c)

so
def sum3(a + b + c):

will give an error.

you want the first define line to be:
def sum3(a, b, c)

then after the definition, say you want to add 2, 3, and 4 and print -
print sum3(2, 3, 4)

Can you please explain why the instructor in this video shows to put '+' signs between the letters a b and c after the word 'return' and yet you are saying this is incorrect? I am not saying you are wrong, but can you please tell me why the instructor says to do this, and you say not to do it?

No doubt someone here (me...him, whatever) is making an assumption, and the other person is missing that assumption.

I would appreciate it if you could explain this to me.

Thank you

Your code should look like this:

def sum3(a, b, c):    return a + b + c  print sum3(2, 3, 4)

With this stuff, usually what trips me up is that I mistyped something (most of the time, I mix i and 1 for some reason). From what you're saying, it sounds like you're mixing up all three of the lines. The only one with + between letters is the return statement. Both of your other statements need to have commas between your letters/numbers.

Also, make sure that when you call sum3, you send 3 arguments (the things in parenthesis).

Ah, finally! You told me what I was doing wrong. Thank you! I need to put something after the 'sum3' after 'print'. Thank you so much. I will make a note that I did not pick this up from the video, and do some more practice exercises on this.

data-item.data-item-item:
I think the forum needs some categories for the questions and community wikis, in order to be more accessible and easier to find.

Right now there are a thousand questions on the forum and it keeps on counting...

You can suggest the category names here:

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

For starters, I will state the obvious:

  • Unit1
  • Unit2
  • ...
  • Homework1 (with big transparent about ethics and code at the very top)
  • Homework2
  • ...
  • Python (general questions on python)
  • ""Administrivia"" (deadlines, technical issues, bugs, ...)
  • ""Cafe lounge"" (little off topic threads like thanks, T-shirts, brown-haired groups, ...)
"

• New Comers
  • BUGs
  • Suggestions
  • Homeworks
  • Office Hours
  • Python
  • Programing
  • wikis
  • Quizzes
  • More Resources
  • Hangouts

"

There was also suggestion for ""canonizing"" tags, which would help as well - regardless of existence of categories.

"

Either that, or we need to have specific tags for each of those things, and make sure people use them/retag posts more actively. I thought it was good in AI that the tags to use were specified under each video/homework.
Also the forum needs more administration. The repeated and not-related questions should be deleted.

Mareq has some very good categories. I'd also suggest something along the lines of:

Groups - (for the users who have come together under some sort of umbrella such as location, language, etc.)

Surveys/Polls (for those users who enjoy asking demographic-type questions)

You need big crowd of forum moderators or very disciplined users in both cases: misplaced threads need to be either moved to correct category, or wrongly tagged threads need to be retagged (or both, but it is not twice as much work as any of the single tasks, since you can do it at the same time).

Have there been many non-related questions? I think I've only seen a couple and they soon got downvoted.

We could do with being able to close repeated questions though. I don't know if that is possible for anyone at all, or if it's possible for those have high karma.

"

@Mortazavi: Yepp, can't agree more, but don't forget: this is beta, it is free and whatever the revenue model of Udacity is, I doubt they started to earn money, yet. And more moderators means higher expenses (you can also make community to manage itself, but results would be discutable). Thus, I think it will take some time to add more moderators.

@fnenu: You are right, non-related questions were downvoted very fast, but there are lots and lots of duplicities as well (this very thread can serve as an example, since there is exactly this suggestion in general suggestions thread and I think I already saw few separate threads like this one, too)

"
If we had standard tags, it would be easier to know how to retag consistently.

Given it's only a 7 week course, it's going to be hard to get the community to manage itself when some tasks can't be done without such high karma. At the moment, only 4 people have sufficient karma to edit posts, and I'm guessed that is needed to close posts too, although I don't know.
Students wanna help, they should be allowed to do so...

"

@fnenu: Then, maybe karma levels need to be adjusted. Are there those limits published somewhere, anyway? (I saw few threads mentioning it, but it was nothing official.)

"

"

My two cents Tagging for lectures and homework.

I opened this thread to discuss a basic tagging convention for the Homework, Lectures and Quizzes related questions. I think this could help reduce the repetition noise a little --).

"

The table below explains karma requirements for each type of moderation task.

â€¢ close own questions ->-- 0
â€¢ reopen own questions ->-- 0
â€¢ add comments ->-- 50
â€¢ retag questions ->-- 500
â€¢ edit any answer ->-- 2000
â€¢ delete any comment ->-- 10000

Take a look at FAQ

data-item.data-item-item: How can you round any number with python code? For example the pi number (like de nineth exercice in Unit1).

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I'll post a brief discussion of the same once the homework submission is done.

How you must do it for the homework, and how you would really do it, are very different. Prof. Evans asked you to do it using the str() function and nothing else but what he explained in unit 1.

When you really want to round numbers in the future, Python has functions for doing that without converting anything to a string, which is inefficient. You'll learn them soon, but forget about them now. This is a different exercise. So if you googled for the solution you'd find how to round a number with functions that David hasn't explained yet, but not how to do this homework.

You can round with a very basic arithmetic trick and str().

The solution can be under 30 characters.

So you don't really round numbers, you change a number to a string and then you print the integer (or decimal if you want) part of the number you want to round? Because if you want to round 15.7, how do you do that?

So I put in the homework:
number = str(x)
print number[0:1]

isn't it cheating if you ask for help with a homework question? It's alright if you can't figure it out, you're not gonna fail because of it. Asking for help on it isn't fair to the other students who try to solve it on their own. There is a trick to it, but it can definitely be done.

That won't work because your code assumes the decimal is in the 2nd position. If your str(x) has a decimal in the 3rd position or later, then your code will only print the first digit of the whole number. You will need to use find().
I did`t asked for the exact solution, I only asked for help and about a little orientation of it, not to show me everything I need.
There is no fun if you don't try it by yourself, try try try!

Finally, after be trying different solutions, I have put a final answer with find().

Thank you for your help!

I try it but no resultat
x =3.14159
N = str(x)
print N
resultat 3.14159

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I use ""Ideone.com"" python as recommended by one of the registrants here.

I input as follows:

def sum (a,b): return a=b+1

The response returned was an error.

Will you please show me what's a proper way of inputting def as recommended by David?

Thank you,
from a Computer Illiterate

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
There are two possible errors in your code:

  1. You define a procedure with this syntax, where the Indention (usually 4 spaces) is very important

  2. If you return a value, you must use an expression. In your last line you have an assignment statement instead of an expression:

    def <--name>--([<--parameters>--])     <--block>--     return <--expression>--

Btw: You don't need a as an parameter if you don't read the value from it.
def sum(a,b):     return b+1 # not a=b+1

data-item.data-item-item:
"

` Hi

I use ""Ideone"" for Python as recommended by one of the classmates here.

I input as follows:

def sum (a,b):
return a=a+b

I got a response stating as invalid syntax.

Will you please show me how to put a proper def with Python to get a meaningful response?

Thank you,
from Computer Illiterate

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Why are you assigning to a in return statement? It is going out of scope anyway and thus it is not needed.
`OK, I'll retry.
What does scope mean?

"

What you are trying to do is add two numbers, a and b. You don't want to make a equal to one more than b. What you want after the return is just the answer when you add a and b. In other words, you want a + b.

What comes after the return gives the answer to the question, ""What is the answer when I add a and b?"" a + b

What you have: ""What is the answer when I add a and b?"" ""Make a equal to the sum of a and b""

I don't know whether it's just the way the forum displays the text, but you also need some spaces before the return so that it's indented.

"

`Thanks fnenu,
Yes I think I put 4 spaces but it came out as you saw it as some person mentioned it to me just before your answer.
Next time, I will make sure that there'll be 4 spaces.

Thanks again,
Computer Illiterate

"

Variables a and b are defined inside the function sum. By saying ""goes out of scope"", I am referring to their lifetime being ended by the return statement.

"
@Mareq thanks. I was trying to think of what the scope of the return statement would be.

"

Take note that no assignment, i.e. and equal sign, can be in the return statement. ""Return a+b"" returns the sum of a+b. ""Return a=a+b"" is a syntax error.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

I really like the idea of introducing some of the people in the history of the field of computer science, as well those used to make the quizzes more interesting. Below is a summary of the historic figures mentioned so far (mostly taken from Wikipedia and the History of Computing Project)

John Backus (1924-2007)

Lead designer of the programming language Fortran (Formula Translator) and developed the Backus-Naur Form notation. Awarded the Turing Award in 1977. His award lecture 'Can Programming Be Liberated from the von Neumann Style? A Functional Style and Its Algebra of Programs' can be found here. Referenced in Unit 1 - Grammer.

Lothar Collatz (1910-1990)

A German mathematician who proposed the Collatz conjecture (or 3x+1 problem) in 1937. At present the conjecture remains unsolved. One part of HomeWork 2.5 used this conjecture as the basis of a program for which it is not currently known if it will always halt for any given positive integer. The sequence of numbers generated by this formula is know as a hailstone sequence.

Georges Danton (1759-1794)

A prominent figure in the French Revolution. Gave us a great quote to work with in the example Unit 1 - Finding with Numbers ""il nous faut de l'audace, et encore de l'audace, et toujours de l'audace"" - ""We need audacity, and yet more audacity, and always audacity!""

Grace Hopper (1906-1992)

Developed the first compiler for a programming language and influenced the design of COBOL (COmmon Business-Oriented Language). Referenced in Unit 1 - Grace Hopper and more details supplied in the CS101 Unit 1 Notes.

Augusta Ada King (1815-1852)

Wrote what is considered to be the first algorithm designed for execution on a computing machine (Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine) for calculating Bernoulli numbers, hence she is credited as the first programmer. The computer language Ada is named in her honor. Referenced in Unit 1 - Ada and more details supplied in CS101 Unit 1 Notes.

Richard Feynman (1918-1988)

Considered both a great physicist and teacher. Made fundamental contributions to quantum electrodynamics and theoretical physics. Well know for his pictorial representation of particle interactions known as Feynman diagrams. Won the Nobel prize in physics in 1965. Feynman gave, a now classic, talk on the prospects of what has grown into the field of nanotechnology. You can read his Nobel lecture here, and a transcript of his talk 'There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom' here. Referenced in Unit 3.20, his picture appears on the hypothetical nanodollar.

Alan Turing (1912-1954)

Established several important concepts in computer science and mathematical logic. His 1936 paper 'On Computable Numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem' introduced the concept of an abstract computing model which is now known as the Turing Machine. He also had important an influence on the fields of artificial intelligence ('Computing machinery and intelligence in Mind'), mathematical biology, and cryptanalysis. Mentioned at the end of Unit 2. There is also great summary in the Unit 2 Notes on page 12.

"

She's both funny and prophetic, but it's also a great snapshot of media perception of computers and technology in general from 30 years ago.

""We've got the Model T. That's where we are now.""

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

There are two identical threads already. You have received at least one good response on this one

"

The definition should be

  • def sum(a,b):
  • return a+b

Take note that the return statement must be indented and four spaces are standard

Also, no assignment (i.e. an equal sign) can be in the return statement

Udacity's pen and whiteboard is absolutely fantastic for every other use in the lectures. But I think it would have been better and more instructive if Prof. Evans had recorded the lectures with code being typed, and then we could see the output from a read Python interpreter, instead of he saying, ""This will produce this output."" He does it in a couple of occasions, but he mostly uses the pen. Of course we can try the code ourselves and we should, but still.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It is sometimes better, when you do not get everything on golden tray and you are forced to try to think about it and do it yourself - you learn more that way. Just my two cents...

I don't think it's easier in any way if he's typing, it's not like we can copy text from the video. I only think it's more real and more instructive if he's typing, and it can even encourage people to try running the code themselves.

It's like if he's teaching us to play soccer, and instead of playing it while explaining, he just explains in words how it's played. OK this is an extreme analogy, the difference between typing code and writing it by hand isn't that big, but that's the idea I get.
I personally think it is so cool. I like it that way. Yeah, it is all about bring the developer in you out of the closet. Do it and you will know it.

Some of the students might not follow the conventions used for hand writing code.
When it is typed into the interpreter, it is clearer what the syntax should be.
I think the handwriting thing is actually great! It reminds us to think beyond the code and out of the box.

"

Of course I won't mind it if most people like it :-)

It's not because I've just started programming and it's hard for me, that's not the case at all. I have previous programming experience and I'm taking CS373 too.

My opinion is that it's of course good to think in abstract to learn to program--AS LONG as you're doing it with your hands on the keyboard! Everyone should be encouraged to install the compiler/interpreter on his machine, and start playing with it, right from ""print 'Hello world!'"" and ""print 2+2"", even before he's explained anything else about programming. No lecture is a substitute for that. This course is great because it's online and yet it has real online programming quizzes and homework. But I'd have extended all this to the lectures. Just my opinion. :-)

"

data-item.data-item-item:
"

Just got through Unit 2 and enjoyed it (especially the smiley-face-accompanied assurance that after 2.21, you could theoretically write any program -- albeit inefficiently!). One question that came up for me was really one of readability and style.

In Unit2.30 (""Print All Links""), Prof. Evans used while True as the test condition of the conditional. Is there an advantage to that approach, rather than, say, while page != """"?

The latter came more readily to my mind, as I would want the code to execute until page is empty, or until the break condition occurs (namely, that there are no more URLs to be found). Does this mirror the way others addressed the problem, or did most people adopt the method used by Professor Evans?

EDIT: I did in fact use the second approach, and did get credit for it (as it also works). This was more a question of what other people thought of first, and whether the first is more stylistically accepted, and so on.

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
I also used a similar approach to yours namely:

while page:

And I got it right so it seems to be valid
Oh, right, I should mention that this is not a bug/error -- I got credit for it, too. Just wondering...

That is the beauty of programming, you can achieve what you want through different ways. At some point however, you might be asked to stick to the most efficient ways of doing things. I preferred while True, just because it worked for me &-- of course the professor!

I actually did use

while page != '':

However, if you think of the problem in CPU time wise the while true is better since it only evaluate one condition (the while condition) which is in this problem always true.

On the other hand, in the statement while page != '': it should evaluate the page != '' before it can evaluate the while condition. Meaning that more work for the CPU to do-- thus, more processing time.
Exactly what I think

"

In this case it doesn't matter, but there are some subtle differences between your method and Evans.
Evan's checks for the break condition in the if statement and executes the break in the else statement.

Your method does the equivalent of both checking for the break condition and executing the break in the while statement.

If you needed to do extra things between deciding it's time to break and actually breaking, you would want to use Evan's method, otherwise yours is good.

Any of these would work:

while page != """":   page = something  while page:   page = something  while True:   #do something   break  while 1:   #do something   break
"

"

I've been testing different versions of the script, including my first idea

 def print_all_links(page):      url = True      while page:          url, endpos = get_next_target(page)          if url:              print url              page = page[endpos:]

which I, because of the need to set url to something before the 'while' loop, couldn't use on the quiz - and, well, these are the conclusions I came to.

If you use a variable that doesn't turn to None, False, '', 0 (or one of the other expressions that are interpreted as a Boolean 0), you need the 'else: break' block-- you're never going to get the 'while' condition to terminate the loop, and might as well use True. And the only two variables that actually turn into a Boolean 0 are url and endpos, which are set to None and 0, respectively. page gets set to what's left of the string after the last link, which in the test string that was used in the answer,

'this <--a href=""test1"">--link 1<--/a>-- is <--a href=""test2"">--link 2<--/a>-- a <--a href=""test3"">--link 3<--/a>--'

will be the string '"">--link 3'.

So, the only reason I can think of to use page as the while test would be to not run the while loop in the case where the page string is empty from the start, but in that case there's no need to call the procedure at all.

"

My original thought was to use

while url:

But I didn't know if it would evaluate the url as soon as it was set to None, rather than waiting for the loop to complete to re-evaluate it. In the second case, there would be a jibberish print statement included.

def find_second(string, targetString):

firstOccurence = string.find(targetString) + 1

string = string[firstOccurence:]

secondOccurence = string.find(targetString)

return secondOccurence

So yeah thats my code, Ive gone through it all on paper step by step but I keep getting 19 instead of 25, Its really bugging me, can anyone point me towards the problem?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

Don't forget to enclose your code in the code tags. Since indenting is important in python it's hard for us to tell if you have it correct or not. I'll glance at the rest of it here.

For one thing, you're adding 1 to your firstOccurrance. It should be 5, you're coming up with 6.
Secondly, your ""secondOccurance"", you are starting the search index from targetString, rather than from past the end of the firstOccurance.

"
When you assigns a new value to string (string = string[firstOccurence:]) the new string has fewer characters. One solution is use another variable.

"

Your ""secondOccurence"" statement is not indexed by the value of the first occurance.

"

Update to my last comment:

In your code, you delete 6 characters from the original string, thus making your count 19.

But your code needs to compensate for reducing the string length.

I believe the instructor wanted us to do this using indexing without changing the scanned string.

data-item.data-item-item:
"

This might be little off-topic, but anyway: There are at least three threads (here, here and here), which define user function sum. However, function with this name already exists (standard one, producing sum of elements of a list). These two obviously do not clash (I tried it and it works), so the question is, how doess such overriding/overloading/shadowing/hiding/whatever of functions work in Python?

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: If you come from other languages like Java, you will probably notice that if it worked well with your problem, then it means python allows Overloading. Read the python documentations and you should be able to find the solution to this question.

Python has dynamic typing so it works out from their context at run time what type objects actually are.
Sum for a list type is one thing - sum for two variable inputs in a def object are another.
This makes Python far faster to code than static type languages such as C#.

data-item.data-item-item: A little embarrassed to say this but during unit 1 with the simple conversions of converting the speed of light into nanosticks or whatever I was a bit confused by the simple algebra..Does anyone know any excellent preferably free math resources concerning math you'd find in computer science such as algebra,calculus,trig etc?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

The Khan Academy - awesome resource for free videos and brushing up on math, all the way from 1+1 up to Calculus, Linear Algrebra, etc

However, everything that's been needed in this course so far, they didn't expect us to have any math skills. They've given numbers and said ""just multiply these"" or whatever, but there hasn't been any complicated math anywhere along the way.

"

For conversion problems I always put the units in square brackets, and make sure that I end up with the right units in the end. I think that it's known as dimensional analysis?

For example lets say that I'm trying to find how far light travels in a picosecond in terms of millimeters:

x [mm/ps] = 299,792,458 [m/s] * 1000 [mm/m] * 1 [s] / 1,000,000,000,000 [ps]

x [mm/ps] = 0.299 [mm/ps] (helps to explain the packet of pepper in the Grace Hopper video)

If you're doing it on paper then you can cross out any units that appear in both a numerator and demoninator, and check that you wound up with the right units. If not then play around until you do.

Does this help?
Great, that did help KeithE, and thanks for the Khan Academy resource Velak.

"

Khan Academy also has some great vids on Python. EX: Introduction to Programs Data Types and Variables

"

"

As I was driving home I thought of something that might be confusing to you, and it's related to the Grace Hopper material too. When people quote CPU speeds they typically say something like my Intel Core i5 core runs at 2.7 [GHz]. If you wanted to compute how far light travels in one clock cycle of this CPU, then it might be helpful to restate the [GHz] units as 2,700,000,000 [clocks/s] or [cycles/s]. Then you might want to solve:

x [inches/clock cycle] = (1 [s] / 2,700,000,000 [clock cycles]) *( 299,792,458 [m] / 1 [s]) * (100 [cm] / 1 [m]) * (1 [inch] / 2.54 [cm]) = 4.37 [inches/clock cycle]

I sure hope that I worked it out correctly, and that it saves you some confusion in the future. The wikipedia page ""International_System_of_Units"" might come in handy as well.

"

data-item.data-item-item:
Is it just me or do others believe there is too much discussion of how to solve homework questions? I've even seen people posting code.

Personally, I think we should limit discussion of homework problems to explaining what the question is asking for when someone doesn't understand the question.

We will all see the solutions after the deadline and will see more possible approaches if everyone figures out the questions on their own. People who solve the question on their own will get the confidence boost.

Ethics is more important than getting a problem right or showing off our own approach to the answer before the deadline. I know it's tempting to tell other students how to solve a cool question, but let's show more will power.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: This is an interesting question. Like you, I think I benefit more from trying to solve the homework on my own even if I don't get the answer completely correct. I'm approaching the homework like I did when I really was in school by doing it on my own. However, it seems to me that might be considered old-fashioned nowadays in this age of online collaboration. I'm sure most people are just trying to help one another out -- it's one of the great features of classes like this. If the post has anything to do with the homework, I just skip it.
Maybe adding a spoiler tag for posted code solutions?

I wouldn't consider it old fashioned. I took two classes online last semester, Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. At first there was a little bit of this but it cleared up pretty good. The ML class didn't even allow posting solutions after the homework deadline.

Technically, it's against the terms of service. I think we can all keep pressuring students to keep things legit.

It will result in better data for Udacity, as well. The professors can only see what teaching strategies work best if they have accurate data about which questions were correctly answered.

The problem with your suggestion for the spoiler tag is, it does not solve the ethical issue of doing your own work. I can understand the need to receive clarification on a question, especially if english is not your first language, but there's absolutely no need to post code. Of course, it's impossible to prevent cheating but we certainly shouldn't encourage it.

Amen! If I'm really struggling I want to see another perspective on the problem or even a recommendation on the section of the course material that I should review again to find the answer myself NOT the code! Maybe all the 500 errors are a blessing until more students learn to not post code showing the answer... --)

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

I'd like to be able to help you but I'm not sure I follow your question. Unit 2, excercise 11 on the video list is ""Sum Procedure with a return statement""

There is no variable 't' or 's' in it, so hopefully you can clarify your question?

"

"

Oh, sorry: it is in when Dave explains how and why the quiz of the question 11 , had to be solved like that. He makes an example on the interpreter using t and s and the result is
""Hello Dave!""

"

"

Location of the example

when Dave explains how and why the quiz of the question 11 , had to be solved like that. He makes an example on the interpreter using t and s and the result is ""Hello Dave!""

"

I'm not 100% sure about your question but it looks very much that you are having trouble with the spacing.

Remember Python uses blank space to denote where the block starts and ends.

Example:

<--procedure>-- (Argument1, Argument2)     BLOCK START     CODE     CODE     CODE     CODE     Block END (NOTE: this is where the return goes.  #All the lines with no space added will be out side of the scope of the procedure above.

Additional code outside of the procedure can't be inside the procedure's block so you can't have it indented (or with 4 spaces)

Real life example:

#I want a producer that returns something and then pass it to code outside of the procedure.  deff addExclamationMarks(name): #This is where I define my procedure     name = name + '!!!' #I added 4 spaces so this code is inside the procedure's block     return (name) #I added 4 spaces so this code is inside the procedure's block  name = joel #I assign 'joel' to name # I added no space before the var because it is outside of the procedure's block  excitedName = addExclamationMarks(name) #I call for the addExclamationMarks procedure and pass it the stuff inside name and it returns a new value which I put inside excitedName  print excitedName #I print the string inside excitedName  addExclamationMarks(name)

I hope that makes sense to you... Now back to my steak dinner. :)

Ok, I see where you're referring to now. I have to admit that I have python installed on my machine and if I need to run code like that I run it on my machine, not in the web interpreter here. I only use the web interpreter for the quizzes and such.

I did however try it in the online interpreter here, and it ran just fine. Here is a copy/paste of the code:

def sum (a, b):     a = a + b     return a  s = 'Hello ' t = 'Dave!'  print sum(s, t)

I hope I've helped, but I'm still not entirely clear on the question. :)

Be careful about your indents. I have a feeling this may be the source of your problem.

it looks like interpreters can be fussy ..

on my computer I need to hit the return key twice to be able to go on the correct line to write s

data-item.data-item-item:
I think it is appropriate when mentioning the contributions of Alan Touring, that his death also be mentioned. The following quote is from Wikipedia page on Alan Turing.
â€œTuring's homosexuality resulted in a criminal prosecution in 1952, when homosexual acts were still illegal in the United Kingdom. He accepted treatment with female hormones (chemical castration) as an alternative to prison. He died in 1954, just over two weeks before his 42nd birthday, from cyanide poisoning. An inquest determined it was suicide-- his mother and some others believed his death was accidental. On 10 September 2009, following an Internet campaign, British Prime Minister Gordon Brown made an official public apology on behalf of the British government for the way in which Turing was treated after the war.â€

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It is truly sad that someone so brilliant, who had contributed so much to humanity and could have contributed so much more was the subject of such horrible discrimination.

"

His work to crack the German Enigma codes saved many hundreds of lives at sea.
That includes my father, with the Royal Navy, and if it was not for Turin and his colleagues I would probably not be here.
The UK Government has recently refused to pardon him for his ""crime"" of being who he was.
It is truly shameful.

"

I disagree that these details of his private life should be mentioned. If people want to know more about him, they are welcome to do extra research on their own but this isn't a history or sociology class. His sexuality isn't important and has no bearing on his contribution to society.
In the same way that seeing women represented in the field helps reduce stereotypes, so too does having other genders besides male/female.

But again, this isn't the responsibility of the instructor of computer science. The student has a responsibility to explore side paths himself, the instructor must stick to the course objectives. The instructor has time constraints and a responsibility to teach the critical material, that the majority of us are here for. There's no way he can be reasonably expected to provide such extraneous material, he may not even be aware of himself.
It has a bearing on why he was unable to contribute more to society because of his untimely young death.

I don't think there was an implication that this information should be brought to light by the lecturer. I see it as one student sharing information with the rest of us, and that it is something to think about.
umm, homosexuality is not a gender!

My comments were made as a student in response to the instructorâ€™s short statement on Alan Touring, perhaps â€œthe most important computer scientistâ€ whose contributions had a large impact on the outcome of WWII. The instructor made no comment about Turingâ€™s sexuality.

I agree Turingâ€™s sexuality had little import on his contribution to computer science or to winning WWII. However, as many students (but apparently not all students), I thik of myself not a student only of computer science, but of life. I think that it is important to know that the governmentâ€™s response to Turingâ€™s sexuality was very directly involved with Turingâ€™s persecution and his death.

If you truly believe â€œHis sexuality isn't important and has no bearing on his contribution to societyâ€, then why are you not outraged that the government prosecuted him for sexuality and drove him to suicide? Do you think his suicide, at age 41 may have had some â€œbearing on his contribution to societyâ€?

I am curious. Do you think he should have been prosecuted for his sexuality? Do you think he should have had to choose chemical castration to avoid prison? Do you think his suicide made the world a better place?

The purpose of education is to make you think. Think about these questions.

"

In the UK, ""the government"" is elected by the people. In Turing's time, that was the public majority wish. Don't look back at history and judge, just learn from it

"

data-item.data-item-item:
I just finished the question (choosing the two outputs) for section 6 of Unit 2.

It's very unclear (assuming the correct two variables are A and B), whether we type:

A,B
B,A
A, B
B, A
A B
B A

I typed the first four, and none was correct.
I then tried the fifth one. It too was incorrect.

I gave up out of frustration, checked the answer, only to find out it was the sixth option
B A

This question should have a SINGLE input box. The student should be required to type in the comma.
Any of the first four responses above should be correct.

Thanks.

David

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: It was originally that way, but that box checks only exact strings and a few students were getting it wrong based on their spacing. There was a consensus on the forums that two boxes would be better so that's what I changed it to. In the future we'll set the box up to something that can do arbitrary parsing of the solution.

data-item.data-item-item:
I'm just finished Unit 1 and I have loved it so far. I think the quality of the teaching is superb. However I'm a complete beginner when it comes to programming and I find that the questions asked are somewhat of a leap from the material taught. They don't require extra knowledge beyond that taught but they do seem to suppose more familiarity with slightly different notation than that taught and they infer a familarity with some concepts that beginners don't have. While it's nice to be challenged and so far in Unit 1 is possible to follow it would be nice if maybe there was a slower approach for total n00bs!

I realise Udacity is trying to respond to a wide variety of abilities here but given the teaching is so fantastic it would be a huge pity if complete beginners were sidelined because there are lots of us who are so excited to learn from you too and would be willing to pay for courses.

Anyway, I just wanted to say please don't forget about us or think we aren't as interested as those with more experience when you're finishing this course or planning new courses.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I totally agree with you Katty.

Tough it out in the early stages it gets easier and starts to make sense.
Take it slow, break it down and do the exercises over and over.
Keep asking any questions you have.
No one knows it all, but there are 100s here who can help with the little bits that confuse.
One more Pythonista in the World is a better World - we need you.

Agreed. I have zero prior exp and find myself, sometimes, baffled by small omissions in the instructions or non-clarity in definitions. However, it is also true that it is not impossible, obviously! Which is a testament to how awesome it is overall.

A lot of what is required to be a programmer is just simple perseverance. I've had students that came in the door gifted, and those that struggled. Given two students, one who was brilliant and gifted and to whom it all came easily, and another who struggled and needed to ask for help and learned much slower, do you know which one was most likely to be top of the class come graduation? The one who worked at it the most, the one who spent most evenings working on improving, no matter which of those two 'types' they were coming in the door. I've seen it happen over and over again, and that's because programming is a lot about determination and practice.

There are lots of people here to help out, and I'm positive the course is aimed at you. Take it slow and steady, there is no rush. Go back over material to refresh yourself about how it works, do a little every day, you will find it all coming together after a while.

We've had the same experience, Kathy! With no background we are sometimes at a complete loss as to where to begin. So what may be a relatively simple task takes quite a bit of time.

Robert99, thanks for the encouragement. I'll look forward to the work getting easier.

"

I feel the instructor is excellent. However, esp. for beginning students, many of the questions need to be worded more precisely and clearly. Some of them are ambiguous.

I also feel that questions with ""trick"" answers (that is, ""special"" cases of empty strings or negative numbers, etc.) shouldn't be included as possible choices. Perhaps a better way to present those special cases would be a tag question, something like ""Can you think of any special cases/inputs/values where this procedure will fail or won't do what we expected it to do?""

I can certainly see the value of testing a student's knowledge of all exceptions and special cases, but in CS101, this is very discouraging to students trying to get their feet wet and to understand the basic, simple concepts.

Other than that, congratulations to the instructor. I admire your teaching skills, presentation, and humor!

David
(Seattle)

Some people really feel the need to ""fully grok"" material to learn it. While that is nice, I prepare my students for the hacker world of programming by telling them ""don't be scared to research and go read books that they don't really understand. This is actually part of problem solving-- you read things you don't fully understand, then try to figure out enough to get a solution. Hackers do this all the time. Gradually, you come to understand more and more. The trick is, can you solve the problem? If so, everything is going great-- a deeper understanding of the material will come with time (usually a surprisingly short time, in the grand scheme of things, as long as you keep applying the principle of ""don't be scared of information and keep reading even when you only are understanding 10% of what is there""). If you can't solve the problem, read some more, play some more with the code (Python, an interpreted language, is great for this ). If you can enjoy testing things out in code as play, you are really set :)

And, worst case scenario, if you don't master the programming, you'll understand the basic concepts or ""big picture"" of what happens when you enter a search on Yahoo or Google.
