One suggestion I want to throw out there:

I would be very careful in using programming terminology outside the context of the lesson plan up to that point-- some of the things programmers say nonchalant in the midst of coding can be very ambiguous to someone without a deep understanding of all the major programming terms.

For example, in Unit 1 of ""CS 101: Building a Search Engine"" the word ""construct"" was used a few times without first fully explaining what that means in a more literal sense. We can argue whether this matters to the lesson at hand or not, but I think it would be best to avoid all possible ambiguity for the students' sake so they can focus on the actual lesson at hand.

Regardless, this first lesson was great even for a seasoned programmer like myself as it allowed me to get familiar with some of the nuances of entry-level Python.

Putting these lessons in real world context (like building a search engine) was a magnificent idea as well! Thank you!

"

"

You should consider yourself quite lucky. You'll often find professors and recruiters really enjoy a fresh mind, and that this actually puts you at an advantage.

The disadvantage some experienced programmers may have is ""too many pre-conceptions"". Learning a new language often means putting aside some pesky, ingrained, or even incorrect assumptions one may have acquired from learning a previous (sometimes inferior) programming language. It is often too easy to use this previous language as a crutch, or to let it cloud your judgement, and thus to get questions wrong by leaping to the wrong conclusion based on the way a certain thing works in the other language(s). Sometimes, a certain arrogance in thinking, ""oh, I already know this"" leads to a wrong answer simply due to carelessness.

The challenge for me is to go extra slow for this very reason, and not fast-forward through videos or skip steps. Otherwise I find myself face-to-face with a stupid syntax error based on the way things are done in other languages, that waste a lot of time trying to debug.

So in many ways, the experienced programmer must be extra vigilant not to become complacent or sloppy. I have spoken to a lot of recruiters and professors who often prefer a relatively inexperienced person with the right attitude over someone old, cynical, and lazy. (Also, inexperienced programmers are cheaper to hire.)

I try hard not to be complacent or sloppy, because there is a lot of ageism in the industry, and a lot of sexism. In order to overcome these two natural factors against me, I need to learn new things and keep my brain flexible, and never let myself be sloppy or lazy or STUCK in my ways. Otherwise, new programmers will always win at getting the hot jobs in newer programming languages.

You can take advantage of my disadvantages and do really, really well. I'm serious about this, because I've been on the other side as well, being the interviewer and not the interviewee. Sometimes I have interviewed potential job candidates for junior programmer jobs that I would supervise, and the older programmers would later turn out to just not be able to learn the new language, either out of ossification or fear. Since I didn't have at all the final say in these hiring decisions I don't lose sleep over this, but I do see why hiring managers sometimes dismiss older candidates out of hand.

I have an undergraduate degree in History. I only fell into programming accidentally, and only went to graduate school after working as a programmer for many years. So it is easy to pick up if you haven't done it before. Don't despair, and learn to embrace the advantages that you do have!

Thanks for the responses everyone and for the encouragement. I have no intention of quitting don't worry.I'm excited everyday to be tucking into this and learning something so alien to the disciplines I'm more at home with.

Someone asked for an example of where a new person might feel steps were missed or where there seemed to be a leap from the material taught to the question so I thought I'd mention two example in case it might be of use in making future courses or to others who teach these languages.

Quiz (Video: Testing)
For any string,

s = '<--any string="""">--'
which of the following always has the value 0?

a. s.find(s)

b. s.find('s')

c. 's'.find('s')

d. s.find('')

e. s.find(s + '!!!') +1

The last question (e) was quite confusing in that to me as a beginner.We learned that a returned value of 0 indicates that the section of the string you are looking for is found within the original string.Here the ""!!!"" is not found in s so a value of -1 is returned. Then you ad 1 to it and suddenly it's returning value 0... even though the ""!!!"" still is not found in s. I'm still not sure what that means or how that works(except in terms of basic addition).It's difficult to get your head around the idea that 0 and -1 in this context are not absolute values depending on whether something is found within the string or not.

Also

Quiz (Video: Finding with Numbers Quiz)
For any variables s and t that are strings, and i that is a number:
s = '<--any string="""">--'
t = '<--any string="""">--'
i = <--any number="""">--
which of these are equivalent to s.find(t,i):

a. s[i: ].find(t)

b. s.find(t)[ :i]

c. s[i: ].find(t) + i

d. s[i: ].find(t[i: ])

In this question the notation was different that we'd had before. It totally threw me and it took me a few occasions of watching the explanation video before I could absorb it, which I finally did. The concept of assigning any string and any number is a bit new too.With the strings assigned in the video I could negotiate the question.With the strings I'd assigned myself at first I was completely lost.

I'm not intending to be complaining I here.I realise Udacity is catering to all backgrounds and abilities and I'm astonished at how well it's doing that &-- will highly recommend it. I just wanted to make my point so it could be considered when doing future courses or preparing the rest of the courses.

"

I agree with Kathy, this is my first venture into programming myself so I'm completely new to this while I found the instructional videos good, i found that the quizzes or questions can be a huge leap from what you were just taught.. I dont think the questions are actually written by the instructor himself, that might be why i find parts straightforward and easy to follow and others have me frustrated. I'm aware you're told everything you need to know but i think it could be done in smaller steps.

"

For your first sample, + if used with strings, concatenates the strings together. So for example, print 'th'+'e' prints 'the'. So let's take the value of s to be 'asdf'. Then s.find(s + '!!!') + 1 translates to s.find('asdf!!!') + 1. That means, look for 'asdf!!!' in 'asdf"". It will return -1 since it won't match. Then 1 is added to the returned result which turns the whole result to 0. And yes I can see how difficult this things can be when you are a beginner. Just keep on working on it and you will laugh at what used to confuse you. It happenes to everybody, the only solution is to keep on doing what you're doing and try to understand everything on this courses (the hows and whys).

"

The Norvig article is very interesting, especially in regards to the 10,000 hours of deliberate practice. It reminded me of this guy named Dan McLaughlin who is applying that theory of 10,000 hours of deliberate practice to become a professional golfer. I guess it's all in the commitment.

"

The best way to understand programming is to experiment. This is done by designing a program, and providing a wide variety of test input.

It may seem like extra work, but will quickly pay off with a deep understanding of the execution of your programs. Once you begin to design larger systems, quality of your program is ensured with test cases. With test cases, you try to break the code (even if you think it is perfect).

Consider a simple example for a function add(a, b)

def add(a, b):      return a + b  print add(0, 0)           # 0 print add(1, 3)           # 4 print add(-5, -6)         # -11 print add('my', 'String') # myString print add(3, 'myString')  # <--throws Python type exception>--

Now we can extend the definition of add(a, b) to check for the type exception. The test case that uses an integer and a string will no longer cause a Python exception. An error message is returned notifying the user of a type mismatch.

# check if a and b are the same type, otherwise return error message # def add(a, b):     if type(a) == type(b):         return a + b     else:         return ""ERROR: type mismatch""  print add(0, 0)           # 0 print add(1, 3)           # 4 print add(-5, -6)         # -11 print add('my', 'String') # myString print add(3, 'myString')  # ERROR: type mismatch

There are many more possibilities for test cases that you may explore. This includes preventing that integer overflow/underflow does not occur, or combinations of other data types.

When you begin solving a new problem think about the various conditions that may happen, even if in your program you ensure that type of input does not occur. Other users may not be aware of limitations, and use your functions with improper input. It is these types of input that you should include in your test cases.

Keep practicing and you will get better. This includes working small examples with pen and paper, and implementing those examples in the computer. Keep a sheet of Python syntax for quick reference, and read the documentation for detailed explanation of the language. If there is a concept that you do not understand completely, just continue to experiment and think why the program is producing the output with your given input. Soon you will be able to recall functions with ease, and be able to develop larger software creations.

"

just to add to shebaw's comment, it may be useful to think about doing these procedures from the inside out. so, take s.find(s + '!!!') +1
if you go inside out, you find this equation is really:
(something) + 1
where something is s.find(s+'!!!')
so, figure out the inner thing first, then go back. The inner thing just returns a value of -1, then you add that to 1 and get 0. The 0 has nothing to do with the s.find(something) bit, you just happen to be adding a method and a number to get another number.

as for assignment stuff, that's part of learning to 'think like an engineer'. I really found Learn Python the Hard Way (google it) to be excellent for the absolute beginner, because Zed really breaks down the basics of making sure you avoid typos, making sure you get assignment hammered into your head, etc. It's less a matter of memorization than that of familiarity, so don't hesitate to go to an interpreter on your computer or on the web (there's one for python at Codecademy, in their labs) and practice just assigning things, then using add, subtract, multiply, etc on your variables. Practice manipulating strings, too, to get parts of them. It'd be great if this site had a lab for you to practice in, but I suggest watching one video at a time, then going to an interpreter and practicing what you just learned.

"

I wouldn't be discouraged if I were you. If you find certain things hard to grasp, you can always refer other sources. Search the internet or get a Python book &-- read through.

A good places to search for answers would be StackOverflow &-- Programmers StackExchange.

You can also try solving some other problems, to help you better understand Python. I suggest Project Euler &-- CodeGolf-StackExchange

Everyone gets stuck. When I wrote my first(working) C++ program I had many facepalm moments. Had been shown how to input two numbers &-- print out their sum by a friend in the Lab at school so at home I tried, with a book in hand &-- copied the program verbatim from the book, well almost. I had made one mistake, that I used the input function in place of the output function &-- spent a considerable about of time wondering why the program is not printing the answer.

So if you get stuck, don't let it bother you too much and just work though it.

""i now realize it's not about being a walking reference guide who can reproduce and apply everything taken in during the last unit instantly. I'm better off knowing where i have to look in order to find the answers to the questions and queries i have""

You'll find over the years that this maxim is true in general. Most people don't have incredible memories for all the small details, especially since some small details can change from time to time. If you go and memorize all the trivia of every string function in a given language, then in the next version of the language some of that will have changed anyway. It's better to be familiar with general programming techniques and ways of thinking, and to be familiar with how to find out what you need to know, and how to use the debugging tools and so on.

data-item.data-item-item:
My experience in programming has been pretty limited. I've done a fair amount with html and have hacked around programs written in PHP, but not written PHP programs from scratch.

The approach of this class is really cool, because we are starting from scratch. I am learning things that I would have probably tried to skip by. Plus, building a search engine is something I've wanted to do for a long time.

So now, I'm thinking forward and the Web Application class sounds like a good next step.

Are other people on here planning to take that class next?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: I am definitely planning on taking the web app class and a couple others if I have time. I know I'm late getting in the game but making web apps really seems like it will be a necessary skill. Even if I can't make money at it, having the skill set will make me more employable.

Python has many frameworks for developing web applications, such as Django. It might be possible that at the later stages they might show us how to display the data from the crawlers using a web application.

Yes, I see web apps as a necessary skill. Not for my own employment, but I'm always coming up with ideas to try on the net. I can setup web servers, and install most content management software, but programming is my weakness.

I like the idea of displaying the crawler data using a web app. I will look into Django.

Ah yes, I remember when I first started doing Web Development I went straight to CMS's and honestly I do not think I learned very much from it. However, when you start to look into PHP (very common for web development) you start to appreciate how it all works.
There are many practices to be learnt, there are also many alternatives. If you want to use PHP, then learn some pure PHP and then once you have the basics under your belt look into using a framework to make life easier.
I currently use the PHP framework called Codeigniter (there are many others out there). It makes developing Web Applications a much easier process, since it provides many helper functions that allow you to save time in the long run for repetitive tasks.

I started Web Development in 1995 with telnet to the web server and using I think it was vi as a text editor to write html. It has never been more than a hobby and I didn't do it for a long time. Yeah, the CMS approach doesn't teach you much and configuring some aspects is a pain.

I found that I learned quite a bit moving my websites to cloud servers. Setting up the OS, LAMP server taught me a lot and gives me a lot of potential to try new ideas if I get programming figured out.

I will look into Codeigniter, too.
Absolutely, Web Application class sounds amazing. I too only have some basic html background and don't even have the least experience with PHP, but with this teaching style I'm eager to jump into it.

To get a screen where you can go back and edit your code, go to the top menu and, under File, select New Window. Save this window as somename.py and then start coding. When you are ready to run your code, go to top menu, and under Run select Run Module. The program will prompt you to save, and after you hit okay, you'll see the results of your coding in the Python Shell window.

Hi

I don't understand that why 'ada'.find('') returns value of 0 instead of -1? Does it mean nothing can be anything? what's the insight of it? Please help.
Thanks!

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
"

This is actually harder to explain than to understand. But let's see if I could help.

So, string.find(<--substring>--) looks for a string - the substring - inside another string.

Now, think of string that's composed of:

<--text>-- + <--substring>-- + <--text>--

In other words, the substring is between some sequence of text (which also includes the empty string) that is concatenated together. In this case, find() returns a non-negative number.

Now, take 'ada'.find(''), we can construct 'ada' by:

"""" + ""ada""

This is the case described above, and .find() returns a non-negative number (0).

Hope that helped.

Just remember, the empty string is an element of any string.

"
Thanks! That makes sence!I guess I have to remember this from now on.

All formatting is lost when the text was copied-pasted. Make sure that you insert the appropriate white spaces because Python depends on them for parsing the text. The code you have should be inputed as:

danton = ""De l'audace, encore de l'audace, toujours de l'audace"" <--new line="""">--
def find_second(danton, audace):<--new line="""">--
<--tab>--find_first = danton.find('audance')<--new line="""">--
<--tab>--find_second=danton.find('audace', find_first + 1)<--new line="""">--

There are many simple IDEs for Python that work in Windows. Try installing Python 2.7 Windows version from here, then download the PyQt-Py2.7 windows installer under Binaries from here. Lastly, go get Eric4 from here. Run the install.py file inside the Eric4 directory (you may have to add the path to where python27 is installed into your Windows Path variable, google ""setting windows Path for <--windows version="""" you="""" have="""">--""). Peter,

Can you tell me what you did to make my post visible? Was it an error on my part...?

"

Looking at your code a few things strikes me as odd:

danton = ""De l'audace, encore de l'audace, toujours de l'audace""  def find_second(danton, audace):                       find_first=danton.find('audace')     find_second=danton.find('audace',find_first+1)     return find_second

what does your procedure call look like?

If you do:

print find_second(danton,'audacity')

There are 3 things that is worth noting here:

(I).

 def find_second(danton, audace):                           find_first=danton.find('audace')

In the above, despite passing 'audace' in the method call you are manually entering the target string in find_first=danton.find('audace') which defeats the purpose of passing a target string.

(II). The scond thing worth mentioning is you'll notice that find_second is the local variable name and the procedure name.

 find_second=danton.find('audace',find_first+1)     return find_second

I believe this will return the reference to the procedure on the heap/stack. (Please correct me if i'm wrong here)

(III). you are using the global variable name danton as a procedure argument.

 def find_second(danton, audace):    <--block>--  print find_second(danton,'audace')

Which should look more like this:

def find_second(search_string, target_string):        <--block>--      print find_second(danton,'audace')

From playing around i've discovered that this will work if you declare the method without a search string in the following way:

 def find_second(target_str):   Inside the method when you refer to dalton you are accessing the global variable dalton defined outside the method

if your code were to look like this it should work:

danton=""De l'audace, encore de l'audace, toujours de l'audace""  def find_second(search_string, target_str):    first = danton.find(target_str)    second = danton.find(target_str, first+1)    return second  print find_second(danton, 'audace')
"
good point

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
a) In Python, whitespace (spaces, new lines, tabs, etc.) is very important because it is the only method to provide structure to python programs.

Therefore, in the code for slide 11, you should enter

def sum(a,b):   a = a + b

Make sure to insert a tab (hit tab) before the line 'a = a + b'.

b) You can try the official Python IDLE, which comes bundled with almost all python installations. Otherwise, I would suggest TextWrangler (free) or TextMate as editors with excellent code highlighting (though they also have their built-in behaviors (such as inserting tabs for you) that may takes away from the learning experience.) If you really feel ambitious, try vim or emacs.

Thanks man,

It was a great help!

Cheers,
Augusto

@graemeblake, what we should print out is actually the full multiplication table leading up to the number shown. In your example, you still need to print the ""="" followed by the result. In short, it should look like this:

1*1 = 1

1*2 = 2

1*3 = 3

2*1 = 2

2*2 = 4

2*3 = 6

3*1 = 3

3*2 = 6

3*3 = 9

Also, a formatting tip: you can just include manual line break tags (<-- br >--, with no spaces) after each line. to ensure that your choice of new lines are preserved.

"

Use double space after the word to enter a new line.

The problem with using two returns (I assume you don't mean the space bar), is that every single line will be double-spaced. If you are writing a few paragraphs, that's fine -- but here, where we have a long vertical list, I'd say it's better just to use line break tags, to avoid taking up twice as much space.

When I try to award someone a point for giving me the right answer, or for someone else answering the question correct, udacity seems to think that I have awarded myself the same number of points an penalizes me!!! What do I do? I don't want to loose points for no reason.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item:
The same thing happened to me! (:-O)
But is that a bug or a feature?
I hope its not a feature !!

"

That is actually the way the system is intended to work. It is analogous to the 'bounties' on StackExchange sites.

If you think an answer is good on any question, you can vote it up using the ""thumbs up"" button. If you asked the question, you can also ""accept"" that answer using the check mark.

Additionally, you can ""award points"" for a truly exceptional answer, or as a reward in response to a request. This transfers your own karma to the other person, so you will lose as much karma as you want to give them.

"

All those in Chrome Incognito while not on my pc, because of login info, history etc. Other stuff (Facebook etc.) in a separate window.

I'll often open many threads at the same time, so usually there are even more tabs than described above.

A quick way to open all of those is to make a bookmark folder with them all and, upon beginning a study session, right-clicking the folder and selecting ""open all in new window"". There. :D

I'm wondering just how ""picky"" we need to be in answering these questions about loops ending...
Do we need to be concerned about the maximum integer that can be expressed, or not? Or should we ignore such subtleties? For the answers depend on the answer to this question. Thanks!

"

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Not really, I guess whatever maximum integer you consider the program will execute, just might take a longer execution time!
If the subtleties haven't been covered in the lessons, then you shouldn't worry about them.

"

But there are integers too large to be called ""integers"" in Python. There is a maximum one. On my system, 2147483647 is the maximum int, and if I add 1 to that it automatically becomes a ""long"" integer. But still an integer. Eventually though, there is a maximum long integer...

"

Also, remember to include with your response a proof of the Collatz conjecture.

"

If we prove the Collatz conjecture, do we win the $500 prize?! If Paul Erdos couldn't prove it... YIKES. He said ""Mathematics is not yet ripe for such problems"".

"

I'm not even sure which way to treat the subtleties. I don't know if what I consider a subtlety is what other people consider a subtlety. Whichever way they want us to think, it's certainly an interesting question and I've learnt some things about python that I wouldn't have thought of otherwise.

data-item.data-item-item:
In the answer video for quiz for unit 2-18, we see the following function:

def is_friend(name):     return name[0] == 'D'

This function throws an error if you pass in the empty string. While this could be the intended behavior, you might be better off with the following:

def is_friend(name):     return name[:1] == 'D'

This will instead return False in the case of an empty string, indicating that the person with a blank name is not your friend.

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: agree. Your answer is better.

Zu deiner Aufgabe 9 Unit 1:
Die Aufgabenstellung ist ja das eine Variable X gegeben ist die einen Wert (eine Dezimalzahl) enthÃ¤lt. Wenn nun diese Zahl eine Kommazahl ist soll gerundet werden, bei 3.14 soll die Ausgabe 3 sein, bei 27.69 soll die Ausgabe 28 sein. Soweit die Aufgabe.

Nun zur Ãœberlegung der LÃ¶sung. Ich nehme mal an wir sollen und dÃ¼rfen keinen round Befehl benutzen (falls es das bei Python Ã¼berhaupt gibt) die mÃ¶chten das wir es ""tradionell"" lÃ¶sen. Also erst den Wert auslesen bis zu dem Punkt (falls es einen Punkt gibt), dann hat man schon mal die Zahl ""vor dem Komma"", nun noch die erste Zahl nach dem Punkt einlesen und Entscheiden ob die Zahl grÃ¶ÃŸer gleich 5 ist, wenn ja die Zahl plus ein addieren, wenn nicht, nix machen. Und dann die Zahl ausgeben.
Aber um diese Aufgabe zu lÃ¶sen da braucht es Fallunterscheidungen, also Ja/Nein (if). Ich habe mir die Videos gestern komplett angesehen, aber Falluntersheidungen haben die noch nicht behandelt. Wie man das ohne if lÃ¶sen kÃ¶nnte, das wÃ¼ÃŸte ich auf die schnelle auch nicht..

Das ist das schÃ¶ne in der Informatik, in der Mathematik gibt es stur nur eine LÃ¶sung die richtig ist, in der Informatik gibt es viele LÃ¶sungen. Wie ein Maler der ein Bild malt, jeder malt die Blumenvase anders. Reine KreativitÃ¤t also --)

Also ich kenn das von Programmierkursen an der Uni, da ist auch der Grundsatz, nur das verwenden was man in den Vorlesungen biÃŸher gelernt hat. Je nach Prof und Laune gibts bei solchen Aufgaben dann Punktabzug oder komplett falsch.
Ob die hier kontrollieren ob if Bedingungen verwendet wurden oder nicht und nur die Ausgabe kontrollieren da wÃ¤re ich mir nicht so sicher.
Davon ab die LÃ¶sung ohne if ist wirklich nicht schwer, nur etwas anders gedacht und auch fÃ¼r Nichtprogrammierer wirklich lÃ¶sbar, man sollte sich vielleicht den Tip oben von mir nochmal oder auch zweimal durchlesen. OK for the fourth choice in problem26 isn't S
being evaluated 2 times for each loop?
mike

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: What you have to keep in mind is that T is evaluated before the second time S is evaluated.

"

To expand on what @PeterUdacity said...

You can picture any loop ""rolled out"" into repeated instances of the test and loop body. So the following:

i = 0 while i <-- 2:     print i     i = i + 1

Is equivalent to: (in terms of inputs and outputs)

i = 0 if i <-- 2:     print i     i = i + 1 if i <-- 2:     print i     i = 1 + 1 if i <-- 2:     print i     i = i + 1

So by the same token, this:

while t:     s()

is equivalent to:

while t:     s()     if t:         s()     else:         break

or several other variations. As long as you run the test (or are otherwise sure it will pass) before each time you run the loop body, it will be equivalent to the loop.

As an aside, there was an old optimization technique called ""rolling out the loop"" (which should not be used anymore, for various reasons) in which the bodies of fixed-length loops would be repeated multiple times in the loop to save on the overhead of running the loop.

"

data-item.data-item-item: My IQ is high enough but I'm not following this. Is there a remedial class one can take to understand the basics so I might comprehend this introduction to programming?

data-item-item.data-item-item-item: Have you tried using the lecture notes along with following the videos? That might help you some.
This is as introductory as you're probably gonna get... Anything in particular your are having issues with?
If you ask a question on this forum, it will be answered almost instantly! Try making use of this wonderful resource.
Also going over an external python tutorial may help

"

Why limit yourself to one teacher?

There is no need for a remedial class, but you can learn a lot more by taking a few more courses to fill in some blanks. I recommend Khan Academy's section on programming (also in python). Maybe read some of the python documentation. Also the Stanford iTunes University courses are a good orientation to programming.

I have found that using a few different resources gives me a severe advantage and fills in the gaps.

"

"

IQ alone doesn't help much. This course is about as (as noted above) introductory as it gets. Watch the videos, feel free to pause and rewind as needed. Use a paper notebook and a pencil to write things down as it goes along and install python on your machine so you have a sandbox to play in offline. I'm happy with 2.7 from python.org and the IDLE editor that comes along with it.

You may also want to spend some time here: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Python_Programming
and here: http://docs.python.org/contents.html

Both sites have good explanations and associated exercises that can really help to clarify concepts. Look at your own code, look at other code, take it apart, play with it and learn from everything. Do not be afraid to make mistakes either, as you will likely learn far more from those than you ever would from getting things right all the time.

"

"

Also try the free introductory textbook here, it rocks, and provides a slightly different ""angle of attack"" on learning Python. It explains a lot more, at the expense of requiring you to read many pages of text. Great book.

"

"

Don't get discouraged.. it takes a little while to 'get' it.. go over each example in the class and make sure that you understand it. If this is your first exposure to programming, statements like ""n = n+1"" and ""s,t=t,s"" are bound to be confusing until you get out of your head that programming might look like math but it is not.

"
Or that it might look like math, but it' not...but wait, it really is math, but it's not that hard!

One of the great things about online learning is that you can re-watch the videos.

That should help.

"

Step by step, I'm realizing that- presuming the baseline intelligence is there (I'd estimate IQ 110+ - probably have to be reasonably bright, but no expectation of huge genius)- the only real limitation is your determination to learn. That might sound hokey and cliche, but totally true. This methodology here is very similar to learning how to read and write music.

Right now, I'm applying concepts that not 24 hours ago had me pulling out my hair. Granted, I had to watch the videos over and over and over again to 'get it', but as someone who comes to this with ZERO code background, I can say that it is do-able- but don't expect it to be 'easy' if you're starting at Ground 0, like I am. It's going to take a genuine commitment.

My only criticism of it so far is that the instructor leans very heavy on the intellectual abstractions, painfully light on the applied concepts. Every single lesson should conclude with ""... and this is how what I just showed you will apply to the construction of a search engine..."" #commence demonstration

"

Hey Solarbike you are not alone. I understand parts of the instruction but towards the end I'm dying a slow painful death. I am going to check out the textbook pdf but seriously, my head hurts, my ego is shot and I want my blankie.

If I don't get kicked out for my homework I'm going to give it another go for week 2. Week 3 - too far for me to contemplate.
They don't kick anyone out for homework. Don't worry about grades, just keep at it and learn and hopefully have some fun.

"

Hey, don't let it get you down -- this is hard stuff, and not necessarily intuitive or easy to pick up! Why not try posting specific questions, like ""What does ______ mean?"" or ""How do I do ______?""
I've had some questions answered wonderfully by other students who are farther along than I am, and I'm sure I'll have many more.

We all start at different points on this journey, but we're in it together at Udacity. Remember, this class is not curved!

"

"

Learn Python the Hard Way is even more basic. There's no logic introduced until halfway through. It's free:

http://learnpythonthehardway.org/

edit: my comment seems to be blank, I'm trying to see if I can make it appear.

"

you're not alone man, it was quite challenging at first for me too. but the course is taught so well, you're bound to get it with some practice.

besides. i made the mistake of enrolling in the other course, where they're building a program for a robot car with Professor Thrun. i have never ever ever felt more stupid in my life. it's just too intense. but i have no plans of dropping it - i know more than anything that if something can be learned, it will be learned.
Practice makes perfect.

I started programming just 4 months ago, and like you I felt that I was picking it up slowly, sometimes frustratingly so. Nonetheless, after a few weeks things started to really click, and fast forward to today, most of these first two units have been child's play (don't mean to brag, these are just the basics after all). It just takes a while for your brain to snap into 'programming' mode.

Of course nothing complex can be learned without effort and determination.

I'd strongly recommend the book 'How to Think Like a Computer Scientist - Learning With Python'. It's free, just google it.

I am sure you are doing the following. You are going to the next video even if you don't understand the current video. This works in certain fields NOT in programming. Programming classes are built up. They are not like solving a zig saw puzzle.

DONT move to the next video until you clearly understand the first one. Watch the videos repeatedly if you dont understand. If you still have a problem with something specific you should post it on the forum. I am sure you will get help.

"

While it is important to eventually understand each concept, not everyone learns best this way. Sometimes, if you just don't 'get' something, just move on a bit and see if it falls into place once you see that material used in another context.

I know to some folks this seems like heresy, but I have 17 years experience teaching programming, and I see this work all the time. It really works easily with the video lectures-- you can always hop back a few lectures and review something you didn't fully grasp. The trick is to take note when things seem fuzzy in your mind, and remember to keep trying to figure out how those things really work.

I should point out that I am not saying ""watch the videos real fast one after the other, whether you understand any or not"". You should try to work out each section, don't be in a rush, take your time. But, if it really isn't getting anywhere, try a) asking for clarity on the forums, and b)try taking a peek ahead and see if after watching a few more sections it doesn't all start to become more clear.

"

"

@Gibgezr - You are correct. I think he is doing too much of it(skipping a lot).That is why I was strongly suggesting the opposite. He would not be this frustrated otherwise. Actually when we sit and study alone the method you propsose is the best- which is the case usually. Now we have an added advantage of forum very specific to the course he can choose to go step by step.

"

"

That's normal when you make your first foray into programming. You should just keep working at it. Even if you don't understand every single idea at the end, you will still have learned a lot. Meanwhile there are lots of free resources on the internet to help you on your way.

You can work your way through the python tutorials at The New Boston pretty quickly. It doesn't delve deep into the concepts were learning, but doing it will familiarize you with the syntax were using here. Which will free your mind a little bit to focus on the bigger picture of why were doing one thing or another. If you have time after that there are lots of free books online that you can read. ""Dive into Python"", ""Think Python"",and ""Learn Python the hard way"" are all great books that you can read for free. Invent with python has tutorials for making simple games with python and a new volume for making bigger games with Pygame. Also MIT has their own CS101 online. You can learn a lot from it, but it does use a lot of theorems later in the course (What do you expect from MIT). Also Google has instructional materials available at Google Code University Then there's CodingBat which has a series of basic coding challenges that you can use to hone your skills. Another great resource for that is Project Euler it has a bunch of questions that are meant to be easy for a computer program, but next to impossible with out one.

Just keep plugging away and take advantage of the myriad of free resources that are available to aspiring hackers including this discussion group.

"

Of cos its hard :)

That's why they pay us the big bucks :)

AND that's why you should just stick at it.

I've trained a few people over the years and the start is
always the hardest but eventually the light goes on and they get it.

Same will happen with you

BUT and this is REALLY important:- Programming is not THEORY is a very hands on thing

Right this second im a working on a project for work and i've done a lot of research into how the
code should be written and its ONLY when and as i try to fit the pieces together that you see if it works or not, then there is a lot of frustrated head banging and trying again

BTW there are many days i wonder if being a street sweeper wouldn't be an easier career :)

BTW i've been wondering that for 40 years, still haven't changed though :)
I second that book by Downey -- I have the paper back published by Cambridge University Press and it is well-written (very) and extremely easy to follow.

I suggest you:

1)watch and review the videos, try to solve the problems several times, even having already seen the answer

2) read this book: â€œInvent Your Own Computer Games with Pythonâ€ (it was written so as to explain Python programming even for children)--

3) watch Khan Academy videos of computer science (also in Python):
khanacademy org/#computer-science

4) believe in yourself, every mind has its rhythm and you may be surprised with yourself soon!

Good luck!

Folks, I looked at the glossary and the handouts and other stuff. I watched the videos at least two times each. Let me put it this way. I am learning a new language. I'm in the grammar vocabulary section. There is a transition from English to Python.

Now I was ok until I got to concatenation. I knew the term/concept from Excel so I was feeling ok and then I slid into gobblygoo land. When the examples were English or math based I have a better understanding. When it go into s stands for any string type stuff I'm trying to make the connection between concept and execution.

I wasn't all that strong in the concept and I had to do something. I'm up for the challenge but I need to find ways to make this accessible to me. Re-reading/viewing what I don't understand isn't helping. Yes, I have downloaded the book so many have recommend. I'll slide of to Khan Academy but if I don't have a ah-moment soon I'm not going to be able to go forward.

That is okay and a choice I'll need to make. There is a distinction between those that get if from jump street and those of us who really didn't know what we stepped into and are trying to find our way. There are all kinds of learning styles. I haven't found mine (yet) in programming.

Think in a positive way, I did not understand well the class + english is not my native language,but I found help here in this forum that encourage me to continue and to not quit..

Open your mind to aknowledgment.

Best Regards!!!
